fields.headline: In the frame
fields.standfirst: Who next at Parkhead?
fields.trailText: Who next at Parkhead?
fields.body:
Kenny Dalglish has made it clear that the search for a permanent replacement for the sacked John Barnes will begin immediately. Here are some the possible candidates for the job.

Joe Kinnear: The former Wimbledon manager has recovered from heart trouble and is anxious to get back to the club scene. Made the Dons an established Premiership side on limited resources and has a sound reputation in the game.

Mick McCarthy: Although he is currently planning for the World Cup qualifiers, the Republic of Ireland manager would probably be tempted by a chance of running the club where he used to play.

Tommy Burns: Was dismissed by Celtic in 1997 and then had an unhappy spell south of the border with Reading. But he remains a popular man with the Celtic supporters and has already been linked with a coaching role.

John Toshack: The former Wales and Liverpool striker has vast management experience in Europe including two spells with Real Madrid. He is currently without a club and could have the kind of CV Celtic require.

Ruud Gullit: A point to prove after his bitter departure from Newcastle. But during his time at Chelsea he installed the team with the kind of flair the Celtic supporters are desperate to see.

David Moyes: Another former Celtic player, although his profile was nowhere near as high as McCarthy's. However, Preston's progress in the English Second Division under his stewardship won't have gone unnoticed.

webTitle: Cameroon overwhelm Tunisia to reach final

fields.headline: Cameroon overwhelm Tunisia to reach final
fields.trailText: Cameroon 3 - 0 Tunisia
fields.body:
Cameroon reached the African Nations Cup final for the first time in 18 years by scoring three second-half goals last night.

They made the breakthrough three minutes after the interval when a long throw from the right created panic in the Tunisian penalty area, allowing Mboma to blast the ball in from close range.

As Tunisian efforts to equalise became more desperate, Real Madrid teenager Samuel Oto'o doubled the Indomitable Lions' lead in the 83rd minute. Mboma, leading a counterattack, threaded a pass through to Oto'o, who expertly lifted the ball over Chokri El Ouaer.

Mboma finished off the job two minutes from time, when he broke away down the right and shot from a tight angle.

Mboma missed his best chance of the match. Just before half-time, after El Ouaer blocked an Oto'o shot, the big striker blasted the ball wide of an unguarded net.

Tunisia's best chance came midway through the first half, when Meher Kanzari's shot from the edge of the area was well saved by Boukar Alioum.

webTitle: Babangida double helps Super Eagles soar into final

fields.headline: Babangida double helps Super Eagles soar into final
fields.trailText: Tijani Babangida scored two spectacular first-half goals in Lagos yesterday to steer Nigeria into the final of the African Nations Cup with a 2-0 victory over South Africa.
fields.body:
Tijani Babangida scored two spectacular first-half goals in Lagos yesterday to steer Nigeria into the final of the African Nations Cup with a 2-0 victory over South Africa.

They will meet Cameroon, who beat Tunisia 3-0 in Accra with two goals from the Cagliari striker Patrick Mboma, in the final in Lagos on Sunday.

Urged on by a jubilant crowd at the Surulere Stadium, Nigeria took the lead after only 40 seconds, added a second in the 34th minute and resisted sec ond-half pressure from the 1996 African champions to move a big step closer to a third title of their own.

Nigeria's greater desire was decisive, said their coach Jo Bonfrere. "When one team has 11 players that will do anything to win and the other has seven or eight it is obvious who will win," the Dutchman said. "We created more chances and took them."

Babangida got the Super Eagles off to a perfect start with a first-minute strike that delighted the 42,000 crowd.

When South Africa's Thamo Mngomeni lost possession near the halfway line on the right, a long corridor opened up in front of the Ajax winger. He ran a long way towards the edge of the area, then cut in from the left and unleashed a superb right-footed shot from 20 yards.

South Africa's rearguard, so impressive in the quarter-final triumph over Ghana, suddenly looked harried and unsteady.

In the 16th minute Andre Arendse had to make a brave block at the feet of Chukwu Ndukwe from an incisive pass from Babangida. But Bafana Bafana had no answer in the 34th-minute when Babangida completed a glorious Nigerian passing move with a first-time shot at the far post.

"Those early goals really changed the match," said Nigeria's captain Sunday Oliseh. "Things became easier for us and South Africa had a mountain to climb."

Nigeria, unbeaten in the African Nations Cup since 1992, slowed the game down and lost some of their impetus, but remained a threat on the counter-attack.

Finidi George had two chances to finish the South Africans off in the second half, but he shaved the crossbar with his first and messed up his second after a penetrative run from Julius Aghahowa.

As South Africa's cup hopes slipped away, Siyabonga Nomvete looked to emulate Babangida with a determined run down the left, but Ike Sharunmu held on to his shot at the second attempt.

webTitle: Dalglish steps into the breach at Celtic

fields.headline: Dalglish steps into the breach at Celtic
fields.standfirst: Sacked Barnes is replaced by his boss, who was also ready to leave
fields.trailText: Kenny Dalglish yesterday took over the task of reviving Celtic but made it clear that the search for a permanenr replacement for the sacked John Barnes will begin immediately. Terry McDermott and Barnes's assistant Eric Black also left the club.
fields.body:
Kenny Dalglish yesterday took over the task of reviving Celtic but within minutes made it clear that he does not regard it as a task for life. The search for a replacement for the sacked John Barnes will begin immediately and his successor should be in place by the end of the season.

After a day when the fans waited patiently for the announcement confirming what half of Glasgow already knew, Dalglish and the club's chief executive Allan MacDonald emerged at teatime to say that the head coach and his assistant Eric Black had had their contracts terminated. Terry McDermott, nicknamed "the social manager", left by mutual consent.

MacDonald looked grim and Dalglish downcast after some of the worst days in the club's history. Celtic lost, after leading by two goals, in the league last Saturday and their humiliating 3-1 home defeat by Inverness Caledonian Thistle in the Scottish Cup on Tuesday sealed the fate of the novitiate English coach.

"This does not bring me any pleasure at all," said Dalglish. "The three lads who have gone were all great fellows. John Barnes will go on to be a successful manager because he has all the qualities for the job but it will not be at Celtic. Eric Black did a great job with the young players. Unfortunately John gave Terry that nickname but anyone who thinks he was merely my runner bringing me back stories from the dressing room is simply telling lies.

"I feel the responsibility as well. If the board had asked me to go, I would have done so. Maybe I should have spent more time as director of football with the first team but there were other areas I was concentrating on. I am taking over until such time as we find a replacement and it will be done as soon as it possibly can be." So Celtic are looking for their fifth manager in four years.

Dalglish will hold a press conference today and his team for Saturday's match at Dundee will give some clues to the state of mind in the dressing room - a major reason why Barnes's stay at the club ended after only seven months. Dalglish clearly thinks the players let down a friend with whom he played at Liverpool and whom he signed for Newcastle.

"John was manager of the month in December," said Dalglish. "Players can gain you results but can also get you the sack. The players should look at themselves and realise that Celtic demands passion and commitment. If they don't want to wear the jersey then they should not come to work. If there are any people like that, they won't be here long. There will be problems for those who won't give 100% for the club."

The fans will certainly give Dalglish a chance but there remains the impression that Celtic are again in a process of transition. The director of football, who is on a seven-year contract, has made it clear that, although he is prepared to step into the brreach, he has no intention of reviving a full-time managerial career.

He stressed that Barnes's successor should know about the traditions of the club and the favourites are led by Tommy Burns, a former Celtic manager who is the choice of the supporters despite his subsequent failure in England with Reading, and Joe Kinnear, the former Wimbledon manager who recently indicated that he is ready to return to football following a heart attack last year.

It is unlikely Dalglish would be attracted to Wim Jansen, the Dutchman who won the title in 1998 but left after his only season at Parkhead and is now scouting for Feyenoord.

 Rangers have ended negotiations for Sergei Rebrov, Dynamo Kiev's £12m striker. The Ibrox chairman David Murray said: "We have pulled out because of something which came to our attention at a very late stage." He did not specify the problem but insisted that Rebrov was close to joining - " a deal was in place between myself and Kiev president Grigory Surkis. The player had also agreed to come to us and we expected to have him by next Tuesday."

webTitle: Off-the-pitch fortunes reflect tumultuous six months at Parkhead

fields.headline: Off-the-pitch fortunes reflect tumultuous six months at Parkhead
fields.trailText: Celtic yesterday warned that this year's profit levels depend on creating a successful team and in the careful handling and timing of forays into the market as finances came to the fore at Parkhead.
fields.body:
Celtic yesterday warned that this year's profit levels depend on creating a successful team and in the careful handling and timing of forays into the market.

Soaring costs incurred in developing the squad and expensive action to offset injuries, notably the loan-signing of Ian Wright to replace Henrik Larsson, who broke a leg, sent profits tumbling 63% in the half-year to December 31.

Pre-tax gains fell to £700,000 from £2m for the period year on year, with earnings pushed down by a 22.5% rise in operating expenses to £17.8m.

The expense of extending existing contracts was also a factor and a further squeeze came from having played only 14 home games in the six months against 16 in the same period of 1998-99.

Turnover, however, rose from £19.33m to £22.15m, boosted by a 35% rise in merchandising revenue and a 55.5% increase in revenues from the media. Allan MacDonald, the chief executive, hinted that shareholders ought to be patient and let the club "create a firm foundation for achieving our ambitions for football success".

Investors seemed to respond, shares rising 1.2% at 207.5p, putting a market-value of £62m on the club.

fields.headline: No hiding place for Dalglish
fields.standfirst: Many Celtic fans will want conclusive proof that he can manage
fields.trailText: Many Celtic fans will want conclusive proof that Kenny Dalglish can manage and may doubt whether he has the ruthlessness to hunt those in the squad who have not been contributing.
fields.body:
If Celtic's results do not improve soon Kenny Dalglish will have some explaining to do now that his job as director of football extends to running the team in the wake of the departure of John Barnes.

The new role of Dalglish no longer permits his daily routine to start with a five-a-side game on the training ground before taking advantage of the privacy of his own office. In short, he will have to stand up and be counted.

Even as he took over the reins yesterday he was enigmatic. By making it clear that he was prepared to take over the first team he signified that he was prepared to serve the club. By adding, in the same sentence, that the search for a new manager was a matter of some priority he made it clear that he intends to stay as the overlord during the course of a seven-year contract reputedly worth £5m. The Celtic fans may be puzzled by that seeming dichotomy.

In the meantime Dalglish will doubtless enjoy the proximity of the players but whether he has the ruthlessness to hunt those who have not been contributing is a matter of some conjecture.

It did not prevent him yesterday questioning the role of certain players in the downfall of Barnes - Dalglish's own choice as head coach - in stating the obvious: "The biggest thing is results," before adding, "the people most responsible for results are the players.

"The supporters demand that the players who wear the shirt wear it with pride. We want players who are totally committed. If they aren't, they don't deserve to be here.

"I can guarantee you, if we get on the pitch and we don't try to grace that pitch, there are problems for those people."

Certainly there is a massive task ahead as Dalglish steps into the breach 18 months after his last managerial expe rience ended with his sudden departure from Newcastle.

Celtic are already out of the Scottish Cup after the defeat by Inverness Caledonian Thistle, one cutting right to the supporters' bones, and 10 points adrift of Rangers in a league chase that is all but over.

So Celtic are effectively involved in only one competition, the CIS Cup, the sponsored name of an old league cup now so undervalued that it does not even carry an automatic entry into Europe for the winners.

Dalglish will have serious financial backing but not completely unlimited funds. Celtic is a plc, answerable to its shareholders, and yesterday's interim figures must have made grim and lengthy reading for institutional investors, coming in a fax that was 11 feet long.

The rebuilding of the club's playing standards is one for the long haul and Dalglish was adamant that it would, sooner rather than later, become the responsibility of someone else, as yet to be identified.

But for the moment it is Dalglish who will be judged and, just as the Celtic fans were scarcely impressed by Barnes's credentials, they may also look at Dalglish warily.

It is an unusual situation for a man who was by far and away the best player in his years at the club. Many fans will want conclusive proof that he can manage.

The popular version of his time spent upstairs is largely unfair but the man himself does not feel he needs to dispute it. Roughly put, it maintains that he simply tended a well-stocked shop at Liverpool, used Jack Walker's money lavishly at Blackburn and failed at Newcastle. That rather ignores that titles still have to be won even if the players are either inherited or bought at premium prices.

His decision to quit Liverpool still looks mysterious and his job as director of football at Blackburn, like the one at Celtic Park, has never been adequately explained at either place. The judgments now will be made in the hard realities of the transfer market, the team sheet and in the dug-out.

As his own worst enemy, Dalglish could not even take advantage of a classic PR opportunity when he returned to Celtic last June and was asked if it was special returning to this particular club.

Instead of the stock reply, he hummed and hawed before saying: "Well, I was born in Glasgow, so I suppose it is." There is also the matter of his working for a brief period at Ibrox, scouting for Rangers and their chairman David Murray.

If he stays in the managerial role for long, it will be intruiging to see how many of the players bought by Barnes command his respect. His other task is to improve morale, which has been desperately low in the last few months. He will need no reminding of how difficult this job can be, for he has to raise the playing standards to a level which he established himself in the 70s.

In his favour is an unremitting enthusiasm for the game. During his own playing career he was never happier than in a dressing room or on a training pitch.

Now Dalglish must show that he enjoys organising a fading football club every bit as much as he thrilled to the sight of a ball and the sound of the whistle to kick off.

So Celtic are effectively involved in only one competition, the CIS Cup, the sponsored name of an old league cup now so undervalued that it does not even carry an automatic entry into Europe for the winners. Dalglish will have serious financial backing but not completely unlimited funds. Celtic is a plc, answerable to its shareholders, and yesterday's interim figures must have made grim and lengthy reading for institutional investors, coming in a fax that was 11 feet long. The rebuilding of the club's playing standards is one for the long haul and Dalglish was adamant that it would, sooner rather than later, become the responsibility of someone else, as yet to be identified. But for the moment it is Dalglish who will be judged and, just as the Celtic fans were scarcely impressed by Barnes's credentials, they may also look at Dalglish warily. It is an unusual situation for a man who was by far and away the best player in his years at the club. Many fans will want conclusive proof that he can manage. The popular version of his time spent upstairs is largely unfair but the man himself does not feel he needs to dispute it. Roughly put, it maintains that he simply tended a well-stocked shop at Liverpool, used Jack Walker's money lavishly at Blackburn and failed at Newcastle. That rather ignores that titles still have to be won even if the players are either inherited or bought at premium prices. His decision to quit Liverpool still looks mysterious and his job as director of football at Blackburn, like the one at Celtic Park, has never been adequately explained at either place. The judgments now will be made in the hard realities of the transfer market, the team sheet and in the dug-out. As his own worst enemy, Dalglish could not even take advantage of a classic PR opportunity when he returned to Celtic last June and was asked if it was special returning to this particular club. Instead of the stock reply, he hummed and hawed before saying: "Well, I was born in Glasgow, so I suppose it is." There is also the matter of his working for a brief period at Ibrox, scouting for Rangers and their chairman David Murray. If he stays in the managerial role for long, it will be intruiging to see how many of the players bought by Barnes command his respect. His other task is to improve morale, which has been desperately low in the last few months. He will need no reminding of how difficult this job can be, for he has to raise the playing standards to a level which he established himself in the 70s. In his favour is an unremitting enthusiasm for the game. During his own playing career he was never happier than in a dressing room or on a training pitch. Now Dalglish must show that he enjoys organising a fading football club every bit as much as he thrilled to the sight of a ball and the sound of the whistle to kick off. webTitle: Dons raid Norway for striker Lund

fields.headline: Dons raid Norway for striker Lund
fields.trailText: Egil Olsen has moved to halt Wimbledon's slide into relegation trouble by signing the Norwegian international striker Andreas Lund from Molde for £2.5m.
fields.body:
Egil Olsen has moved to halt Wimbledon's slide into relegation trouble by signing the Norwegian international striker Andreas Lund from Molde for £2.5m. Lund, previously a target for Coventry and Tottenham, will be available for Wimbledon's match against Chelsea tomorrow.

Both Molde and Wimbledon are owned by the Norwegian businessman Kjell Inge Rokke, and Olsen had been told that there was no money available for transfers. "I was a bit surprised that we had enough money," he said, "but it's probably because it's another club under the same umbrella."

Lund, 24, has scored four times in eight appearances for Norway and brings to five the Norwegians in Olsen's squad.

Derby's Danish striker Mikkel Beck has joined Queens Park Rangers on loan for a month after turning down a move to Crystal Palace.

Barnet have been handed a reprieve to continue playing at Underhill while they develop a new ground with the proviso that it has a minimum capacity of 5,500 by August.

Peter Middleton is to retire as chairman of the Football League at the end of the season.

Scotland and the Republic of Ireland are to meet in a friendly in Dublin on May 30. Meanwhile Mick McCarthy has named his squad to face the Czech Republic at Lansdowne Road on Wednesday week.

webTitle: Cut-price Collymore leaves Villa to pick up tab

fields.headline: Cut-price Collymore leaves Villa to pick up tab
fields.trailText: Stan Collymore yesterday showed little sorrow about leaving the club he supported as a boy, Aston Villa, as he spoke about his move across the midlands to Leicester City..
fields.body:
Stan Collymore looked remarkably unconcerned after completing his latest painful move yesterday, 40 miles across the midlands to Leicester City. Dressed in black slacks and matching shirt for his Filbert Street introductions, the 29-year-old, who arrived late for the press conference, showed little sorrow about leaving the club he supported as a boy, Aston Villa, after 2 unhappy years.

"We all make mistakes but mine have been lived out in the public eye," he said. "God willing, I've come through it and I'm a stronger person. I always wanted to play for Villa, they were my club, but my time there turned into a nightmare.

"I told the chairman and manager I wanted to play for them after I came out of the Priory clinic but I was excluded from the first-team set-up. Now I want to be given the opportunity to have a future."

Being given that chance is costing Collymore a relative packet. Having earned £20,000 a week at Villa, he is understood to have agreed an £8,000-a-week pay-cut to join Leicester. To most observers, though, it is City who have taken an even bigger gamble.

But sitting alongside Collymore, their manager Martin O'Neill looked similarly unconcerned. The £500,000 fee Villa will receive has been astutely negotiated by City's chairman John Elsom: to be paid in two instalments, Collymore will have to play 50 games before the debt is satisfied. Which is one more start than he made in his time at Villa Park, and £6.5m less than the club-record fee they paid Liverpool in May, 1997.

O'Neill maintained Collymore would be an asset on the pitch. "At his best he's magnificent," he said. "At 80% he'll still be good news for us. If he does have problems, there's plenty of people to talk to."

Not least the Leicester players who, according to the long-serving defender Steve Walsh, will roll out the welcome mat but not the red carpet.

"The lads don't pre-judge anybody," Walsh said. "We'll welcome him but he's just another player, so they'll be no special treatment. But if he lets us down he'll be back to square one. Stan knows that."

Back at Bodymore Heath, where Collymore ended his days at Villa training with the youth team, his former manager John Gregory was in conciliatory mood. "Unfortunately Stan didn't give me enough quality performances on the field," he said. "But there are no hard feelings from my end - I hope he takes his chance and would like to thank him for the contribution he has made to the club." With each of his 15 goals costing £433,333, it was an expensive one.

Paul Merson, a former team-mate of Collymore's at Villa, said: "It might be a new club but it's still the same you. And it's up to that person to work things out - a club won't change him.

"I discovered that when I moved from Middlesbrough to Aston Villa. I could have been in Milan playing with Ronaldo and I wouldn't have been happy. So if Stan sorts himself out then it won't matter who he's playing for. He's got the talent; it's up to him to knuckle down and use it."

fields.headline: Chelsea in £18m Dutch auction
fields.standfirst: Vialli watches van Nistelrooy score a valuable and timely goal in Eindhoven
fields.trailText: The Chelsea manager Gianluca Vialli was in Holland last night hoping to sign PSV Eindhoven's much-coveted striker Ruud van Nistelrooy for a British record £18m in what amounted to a public auction.
fields.body:
The Chelsea manager Gianluca Vialli was in Holland last night hoping to sign PSV Eindhoven's much-coveted striker Ruud van Nistelrooy for a British record £18m in what amounted to a public auction.

Vialli and Chelsea's managing director Colin Hutchinson were joined by the Arsenal manager Arsène Wenger at PSV's league match against Ajax as the race for the 23-year-old Holland international gathered pace.

Alongside them were representatives from Liverpool, Milan, Atletico Madrid, Lazio and Roma. Van Nistelrooy has also been strongly linked with Internazionale.

Liverpool are likely to have been watching PSV's other main striker Luc Nilis. But the majority of eyes will have been on Van Nistelrooy. When he tapped in PSV's second goal last night he took his tally to a remarkable 55 from 52 games since joining the club from Heerenveen for £4.7m in 1998.

Roma have had a £17.5m offer rejected but Vialli is willing to up the bidding, smashing the club record £10m he paid for Chris Sutton last summer and the British record £15m Newcastle spent on Alan Shearer. Van Nistelrooy is said to be keen to move to London.

The 6ft 2in Dutchman is reportedly wary of the pressure of Serie A, perhaps influenced by the failure there of Patrick Kluivert and Dennis Bergkamp. At Stamford Bridge he would join his compatriots Ed de Goey, a goalkeeper, and Mario Melchiot, a former Ajax defender awaiting his Premiership debut.

Van Nistelrooy, who has also been linked with Leeds United, is two years into a five-year contract. But he has an agreement that he can leave for his "dream club". It should soon become clear whether he spent his childhood chanting "Bobby Campbell's Blue and White Army".

Van Nistelrooy has scored 23 goals this season, including three in six Champions League games for a struggling side who finished bottom of Group F, which included Rangers, with one victory and only five goals.

"He is a very complete player," a Dutch commentator said. "He is very strong, very good with both feet and very quick. Sometimes he can be too aggressive but he is a wonderful player."

Chelsea know Van Nistelrooy is ineligible for the Champions League, having represented PSV in the competition this season. But Vialli is aware a place in the Premiership's top three is worth millions in Champions League booty and may try to tempt his target to England this season rather than wait until the summer, which would be PSV's choice.

His willingness to spend £18m on one player not only signals his determination to establish Chelsea as a major European force but reflects the team's shortcomings this season despite a huge investment in Sutton and an apparent surfeit of strikers.

Sutton and Gianfranco Zola have managed only two Premiership goals between them, and the forwards' failure to contribute more has severely hampered Chelsea's championship ambitions. Tore Andre Flo leads the way with nine.

The move to bring George Weah on loan from Milan until the end of the season was an admission of failure on that front. Weah may become available on a permanent basis but he will be 34 in October and Van Nistelrooy looks a better long-term option.

There is no doubting his goalscoring ability despite a relatively slow start. His first professional experience with Den Bosch from 1993-97 produced 17 goals in 69 games. From there he moved to Heerenveen (31 games, 13 goals) and thence to PSV, where his career has taken off.

The 31 goals he scored last season made him the Dutch player of the year. He is a key member of the Holland squad, and has begun the tough task of dislodging Bergkamp and Kluivert.

While the full Dutch side were at France 98 he was representing his country at the European Under-21 championship in Romania. Now he is among the most sought after players in the world.

webTitle: Cricket umpires to have yellow cards

fields.headline: Cricket umpires to have yellow cards
fields.trailText: Club cricket in the north of England plans to take a step towards curbing increasing anarchy in the ranks by introducing a football-style yellow card system for players.
fields.body:
Club cricket in the north of England plans to take a step towards curbing increasing anarchy in the ranks by introducing a football-style yellow card system for players.

Although there is no intention to add a red card, the Northern Premier League, one of Britain's top competitions, is to issue automatic two-match bans for players who collect three formal warnings.

In the past umpires have had to rely on the co-operation of captains in disciplining unruly players but it is hoped that the new measures will give officials more clout.

The initiative comes as a result of several seasons where indiscipline has been on the increase in what is generally regarded as one of the most fiercely contested of leagues. The Australian Test leg-spinner Stuart MacGill has received a life ban from the league as a result of his general conduct when he was a professional for St Annes and last season an air ambulance had to be called to one ground to ferry an injured player to hospital after a brawl erupted.

However, despite the desire of international and domestic cricket bodies to stamp out dissent and bad behaviour, there are no plans to extend the idea to first-class cricket.

At international level certainly, while there is still room for improvement, the introduction of one independent official at matches, together with a code of conduct and the presence of a match referee with the power to enforce its terms, has had a positive effect.

Since these measures were brought in eight years ago indiscipline has diminished in certain respects, in particular dissent at decisions, although the grey area between "dissent" and "disappointment" is always open to interpretation by referees and consistency of sentencing is difficult to attain.

Umpires in club cricket have had no such protection, however, and too often the feeling has been that strong action on the part of umpires will not be backed up by the authorities. In such a climate of uncertainty, prospective umpires are being deterred from the game.

It remains to be seen whether card-wielding umpires are the solution, or if indeed the prospect of players being carded will not in itself lead to further poor behaviour. But the feeling is that steps needed to be taken to preserve the game's integrity.

According to the league's secretary, John Cooper, the umpires' "quiet word" will still be an option. "But if a player carries on misbehaving," he added, "the official can now issue a formal warning. We want to make discipline in league cricket work."

webTitle: Roof strikes hit for six as indoor internationals are given all clear

fields.headline: Roof strikes hit for six as indoor internationals are given all clear
fields.trailText: The final obstacle to the staging of one-day internationals indoors was removed yesterday when the International Cricket Council decided that, if the ball hits the roof, it will have to be bowled again.
fields.body:
The final obstacle to the staging of one-day internationals indoors was removed yesterday when the International Cricket Council decided that, if the ball hits the roof, it will have to be bowled again.

The decision clears the way for the three-match series between South Africa and Australia to be held in Melbourne's Colonial Stadium in August.

"The only doubt was what happens if the ball hits the roof," the ICC's chief executive David Richards said. "We then decided to recommend to the Australian board that the ball be declared a dead ball and bowled again in case the 38-metre ceiling is indeed hit."

The ICC has also approved an application by New Zealand to organise indoor cricket in their next season.

webTitle: After the flood a curse for South Africa

fields.headline: After the flood a curse for South Africa
fields.standfirst: Even if the final is cancelled, Zimbabwe's coach is backing England
fields.trailText: The last few days have seen the worst rain since 1958 fall on the Wanderers, but Zimbabwe coach Dave Houghton's abiding admiration for Duncan Fletcher and disappointment with South Africa will see him backing England even if the final is cancelled.
fields.body:
There is a growing suspicion that unless Moses, or perhaps King Canute, is appointed head groundsman here, the one-day final between England and South Africa will not get under way at the Wanderers tomorrow.

The sodden ground has had its worst rain since 1958, according to the Gauteng Cricket Board, and there is already speculation that the game will be played on Sunday, if at all.

If there is play, England will have an unlikely supporter in the muscular, shaven-headed shape of the Zimbabwe coach Dave Houghton, whose old friendship with Duncan Fletcher, together with a certain disaffection with South African cricket, will have him cheering on the boys in blue.

Houghton, who once scored 266 in a Test match and is considered the best batsman in Zimbabwe's short international history, said yesterday: "I know Fletch well. We were mates and roomies when I first played for Zimbabwe.

"I was delighted to have a chat with him the other evening. It was about the first time we had had a proper talk since he left the country 15 years ago.

"It is already easy to see the influence he has had with England. When he played he used to bowl little outswingers and fast off-breaks. And suddenly all the England bowlers are bowling fast off-breaks.

"The thing that really impressed me about Fletch was that he was a great captain and player under pressure. Whatever the situation in a match I would look at Fletch and suddenly feel I was winning.

"His body language, the whole aura about him, suggested we were winning. Even if we scored 200 and the other lot had 180 for one I'd look at Fletch and immediately feel we had a chance. And he always seemed to get runs under pressure. If we were 40 for four he would score 80. If we were 260 for four he would make 10.

"He has a way of gelling a unit together and I can see that England are already on the way up under him. The players clearly have a great respect for him. The team spirit is up. England must give him two years to rebuild. And Duncan should be looking at the 2003 World Cup."

The other reason Houghton will be cheering England on from his Harare home this weekend is his disappointment with South Africa. "I'm just sorry this weekend's final is not between Zimbabwe and England.

"I'm not a supporter of South African cricket. I was. But since we got Test status they have not done enough for us.

"They have not given us the respect we deserve as a Test nation. You can hear it on the field. They call us club cricketers. We are only an hour up the road but they do not play us that often."

Club cricketers, of course, are what the Zimbabweans really are. Remarkably, some have played more Tests than other first-class matches, which is why they are so anxious to play a number of counties in England next summer.

"I was surprised by the recent Test series," said Houghton. "I did not expect England to go 2-0 down.

"South Africa are as beatable as anyone right now. Their depth is not as good as people make it out to be. Their top 15 players or so are good. But when they lose a player or two, such as Daryll Cullinan and Allan Donald, and replace them with youngsters, they do not look so strong.

"England have a great chance in the final. They are realising that in one-day cricket everybody must be able to bat, bowl and field and they are playing some good cricket right now."

At the moment, however, a groundsman who can mop, pump and squeegee is just as important. Chris Scott, head groundsman at the Wanderers, said yesterday: "If it stops raining, this match could still go ahead but the forecast is not very good.

"I have been here for 26 years and this is the worst the rain has been. We have pumps and hot air blowers in position but, if it is still raining on Saturday morning, we will have problems."

If there is no play South Africa, who have beaten England twice in three matches, would be the tournament winners.

"The thing that really impressed me about Fletch was that he was a great captain and player under pressure. Whatever the situation in a match I would look at Fletch and suddenly feel I was winning. "His body language, the whole aura about him, suggested we were winning. Even if we scored 200 and the other lot had 180 for one I'd look at Fletch and immediately feel we had a chance. And he always seemed to get runs under pressure. If we were 40 for four he would score 80. If we were 260 for four he would make 10. "He has a way of gelling a unit together and I can see that England are already on the way up under him. The players clearly have a great respect for him. The team spirit is up. England must give him two years to rebuild. And Duncan should be looking at the 2003 World Cup." The other reason Houghton will be cheering England on from his Harare home this weekend is his disappointment with South Africa. "I'm just sorry this weekend's final is not between Zimbabwe and England. "I'm not a supporter of South African cricket. I was. But since we got Test status they have not done enough for us. "They have not given us the respect we deserve as a Test nation. You can hear it on the field. They call us club cricketers. We are only an hour up the road but they do not play us that often." Club cricketers, of course, are what the Zimbabweans really are. Remarkably, some have played more Tests than other first-class matches, which is why they are so anxious to play a number of counties in England next summer. "I was surprised by the recent Test series," said Houghton. "I did not expect England to go 2-0 down. "South Africa are as beatable as anyone right now. Their depth is not as good as people make it out to be. Their top 15 players or so are good. But when they lose a player or two, such as Daryll Cullinan and Allan Donald, and replace them with youngsters, they do not look so strong. "England have a great chance in the final. They are realising that in one-day cricket everybody must be able to bat, bowl and field and they are playing some good cricket right now." At the moment, however, a groundsman who can mop, pump and squeegee is just as important. Chris Scott, head groundsman at the Wanderers, said yesterday: "If it stops raining, this match could still go ahead but the forecast is not very good. "I have been here for 26 years and this is the worst the rain has been. We have pumps and hot air blowers in position but, if it is still raining on Saturday morning, we will have problems." If there is no play South Africa, who have beaten England twice in three matches, would be the tournament winners.

fields.headline: Roger Vadim dies
fields.trailText: Roger Vadim, the famed French director whose films and life revolved around female beauty and whose romances included Brigitte Bardot, Jane Fonda and Catherine Deneuve, died today after a long struggle with cancer
fields.body:
Roger Vadim, the famed French director whose films and life revolved around female beauty and whose romances included Brigitte Bardot, Jane Fonda and Catherine Deneuve, died today after a long struggle with cancer. He was 72.

Vadim died in a Paris hospital, RTL radio said. A family friend and the National Cinema Center confirmed Vadim's death.

Vadim was best-known for the 1956 groundbreaking And God Created Woman about a young married woman's quest for sexual freedom. The film brought his new wife Bardot instant fame and enjoyed commercial success around the world.

The scene of Bardot dancing barefoot on a table remains one of the most titillating scenes in French cinema.

"There was really nothing shocking in what Brigitte did, what was provocative was her natural sensuality," Vadim told The Associated Press in a 1988 interview.

The film defined the content and set the tone for many of Vadim's films, including the 1968 Barbarella, an avant-garde sci-fi romp starring his new blond wife, Jane Fonda.

Vadim also earned praise as a producer, writer and theater director in a career that spanned half a century. His most recent work included several made-for-television mini-series. His films sometimes were superficial in content, but always technically strong and full of visual elegance.

Mostly, though, his films were known for their beautiful women.

"You wouldn't ask Rodin to make an ugly sculpture, or me to make a film with an ugly woman," Vadim told AP. "That's my style, that's my nature."

Vadim cast 26 movies with leading ladies ranging from the elegant Deneuve to earthy Angie Dickinson, intellectual Jeanne Moreau and Susan Sarandon. In 1988, he did a remake of And God created Woman, starring Rebecca DeMornay.

But he was best know for And God Created Woman, in which Bardot played a woman who marries a man in order to escape an orphanage, only to fall for the man's younger brother.

"I wanted to show a normal young girl whose only difference was that she behaved in the way a boy might, without any sense of guilt on a moral or sexual level," Vadim said.

Vadim was born Roger Vladimir Plemiannikov on Jan. 26, 1928, in Paris, the son of a diplomat. He met Bardot when she was 15. He was behind her early career as a fashion model, and later introduced her to the cinema. They married in 1952 when she was only 18. He was 24.

His other films include Sait-On Jamais? (No Sun in Venice) (1957), Les Bijoutiers du Clair de Lune (Night Heaven Fell) (1958), Les Liaisons Dangereuses, (1959), Et Mourir de Plaisir (Blood and Roses) (1960), Pretty Maids All in a Row in the United States (1971), Dom Juan (1973) and The Hot Touch (1981) .

Recent television productions include Mon Pere Avait Raison (1996), La Nouvelle Tribu (1996), and Amour Fou (1993).

Vadim also wrote several books including his autobiography, D'Une Etoile a l'Autre (From One Star to the Next) in which he described his marriages to Bardot and Fonda. He was also married to Annette Stroyberg and Catherine Schneider.

His is survived by his wife, actress Marie-Christine Barrault, and four children, Vanessa, born to Fonda, Christian, born to Deneuve, Nathalie, born to Stroyberg, and Vania, born to Schneider.

Funeral arrangements were pending.

webTitle: Reaction to the suspension of Stormont

fields.headline: Reaction to the suspension of Stormont
fields.trailText: Northern Ireland minister Peter Mandelson
fields.body:
Northern Ireland minister Peter Mandelson

"I have decided to suspend the executive and the institutions. There has been progress but not sufficient progress.

"We have got to clear up the issue of decommissioning once and for all.

"I hope that with goodwill and in a measured and calm way people, will be able to build on the progress that has been made ... so that we can resolve this issue and get the executive and institutions up and running again on an even firmer foundation than they were originally."

President Bill Clinton

"We believe that all the requirements of the Good Friday accords which the voters of Northern Ireland and the Irish republic embraced should be fulfilled and we hope a way can be found to keep this going."

Rev Ian Paisley, leader of the Democratic Unionists

"Democracy has been vindicated when the flaw in the system of having spokesmen of gunmen holding us to ransom is going to be addressed."

"We know the mayhem and murders that his particular organisation has brought on the people of Northern Ireland.

"Now the Secretary of State says there is a progress - and cannot tell us anything about the progress."

Liberal Democrat spokesman on Northern Ireland Lembit Opik

"All our colleagues involved in the peace process must continue to try to move the position on. "The process has gone too far - and too many people have sacrificed too much - to give up on it now.

"The assembly has been working well for all the people of Northern Ireland. Devolution has given local politicians the responsibility of taking decisions on local issues affecting local people.

"Whatever the short term challenges that decommissioning presents, all sides have taken such strides towards peace, it would now be a tragedy for the people of Northern Ireland if the peace process falters for any significant period."

fields.headline: Go back where you came from
fields.standfirst:
British tabloid newspapers have offered little sympathy to the passengers who were held on the hijacked 727

Read the Guardian leader from today
fields.trailText: The Daily Mail
fields.body:
The Daily Mail

Here to stay?: So platoons of passengers freed in the Stansted hijacking are already queuing up for asylum. Small wonder, when it is so obvious that this squalid episode was never more than a cynical attempt to exploit Britain. Would-be refugees are growing old waiting for their cases to be processed. And well wager that most victims of the Stansted hijack are still enjoying life on benefits in Britain, five years hencePolice have booked 83 suites at the four-star Hilton National Hotel where rooms cost £202 a night. One guest at the hotel said: This hotel cost an arm and a leg to stay at although it is very nice. The hostages must think they are in heaven after coming from Afghanistan. I dread to think how much it is costing. (Leader comment and news report, February 11)

The Mirror

Hijack gang should be sent packing: It is right that Britain should play its part in helping people who face murder, torture and rape in their own lands. But it would be offensive if people who want a better life could hijack a plane, be put up in expensive hotels and then be allowed to settle here. The hijackers and their accomplices must be sent back. (Leader comment, February 11)

The Star

Welcome to your home cheat home: The flood of asylum bids  likely to total around 100  confirmed growing suspicions that the hijack had been a well-planned scam by Afghanis who want to settle in the West to escape the poor conditions in their strict Muslim homelandJack Straw promises to be tough with the criminals and scam merchants from the hijacked 727. So far this entails putting the whole lot in a four-star hotel while Mr Straw decides what to do with them. Theyre enjoying satellite movies, and getting all the food and clothes they need from soft touch Britain. No wonder one passing policeman said they were all smiles. Why on earth arent they awaiting their fate behind bars? (News report and leader comment, February 11)

The Sun

Mugs game: Amazing, isnt it. No wonder the reaction in Afghanistan to the hijack was one of envy. It is a passport to a new life of decent housing and social security. Maybe [the hijackers] read about the gang who hijacked a Sudanese plane three years ago. They are still here in Britain, doing very nicely at your expense. (Leader comment in The Sun, February 10)

The Express

Hijack passengers should not expect asylum here: There should be no sympathy for the hostage-takers. The arsenal of weapons found on board shows that they were prepared to kill to achieve their aims. [Jack] Straw will now have to follow up yesterdays tough talk with fast action. Only then will he discourage others from seeing Britain as an easy target. (Leader comment, The Express, February 11)

fields.headline: Geri spices up courtroom drama
fields.trailText: Quitting the Spice Girls was like leaving a marriage, Geri Halliwell told the high court in London today.
fields.body:
Quitting the Spice Girls was like leaving a marriage, Geri Halliwell told the high court in London today.

Ms Halliwell, 27, known as Ginger Spice before she left in May 1998, was giving evidence in support of the the girl pop group in a two-way legal action with Aprilia, official sponsor of their 1998 world tour.

She told the judge, Mrs Justice Arden: What one wants to do and what one does are two different things. At the back of my mind I wanted to leave, but I didn't know whether I was brave enough to do that  leave the security of such a big band.

Explaining the circumstances of the build-up to her leaving the group, she said: So the reason I was drip, drip feeding the idea to the others and myself was to see if I was brave enough. So there wasn't one defining moment when I consciously made that decision.

She added: It was like leaving a marriage. You get such mixed feelings: one part of me wanted to stay, but the other half said it was time to go.

Ms Halliwell, who arrived in court accompanied by her own lawyer and two minders, spent an hour in the witness box of court 19.

Aprilia, an Italian motor cycle manufacturer, which had signed a £500,000 deal with the group to promote its products (including a special Spice Sonic scooter featuring a picture of all five girls - singers), and claims that Ms Halliwells departure cost it £1.6m million in lost profits.

Asprilia claims that the Spice Girls were aware of Ms Halliwells her plans to leave the group when they signed the contract. The group have launched a counter-suit, claiming for £212,000 in unpaid sponsorship and royalty fees from Aprilia.

Relaxed and smiling, wearing a black trouser suit and rimless glasses, Ms Halliwell said she had wanted a little bit of breathing space" before she made making new plans. She has since The singer, who has pursued a successful solo career and become a goodwill ambassador for the United Nations.

She told the court she remembered telling the Spice Girls others on their tour coach in Frankfurt in early March 1998  before the Aprilia deal was signed  that she planned to leave at the end of September. But she added: I do not think they took me seriously.

Later in the tour, in Milan, she reiterated the fact that I was going to leave". Asked by Andrew Sutcliffe, for Aprilia, how the others reacted, she replied: I think it was possibly disbelief, a mixed reaction, and still not taking it seriously."

When one asked why she wanted to leave, she told them that she had had enough and wanted to finish with a big finale at Wembley.

Ms Halliwell said the decision to keep her departure secret was not because of a fear of adverse publicity but was more quite an emotional thing among the band".

We wanted private time to possibly resolve it, she said. The whole media thing wasn't the main reason. We wanted to come to terms with it first, and then make it public. It felt kind of better to do it at the end of the tour.

Ms Halliwell She agreed that she was aware, while filming a commercial shoot for Aprilia early in May, that the firm company was investing a lot of money in its association with the band; but it would not have been uppermost in her mind during the shoot  when you are an artist, you are an artist".

She said that it did not even cross my mind at the time" that the scooters, with the logo of the five Spice Girls, would be out of date if she left, adding that she thought they had become more of a collector's item as a result.

She added: It didn't concern me because I felt that the Spice Girls were strong enough and had momentum to go on as a four-piece. The whole concept of it was there."

After Ms Halliwell left court, her spokesman stressed that she was not a party to the proceedings but had come voluntarily as a witness to help out the girls.

Earlier this week, Emma Bunton  Baby Spice  told the court that the group had never believed Ms Halliwell would leave.

The hearing continues on Monday.

webTitle: Morgan begins search for truce in Wales

fields.headline: Morgan begins search for truce in Wales
fields.standfirst: New Labour leader will 'bust a gut' in cash talks with treasury
fields.trailText: February 11 2000: New Labour leader will 'bust a gut' in cash talks with treasury
fields.body:
Less than 24 hours after being catapulted into place as Labour's first secretary-in-waiting, Rhodri Morgan moved swiftly yesterday to prepare the ground for a much needed period of stability in the troubled Welsh assembly.

With the dust barely settled on the acrimonious no confidence debate that triggered the resignation of his predecessor, Alun Michael, the acting leader of the minority Labour admininstration began meetings with opposition leaders in Cardiff in an attempt to find common ground on ways to make the assembly work.

Mr Morgan was careful to make no firm commitments ahead of his expected election as first secretary early next week. But he pledged to "bust a gut" to get the top deal for Wales in any negotiations with the treasury over European funding, the issue that ostensibly led to Mr Michael's downfall.

He refused to be drawn on the prospect of a formal coalition with the six strong Liberal Democrat group but defused speculation about the possibility of sweeping cabinet changes. "I am very, very happy with the members of the cabinet that I have got at the moment and how, if I were elected, I will fill that one vacancy is not something I have given any thought to as yet."

Mr Morgan will be officially endorsed as the Welsh Labour leader and its candidate for first secretary at a meeting of the party's executive in Cardiff this afternoon. Plaid Cymru confirmed yesterday that it will accept his nomination as first secretary when the assembly meets next Tuesday.

As Mr Michael warned him to "watch his back" to avoid the fate that he had suffered, Mr Morgan stressed in interviews that the assembly had to have stability "to deliver the better health and the better wealth that the Welsh assembly should deliver for the people of Wales".

Whether that stability could be achieved by coalition along the Scottish route, through a Lab-Lib pact or through some other means, he did not yet know.

Despite Downing Street's previous opposition to his attempts to become party leader in Wales Mr Morgan is confident that relations with the Labour hierarchy in London will be good. "This idea that you should be aggressive and do all your negotiations with Tony Blair and Gordon Brown by megaphone is completely absurd. You can fight very hard for Wales to get additional resources but you have got to do it by having very good relations with Westminster."

As his successor prepared formally to take over the reins in Cardiff, Mr Michael launched a ferocious attack on the conduct of Plaid Cymru and one of the party's leading peers, the assembly's presiding officer, Lord Dafydd Elis Thomas.

Mr Michael warned his successor: "I am absolutely certain that Plaid Cymru will look for an excuse for a repeat run at some point in the future. That would obviously create problems for Rhodri and any future leader, but it will also again risk the reputation and the standing of the assembly.

Mr Michael claimed Lord Elis Thomas had changed the rules over the timing of the re-election of the first secretary in a way that would have caused considerable difficulty to the 28-strong Labour group, who would have been faced with a series of further votes without having the opportunity to reflect or consult the wider party. "I felt that was intolerable, I also think it is wrong. And I thought it was time to cut through this sort of dictatorship from the smaller parties by allowing the Labour party to take a decision."

Having given up the top job in Welsh politics Mr Michael said it was too early to talk about his political future. He said he did not regret having given up his home office position to take on the role of first secretary in Wales. He believed he had achieved a great deal in his time in the post.

"I felt that was intolerable, I also think it is wrong. And I thought it was time to cut through this sort of dictatorship from the smaller parties by allowing the Labour party to take a decision." He said he did not regret having given up his home office position to take on the role of first secretary in Wales. He believed he had achieved a great deal in his time in the post.

fields.headline: Mandelson suspends Stormont assembly
fields.trailText:
The Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson has suspended
                                                  the Stormont assembly, despite a last-minute announcement
                                                  from Sinn Fein of a new proposal for decommissioning.
fields.body:
The Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson has suspended the Stormont assembly, despite a last-minute announcement from Sinn Fein of a new proposal for decommissioning.

On a day of political interventions, from Gerry Adams to President Clinton, nothing proved enough to avert the suspension of Northern Ireland's power-sharing administration that has wielded authority for just 72 days.

Announcing the reimposition of direct rule, Mr Mandelson said: "We have got to clear up this issue of decommissioning once and for all."

Earlier, Mr Mandelson had confirmed talks were continuing to win a clear-cut disarmament commitment from the IRA, but said he didn't want "to raise people's expectations" because he had "no news of any last-minute breakthrough."

Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble said: "It is not an event in which we take any pleasure at all." But he said it was now time for the IRA to "reciprocate" the moves to peace that unionists had made.

Sinn Fein president Gerry Adams said late in the day that a new proposal set out the context in which the IRA would deal with decommissioning.

"When set alongside the IRA's recent assertion that the peace process is under no threat from it and its guns are silent, this new development takes on an enormous significance and can, if there is political will and goodwill, finally resolve this matter."

The Sinn Fein president said he anticipated the report by the international decommissioning body would reflect the latest developments and "clear the way to end this crisis".

However, Mr Trimble said he had spoken to both Mr Adams and Sinn Fein's chief negotiator Martin McGuinness. "They had nothing to put before me," he said.

In Washington, US president Bill Clinton said that if the cabinet does lose its powers, "it is imperative that all the parties do it on terms which do not allow a backslide."

Mr Clinton has been involved in a week of telephone diplomacy involving the British and Irish prime ministers, Tony Blair and Bertie Ahern, Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble and Sinn Fein leader Gerry Adams.

Northern Ireland deputy first minister Seamus Mallon made a last-ditch effort to ward off the suspension of the political institutions, meeting Mr Mandelson to warn him yet again of the dangers of suspension.

Speaking afterwards outside Castle Buildings, Mr Mallon said he believed suspension would "make obtaining decommissioning immeasurably more difficult".

Suspension would make it "very, very difficult timewise, politically, logistically and every other way to have the institutions reinstated", he said.

Sinn Fein also appealed to Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson to step back from suspending political institutions in the province over the row about IRA decommissioning.

Stormont education minister Martin McGuinness urged the Northern Ireland secretary to reconsider his decision and stressed that republicans are still working hard to try and achieve a resolution of the arms issue.

"Even at this late hour, Sinn Fein is continuing to do its best," he claimed. "We all know that there is a need to remove all ultimatums and deadlines, threats of suspension and resignations from this process.

"Even at this late hour he should reflect and he should pull back from the disastrous course on which he appears to be set," Mr McGuinness added.

Meanwhile, two dozen Sinn Fein protestors gathered outside the central Belfast headquarters of the Ulster Unionist party. The demonstrators held up placards declaring "Peter Mandelson betrays 2.5 million voters", "unionists ran away. Sinn Fein here to stay" and "Tony Blair no suspension".

webTitle: Shuttle Endeavour blasts off to map the world - at last

fields.headline: Shuttle Endeavour blasts off to map the world - at last
fields.trailText: After five months of delays, space shuttle Endeavour thundered away on a mission to map the world as never before. Endeavour rose from its seaside pad at 12:43pm (17:45 GMT), carrying six astronauts and 13 tons of Earth-scanning radar.
fields.body:
After five months of delays, space shuttle Endeavour thundered away on a mission to map the world as never before. Endeavour rose from its seaside pad at 12:43pm (17:45 GMT), carrying six astronauts and 13 tons of Earth-scanning radar. The gorgeous, sunny weather was especially welcome given the rain during last week's failed attempt.

"It looks like a great day to go fly," launch director Dave King told the crew shortly before lift-off.

"We're ready to map the world," shuttle commander Kevin Kregel responded.

It was NASA's second launch attempt in as many weeks. Lift-off came 13 minutes late because of three minor technical problems that popped up at the last minute.

During the first try, on Jan. 31, the weather and a faulty computer kept Endeavour and its crew from lifting off on a quest to create the most accurate 3-D map of the world.

The astronauts were eager to get started on their 11-day mission. They should have tackled the job last September, but were kept waiting because damaged wiring all over Endeavour had to be repaired.

Shuttle program manager Ron Dittemore said he would not rest easy until Endeavour was in orbit and its long radar antenna was all the way out and thoroughly tested.

The 197-foot antenna mast was to be extended from Endeavour's cargo bay late this afternoon, just five hours after lift-off. It will be the longest rigid structure ever deployed in space - if it makes it all the way out.

"There's certainly an element of mission risk. Not safety risk, mission risk," Dittemore said.

The steel, titanium and plastic mast, which has a radar antenna on the end, has never flown in space. As a result, engineers had to rely on ground tests to determine how the mast would move in weightlessness. It was so long that workers used phones to talk from one end to the other.

"We've done all that we can think, as far as testing in a one-G environment and simulating the effects of our (shuttle) manoeuvres on the mast," Dittemore said. "But there is that element of risk that there may be something we didn't get, that we don't quite understand."

If the mast bends too much or breaks, the astronauts can simply eject it and fly away.

NASA added the mast in order to get the best 3-D snapshots ever of Earth's terrain. A large antenna anchored in the shuttle cargo bay will bounce radar signals off the Earth's surface; the signals will be received by both that antenna and the smaller antenna on the end of the mast.

If all goes well, more than 70 percent of the Earth's terrain will be mapped. The results will be used by the Defense Department for security purposes, as well as by environmentalists, airlines and emergency relief groups.

An aerospace safety panel, meanwhile, is raising concern over what will happen once the number of shuttle flights picks up.

NASA is coming off its slowest year in a decade because of damaged shuttle wiring and stalled work on the international space station. This year promises to be almost as bad. With the wiring problems behind them and the space station setbacks being tackled more aggressively, shuttle managers hope to launch nine times in 2001 - triple the 1999 rate. And that has the Aerospace Safety Advisory Panel worried.

The panel, which was formed in the wake of the deadly Apollo spacecraft fire in 1967, stressed that safety consciousness remains high at NASA.

"Nevertheless," it warned Thursday in its annual report, "workforce issues remain among the most serious safety concerns of the panel. Cutbacks and reorganisations over the past several years have resulted in problems related to workforce size, critical skills and the extent of on-the-job experience," the panel said.

The problems could affect safety as the space shuttle launch rate increases to meet the demands of the space station and its other customers, it said.

webTitle: NatWest: it's all over bar the announcement

fields.headline: NatWest: it's all over bar the announcement
fields.standfirst: Board tantalises with silence as Royal Bank heads for 50% support
fields.trailText: NatWest last night refused to admit that its days as an independent entity were over even though Bank of Scotland abandoned its £23bn bid to clear the way for Royal Bank of Scotland to clinch victory.
fields.body:
NatWest last night refused to admit that its days as an independent entity were over even though Bank of Scotland abandoned its £23bn bid to clear the way for Royal Bank of Scotland to clinch victory.

Despite the NatWest intransigence, the City was increasingly convinced that Royal Bank was racing toward the 50% barrier of support from NatWest shareholders that would allow its bid to succeed.

But yesterday's stunning silence from NatWest, which tantalised and frustrated the City, came against a backdrop of yet another slide in Royal Bank's share price. Royal Bank, however, was unable to claim victory because it did not formally have support from half of NatWest's investors, who must decide by Valentine's day whether to back the bid.

The shares lost a further 3%, an uncomfortable position for Royal Bank because it served to slash the headline price of the bank's bid for NatWest. That might make it difficult for NatWest's board to recommend that its shareholders support the offer.

But the share price fall to 875p did not appear to worry investors yesterday who, after a roller-coaster week which started with BoS apparently in the lead, lined up behind Royal Bank's offer yesterday.

In admitting defeat, Peter Burt, chief executive of BoS, claimed to have had the support of major NatWest shareholders until Tuesday, the day Schroders and Mercury Asset Management backed the rival bid by Royal Bank.

"Until Tuesday many large shareholders had indicated support for ourselves but one major vote went against us and then others switched decisions as their first priority was to ensure that NatWest didn't survive," Mr Burt said in a memo to staff. "It was an extremely close call."

City sources indicated his analysis of the situation was correct, particularly after Phillips & Drew, NatWest's seventh-largest shareholder and the only one publicly to back BoS, admitted it would switch its allegiance to Royal Bank to ensure NatWest lost its independence.

Bankers admit that the decision by Schroders and, in particular, MAM to support Royal Bank was probably the turning point in the battle which has been raging since September when BoS fired the first shot at NatWest.

MAM's decision to back Royal caused confusion among sophisticated professional traders known as arbitrageurs who play on differences in prices and had become convinced it was poised to back BoS.

While the crumbling Royal Bank share price continued to cause angst in some City circles, sources insisted last night that this could not be the reason for NatWest's silence yesterday. "It must be about emotion," one source said.

Talks between NatWest and Royal Bank, initiated on Wednesday as support started to flood in for Royal Bank, failed to continue yesterday when NatWest's senior managers were said to be locked in a serious of internal meetings.

NatWest's 64,000 staff face 18,000 job cuts with Royal Bank in control, while NatWest's own defence strategy involved cutting 15,000 posts.

Mr Burt, who faces speculation that his bank will become a takeover target, insisted to his staff yesterday that the failure to win NatWest would not alter their future.

fields.headline: Vaughan Williams: Symphony No 5
fields.trailText: In our series on building a classical library, Andrew Clements selects the definitive recording of Vaughan Williams' Symphony No 5.
fields.body:
The most common image of Ralph Vaughan Williams is that of the comfortable English pastoralist, and the Fifth Symphony, the most widely performed of his nine, seems on first acquaintance to conform totally to that image. But there's more to the genesis of the work than that. It is bracketed in Vaughan Williams's symphonic development by two very different works , the violent and extreme Fourth Symphony of 1935, which seems to foreshadow the world-wide conflagration to come, and the Sixth (1947), which inhabits a world totally numbed by the horror of what that war has produced.

Yet the Fifth appeared at the height of the second world war in 1943 how at such a moment did Vaughan Williams produce a work of such serene contemplation? In fact the origins of the work date back well before even the composition of the Fourth Symphony. For much of the 30s he had worked on an opera based upon Bunyan's Pilgrim's Progress, before setting the project aside (he eventually completed it in 1951), and deciding to recycle some of what he had written in symphonic form.

There is a dark undertow to the symphony, which wells up most clearly in the scherzo's brusque brass punctuations and in the troubled central section of the slow movement. The landscapes that the Fifth explores are by no means as benign as they at first appear, and the finest interpreters of the work do not mistake the surface calm for the key to the whole work. Some versions do just that , Leonard Slatkin's, for instance, is bland to the point of harmlessness (RCA) even Adrian Boult's (EMI) is more superficial than it needs to be, and Vernon Handley (EMI) takes his cue from the same approach.

Something sharper is suggested by Andre Previn (RCA) and Andrew Davis (Teldec), but the one who draws all the elements of the Fifth Symphony most purposefully is a Dutchman. Bernard Haitink's carefully measured version with the London Philharmonic has a monumental integrity and real troubling depth, to which his wonderfully paced unfolding of the passacaglia provides the perfect finish.

Key Recording: Haitink (EMI 5 55487 2)

fields.headline: Ram rider
fields.standfirst: Sheep on the move, cougars on the prowl and a panther on the draw
fields.trailText: Sheep on the move, cougars on the prowl and a panther on the draw
fields.body:
Police in woolly pull-over
We've all seen sheepskin car seat covers. This week, however, a man in Kings Lynn took things a step further by having not merely a sheepskin, but an entire sheep in his car. Lambsie, a three year old ram, was being driven along the A47 in the back of a Peugeot 309 when he was spotted by two RSPCA inspectors. "I saw this head poking out of the back window," recalled inspector John Bowe. "Initially I thought it was a dog, but my colleague said 'No, it's a sheep!' and so we did a U-turn - if you'll excuse the pun - and followed the car, which drove into a nearby wood." Having caught up with the vehicle Inspector Bowe informed its driver he was in breach of the Welfare of Animals Transit Order of 1997, which forbids the transporting of farm animals in cars, and should turn round immediately and take his sheep home again, a request with which he complied. The man, who has not been named, insisted he was only taking Lambsie for a walk, and that the red rubber cape was simply to stop his sheep getting wet in the rain. PA News

Bottom defaced
Telford, that jewel in the crown of new-town planning, has been suffering of late at the hands of a mysterious graffiti artist dubbed the Pink Panther. Striking under cover of darkness, the Panther initially limited his activities to the town's outskirts, decorating roundabouts with large pink smiling faces. Now, however, he has struck at the very heart of the town, drawing eyes, nose and a mouth on the buttocks of a statue of its architect, Thomas Telford. The statue stands outside the town's magistrates court, and is, according to a spokesman for Telford and Wrekin Council, one of the town's largest, and indeed only, tourist attractions. "It is unfortunate that this has happened," he admitted . "This is definitely not what people want to see when they come to Telford." Not everyone, however, is quite so negative about the Panther's activities. "To be honest it's the most exciting thing ever to have happened here," opined one local man, "Apart from when that lorry full of condoms jack-knifed on the A4169 back in '87."
Shropshire Star

Lard to believe
A novel defence was put forward at Gloucester Crown Court this week, where a man standing trial for an alleged sex assault argued that his belly was simply too big to have carried out the act of which he was accused. A woman passenger in his car had claimed that 25-stone Reg Daldrey, a fish-and-chip shop owner of Tuffley, Gloucestershire, had taken her hand and pressed it into his groin whilst driving her home. Mr. Daldrey, however, insisted that his rotund figure made such an act impossible since there was no room between the steering wheel and his belly to actually get a hand in. Even with his seat pushed right back his gut was still touching the wheel and, after displaying his belly side-on to the jury from the witness box, he was found not-guilty and awarded costs. "It was huge," commented one man. "Frankly I was amazed he could even get in a car, let alone commit a sex act in one."
Western Daily Press

Peak unease
A pall of fear has settled over the Peak District after the admission by a former lion-tamer that he released a panther and a cougar onto the moors back in the early 1970's. Leslie Maiden, of the West Midlands, claimed that he set the animals loose in 1973 on the A57 Snake Pass. Since the Dangerous Wild Animals Act only came into force in 1976, Mr Maiden's actions broke no laws. His admission has, however, fuelled fears that the area is home to something rather more sinister than blue tits and hedgehogs. "We're certain there are wild cats loose up there," said one RSPCA spokeswoman. "A lot of people kept such animals as pets until it became compulsory for them to have a licence, at which point they released them into the wild." Although the authorities are insisting there is no threat to human life, at least one local man believes there is something truly dangerous living in the vicinity. "It's big, hairy and very, very loud," he said, "And unfortunately I've been married to it for thirty years."
Derbyshire Online

Letter of the week
I am writing to the driver who on the 5th February, at around 2pm, drove down the east end of Chirnside and hit a grey cat. I wish to inform you, since you did not stop to see if the animal required assistance, that the cat, Amy - short for Amiable - died. She was the gentlest, sweetest cat I have ever known, and I shall sorely miss her. You were obviously going too fast to stop. I would like to ask you to consider the danger of driving so fast. This time it was my cat. One day it may be someone's child. I find it difficult to comprehend that someone wouldn't care about causing such injury to an animal. If your ways are common, I fear it is a very sad world. I honestly wish the police would enforce sleeping policemen before someone - perhaps one of your friends, if not yourself - hits a child or a pensioner.
L. Fernie,
Chirnside
Berwickshire News
