webTitle: Mobile phones, DVDs and Satellite broadcasting

fields.headline: Mobile phones, DVDs and Satellite broadcasting
fields.trailText: VODAFONE A FRIEND
fields.body:
VODAFONE A FRIEND

Would it be Amazon? Would it be Microsoft? Would it be Stretford Ron's 24 hour wash-o-rama? The intrigue over Manchester United's new shirt sponsor (honestly) finally came to an end today when the treble winners announced a not inconsiderable £30m four-year deal with Vodafone. Experts suggest that the money should keep the wolf from the door for another few months at least.

United players celebrated the news this afternoon by unconvincingly holding mobiles to their ears for a photo shoot. That's not because they're useless actors you understand, it's just that they're all hands-free nowadays. Peter Kenyon, United's deputy chief-executive (in the Fiver's book, you're either a chief or you're not), was more impressive. "We are delighted to welcome Vodafone as our new principal sponsor," he said. "They will bring us the capability to give our fans around the world news and information about the team anywhere, any time."

The Fiver is disappointed that it won't ever see Roy Keane with Yahoo! on his shirt, but this deal makes sense for United. After all, when the Sun devotes its back page to the possibility of watching goals on your mobile, you know something's got to be up. By allying themselves with the world's biggest telecommunications company (for this week at least), United are perfectly placed to earn a pile of cash that, when the time comes, will make £30m look like pocket money. Which must be amusing for Swindon fans.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

REEDING BETWEEN THE LINES

A referee receiving a reprimand from the Premier League is about as common as finding a copy of 'Nottingham Forest: Season 1998-9' on DVD. The fact that such a measure is about as corrective as a lunchtime detention is neither here nor there. So may the Fiver take this opportunity to congratulate the League on their censure of roaring Mike Reed.

Reed got into trouble for seemingly celebrating Patrik Berger's goal against Leeds at Anfield last Saturday. "We have issued a reprimand and a warning to Mike Reed for his actions on February 5," said Premier League spokesman Mike Lee today after warning Reed to keep his emotions under control in future, young man. "The impartiality of our officials must not be open to question," he concluded.

Roaring Reed himself reckons his impartiality has never been in question, claiming instead that he was merely happy at implementing the advantage rule in the build up to the goal. Like doing your job properly is something to go mental about. "I felt I was right awarding the advantage rule, " Reed moaned to the Evening Standard today, "but instead I've got a rollicking for it. Although I've enjoyed my 15 years refereeing at the top level, I'm glad this is my final season." You're not the only one, mate.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"If it's a grey day, I might play some soft mellow music or if I can't sleep I put on the Whisperers for their great words and wonderful beat" - Les Ferdinand reveals his cultural life to the Guardian.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

PREVIEWS

Our pick of the week. And we've ignored Manchester United's match again!

Actually, no we haven't.

Arsenal v Liverpool

It's the Super Sunday game on Sky. Super, we'll be bound, for Manchester United, who will go 53 points clear when Leeds lose and this ends up a draw. Dennis Bergkamp, Tony Adams and Patrick Vieira are back to make life difficult for Liverpool's stingy defenders (and Jamie Carragher). Gerard Houllier will field the same team he put out for the game against Leeds, with the exception of Mike Reed, who is refereeing elsewhere.

Leeds United v Tottenham Hotspur

Leeds "welcome" back their old manager tomorrow, so this should be fun. Michael Bridges won't be playing, as he damaged his ankle in training, so stroppy young duo Harry Kewell and Alan Smith will be moaning, sneering and whining in the final third of the pitch for Leeds. And to sprinkle some semtex on top of an already volatile TNT-based mix, Willem Korsten looks likely to make his first start in a Tottenham shirt against the club he left in controversial circumstances last summer. Expect post-match interviews where the managers "didn't actually see that incident".

Newcastle United v Manchester United

Alessandro Pistone is in traction, and Nobby Solano is in Peru. Other than that, Newcastle have a full squad to pick from, so the first 11 names Bobby Robson remembers are in. Warring partners Andy Cole and Teddy Sheringham, the Premiership's answer to Itchy and Scratchy, are likely to start up front for United. Hopefully, one of them will misplace a pass intended for the other and they'll both end up rolling around like Oliver Reed and Alan Bates in Women In Love. But with their kit still on, of course.

Sheffield Wednesday v Southampton

Andy Booth, the big lummox, is back in contention for a Wednesday place after a six-week lay-off. He's unlikely to take the place of Gilles De Bilde and Gerald Sibon up front, though, as they fail to find the net in a much more skilful way. Meanwhile, dependable Saints defender Claus Lundekvam is all excited - now his suspension is over, it's his first chance to impress new boss Glenn Hoddle with his amusing routine of stunts and pratfalls. Matthew Le Tissier, surprisingly, is unfit.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Gilles de Bilde has been offered a return to his old club Anderlecht if he chooses to quit relegation-threatened Sheffield Wednesday.

Former Newcastle loan striker Louis Saha could be set for a move to Middlesbrough. Boro boss Bryan Robson is in the market for a striker, and he sees Saha as fitting the bill.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

PSV Eindhoven have told interested Chelsea that £20m-rated striker Ruud van Nistelrooy is "not for sale". However a spokesman for the Dutch club seemed to hint that it was more a matter of price than availability when he went on to say: "Van Nistelrooy has asked PSV to negotiate if a dream club shows interest. We promised to do that. But he is a top scorer, and top scorers are pricey."

Mark Viduka will not be punished by Celtic for refusing to play the second half of his club's shock 3-1 Scottish Cup defeat to Inverness Caledonian Thistle. Kenny Dalglish confirmed that the Australian striker did clash with now departed assistant head coach Eric Black at half-time, but claimed the matter had now been resolved and will be consigned to the past.

Kevin Phillips has been credited with scoring at Watford earlier in the season. The Premier League's superbly-named Dubious Goals Panel decided that the Sunderland striker's effort was not a Robert Page own goal.

Terry Dolan is the new manager of York.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Sky Sports 1: Futbol Mundial (5pm)

A programme which, if it turned up at a 'world football' party, would stop conversations and turn heads.

Sky Sports 2: Friday Night Football - Live (7pm, 12midnight, 4.30am)

Tranmere play Barnsley. Expect the commentary team to go on and bloody on about that bloke who does the long throw-in.

Hold The Back Page (11pm)

They may mention John Barnes.

Radio 5 Live: 5 Live Sport (7pm)

Alan Green is worth a thousand Lionel Bienvenus.

talkSPORT: Friday Night Kickabout (7pm)

Lionel Bienvenu is worth a thousand Kelvin MacKenzies.

webTitle: Face of gardening signs £1m five year book contract with BBC

fields.headline: Face of gardening signs £1m five year book contract with BBC
fields.trailText: Gardening is officially the new cookery, at least as far as television spin-off deals go. Alan Titchmarsh was yesterday catapulted into the Delia Smith league of celebrity publishing when he announced a £1m five-year book contract.
fields.body:
Gardening is officially the new cookery, at least as far as television spin-off deals go. Alan Titchmarsh was yesterday catapulted into the Delia Smith league of celebrity publishing when he announced a £1m five-year book contract.

Titchmarsh, who becomes the most valuable gardening writer in the country through the deal, will write three gardening books to be published from next autumn.

BBC Worldwide, the corporation's commercial arm, which also publishes Smith's best-selling series How to Cook, signed the deal with Titchmarsh after several months of negotiations.

Around 10m people garden every day and half the country now does some gardening once a week. "Broadcasters and authors like Alan help to feed and develop this interest through accessible programming and quality books, and we see no signs of the demand slowing up," said Seamus Geoghegan, director of lifestyle publishing for BBC Worldwide.

Mr Geoghegan said the size of the deal demonstrated the scale of the BBC's commitment to Titchmarsh. "Alan is the face and voice of gardening in Britain and his ability to communicate that knowledge is unparalleled," said Mr Geoghegan.

Titchmarsh, the main presenter of Gardeners' World, has written more than 30 gardening books and two novels.

webTitle: Blind to get TV licence fee halved

fields.headline: Blind to get TV licence fee halved
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: Blind people will be qualify for a half-price licence fee in a concession which will cost the BBC up to £22m a year, Whitehall sources confirmed yesterday.
fields.body:
Blind people will be qualify for a half-price licence fee in a concession which will cost the BBC up to £22m a year, Whitehall sources confirmed yesterday.

The recommendation made by economist Gavyn Davies' panel into the future of the corporation's funding is understood to have been accepted by government and will be announced, along with a rise in BBC income in the next week or so. The move follows the introduction of some licence fee concessions to the elderly, announced in the last budget.

Around 400,000 blind people are estimated to qualify for the proposed reduction in the licence fee - roughly double the current number of registered blind. To date the registered blind have been entitled to a concession of just £1.25 on the £101 fee, which only 30,000 people have taken up, despite research showing that 94% of the 1.7m people with serious sight problems use television.

Government figures show that the cost to the BBC of an expected rise in take up of the concession would be somewhere between £10m and £22m. It is the first confirmed proposal to emerge from the Davies report and a strong indication that the government intends to raise the licence fee when it pronounces on the future funding of the corporation.

Although there is still thought to be dispute between the treasury, Downing Street and the department of culture, media and sport over the method of increasing the BBC's funding, sources suggest that the corporation has won the battle to persuade government that it needs more money for its digital plans.

Chris Smith, the secretary of state for media is thought to believe that on the basis of a report from external efficiency consultants sent into the BBC that its programme plans merit extra funding. But no consensus has yet been achieved on which of the three possible options for increasing its funding should be used.

The BBC's commercial rivals have argued strongly against the digital licence fee, which they term a "digital tax", recommended by the Davies report. The levy, which has been considered at amounts ranging from £5 to over £20, would be paid by digital subscribers on top of the existing licence fee. Other options still being considered are an across the board rise in the fee or a combination of the two.

fields.headline: Most everywhere:  Dial-a-diet
fields.trailText: It was only a matter of time before New Yorkers found a way to marry up their twin food-related obsessions: diets and takeaways.
fields.body:
It was only a matter of time before New Yorkers found a way to marry up their twin food-related obsessions: diets and takeaways.

For those whose will power wilts when confronted by the chocolate bar at the check-out or the slab of cheddar in the fridge, New York's latest craze provides a solution: throw out the contents of your fridge, cross the road to avoid food stores of any description, and have a properly measured out, calorie-controlled diet delivered to your door every day so that you don't even have to think about going to the shops, never mind counting the calories in everything you buy.

Most fashionable at the moment (Winona Ryder is a customer) is the Zone diet delivery, which takes all the effort out of achieving that tricky 40% carbohydrate, 30% protein, 30% fat balance by delivering three meals plus side dishes and snacks to your door each morning, all ready to pop into the microwave.

And for those can't afford the steep Zone fee ($425 for seven days' supply), there are cheaper Dial-a-Diet alternatives springing up all over the city. Just don't expect to find chicken tikka masala in your meals on wheels.

fields.headline: Hell for leather
fields.standfirst: Fur may be running riot (and causing one) at this season's collections - but it's a different type of skin that is really turning heads at the shows, says fashion editor  Laura Craik
fields.trailText: Fur may be running riot (and causing one) at this season's collections - but it's a different type of skin that is really turning heads at the shows, says fashion editor Laura Craik
fields.body:
Enjoy your shoes." Can you imagine any of the surly shop assistants in Britain saying such a thing? They'd get sacked for being cheeky. In New York, faux-politeness is as natural as breathing. In New York, you can't go shopping without being complimented every five minutes: "I love your bag," "cute purse" and "what a beautiful coat" were three offered up to me in Barneys. So convinced did I become of my very perfection that I left without feeling the need to buy anything at all.

Funny, but I've felt the same sentiment during most of the shows. Not much has rocked my casbah. Taking their lead from Milan, no doubt, many New York designers seem to have abandoned the casual sportswear and relaxed dressing they do best in favour of a classic, tailored, ladylike approach peppered with buzzwords such as "elegance" and "femininity". DKNY, whose last three seasons have been superb, was less so this time, with Karan departing from loose, slouchy daywear to cater instead for an uptown girl with a penchant for waxy leather trenchcoats, black pencil skirts and chiffon blouses. There were many good pieces here - a calf-length pleated chiffon skirt with a low leather waistband, and a simple turtleneck jumper - but the show hardly pushed the simple throw-it-all-on-together-without-thinking philosophy for which Karan is most loved.

New York Fashion Week is alone in showing mens and womenswear concurrently: the menswear shows are at the beginning of the week, there are some mixed shows in the middle and the last few days are devoted to womenswear. Front row at Sean "It Wasn't Me" Combs's first menswear show was a selection of rap royalty including Missy Elliot and Lil' Kim - both dripping with fur, as was the catwalk. As you'd expect, Combs's Sean John label is for men who aren't afraid of being mugged on a badly lit sidewalk. They probably travel everywhere by limo. Full-length mink coats, baggy-cut cashmere suits and diamonds were the order of the day.

Fur: will you or won't you? Nearly every designer in New York incorporated it into their collections, and you can bet your veggieburger that Milan and Paris will follow suit. Carolina Herrera went the whole hog (or the whole mink; in fact, several mink must have lost their lives in making her stripy blouson jackets) with a full-length coat described as "Russian golden sable".

Though Oscar de la Renta's show was stormed by anti-fur protesters, he was hardly the worst offender. Mink trims, knitted fox and fluid shearling were as ubiquitous as off-duty yellow cabs. It is utterly bizarre, as a British person, to find yourself waiting for a show to begin while surrounded by fur-clad fasherati. They wear it without apology, heads held high, in every permutation known to man, or at least to David Attenborough. I had trouble identifying some of the more outlandish types myself.

Outlandish, certainly by standards, was the collection by Miguel Androvar, who recycles old fabrics and fashions them into something new and quite wonderful. Logo mania? Try his mac, made from old Burberry fabric and with the label bang in the centre of the chest. Raw edges and unfinished seams featured on a coat of mattress ticking (the mattress apparently once belonged to Quentin Crisp) yet the overall effect was super-sexy. Definitely one to watch.

Hugo Boss's menswear (beige bonded cotton coats, button-up anoraks, chunky polonecks and slimmish trousers) will sell in spades, but the womenswear was hit and miss. Strongest were loose, square-neck muslin dresses with embroidered yokes, in beige, navy or muslin, but Hugo loses points for making even Gisele's body look lumpy in a black velvet evening dress that bunched up round her tummy.

The wilds of Scotland are possibly the last place you'd expect to find the rock fan, sweatshirt king and all-American geezer Tommy Hilfiger. Last season, it was glam rock chic and a live performance by Bush; this season, it was a tumble in the heather in a twinset. "I visited Scotland with my family to explore the history of my ancestors and was overwhelmed by the striking beauty of the land," said Hilfiger, playing up to fashion's current obsession with heritage in a highly bogus way.

Ponyskin, crocodile skin and cashmere were mixed in with lots of tartan: black leather jackets with tartan lining for men and tartan kneelength skirts or chiffon evening dresses for women. All a departure for Hilfiger, but a far from original one. The man who made his money dressing hip-hop kids in clean-cut casual clothes is guilty of trying to cover all bases: combining "Scottish heritage" with an "all-American sensibility" was never a logical idea.

Ralph Lauren's show was Scottish in places, but more subtle and assured. You've got to hand it to Ralph: if you had all the money in the world, it would be pretty dandy to "dress down" for the weekend in his super-luxurious burnished gold leather jeans, Fair Isle cashmere turtleneck and moss-green Donegal tweed jacket. For evening, black velvet was in abundance: sweeping floorlength skirts worn with sequinned shell tops in a red-and-burgandy tapestry effect. Lauren called it Modern Opulence, and indeed it was.

Marc Jacobs took us back to the 60s for his show, which made use of heavy fabrics such as leather, tweed, corduroy and denim. His vision for men was a corduroy car coat with big buttons and a leather trim, chunky polo and tapered denim trousers. For women, it was a herringbone trapeze-line pinafore dress worn with a cashmere jumper underneath, bare legs and low-heeled shoes. Although these were boys and girls, rather than men and women, it's hard to feel anything but girlish in a pinafore dress. This was a very demure collection, full of condiment colours - mustard, brown sauce and ketchup. Eveningwear was a modern reworking of the prom dress: tight bodices, bell-shaped skirts which fell to mid-calf and layers and layers of tulle, cut to look like flower petals, frothing over shoulders.

Anna Sui also stayed with the 60s/early 70s, presenting a bunch of girls dressed to smoke pot all day and sway along to the Rolling Stones. Eveningwear was weak: lurex skirts with silky fringes and mohair embroidered tulle tops looked clumsy, but elsewhere her rich hippy aesthetic triumphed. Long brown suede shearling coats, patchwork jeans and fringed tops were worn with floppy wide-brimmed hats and block-heeled boots. Colours were bright - burned orange, plum and violet.

Head and sexy leather shoulders above everything else this week towered Bottega Veneta - not as catchy a name as Gucci or Fendi, granted, but if there's any justice in the world, this label deserves to be just as huge. This was a superb collection: a super-sensual marriage of tweed, leather and wit in hot pink, toffee brown or car-seat grey. Strapless tweed dresses with wide leather belts, loose nappa trenchcoats and high calf-length boots oozed sexiness, while the leather wear - slashed, woven and patchworked - was unparalleled. It was 80s, but modern rather than retro. It made me drool. It rocked my casbah, my boat and my world. And if I were rich enough, it would rock my wardrobe, too.

 Still to come at the New York shows: Helmut Lang, Donna Karan, Daryl K, John Bartlett, Calvin Klein and Tse.

webTitle: Most wanted:  A table at Pastis

fields.headline: Most wanted:  A table at Pastis
fields.trailText: If you think fashion is fickle you should try keeping up with the New York restaurant scene. Securing a reservation in the 10 days between a restaurant being billed as absolutely the only place to be seen and being declared hopelessly passé and strictly for tourists is almost impossible.
fields.body:
If you think fashion is fickle you should try keeping up with the New York restaurant scene. Securing a reservation in the 10 days between a restaurant being billed as absolutely the only place to be seen and being declared hopelessly passé and strictly for tourists is almost impossible.

So since Pastis, new hotspot in the still-just-about-edgy meat packing district (think London's Shoreditch), has been open long enough for both Vogue and Vanity Fair to have held parties there, I half expected it to have closed down. But while the decor (faux Parisian in the tiled-walls-tarnished-mirrors Dome/Cafe Rouge style) seems to bear little relation to the menu (beans on toast, $7), the beautiful people don't seem to have noticed yet, and are jealously guarding the VIP reservations number. No, it's not this one.

 Pastis, 9 Ninth Ave at Little West 12th; Tel: 001 212 929 4844

fields.headline: The right trousers
fields.standfirst: Katayone Adeli is said to design the sexiest trousers in the world but shuns publicity and can't be bothered with fashion shows.  Jess Cartner-Morley tries them on to see what the fuss is about
fields.trailText: Katayone Adeli is said to design the sexiest trousers in the world but shuns publicity and can't be bothered with fashion shows. Jess Cartner-Morley tries them on to see what the fuss is about
fields.body:
Talk to any woman about clothes, and one subject is almost sure to come up: finding the perfect trousers. While the pomp and pageantry of catwalk fashion hold the gaze of the media, the wardrobe fantasies of real women are more likely to centre around that elusive pair of black trousers. This is what the real business of getting dressed is all about: trousers that fit like a dream, go with everything and can be worn anywhere. Oh, and make your legs look longer and your backside smaller.

Reader, I've found them. Not that I can take the credit, sadly: Gwyneth Paltrow let the world in on the secret when she told American Vogue, "I try to get every pair of pants Katayone Adeli makes." Even before that, Garbage singer Shirley Manson told American Harpers Bazaar that Katayone Adeli "knows how to dress women's arses - more people should learn how she cuts."

If you're thinking "Katayone who ?" you're not alone. The Iranian-born, California-raised designer is still little known in this country; Harvey Nichols is her only British stockist although this is likely to change soon as industry insiders predict 2000 to be a breakthrough year for her label. Katayone Adeli (pronounced kat-eye-own a- del -ee) made her name as designer for the Los Angeles line, Parallel, before moving to New York and launching her own label.

Last year the two-and-a-half year-old label did $20m in sales and won Adeli a new designer nomination for the Perry Ellis award, given by the Council of Fashion Designers of America.

Adeli does not, of course, just design trousers. Her designs runs the gamut of womenswear from jeans to evening dresses, with shoes - in association with Jimmy Choo - to be added from next season. But her trousers are legendary. Yasmin Yusuf, managing director of the British high street group Warehouse and a confirmed Adeli addict, credits the designer as "hugely influential in the whole trend for low, tight trousers" - the boy-cut, straight-leg hipsters that in the past five years have replaced traditional high-waisted, tapered trousers in many women's wardrobes.

In the hip store Scoop in downtown New York, I try a controlled experiment to see what all the fuss is about. They only have one pair of Katayone Adeli "pants" left in my size - and they're turquoise, not generally a sensible colour, bottom-wise. I try them on anyway and they look good. Really good. At first I can't figure out why. Perhaps turquoise is my colour after all.

But no, that's not it. First, there's the low waistband, a simple ploy to make your behind look more petite, as there appears to be less of it. Secondly, the back pockets are placed a little wider than usual - later, at Adeli's own store, it is explained to me that this makes your bottom look narrower.

The legs are cut straight, but taper very slightly around the knee - the thinnest part of the leg - to give a lengthy, svelte look. The fabric is stretchy enough not to look bulky, but sturdy enough to keep a clean line. Had there been any colour other than turquoise, I wouldn't have been able to part with my $128 fast enough.

It is her skill at flattering the female form that inspires devotion among Adeli-wearers. Adeli herself is an attractive, limelight-shy 33-year-old who prefers to let her press officer, Antony Halabi, do most of the talking. She refuses to be photographed, sending out copies of her publicity picture instead. She has a no-nonsense attitude to fashion, disdaining catwalk shows as "high drama for no drama at all".

Suspicious of the media and its constant need for an "angle", she appreciates perfectly that most women are far more interested in clothes that flatter than in wearing this season's perfect shade of purple or the latest hi-tech fabrics. The root of Adeli's body-consciousness lies in her West Coast background. As Adeli puts it, "you wear less clothing in LA", so the emphasis on body shape is greater. Almost imperceptible details are used to make the wearer look leaner, more shapely: a few extra gathers on the top of the shoulder of a jacket where the sleeve starts, combined with a precisely cut underarm and torso, give the impression of broader shoulders and a narrower body. Even the colour palette is chosen to be as flattering to the skin as possible. Knitwear, for instance, is woven from a subtle melange of colours, as a slight mixture makes the complexion, by contrast, look more even.

Although New York has taken Adeli to its heart, the West Coast connection continues, Adeli providing clothes for the forthcoming remake of the Charlie's Angels television series.

"They wanted a look that was timeless, but modern." says Halabi. Timelessness is a recurring theme in Adeli's work. She avoids "deliberate trends", preferring an evolutionary and practical approach to her seasonal collections.

Her designs are clean and easy to wear, but with subtle recurring motifs which add flavour - blanket-stitching on a carpaccio-thin leather jacket, pin-pleats at a trouser waistband. The legendary American fashion editor Polly Mellen describes her as being "about pieces, sportswear and a little touch of femininity".

Disregarding the yo-yo of bi-annual trends is radical enough for a fashion designer, but shunning the celebrity circuit is quite another. Although Adeli is "flattered" that Gwyneth Paltrow likes her designs, giving clothes away to celebrities is "a practice she doesn't believe in. If you like the clothes, you buy them." Adeli believes women should buy clothes that suit them rather than ape celebrities.

The new Katayone Adeli flagship store in New York reflects her dislike of publicity. Bond Street in the East Village is a world apart from its London namesake: edgy and painfully hip, with a builders' merchant next door to a photographic supply centre, a hardware store beside a cult perfumery.

The Adeli shop is spacious and white in art-gallery style, with a white plaster wall to prevent clothes being seen from the street. "We wanted it to be private," says Halabi. "Our customer knows we are here."

Word of mouth has already netted Katayone Adeli a robustly healthy customer base. It doesn't take a marketing expert to know that being able to cut clothes that make women look thinner is, to put it bluntly, a licence to print money. Expansion is on the cards; she thinks "it would be fun" to design menswear.

OK, Katayone. But please, keep making those trousers.

Bond Street in the East Village is a world apart from its London namesake: edgy and painfully hip, with a builders' merchant next door to a photographic supply centre, a hardware store beside a cult perfumery. The Adeli shop is spacious and white in art-gallery style, with a white plaster wall to prevent clothes being seen from the street. "We wanted it to be private," says Halabi. "Our customer knows we are here." Word of mouth has already netted Katayone Adeli a robustly healthy customer base. It doesn't take a marketing expert to know that being able to cut clothes that make women look thinner is, to put it bluntly, a licence to print money. Expansion is on the cards; she thinks "it would be fun" to design menswear. OK, Katayone. But please, keep making those trousers.

webTitle: She goes to the parties so you don't have to

fields.headline: She goes to the parties so you don't have to
fields.trailText: After a hard day spent staring at Gisele, Audrey, Maggie, Erin and Guinevere, what does the fash pack do to relax? Why, what could be more refreshing than a trip to a gallery to sip champagne alongside the aforementioned ladies of the catwalk and gaze at photographs of, you guessed it, the very same. Fashion's favourite, Marc Jacobs, clearly fancies himself as New York's answer to Donatella Versace, hosting not one but two aftershow parties in SoHo on Monday night.
fields.body:
After a hard day spent staring at Gisele, Audrey, Maggie, Erin and Guinevere, what does the fash pack do to relax? Why, what could be more refreshing than a trip to a gallery to sip champagne alongside the aforementioned ladies of the catwalk and gaze at photographs of, you guessed it, the very same. Fashion's favourite, Marc Jacobs, clearly fancies himself as New York's answer to Donatella Versace, hosting not one but two aftershow parties in SoHo on Monday night.

First up was an exhibition of drawings by film director Tim Burton and portraits by Pierre Bailly, who had photographed models sporting lank hair and grubby T-shirts (except Gisele, who wore a boobkerchief instead) - a nod, perhaps, to Jacobs' long-forgotten grunge roots.

Five doors down Mercer Street (not that this stopped Maggie Rizer driving there in her chauffeured limo) was the after-after-show party at the cavernous Canteen restaurant, where mini bacon butties were served with champagne. Grunge chic again, I suppose.

Visionaire magazine, on the other hand, embraced fashion's fur-lined New Affluence with gusto, throwing an unashamedly glitzy bash in the Rockefeller Plaza's 65th floor Rainbow Room. Of course, the most experienced partygoers (hello, Chloe Sevigny) were too jaded to be buoyed up by the panoramic views, revolving dancefloor and models in leather knickers gyrating on podiums.

But on a Tuesday night in the middle of model-worshipping fashion week, almost everyone raised a smile at the evidence that the most beautiful supermodels (hello, Audrey Marney) have the most hideous boyfriends.

Lachlan and Sarah Murdoch's party for the city's Page Six gossip column the next night at Gustovino, Sir Terence Conran's New York venture, boasted a six-deep limousine queue and a guest list which was star-studded enough to put the Planetarium to shame. (Here's a representative extract: Coombs, Mr Sean Puffy; Crawford, Mrs Cindy; Deng, Mrs Wendy.)

Never afraid to suffer for her art, however, the Insider forsook those delicious baby Moëts to show solidarity with the leftfield designers Bruce, whose exhibition/party/happening/whatever you like to call it was held in the slightly less paparazzi-friendly environs of a university rotunda, boasted not one but two - count 'em - bottles of medium-dry white wine.

webTitle: Fuel gauge: Shell profits back on track

fields.headline: Fuel gauge: Shell profits back on track
fields.trailText: Shell, the oil dinosaur turned darling among investors, yesterday reported record fourth-quarter profits of $2.23bn (£1.4bn) - a 173% rise on last year.
fields.body:
Shell, the oil dinosaur turned darling among investors, yesterday reported record fourth-quarter profits of $2.23bn (£1.4bn) - a 173% rise on last year.

The surge in earnings, driven by higher crude oil prices and an extensive restructuring programme, helped boost 1999 net earnings to $7.09bn, up 38%, and the return on capital to 12.1% from 2.8%.

With Opec, the oil producers' club, under strong pressure from the west - which is worried about the inflationary impact of prices at around $25 a barrel compared with $10 a year ago - to lift its year-old production curbs when ministers next meet in March, Shell said prospects were unpredictable.

But Mark Moody-Stuart, chairman of the Royal Dutch/Shell group, said increasing demand and low inventories should ensure that prices remained above the historic $15 to $20 a barrel range for the next few months.

Shell has overtaken BP Amoco among investors' affections recently as its British-based rival gets snarled up in a battle with US regulators over its takeover of Atlantic Richfield, and its shares rose 33p in London to close at 450p. BP closed up 21p at 487p.

Market sentiment has moved Shell's way because of evidence that the cost-cutting programme is working and Mr Moody-Stuart said the improvements had come well ahead of plan.

The savings were $2bn for the year and well on the way towards the new $4bn annual target from 2001.

The group, which declared a 3.7% increase in the annual dividend for Shell to 14p, is also able to proceed with its plans for a substantial share buyback now Dutch legal hurdles have been lifted.

fields.headline: Electronic surveillance: the new legislation
fields.standfirst: The home secretary has introduced measures in the <A HREF="http://www.publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm199900/cmbills/ 064/2000064.htm/" TARGET="_NEW">regulation of investigatory services bill that would give intelligence services and other government agencies statutory powers to intercept a wide range of electronic communications. Mark Tran explains
fields.trailText:
What does the bill allow the government to do?

For the first time intelligence services and other agencies would have the statutory power to intercept pagers, mobile and satellite phones, and email, as well as private networks, including office switchboards. Individuals or organisations may also be required to provide the key or the plain text of encoded internet communications if there were "reasonable grounds" to believe these were related to criminal acts.

What does the bill allow the government to do?

For the first time intelligence services and other agencies would have the statutory power to intercept pagers, mobile and satellite phones, and email, as well as private networks, including office switchboards. Individuals or organisations may also be required to provide the key or the plain text of encoded internet communications if there were "reasonable grounds" to believe these were related to criminal acts.

What is the justification for the bill?

Besides bringing regulations into compliance with the <A HREF="http://www.publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm199900/cmbills/ 064/2000064.htm /" TARGET="_NEW">European convention on human rights, the government says the bill will allow the police and other agencies to keep up with sophisticated technology used by criminal gangs. Paedophile networks, for example, were using encryption to protect material on computers. The home office said phone tapping enabled customs officers to seize 1.25 tonnes of class A drugs during a recent 12-month period.

Who will authorise warrants for surveillance?

While the bill says that warrants for intercepting communications would still be signed by cabinet ministers, authorisation for other forms of surveillance would be given by senior police officers or even local authority officials. The bill sets up the post of covert investigations commissioner to monitor the issuing of warrants and a complaints tribunal.

What do civil liberties groups say?
<A HREF="http://www.liberty-human-rights.org.uk/" TARGET="_NEW">Liberty, the civil rights group, says the European court of human rights has always emphasised the importance of prior judicial sanction for warrants rather than the authorisation by a politician or police officer. In their current form, powers to recover encryption keys risk reversing the burden of proof, it says, but overall it welcomes efforts to introduce a consistent regulatory framework. Other groups are more critical. Caspar Bowden, from the <A HREF="http://www.fipr.org/ecommpr.html/" TARGET="_NEW"> foundation for information policy research, said the law as drafted was "impossible" and accused the government of ignoring all the advice and lobbying it had received from the net community over the past year.

What is the situation in the US?
The US equivalent to the British bill is the <A HREF="http://www.usdoj.gov/opa/pr/1999/September/408jmd.htm/" TARGET="_NEW"> communications assistance for law enforcement act, which regulates electronic surveillance. The FBI has been pressing for more surveillance powers which civil rights group say exceed the 1994 law. Last year, the <A HREF="http://www.fcc.gov/" TARGET="_NEW"> federal communications commission granted further surveillance capabilities requested by the FBI. The extra power will allow police and other authorities armed with a court order to obtain a mobile phone user's location at the beginning and end of a call. The FBI will also be able to listen to conversations between all parties to a conference call on mobile and landline phones, even if some are no longer talking to the target of the court-authorised wiretap.

webTitle: Tokyo snub to UK over nuclear fuel

fields.headline: Tokyo snub to UK over nuclear fuel
fields.trailText: Britain has been dealt a humiliating blow by the Japanese government, which is insisting that a consignment of suspect nuclear fuel is returned to Sellafield.
fields.body:
Britain has been dealt a humiliating blow by the Japanese government, which is insisting that a consignment of suspect nuclear fuel is returned to Sellafield.

Tokyo's decision is a blow for British trade representatives, who have spent the past week apologising on behalf of British Nuclear Fuels.

The firm drew the anger of Japan at the end of last year, when it admitted that its workers had fabricated safety data for a shipment of mixed-oxide fuel to be used in Japanese reactors.

The brusque reply to British pleas for a second chance may also be a killer blow for a £300m reprocessing plant that BNFL has built, but is still waiting for permission to open.

The government delegation, headed by Anna Walker, director general in charge of energy at the trade and industry department, expressed "deep regret" at the falsification.

But Tokyo's reply, issued late last night, said: "The UK side is responsible for what happened to the fuel. We have requested that Britain send the fuel back to the UK."

webTitle: Pre-dawn explosion shatters windows at Wall Street bank; no injuries

fields.headline: Pre-dawn explosion shatters windows at Wall Street bank; no injuries
fields.standfirst:
CNNfn video excerpt
New York Stock Exchange
fields.trailText: NEW YORK - An explosive device went off in front of Barclay's Bank on Wall  Street early today, shattering windows but causing no injuries, police said.
fields.body:
NEW YORK - An explosive device went off in front of Barclay's Bank on Wall Street early today, shattering windows but causing no injuries, police said.

The NYPD bomb squad was trying to determine the type of device that exploded at 4.40am EST (9.40 GMT) police Sergeant Elias Nikas said. The bomb exploded at the corner of Wall Street and Water Street in lower Manhattan, close to the New York Stock exchange in front of a building owned by Barclays bank.

Police also were looking for a man wearing a construction jacket and carrying a yellow toolbox seen near the bank shortly before the explosion, Nikas said.

The man is described as five feet ten inches tall, weighing about 240 pounds, with a moustache, the spokesman said. No-one has claimed responsibility for the blast, which took place near the corner of Wall and Water Streets, he said.

Although the incident caused no serious injuries, one witness was taken to hospital and treated for ringing of the inner ear.

A witness interviewed on CNBC described the explosion as "tremendous." "It sounded almost like a transformer going out ... my body was rumbled," the man told CNBC. Wall Street trading will begin at the normal time, a stock exchange spokesman said.

fields.headline: Relationships
fields.standfirst: ...to save you the burden of reading them
fields.trailText: ...to save you the burden of reading them
fields.body:
Are You the One For Me?, by Barbara De Angelis (Thorsons, £7.99)

Buy it at BOL

Falling in love, you know, can be "a magical and powerful experience" because "each kiss, each conversation in the beginning seems so right, so perfect". But, alas, love alone is not enough to sustain a fulfilling relationship. If you want to find and keep your soulmate, work on your "Love IQ" and ditch the "Love Myths" that trip us up every time.

Cupid says: "I wish you love and peace on your journey."

Dating Secrets of the Ten Commandments, by Shmuley Boteach (Hodder & Stoughton, £6.99)

Buy it at BOL

Jewish mystics believe that we are each one half of a soul that was separated in heaven and that our mission on earth is to find our better (or worse) half, thus achieving perfect wholeness. If that does not win you over, then read the Ten Commandments and remember that "a soul-mate is not someone who is perfect, but someone who is perfect for you".

Cupid says: "You are unique, just like everyone else."

The Relate Guide to Starting Again, by Sarah Litvinoff (Vermillion, £9.99)

Buy it at BOL

Face facts: although "no one falls in love thinking that the relationship will end", how many people can honestly say that "their first love is their last"? Not very many, probably. If it all goes wrong, try not to "dwell on the faults of your ex-partner", however strong the temptation. Instead, try to find out why, think positive, and give it a go with someone new.

Cupid says: "As each of you grows, you have more to offer each other."

Emotional Blackmail, by Dr Susan Forward with Donna Frazer (Bantam Books, £5.99)

Buy it at BOL

Beware of "skilful manipulators" - expert emotional extortionists who take on many forms, whether parents, partners, bosses friends or lovers (pretty much anyone you can think of, in fact). And know how to tell a "punisher" from a "self-punisher" and a "sufferer" from a "tantalizer". Never let FOG (fear, obligation, and guilt) cloud your judgment.

Cupid says: "Blackmail takes two. It's a duet, not a solo performance."

Mars & Venus - A Match Made in Heaven?, by John Gray (Newleaf, £6.99)

Men are Martian hunter-gatherers who like sitting in caves and watching TV. Women, on the other hand, are Venusians who like shopping for Martian cavemen. Intergalactic peace can only be achieved by "learning the art of loving an alien". So come on: Martians, leave your caves, and Venusians, though you now wear Martian suits, do not be tempted to build your own caves.

Cupid says: "World peace begins with you."

webTitle: Marrying the Mistress by Joanna Trollope

fields.headline: Marrying the Mistress by Joanna Trollope
fields.standfirst:
(Bloomsbury, £14.99) digested in the style of the original
Buy it at BOL
fields.trailText: Merrion's father died when she was young. Perhaps she was subconsciously looking for a father figure when she met Guy on a train while giggling over a rude word in her book. Guy left his wife. And then left Merrion.
fields.body:
Merrion Palmer had a dull childhood in Wales. She remembered her mother, Gwen, taking away a monster bar of Toblerone chocolate once, but nothing else bad happened. Except her father dying. And her grandmother. But she left them some money, so that was OK.

As Merrion grew up, she was a little wild. She grew her hair and had a butterfly tattooed on her ankle. One day she didn't come home until six in the morning and had a violent row with her mother. As she was going through a wild phase, Merrion ran away to Bristol but went home of her own accord six days later. Merrion decided to study law and went to live in London.

One day after visiting her mother, Merrion found an old book of her father's. She read it on the train home. It was called Esprit de Corps and was by Lawrence Durrell. She collapsed with laughter when she read the story of the faulty typesetting machines in Cairo that omitted all the "c"s from "canal zone" during the Suez crisis. Despite the laughter, she still noticed Guy when he got on the train.

Guy was a gentleman. He wouldn't let her eat free peanuts in bars. "Whose fingers have been in there before yours?" he said. Guy was married. With children. And grandchildren who called him "Grando". "And he's a judge," she told her mother. "I'm in love."

Guy left his wife to live with Merrion. She met Guy's son, Alan. She met Alan's wife, Carrie, in a wine bar by Victoria station. The time had been vague, so it didn't matter that she just missed a train. Carrie had a dull childhood in East Anglia. Nothing bad happened. Except her mother dying. That was hard as Carrie had loved her.

Merrion's mother, Gwen, came to London on a train. She brought her own sandwiches with her. She thought Guy was very goodlooking. "You're ruining my daughter's life," she told him. Gwen went home. She tried to keep herself busy and even took computer lessons. "Why's it called a mouse?" she asked. "Why's it called an icon?"

Guy phoned Gwen. "I'm coming to Cardiff," he said. Over tea in the Angel Hotel he told Gwen that he was not going to marry Merrion. And back in London he told his family that he was taking a job in the north, away from his wife and away from Merrion. "I'll recover," said Guy, "and Merrion will probably go on to be a very successful family law barrister and, hopefully, marry and have children, too."

And if you really are pressed: The digested read, digested:

fields.headline: United announce £30m Vodafone sponsorship
fields.trailText: After months of speculation Manchester United have announced their new sponsors. They have agreed a record-breaking £30million sponsorship deal with Vodafone.
fields.body:
After months of speculation Manchester United have announced their new sponsors. They have agreed a record-breaking £30million sponsorship deal with Vodafone.

The four-year deal, which begins in June, will see the logo of the mobile phone company, who recently completed the biggest takeover deal in history when they purchased German telecommunications firm Mannesmann, replace that of long-term sponsors Sharp on all United shirts.

United have been courted by some of the biggest companies in the world in an attempt to secure a space not much larger than a family-sized bar of Dairy Milk. Blue-chip companies such as British Airways, Emirates and Internet firms Yahoo! and Amazon.com have all been linked with the Treble winners.

webTitle: MPs' third gay sex vote ensures law change

fields.headline: MPs' third gay sex vote ensures law change
fields.standfirst:
Ministers can overrule Lords to force measure through

Life in parliament: special report
fields.trailText: MPs last night voted overwhelmingly for the gay age of consent to be lowered to 16, paving the way for an historic change in the law by Easter this year.
fields.body:
MPs last night voted overwhelmingly for the gay age of consent to be lowered to 16, paving the way for an historic change in the law by Easter this year.

In the third Commons free vote on the issue in this parliament, 263 MPs approved the change against 102, a majority of 161. Supporters included most Labour and Liberal Democrat MPs and a handful of Conservatives, including the new shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, who last year revealed he had had homosexual experiences as a young man.

The reform ends the situation in which heterosexuals and lesbians can consent to sex at 16 but gay men must be 18.

It was about creating a society "free from prejudice", the home secretary, Jack Straw, said last night. Peter Tatchell of the gay campaign group OutRage! hailed the vote as the "last lap" in a 30-year fight for equality.

The vote on the second reading of the sexual offences (amendment) bill, which followed a passionate debate in which MPs were split mainly along party lines, was similar to Commons verdicts after two earlier government attempts to change the law.

In both those cases the measure was thrown out by the House of Lords. Though the upper house - even with the absence of hereditary peers - may refuse again to accept the reform, the government can now invoke the parliament acts to force the measure through with no need for another debate in the Commons.

The bill introduces a new offence of abuse of trust: a person aged over 18 in a position of authority, such as a teacher, can be prosecuted for having sex with a youngster in their care.

The legislation also decriminalises a younger person in male homosexual acts or buggery if one party is under and the other over the age of consent.

Introducing the debate, Mr Straw said: "For me, the issue raised in this bill is one of equality, of seeking to create a society which is free from prejudice, of one where our relationships with others, including with strangers, are based upon respect and not upon fear."

The shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, called the bill a "dangerous move," sending the wrong signals to teachers, parents and young people. "I don't believe the issue of equality should override the imperative to protect young people," she said.

Ann Keen (Labour, Brentford and Isleworth), whose 1998 attempt to equalise the age of consent was defeated in the Lords, said the Tory attitude seemed to be "intolerance, prejudice and discrimination".

It was offensive to suggest that those who voted for the age of consent to be equalised were not concerned with abuse of children. "The key word is consent and that has always been the case as far as I am concerned."

The Liberal Democrat home affairs spokesman, Simon Hughes, said his party had campaigned for a lower age of consent since it was formed in 1988. "You cannot say to gay people that you value them as equals if the law does not treat them as equals.

"If in 2000 we cannot move forward, my friends, we are in big trouble indeed."

The Tory rightwinger John Bercow, education and employment spokesman, previously opposed to lowering the age, this time backed the move, arguing that the status quo did not benefit anybody but was a "recipe for confusion, for misery and for fear".

webTitle: Commons approves bill to lower gay age of consent

fields.headline: Commons approves bill to lower gay age of consent
fields.trailText: Britain's lower house of parliament approved a bill on Thursday reducing the age of consent for gay sex by two years to 16, throwing down a challenge to the upper house which rejected the legislation last year.
fields.body:
Britain's lower house of parliament approved a bill on Thursday reducing the age of consent for gay sex by two years to 16, throwing down a challenge to the upper house which rejected the legislation last year.

Members of parliament in the House of Commons backed the reform by 263 to 102 in a free vote which allowed them to decide according to their own conscience rather than along party lines.

It was the second time in just over a year that MPs had overwhelmingly backed the change. Last year their first attempt was frustrated when members of the upper chamber, the House of Lords, voted the bill down.

Prime Minister Tony Blair's Labour government says the law must be changed to comply with European rights obligations, and threatened to railroad the legislation through parliament if the peers try to block it once again.

Already this month the House of Lords, even keener to pick a fight with Blair since he removed more than 90 percent of its hereditary peers last year, has voted down a law which would repeal a ban on school teachers promoting homosexuality.

"The issue raised in this bill is one of equality, of seeking to create a society which is free from prejudice, where our relationships with others... are based upon respect not fear," said Home Secretary Jack Straw, introducing the Sexual Offences (Amendment) Bill.

Opposition Conservative Party spokeswoman Ann Widdecombe, who opposed the bill, said it was fuelled by a mistaken sense of political correctness.

"I do not believe that issues of equality should override the imperatives of protecting the young," Widdecombe, a matronly and proudly traditionalist figure on the Conservative benches, told parliament.

She said the government's intention to lift the ban on school teachers promoting homosexuality meant lowering the age of consent for gay sex was even more misguided.

"A 16-year-old will not only be able to engage in homosexual acts, but local authorities will be able to spend public money to promote such acts," Widdecombe said.

The bill would also bring in new measures to protect young people of both sexes under 18 from abuse of trust by teachers and care workers. The measures were included after a series of scandals involving paedophiles in schools and children's homes.

Straw said the steps would protect young people in detention, in homes or under medical care, or in full time education.

"This bill is long overdue for the statute book... We need to move now to ensure equality and justice and better protection for our children and young people throughout the United Kingdom," Straw said.

fields.headline: Lastminute founders eye float rewards
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: E-commerce retailer Lastminute.com yesterday unveiled plans for its much anticipated flotation next month that might value the company at as much as £400m.
fields.body:
E-commerce retailer Lastminute.com yesterday unveiled plans for its much anticipated flotation next month that might value the company at as much as £400m.

Lastminute.com, launched in October 1998, intends to list up to 25% of the company, worth about £100m, with a large chunk of the shares going to retail investors.

It will be listed on the London stock exchange and Nasdaq in early March with a pricing range for the float possibly out early next week.

"The retail offering is an important part of what they are about with their business-to-consumer model. It's going to be the biggest retail offering for an internet company so far," one source said.

The float will make instant millionaires of co-founders Brent Hoberman and Martha Lane Fox, who together own about 21% of Lastminute.com. The Oxford graduates met in 1994 while working at a management consultancy firm and set up the site with initial backing of £600,000.

"We really wouldn't have believed, if asked 18 months ago, that we would be a global e-commerce business with 800,000 registered users and the second most recognised e-commerce retail brand in the UK," said MsLane Fox who turned 27 yesterday. Amazon.co.uk is the most recognised brand.

"It was Brent's idea and I actually told him it was not a very good one when I heard it," Ms Lane Fox admitted.

She said her focus had not been on making money but on building Lastminute into a "fantastic company".

"Setting up Lastminute.com has been the most difficult and terrifying period of my life," she said.

The company's 200 staff hold options which would equate to about 12% of the company's stock. The largest shareholder after the founders is venture capital firm Arts Alliance Advisers which holds 19.4%. Bankrupt concert promoter Harvey Goldsmith is also an investor.

Lastminute.com claims to provide customers with the last-minute offering across a range of products including flights, hotel rooms, package holidays and gifts.

Ms Lane Fox expects that Germany, where the business set up a presence in October last year, will soon match Britain, its biggest market, for turnover.

Lastminute.com is also operating in France,and Sweden, with the United States, Asian and Australian markets areas into which they are keen to expand.

Mr Hoberman, 31, said: "The proceeds of the flotation will enable us to expand in the UK and internationally, and to increase our online and offline sales and market initiatives."

The funds raised from the float have also been earmarked to invest in updating the company's technology so that its site can deal with the anticipated large increase in registered users.

Lastminute.com only began a solid marketing campaign in the past few months, having relied heavily on word of mouth.

The company claims it handled transactions worth £2.6m in September last year but compound monthly growth of 30% saw this rise to nearly £6m by December.

Lastminute.com receives only the commission from those transactions, so its net revenue as at September was £195,000.

The potential fortune expected to be reaped by the Lastminute.com founders comes in the wake of Wednesday's announcement that three entrepreneurs would be worth £55m from selling their internet software company.

Cambridge graduate Rob Lewis, who together with Mark Knight and Philip Sant, set up Cromwell Media four years ago, are selling the group to the computer equipment distributor InterX for £226m.

fields.headline: GMC strike off Shipman
fields.trailText:
Harold Shipman, Britain's most prolific serial killer, today
was struck off the medical register with immediate effect after
being found guilty of serious professional misconduct by the
general medical council.
fields.body:
Harold Shipman, Britain's most prolific serial killer, today was struck off the medical register with immediate effect after being found guilty of serious professional misconduct by the general medical council.

The action came after the GMC's professional conduct committee held a full disciplinary hearing into the case of the general practitioner who has been dubbed Dr Death. Jailed for life last month for killed 15 elderly women, Shipman could face further charges as police believe he may be behind another 175 deaths.

"We have been urgently working to bring forward the hearing," the GMC said in a statement. Under English law the GMC must give a doctor six weeks notice of a public hearing but Shipman's lawyers waived the notice period.

The British medical establishment came under fire after the general practitioner from Hyde, near Manchester, was sentenced. Angry relatives of the dead have demanded to know why the GMC did not take action against Shipman earlier. He was a known drug addict and had been convicted in 1976 of forging prescriptions for his own use for the pain killer pethadine.

Despite the conviction he was allowed to continue to practice medicine and ran his own one-man clinic with more than 3,000 registered patients. He was a popular doctor and even received flowers from patients after his arrest. The government announced an official inquiry earlier this month to find out why Shipman was able to kill for so long without being detected. The GP injected his victims with lethal doses of morphine.

The Shipman case has rocked the medical profession and the GMC has introduced wide reforms to regain public confidence. Among some of the measures to be introduced will be a dramatic increase in the proportion of lay members of the GMC's disciplinary committee from less than a third now to 50%. Two reviews of the way the council operates were also announced.

Shipman first came to the attention of the GMC in 1976, after he had been convicted of falsifying prescriptions to obtain morphine for his own drug habit. Following advice from psychiatrists, the GMC let him off with a warning letter. In 1998 officials were told that Shipman was being investigated for murder and then that he had been charged.

The GMC's lawyers advised the council that its regulations would not allow it to suspend Shipman from the medical register while a criminal investigation was under way. Shipman was moved on Monday to the top-security Franklands prison in Co Durham after prison governors learned that the mother of two warders at Manchester prison may have been one of his victims.

fields.headline: Today's other news
fields.trailText: Mel Gibson's fat pay packet, Hollywood's raw animal talent, Chris Klein negotiates star role in Rollerball remake, and Timothy Spall joins Jennifer Aniston in Metal God
fields.body:
 Mel Gibson is the best-paid star in Hollywood. According to the Hollywood Reporter, the Australian star will be paid a massive £15m for his next movie, The Patriot. The figure beats Arnold Schwarzenegger's previous £13m record for End of Days and is a considerable increase on Gibson's film debut in 1976: for his role in Summer City, Gibson was paid the lowly sum of £12. 50.

 There is a lot of raw animal talent in Hollywood - literally. A few weeks ago a spokeswoman for Disney said that the company had found "exceptional live dog talent" for the forthcoming 102 Dalmations, and now director Frank Darabont is waxing lyrical about the star of his film, The Green Mile. No, not Oscar-tippedTom Hanks, but a mouse. Yet it wasn't easy casting exactly the right rodent for the adaptation of Stephen King's best-selling novel.

Darabont held a number of auditions to cast the mouse that becomes a vehicle for the magical powers of a prisoner on Death Row: "we had about two dozen mice and we probably used a core group of a half a dozen of the most talented ones. We brought them onto the set and if they got bored or distracted you'd just replace them." But the mice delivered the goods. Darabont reveals that there were hardly any graphics used for the mice scenes - it was all real. He says, "In the film there's a grand total of five seconds worth, but everything you see, 99.99 per cent of it, is for real. When he's charging up the mile it looks like a little wind-up toy - that's a real mouse."

 Madonna has pulled out of her next film, Quadrille, which was due to start filming in April, citing scheduling problems. The producers, one of whom is a friend of Guy Richie, Madonna's boyfriend, now have no leads in the picture.

 Jude Law, Haley Joel Osment, Clint Eastwood, Ashley Judd, Jane Fonda and James Coburn will all present awards at next month's Oscars.

 Chris Klein is in the final stages of negotiation to star in a remake of ultra-violent sci-fi classic Rollerball. The star of American Pie will reprise James Caan's role, Jonathan E., a member of a modern day gladiator team who fights to the death on motorbikes and rollerblades for its corporate sponsors. Directed by John McTiernan, filming is set to begin this summer.

 Timothy Spall has been signed up by director Stephen Herek for his next film Metal God. The star of Topsy-Turvy will join Jennifer Aniston and Mark Wahlberg in a film based on the true story of a Judas Priest cover band who get the chance to perform with their heroes. Shooting begins next month in Los Angeles.

webTitle: Opec meeting has markets over a barrel

fields.headline: Opec meeting has markets over a barrel
fields.standfirst: EU has reason to be nervous
fields.trailText: Next month the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries meets in full array. In recent years the annual gathering has been regarded as a sideshow by the world's economic movers and shakers. The days of oil price shocks were over, weren't they? This year it will be different. A year ago, with the oil price on the floor at $10 a barrel, Opec agreed production cuts. Nothing new there. Opec production cuts are akin to new year's resolutions and usually last about as long.

Opec production cuts are akin to new year's resolutions and usually last about as long.

But Opec has kept its discipline over the past 12 months. As a result the oil price has recovered to around $27 a barrel. Little wonder then that the European Commission suggested yesterday that the forthcoming Opec meeting would be "extremely important".

To date the global economy has shrugged off the impact of rising oil prices. Growth in the US appears robust and there are signs of recovery in Europe and parts of Asia. Although inflation is nudging up, it remains relatively subdued and the oil price effect should work its way through the data over the next few months.

But theory is one thing, reality another. The EU might be confident that the economic impact of dearer oil is not what it was 25 years ago. Yet policy-makers and markets are nervous. US and European rates are on the rise. The UK chipped in with its latest contribution yesterday. Though the Japanese Nikkei reached 20,000 this week the 250-point fall on Wall Street on Wednesday night is a better illustration of the prevailing mood.

In a sense markets are not inured to crises but they are becoming more used to them, almost to expect them. As a recent paper from the Bank for International Settlements noted somewhat understatedly: "Both the frequency and severity of international financial crises seem to have been rising over the past 20 years or so." In 1997 it was south-east Asia that set off global market turbulence. The year after it was Russia's turn. Last year was crisis-free, although pessimists had fun with the millennium bug.

Hence the EU's appeal to Opec to consider global growth in next month's deliberations. The oil producers are aware that if they overdo the curbs they will hurt themselves as well as the rest of the world. An output level which keeps oil at around, say, $20 to $22 a barrel would probably be sustainable for both producers and consumers. But setting the oil price is far from an exact science. As World Oil Trends 2000 pointed out earlier this week: "Any small supply deficits or surpluses can dramatically affect oil commodity prices, as swings over the past two years have shown."

Getting it right without spooking markets already half inclined to look for crises will be a testing task.

Conspiracy talk

As expected, the Bank of England's monetary policy committee raised interest rates yesterday but already City analysts are pencilling in another rise. The only question appears to be when.

The MPC has shown itself more than willing to move interest rates in quick succession, to seek an incremental approach rather than shock therapy.

But will it go next month or the month after or wait even longer? The calculation is complicated by the budget, which is due to be revealed on March 21.

The relationship between the committee and the Treasury has been under scrutiny from the moment Gordon Brown gave the Bank of England control of monetary policy.

The usual focus of the debate has been the extent to which Mr Brown would seek to influence the MPC's decisions and it is true that he has dropped the occasional hint.

The area of real importance, however, is the relationship between fiscal policy and monetary policy. The problem for the MPC is that if it raises rates next month it might be accused of trying to preempt Mr Brown but if it goes a month later - after the budget - it could be seen as delivering a judgment on the chancellor's handling of his half of economic management. Conspiracy theorists will find grist for their mill either way, so the committee should simply call rates as it sees them.

Hollow protests

Philip Green's decision not to bid for Marks & Spencer is no great surprise. There is a big difference between taking over Sears and mounting a hostile bid for M&S, even at the current share price. Mr Green's protestations of shock at M&S tactics ring a trifle hollow. He must have known what could happen when he let it be known he was considering a bid. The interesting fact for M&S is that Mr Green's intervention did not flush out a rival. Though bid speculation is likely to continue to swirl around the retailer, new chairman Luc Vandervelde might get longer than some expected to get M&S back in the City's good books.

fields.headline: Restoration of Exorcist directors cut
fields.trailText: Warner Bros has finally decided to re-release The Exorcist in the States with 11 minutes of additional footage that was cut from the original film
fields.body:
Warner Bros has finally decided to re-release The Exorcist in the States with 11 minutes of additional footage that was cut from the original film when it was released in 1973.

The studio described the additional footage as "legendary'' and quoted the author of the novel, William Peter Blatty, as saying "the new footage represent(s) a restoration of (director) Bill Friedkin's original cut that he showed me, which at the time I declared a masterpiece ... It makes it more spiritual.''

 The film will shown on a very limited release from March 17 but is likely to get an international release if response is favourable.

fields.headline: Boyle goes baggy
fields.trailText: Danny Boyle's next project will be a film about the Manchester music scene of the late 80s and early 90s
fields.body:
Danny Boyle's next project will be a film about the Manchester music scene of the late 80s and early 90s.

According to Dark Horizons, the director, whose controversial film The Beach received its London premiere on Wednesday night, is seriously considering making a film revolving around the Stone Roses, the Happy Mondays and the other bands that made up the baggy Madchester music scene of over a decade ago.

The director's love of the Manchester groups was revealed when he persuaded New Order to come out of retirement and appear on the soundtrack to The Beach. The Dark Horizons' source also claims that Boyle is considering making a film about Joy Division, the band that imploded into New Order in the late 70s after the suicide of its lead singer, Ian Curtis.

fields.headline: Health fears grow for Spielberg
fields.trailText: Steven Spielberg may have to have a kidney transplant
fields.body:
Steven Spielberg may have to have a kidney transplant. Doctors who removed one of his kidneys last Saturday, now suspect that he may have cysts on his other kidney and on his liver and are performing a series of tests on the director.

Friends are "very worried" about him and one says, "He's such a good guy we just pray that everything is going to be okay." Doctors at Cedars-Sinai hospital in Los Angeles have said, through a hospital spokesman, that: "a complete recovery is promised".

webTitle: ICC decision offers hope to Shoaib

fields.headline: ICC decision offers hope to Shoaib
fields.trailText: Shoaib Akhtar is likely to resume his Test-playing career sooner than expected after the ICC relinquished its power to impose bans on players deemed to have suspect actions.
fields.body:
Shoaib Akhtar is likely to resume his Test-playing career sooner than expected after the ICC relinquished its power to impose bans on players deemed to have suspect actions.

Shoaib, still scheduled to play for Nottinghamshire in the county championship next season, was banned for Pakistan's forthcoming series against Sri Lanka after the ICC judged his bowling action to be illegal. He was later cleared to play in one-day internationals.

While the ban, imposed by an advisory panel of the ICC, still stands, the Pakistan Cricket Board is likely to press for it to be lifted, given the change in policy.

"I knew I would be back to thrill the crowds the world over," Shoaib said. "I play for my country and to entertain the crowds. I look forward to playing in England and take this as a challenge. I will talk to the board officials to give me a break from Pakistan's assignments so I can play a full season."

webTitle: Irving 'should not be deemed a historian'

fields.headline: Irving 'should not be deemed a historian'
fields.standfirst: The David Irving libel trial: special report
fields.trailText: David Irving did not deserve to be called a historian, a leading academic told the high court yesterday.
fields.body:
David Irving did not deserve to be called a historian, a leading academic told the high court yesterday.

Richard Evans, professor of modern history at Cambridge University, said that he was not prepared for the "sheer depth of duplicity" which he encountered in Mr Irving's treatment of historical sources relating to the Holocaust.

Mr Irving, the 62-year-old author of Hitler's War, who is suing for libel over claims that he is a "Holocaust denier", said that Professor Evans's "sweeping and rather brutal" dismissal of his career stemmed from personal animosity.

"I think you dislike what I write and stand for and what you perceive my views to be," he told Prof Evans, who has been called as an expert for the defence by author Deborah Lipstadt and Penguin Books.

Prof Evans, who has produced a 740-page report on Mr Irving's historical method, said he had no personal feelings towards him and had tried to be as objective as possible.

He said he previously had little knowledge of Mr Irving's work - although he knew of his reputation as someone who was in many areas a sound historian - and was "shocked" at what he found.

He said that the proceedings had reinforced his view in the report that Mr Irving "has fallen so far short of the stan dards of scholarship customary among historians that he doesn't deserve to be called a historian at all".

Mr Irving said that he was "scrupulously fair" in everything he did in public life - "the total opposite of being unscrupulous and manipulative and deceptive as you say in your report".

Prof Evans said he agreed that Mr Irving had a very wide knowledge of the source material for the third reich and had discovered many new documents.

"The problem for me is what you do with them when you interpret them and write them up."

Prof Evans said that Mr Irving's published writings and speeches contained numerous statements which he regarded as "anti-Semitic" - to the extent that he blamed the Jews for the Holocaust.

He dismissed the theory that there was a "worldwide Jewish conspiracy" to suppress Mr Irving's works - or undermine Germany in the 1930s - as "a fantastic belief which has no grounds in fact".

Prof Evans said that he had examined a sufficient selection of Mr Irving's output to justify his view that he did not use acceptable methods of historical research.

In his report, he said that Mr Irving had relied in the past, and continued to do so, on the fact that readers, listeners and reviewers lacked "either the time or the expertise" to probe deeply enough in the sources he used to discover the "distortions and manipulations".

He accepted that people should be allowed to challenge the "general consensus" of history but asserted that there was a duty to conform to academic standards in the evaluation of evidence.

Mr Irving, who is representing himself, is claiming damages over the 1994 Book, Denying the Holocaust: The Growing Assault on Truth and Memory, which he says has generated waves of hatred against him.

The defendants have accused him of being a liar and a falsifier of history.

The hearing continues.

fields.headline: Shakespeare v American Beauty
fields.trailText: The multi Oscar-winning film Shakespeare in Love and the Golden Globe winner American Beauty each won seven nominations yesterday for this year's awards of the London Film Critics' Circle, and were pitted against each other for film of the year.
fields.body:
The multi Oscar-winning film Shakespeare in Love and the Golden Globe winner American Beauty each won seven nominations yesterday for this year's awards of the London Film Critics' Circle, and were pitted against each other for film of the year.

Sam Mendes was put up for both British director of the year and director of the year for American Beauty.

John Madden is in the running for British director of the year for Shakespeare in Love. The low budget Asian comedy East is East, best film at the Evening Standard awards, was nominated for British film of the year. Om Puri, who starred as a Pakistani father trying to uphold traditional family values, is on the list for actor of the year, alongside the Oscar winners Kevin Spacey and Roberto Benigni.

Miranda Richardson was nominated as British actress of the year for her voiceover in the animated version of The King and I.

Tom Stoppard and Marc Norman are joint nominees for British screenwriter of the year for Shakespeare in Love.

Other British nominees include Bill Condon for screenwriter of the year for Gods and Monsters. Jeremy Northam, who won best actor accolades at the British film awards and at the Variety Club awards, is up for British actor of the year with Ralph Fiennes, Ian McKellen, Terence Stamp and Robert Carlyle.

Linda Bassett competes for British actress of the year for East is East with, among others, Samantha Morton and Helena Bonham Carter.

The newcomer Rhys Ifans, in Notting Hill, faces old-timers Nigel Hawthorne and Michael Caine for British actor of the year in a supporting role.

The awards will be presented in London on March 2.
