webTitle: Portillo U-turn on gay sex vote

fields.headline: Portillo U-turn on gay sex vote
fields.trailText:
Michael Portillo last night embarked on another U-turn when he voted to
   lower the gay age of consent to 16, in a move which placed him at odds with
   the vast majority of Tory MPs.
fields.body:
Michael Portillo last night embarked on another U-turn when he voted to lower the gay age of consent to 16, in a move which placed him at odds with the vast majority of Tory MPs.

Six years after voting against a similar move, the shadow chancellor joined the ranks of Labour and Liberal Democrats as MPs overwhelmingly backed the latest bid to lower the age of consent for gay men from 18 to 16.

Mr Portillo's decision to vote for a change in the law, which follows his admission last year to "homosexual experiences" as a young man, caused surprise at central office.

Sources close to William Hague said that the Tory leader had expected Mr Portillo to abstain in last night's free vote when MPs approved the second reading of the Sexual Offences (Amendment) Bill by 263 votes to 102, a majority of 161. Mr Hague, who has voted to lower the age of consent for gay men in the past, was not in the Commons for last night's vote.

In all,10 Tory MPs voted for equalisation last night. On the other side, six Labour MPs opposed the bill.

The measure will now move to the House of Lords where it is certain to face strong opposition from peers who have already thrown out two previous attempts to equalise the gay and heterosexual ages of consent. But ministers have indicated that they are prepared to invoke the Parliament act to force the bill through Last night's vote, which followed an impassioned five-hour debate, came just three days after peers rejected government plans to repeal Section 28 which bans the promotion of homosexuality.

Mr Portillo's vote last night came after he was forced to demonstrate his loyalty to Mr Hague by accepting one of the Conservative leader's high-flying aides as his private secretary in the Tory treasury team. The new shadow chancellor also bowed to demands that all his media announcements be cleared by Amanda Platell, Mr Hague's fiercely loyal communications director at party HQ.

Mr Portillo welcomed the appointment of ex-civil servant, Paul Raynes, to his staff. "I am delighted that Paul has agreed to take on this key role. I saw his policy-making abilities and organisational skills at first hand when he worked for me at the treasury," Mr Portillo said in a statement.

Yesterday Mr Portillo backtracked on his apparent doubts about the wisdom of a Tory cast-iron pledge to cut taxes in the lifetime of a parliament, which Labour is trying to present as a formula for cutting public services. "The Conservative party's tax guarantee stands. William Hague and I have both made it clear," he said.

fields.headline: Arms and the boys
fields.standfirst: Whatever the small print may say, the IRA must show a willingness to disarm now if huge progress made in Northern Ireland is not to be lost
fields.trailText:
The IRA is an armed insurrectionist movement. It exists to wage war, and to 
offer a dubious kind of protection to its supporters. Take away its weapons, 
and there is nothing left. No credibility, no influence.
fields.body:
The IRA is an armed insurrectionist movement. It exists to wage war, and to offer a dubious kind of protection to its supporters. Take away its weapons, and there is nothing left. No credibility, no influence.

By that crude analysis, it is easy to see why the Provisionals are so reluctant to disarm; to wipe themselves out as a factor in the evolving Northern Ireland peace process. But there is a huge flaw in the argument. That is, that the IRA is not a stand-alone organisation. It is part of a wider republican movement, the political component of which, Sinn Fein, is a key player in the devolved government.

That government is about to go into a dangerous limbo, with the resumption of direct rule in the province today. First minister David Trimble is putting a brave gloss on the crisis, saying that it is not terminal. But crisis it is, and only the IRA can defuse it.

The argument that the peace process is somehow separate from disarmament, and that the Provisionals can make up their minds in their own sweet time, just won't wash. It is as if the British Army insisted on the right of military intervention, without consulting the government.

For another thing, the IRA is committed to completing the 'decommissioning' process by May 22. Its apologists splutter and rage about the present deadline being a capricious Unionist device - which to some extent it is - but it is plain that the boys in berets never had any intention of keeping their end of the bargain. Today's momentous events merely anticipate what would surely happen in May.

The immediate danger is that tomorrow, with the assembly and all its attendant baggage in the political freezer, the ruling council of the Ulster Unionist party will pile more pressure on Trimble to make new and tougher demands on disarmament.

That in turn could provoke the greatest potential disaster of all: a split in the Provisional ranks, and a resumption of the armed campaign. To some extent it has already happened, with the emergence since the ceasefire of the ragtag 'Continuity' and 'Real' versions of the IRA. Both are politically negligible, but each is capable of killing. So too are the various obscurantist loyalist militias, some of whose members have no more taste than the Republican hard men for the slow, delicate gavotte of political reconciliation.

Standing back from the immediate crisis to gain a better perspective, it is astonishing to reflect on how far the Good Friday process has come. We may be weary of the snarl and whine of Ulster confrontation, but at least the main players are slagging each other off face to face, instead of from separate studios. A couple of years ago, we would have scoffed at the notion that Gerry Adams and Martin McGuinness would be government ministers in part of the UK, that senior Unionists would take part in all-Ireland institutions, and that the RUC would be facing effective disbandment.

Even better than any of that is the situation on the ground. The IRA and loyalist ceasefires have, for the most part, held. British troops remain, but their numbers have been drastically cut and they are rarely seen on the streets. The economy is prospering and investment is picking up. Tourism is growing fast.

Against that background, it seems incredible and even wicked that the IRA is not prepared to give some ground. Everyone in their right minds knows that disarmament will be a slow and painful business, bristling with risks. Human nature being what it is, it is likely that the Provisionals will stay in business as a potential threat, with a cache of undeclared arms, for at least a generation. We can all live with that. What we cannot tolerate is a private army, entirely self-appointed and unaccountable, perpetually sabotaging what is supposed to be a permanent peace settlement.

No credibility, no influence. By that crude analysis, it is easy to see why the Provisionals are so reluctant to disarm; to wipe themselves out as a factor in the evolving Northern Ireland peace process. But there is a huge flaw in the argument. That is, that the IRA is not a stand-alone organisation. It is part of a wider republican movement, the political component of which, Sinn Fein, is a key player in the devolved government. That government is about to go into a dangerous limbo, with the resumption of direct rule in the province today. The argument that the peace process is somehow separate from disarmament, and that the Provisionals can make up their minds in their own sweet time, just won't wash. It is as if the British Army insisted on the right of military intervention, without consulting the government. webTitle: Lloyds TSB cuts jobs despite record profits

fields.headline: Lloyds TSB cuts jobs despite record profits
fields.standfirst: Bank announces massive expansion of online services
fields.trailText: Lloyds TSB, Britain's biggest high street bank, today announced plans to cut 3,000 jobs this year in a cost cutting shake-up despite reporting record profits.
fields.body:
Lloyds TSB, Britain's biggest high street bank, today announced plans to cut 3,000 jobs this year in a cost cutting shake-up despite reporting record profits.

Already the UK's most cost-efficient bank, Lloyds TSB said it would centralise its computer operations and remove the "back office" processing of customers' accounts currently carried out at branches. The bank is also planning an enormous expansion of its online activities.

The bank said the reduction in staffing levels would be brought about partly by natural staff turnover. A spokeswoman said Lloyds TSB was reviewing its 2,300-strong branch structure with a view to possibly closing less busy sites.

The cost of the rationalisation is expected to come to £200 million in 2000. It was too early to state what kinds of jobs would be hit by the losses, the group said.

The announcement came as it reported record profits for last year and said it had continued driving down overheads. Lloyds last year cut its operating expenses by £66 million, taking total costs saved since the merger of Lloyds and TSB to £417 million a year.

The merger has left the bank with two branches in many high streets.

While the savings beat the £400 million annual target originally promised to shareholders, Lloyds TSB pledged to improve on it. Pre-tax profits in the last calendar year came in at £3.62 billion against £3.02 billion in 1998.

Unions were shocked by the job losses. A spokesman for the main finance union, UNIFI, said: "This comes as a complete surprise. We will be seeking urgent talks to ensure there are no compulsory redundancies."

The decision came as unions feared up to 18,000 job losses from the expected £21 billion takeover of NatWest by Royal Bank of Scotland.

Workers and shareholders were awaiting confirmation of RBS's victory in its hostile battle against the NatWest board and rival bidder Bank of Scotland.

Lloyds TSB said its total income last year increased by 7%, from £7.48 billion in 1998 to £7.97 billion. The total charge for bad and doubtful debts was up 11% to £588 million.

Internet banking grew rapidly, with 160,000 registered customers logging on. A million online customers were expected by the end of this year. The bank plans to create a pan-European 'standalone' bank trading solely on the internet.

It would first concentrate on the Spanish market, then spreading elsewhere with the objective of taking on a million customers within three to four years.

A UK 'standalone' internet bank will follow towards the end of 2000, offering current accounts to the public. Plans for the two new on-line banks are still in their early stages and full details of products and branding are not yet known.

Shareholders will collect a total dividend of 26.6p a share, up on the previous year's 22.2p payment.

webTitle: Police charge man over letters delivered to BBC's Anna Ford

fields.headline: Police charge man over letters delivered to BBC's Anna Ford
fields.trailText: Detectives investigating an alleged stalker who hand-delivered mail to the BBC newsreader Anna Ford last night charged a man with harassing her and sending malicious letters to her home.
fields.body:
Detectives investigating an alleged stalker who hand-delivered mail to the BBC newsreader Anna Ford last night charged a man with harassing her and sending malicious letters to her home.

Terence Lawton, 46, of Chelsea, west London, was last night remanded in custody and was due to appear today before Feltham magistrates.

Ms Ford contacted police on Wednesday after reading the contents of six letters that were delivered by hand to her home.

Later the same day a man arrived at her doorstep. Ms Ford answered the door to the man, then had to push him away to stop him from entering her home. She told him to leave her alone and then closed the door on him, before contacting police again. A BBC spokesman said: "The man turned up at Anna's house and gave her various letters.

"Anna has passed these to the police and has made statements. She does not wish to say anything further."

A Scotland Yard spokesman said: "Mr Lawton has been charged with two counts of sending malicious communication to Anna Ford on February 7 and February 9 and one count of harassment of Anna Ford on or before February 9 in Brentford. He will be held in custody prior to appearing in court."

Two uniformed police officers were stationed outside Ms Ford's home yesterday after the incident.

Ms Ford, 56, did not let the incident disrupt her routine. She read the BBC 1 lunchtime news bulletin yesterday before returning to her home.

The incident will no doubt raise concern at the BBC over how people are finding out where its staff live.

A BBC spokesman said the corporation was "extremely concerned for the security" of all its employees.

Security was increased at the BBC after the death last year of the Crimewatch UK presenter Jill Dando, who was shot dead on her doorstep, but it was still not secure enough to stop a man from smashing his way into a BBC newsroom at Television Centre last September after jumping over security barriers.

webTitle: Protesters ban Straw from his old student union

fields.headline: Protesters ban Straw from his old student union
fields.trailText: Students at Leeds university last night banned their former president, Jack Straw, in protest at what they said were his anti-libertarian policies.
fields.body:
Students at Leeds university last night banned their former president, Jack Straw, in protest at what they said were his anti-libertarian policies.

More than 600 students at the union's annual general meeting overwhelmingly voted to revoke the home secretary's life membership of the union, and to lobby the university to overturn his honorary degree.

The union's finance and administration officer, Simon Rothstein, said: "Jack Straw has been responsible for the asylum and immigration bill, the attempted removal of trial by jury in many cases, and the removal of legal aid in many cases, as well as many other anti-civil liberties.

"Students here decided that something had to be done to show our anger at what he has come to stand for since his student days."

Mr Straw was president of Leeds university union from 1967-68 and of the National Union of Students from 1969-71.

The student motion accused Mr Straw of undermining "basic principles of freedom, liberty and democracy," adding that he had "introduced policy even the most right-wing Tory home secretaries didn't dare introduce and about which he spoke strongly against whilst in opposition".

A Labour spokesman last night described the motion as a "puerile gesture" and added: "Jack Straw will be carrying on his job of tackling crime and won't be taking this protest too seriously."

webTitle: 70 hours of sweet talk that ended a crisis

fields.headline: 70 hours of sweet talk that ended a crisis
fields.standfirst:
Textbook tactics: in the end, one of the hijackers had lost his voice as police won a victory

Stansted hijack: special report
fields.trailText: It was, a senior police source said, a case of talking the hijackers into submission. So it was not until midnight on Wednesday, 70 hours after an Afghan Boeing 727 landed at Stansted, that negotiators finally asked the question: "Why don't we start talking about you coming off the aeroplane?"
fields.body:
It was, a senior police source said, a case of talking the hijackers into submission. So it was not until midnight on Wednesday, 70 hours after an Afghan Boeing 727 landed at Stansted, that negotiators finally asked the question: "Why don't we start talking about you coming off the aeroplane?"

Within six hours by 5.57am yesterday, the remaining hostages were free and their 96 hours aboard a plane which took off on a 40 minute internal flight from Kabul at 5.30am on Sunday were over.

Though such a delay in addressing the key issue may seem strange, it appeared to be a textbook demonstration by Essex police of hostage negotiation theory. Every request from the cockpit was negotiated almost into eternity. If someone was ill, the police team would ask, do you want this medicine?, or that medicine?, in pill form?, or solution? On the first day of talks police debated for two and a half hours how chicken the hijackers had requested should be cooked. By the end, the hijacker who had done most of the talking to police had lost his voice.

"You can give the hijackers small victories by delay - take a long time to agree to fairly simple demands because then the hijackers feel they are making progress," said Paul Rogers, professor of peace studies at Bradford university.

More unusual about the hijack is that it apparently ended without any clear political demand by the hijackers and, so police say, no formal request for asylum.

Only in the last hour of negotiations, said David Stevens, Essex police chief constable, did they directly express any concern for the domestic situation in Afghanistan. At no time did they call for the release by the Taliban government of rebel leader Ishmail Khan, as they did at an earlier stop in Moscow on Sunday. And at no time, Mr Stevens said, did they make a formal demand for asylum. "I am not aware it was discussed in any detail at all." Such ambiguity, was, according to the chief constable "very strange". Police had made no guarantees or promises on asylum or anything else.

But there is no doubt that issues surrounding asylum - and the British justice system in general - were discussed widely during days of negotiation, and proved crucial to the ending of the crisis.

Negotiators spent several hours, said Mr Stevens, "assuring them they would be treated safely and in accordance with British law". There was no concession by the British authorities, beyond an assurance that they would be handled fairly.

And it was a crisis: Though negotiations remained generally calm, the discovery yesterday aboard the plane of four handguns, one knuckle duster, two detonators and two grenades without fuses was testimony to the danger. During shouting and screaming in one very anxious five-hour period after the escape of four crew on Tuesday night, police sources confirmed yesterday that the hijackers had threatened to kill hostages.

Throughout Wednesday police worked intensively to rebuild trust and rapport with the hijackers until, around 9pm, they were confidently preparing for the release of all hostages. Parts of the Hilton hotel across the road were cleared, interpreters milled around and goods from Marks and Spencers were brought in.

There were, sources said, several false starts. But at midnight, Mr Stevens and his negotiators began to feel sure that events were turning their way and pressed the point home.

Two walkie-talkies were dropped at the foot of the plane and at about 2.35am were picked up by a hijacker. Fifteen minutes later the two hijackers who had dealt most with police walked off the aircraft for a face to face meeting on the runway with two negotiators. The radios enabled them to maintain contact with the other hijackers. They spoke for a few minutes and a deal was done.

Safety guarantee

Some 70% of the hostages, including all the women and children, would come off in one go. The hijackers asked that their safety be guaranteed, and to be allowed to make a statement on the political situation in Afghanistan, which was agreed but has not been made public.

But just as 85 hostages stood in the aisles, preparing to leave the jet, fire en gine and police car sirens started blaring on-route to a tiny fire elsewhere at the airport. The hijackers stalled, fearing the plane was about to be stormed. Tension. More negotiations.

Then, at 3.17am, the remaining 21 women and 17 children started to leave the plane. Behind them came 42 men, with their hands up - police feared they could include some of the all male team of hijackers.

At 6.10am, Essex assistant chief constable Joe Edwards was trying hard not to sound exultant. 21 minutes earlier the remaining 66 males on board including, it later emerged, most if not all of the 21 who were subsequently arrested by police on suspicion of involvement in the hijacking, had started to walk from the plane.

"Within the last few minutes we have got the last few people off the hijacked aeroplane," Mr Edwards said. He thanked the media for their patience and responsibility. "The drama of the last few days appears to be at an end, but for Essex police there's still a lot of work to do."

That, it emerged yesterday, will include an application to the Home Office for grants to cover the estimated £1m the police spent on the drama that preoccupied the force for four days.

webTitle: Consideration of asylum claims could take months

fields.headline: Consideration of asylum claims could take months
fields.standfirst:
Stansted hijack: special report
Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Jack Straw sounded tough when he declared yesterday that he personally would decide on asylum claims by those on board the hijacked Afghan aircraft.
fields.body:
Jack Straw sounded tough when he declared yesterday that he personally would decide on asylum claims by those on board the hijacked Afghan aircraft but home office sources confirmed last night that it was likely to be at least two months before final decisions were made.

The home secretary said while he "must and will act in accordance with the law" he wanted to see all those who were on the plane removed from Britain as "soon as reasonably practicable."

Immigration lawyers said last night that decisions on asylum claims from Afghans on the plane might not be as straightforward as supposed. It had to be borne in mind that Britain officially regarded Afghanistan as such a dangerous place that nearly all Afghan asylum seekers over the past three years had been given exceptional permission to stay here on compassionate grounds. The latest figures for 1998 show that only 65 out of 1,600 Afghans who sought refugee status were refused permission to stay.

The home office could put the asylum claims through a new fast-track procedure to deport them within days but the numbers involved make that unlikely. Instead, it may take up to two months for the immigration service to interview all the applicants, for Jack Straw to make a decision and for them to exercise any appeal rights. Other asylum applicants are waiting an average of 18 months to get their claims sorted out.

The home office is also considering the possibility of sending them back not to Afghanistan but to neighbouring Pakistan but that could mean a delay turning into months as those involved would have the right to appeal against being sent to a third country. Pakistan would also have to agree to take them.

Nick Hardwick, the chief executive of the Refugee Council, said last night that there had been three groups on the plane. There was no doubt the first group, the hijackers, should face criminal charges. But he said the second group, made up of their families, could face death in Afghanistan and were unlikely to be safe even in Pakistan.

"This is a desperate act by desperate men, desperate to get their families to safety. It doesn't excuse it, but it doesn't mean we can return people to a dangerous situation without very careful thought."

The third group identified by Mr Hardwick was the rest of the passengers, who, because they could afford the £12.50 fare for the internal flight - three times the average wage - showed themselves to be members of the middle class elite who had suffered the brunt of persecution by the Taliban regime.

Although Amnesty International and other human rights activists stressed last night the danger of returning to the Taliban regime with its record of massacres, floggings and amputations of political opponents, immigration lawyers believed the fact that they had been on an internal flight was likely to wreck their chances of claiming asylum on the grounds that their application lacked credibility.

Martin Penrose, of lawyers Winstanley Burgess, said it was likely to take a few days to interview all the applicants. They would then be given five days to collect evidence to substantiate their claim. If refused they would be able to appeal, a matter of a further four weeks. If a point of law arose the case might be referred to the immigration appeals tribunal. They would have no further rights of appeal.

But he said the second group, made up of their families, could face death in Afghanistan and were unlikely to be safe even in Pakistan. "This is a desperate act by desperate men, desperate to get their families to safety. It doesn't excuse it, but it doesn't mean we can return people to a dangerous situation without very careful thought." The third group identified by Mr Hardwick was the rest of the passengers, who, because they could afford the £12.50 fare for the internal flight - three times the average wage - showed themselves to be members of the middle class elite who had suffered the brunt of persecution by the Taliban regime. Martin Penrose, of lawyers Winstanley Burgess, said it was likely to take a few days to interview all the applicants. They would then be given five days to collect evidence to substantiate their claim. If refused they would be able to appeal, a matter of a further four weeks. If a point of law arose the case might be referred to the immigration appeals tribunal. They would have no further rights of appeal. fields.headline: The fallout from Stansted
fields.standfirst:
Mr Straw is anxious to say goodbye

Stansted hijack: special report
fields.trailText: There were two immediate tasks facing the home secretary when he addressed the Commons yesterday on the peaceful conclusion of the hijack at Stansted: to signal to would-be international hijackers that the UK was not a soft and cosy haven to head for; and to reassert our legal obligations under international law to treat all asylum applications seriously.
fields.body:
There were two immediate tasks facing the home secretary when he addressed the Commons yesterday on the peaceful conclusion of the hijack at Stansted: to signal to would-be international hijackers that the UK was not a soft and cosy haven to head for; and to reassert our legal obligations under international law to treat all asylum applications seriously. His task was made more complicated because the hijacked plane contained four different groups: hijackers; relatives of hijackers seeking asylum; non-relatives seeking asylum; and passengers keen to return to Afghanistan.

Where firmness was needed, Jack Straw provided it. No concessions or undertakings had been granted to the hijackers. The surrender from the plane was "unconditional". Some 21 people were under arrest. The attorney general and director of public prosecutions would be deciding how many would be prosecuted, but hijacking was regarded as "a very serious terrorist offence in this country". Some 60 people with 14 dependants had applied for asylum. The rest of the passengers would be returned to Afghanistan, or nearby Pakistan if they wished, beginning today. The home secretary indicated that he would person ally take the decision on the asylum applications. While each would be examined individually, in accordance with international law, he signalled deep scepticism over their chances of being granted refugee status. They will, of course, be able to appeal to an adjudicator and the immigration appeal tribunal, but Mr Straw noted that the plane had been on an internal flight when it was hijacked: "in such circumstances, it seems inconceivable that persons on the flight intended to claim political asylum unless of course they were complicit in the hijacking." That is to prejudge the cases before they are heard.

The Afghan plane contained all the ingredients - hijackers, asylum seekers, Muslim fundamentalists - which the right needs to undermine the interests of refugees. The idea that the UK is a "soft touch" is absurd. We have some of the most rigorous rules in Europe. Similarly, the UK is not a hijackers' haven: of the 18 hijackings involving European states in the past decade, only two have involved the UK. Hijacking can never be an asylum option. Mr Straw's tough talk may have appeased the right, but it rode roughshod over civil rights. He should have resisted temptation.

fields.headline: Freedom fighters
fields.standfirst: As the far right rises to power in Austria, musicians are laying down their instruments in protest. Kate Connolly on a troubled present - and a painful past
fields.trailText: As the far right rises to power in Austria, musicians are laying down their instruments in protest. Kate Connolly on a troubled present - and a painful past
fields.body:
As Graz composer Olga Neuwirth came on stage at Vienna's Konzerthaus last Saturday after a performance of her work Clenamen-Nodus, she carried a funeral bouquet. It was a stark illustration of the mood that has descended on Austria since the entry of Jörg Haider's far-right Freedom party into government.

Austria's cultural community is gravely concerned, both about the new political complexion of their country and the possible implications for their artistic freedom. Black flags have been hung from prominent music and theatre institutions as a sign of the artistic world's discontent. Some have threatened to leave the country; others have said they will renounce their Austrian citizenship.

Gerard Mortier said this week he will leave his position as director of the Salzburg Festival a year earlier than planned. He argued his contract gave him the right to cut short his tenure "if the circumstances necessary to carry out my creative work are not there any more. Now the Freedom Party is in government this is the situation I face".

Hungarian-born pianist Andras Schiff, who has Austrian citizenship, this week cancelled a Bach concert at the Austrian embassy in Washington, and released this statement: "As an Austrian citizen and a European Jew, I am deeply saddened about the political developments in Austria." Conductor Zubin Mehta, who has strong ties with the Vienna Philharmonic, has said he will leave Austria immediately "should Haider put his anti-foreigner politics into action".

Musicians are not alone in expressing their concern. The country's most prominent playwright, Elfriede Jelinek, has declared a ban on her works being performed in Austrian theatres as long as Haider is in power, and the Ingebourg Bachmann Prize, the Austrian equivalent of the Booker, has been withdrawn.

The issue is one of artistic practice as well as political principle. Details of the government's cultural programme have yet to be revealed, but the new cultural minister, Frank Morak, has indicated there will be big budget cuts. "The main worry is that there is nothing in the programme about money that will be set aside to support contemporary art," says Franz Endler, music critic for the Kurier newspaper.

Institutions such as the Vienna Philharmonic, the State Opera and the Vienna Boys' Choir are not under threat financially because laws about their funding are set in stone. It is the more avant-garde institutions that are concerned. Some have expressed their fear that Austria will become a land dominated by Mozart, yodellers and brass bands. "Pluralism does not come into the government's programme," said one critic.

While many have condemned the new government's intention to encourage "Volkskultur" rather than contemporary art, they have been polarised about how to react. During his tour of Austria with the LSO last week, Pierre Boulez was critical of artists who wanted to leave. "One can protest and express an opinion, but one shouldn't flee the country. If there is to be censorship, it is necessary to take real action," he said. Boulez, along with Riccardo Muti, says he will continue to work in Austria.

Sir Simon Rattle, who has strong links with the Salzburg Festival, appears to be prepared to go ahead with plans for a performance of Beethoven's Ninth at Mauthausen, the site of a former concentration camp, on May 7. If it does go ahead, it could become a symbolic act of opposition to Haider and his apologias for Nazism.

Vienna's traditional role as the home of classical music makes this uneasy marriage of art and politics inevitable, and the dilemma facing musicians is a reminder of the agonies following the Anschluss - the annexation of Austria by Germany - in March 1938. When Austria was absorbed into Hitler's Reich, its cultural institutions were immediately Nazified and Jews purged from musical life. The reactions of the country's great musical figures differed sharply. Arturo Toscanini, a key figure in re-establishing the eminence of the Salzburg Festival, resigned in protest at the persecution of Jewish musicians. He was already a fierce opponent of fascism in his native Italy.

Bruno Walter had also been a key figure at Salzburg, a leading conductor with the Vienna Philharmonic and artistic adviser to the Vienna State Opera. He left Austria after the Anschluss, went to Paris, was granted French nationality, helped Toscanini establish a kind of Salzburg Festival-in-exile in Lucerne, and ultimately sought sanctuary in the US. By contrast, Wilhelm Furtwängler, who had conducted many concerts with the Vienna Philharmonic before the Anschluss, became the orchestra's chief conductor in the Nazi period. As with Herbert von Karajan, Richard Strauss and others, there was controversy after the war about the extent of his complicity and it was years before he was welcomed back to the UK.

Haider's new-found political power may seem like a bad dream compared with the Hitler nightmare, yet his rise has reawakened the ghosts of Vienna's musical past. "The mood is in many ways reminiscent of the late 30s and 40s, when thousands of musicians and artists were forced to flee the land," said writer and publisher Richard Brem. Retreat or resist - it is not a pleasant choice.

webTitle: Comedians risk sack for wishing Haider dead

fields.headline: Comedians risk sack for wishing Haider dead
fields.standfirst: The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: Austria's most popular comedy duo are facing possible criminal charges and the abrupt end to successful careers after recommending that far right populist Jörg Haider be shot.
fields.body:
Austria's most popular comedy duo are facing possible criminal charges and the abrupt end to successful careers after recommending that far right populist Jörg Haider be shot.

Christoph Grissemann and Dirk Stermann said in an interview with an arts magazine: "Somebody should shoot Haider. Someone who only has two months left to live."

A spokeswoman for Mr Haider's Freedom party confirmed last night that party bosses had taken the matter up with the police. "We're awaiting their decision on the matter tomorrow or on Monday," she said.

The comedians also faced the prospect that their weekly radio programme Salon Helga, which is aired by the Austrian state broadcasting corporation, ORF, might be axed. "These terrible verbal derailments are unacceptable ... If these declarations are correct we'll be considering whether we are still able to employ the two men," said Wolfgang Fischer, the radio's spokesman.

The two also said during the interview with Rödr@nner magazine that if Mr Haider was to become chancellor, "He wouldn't do it very well, he won't be able to do it well.

"But he might be successful which just goes to show that 'the Austrian' is a spineless, rotten swine." In a statement the two apologised for their outburst, saying it had occurred "in a heated and totally drunken atmosphere".

The comments were made back in October to the arts magazine from Upper Austria, which has a print run of a few hundred copies. They were picked up by the regional newspaper Neues Volkblatt this week.

Dozens of readers telephoned to complain to the paper which is affiliated to the conservative People's party - which a week ago today took the controversial Haider party into coalition with it as Austria's new government.

The Freedom party, which has a reputation as a serial litigator, called in the police to consider whether its party leader had been illegally threatened or defamed.

The incident comes just days after a journalist at an Upper Austrian newspaper was sacked because of his anti-Haider views. Journalists around the country have demonstrated against the dismissal.

Youth culture has also hit back against the new government, with a modified version of the computer game Castle Wolfstein. In the 3-D game players move down corridors and shoot pictures of Hitler and Nazi soldiers. An updated version has appeared on the internet featuring Mr Haider and members of his Freedom party.

In opinion poll results published yesterday the opposition Social Democrats and Greens got combined support of 50%, indicating that if elections were held now they might form a majority.

webTitle: Britain's trade bans can kill, say MPs

fields.headline: Britain's trade bans can kill, say MPs
fields.standfirst: Labour's ethical foreign policy: special report
fields.trailText: Economic sanctions applied to oppressive regimes by the UK can cause as much humanitarian damage as outright war, a cross-party committee of MPs said yesterday.
fields.body:
Economic sanctions applied to oppressive regimes by the UK can cause as much humanitarian damage as outright war, a cross-party committee of MPs said yesterday.

In a forthright attack on Britain's policy over countries including Iraq and the Yugoslav Republic, the commons international development committee said sanctions too often hurt the innocent and failed to harm the governments they were aimed at.

The report, the Future of Sanctions, concludes that regional sanctions - targeted on particular areas of individual countries - have resulted in "catastrophic humanitarian consequences", particularly in Burundi and Sierra Leone.

"Sanctions, unless carefully targeted, have the capacity to kill more children than armed warfare," the report says.

The committee notes that even those in favour of sanctions against Iraq "accept that children, the ill, the vulnerable in Iraqi society are suffering".

The study, whose findings were largely backed by aid organisations but immediately challenged by the government, proposes a new approach to make sanctions "smarter" and more effective.

It argues that the international community should target the assets of specific groups or individuals responsible for breaches of international law, as an alternative to blanket measures which compounded suffering among ordinary people.

The report recommends the establishment in the UK of an office of foreign assets control to track funds connected to the leaders of oppressive regimes. It calls for greater efforts to enforce arms embargoes and improved monitoring of the impact of sanctions.

Foreign office minister Peter Hain defended the government's use of sanctions. He told BBC Radio 4's World at One: "Iraq's threat to the wider world has been contained for over 10 years now, and that is a significant achievement."

fields.headline: Piling on the hysteria
fields.standfirst:
Nick Hardwick is appalled with how we deal with the tiny number of refugees who get here. We rant about scroungers

Stansted hijack: special report
Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: This has been a truly awful week for not only many of those on the hijacked aeroplane but also for all those in this country who want a credible asylum system.
fields.body:
This has been a truly awful week for not only many of those on the hijacked aeroplane but also for all those in this country who want a credible asylum system.

Hijacking an aeroplane and risking the lives of its passengers can never be recognised as an acceptable route to asylum. It is largely due to the professionalism of the emergency teams at Stansted that this situation has been resolved peacefully and the passengers released from their terrible ordeal unharmed. The hijackers now face serious criminal charges and the possibility of long prison sentences.

The home secretary has promised personally to decide on any application for asylum emanating from the flight. However, whether the decision is made by the home secretary or an immigration officer, it has to be made objectively and in accordance with the law.

There appear to be three groups of potential asylum seekers:

 The hijackers themselves, who will have to wait until the judicial process is completed and any sentence served before an asylum claim can be considered.

 The hijackers' families - many of them women and children who face real danger if returned to either Pakistan or Afghanistan.

 Ordinary passengers who have taken advantage of their unexpected arrival in the UK to claim asylum.

The fare for the internal flight these people were on was three times the average monthly wage. Those on the flight were almost certainly affluent professionals - precisely the type of people under pressure from the current regime. This may not be enough for them to qualify as refugees, but it does make their actions more understandable.

Whatever else these individuals are, they are not "economic migrants" involved in some frivolous action to gain the dubious joys of a dodgy bed and breakfast hotel in one of Britain's inner cities and a long wait on vouchers.

Hijacking this aircraft was a desperate act by desperate men who would appear to have had good reason to fear for the safety of themselves and their families. This does not excuse the hijacking - but it does put the media hysteria into context, where the hijackers are simultaneously portrayed as Islamic fundamentalists, international terrorists and dole scroungers - a Daily Mail leader writer's dream. The simple truth is that asylum seekers in the UK live on more reduced levels of support than ordinary citizens and are entitled to only the most basic accommodation.

But, to those who want a credible asylum system which produces fair decisions quickly, this whole affair and its media coverage is a body blow and could not have come at a more critical time. We are only weeks away from the implementation of the government's new system, which will support asylum seekers as they await a decision on their asylum application.

Throughout the passage of the immigration and asylum act, we have consistently stressed that the key to restoring the credibility of the asylum system is making good-quality decisions quickly. What taxpayers and refugees both want is a system which will ensure that refugees are quickly recognised and helped to settle into the community and those who do not fulfil international criteria for protection or other humanitarian grounds should be removed following due process.

A key plank of the new system is to disperse asylum seekers away from London and the south-east. Support will mainly be provided through a voucher system which will humiliate and stigmatise the recipients. Asylum seekers are likely to be isolated from the support of their communities and in consequence many will drift back to London

It may be tempting for critics of the government's proposals to hope they fail. In my view that would be the worst disaster yet. The new support system is going to happen. If it is seen to fail this would be a further huge blow to public confidence in the asylum system and likely to lead to even harsher measures.

The Refugee Council has been vigorous in its criticisms of the home office. However, it does also need to be said that those responsible for establishing the new support system have been genuinely open and responsive. If anyone can make the system work, they can - but they cannot do it on their own. We need to do all we can to ensure the new support system does not fail.

Local politicians outside London have a particular responsibility to ensure sufficient accommodation is provided in appropriate locations and stand up to local prejudice against asylum seekers. Other service providers such as health and education need to make sure they have taken the steps necessary to provide an appropriate service.

We need to take the crisis out of the asylum system. It beggars belief that one of the richest countries in the world cannot deal with the tiny proportion of refugees who come to us without becoming hysterical. We all have a responsibility to restore some sanity to the situation.

Nick Hardwick is chief executive of the Refugee Council

However, it does also need to be said that those responsible for establishing the new support system have been genuinely open and responsive. If anyone can make the system work, they can - but they cannot do it on their own. We need to do all we can to ensure the new support system does not fail. Local politicians outside London have a particular responsibility to ensure sufficient accommodation is provided in appropriate locations and stand up to local prejudice against asylum seekers. Other service providers such as health and education need to make sure they have taken the steps necessary to provide an appropriate service. We need to take the crisis out of the asylum system. It beggars belief that one of the richest countries in the world cannot deal with the tiny proportion of refugees who come to us without becoming hysterical. We all have a responsibility to restore some sanity to the situation. Nick Hardwick is chief executive of the Refugee Council

fields.headline: Digital demand boosts Amstrad profits
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The consumer electronics group Amstrad added zest to its recovery yesterday by delivering a confident forecast of demand for digital television products and a sharp increase in profits.
fields.body:
The consumer electronics group Amstrad added zest to its recovery yesterday by delivering a confident forecast of demand for digital television products and a sharp increase in profits.

The group, chaired by Sir Alan Sugar, turned in doubled half-year profits at £8.2m on sales of £60.8m, a 34% increase. The company said it had benefited from "strong demand" for set-top decoder boxes used to receive British Sky Broadcasting's digital TV service.

Amstrad said it had orders through to the end of this financial year, in June, and "well into the next financial year". The company's performance is also being assisted by higher than expected quality levels, enabling it to release provisions taken against potential warranty costs.

A spokesman for the group said, however, that there were no plans to develop higher-specification set-top boxes, contrary to plans being implemented by rival suppliers such as Pace Micro Technology.

Instead Amstrad said it intended to launch a telecoms product next month aimed at the mass market and developed with BT's internet and multimedia division. The project, entering the market in time to have an impact on the next financial year, will include email and e-commerce.

Sir Alan sought to reward shareholders by more than doubling the dividend to 0.8p a share. He sounded a note of caution, however, by warning that Amstrad would allow its order book for TV sets to fall unless margins improved.

The company sells TVs through supermarket chains, often based on short-term sales campaigns featuring special offers. The company said this market was becoming increasingly competitive.

The group's push into overseas markets continues with the extension of a sales office in Hong Kong to handle business outside the UK.The office had been used only to oversee manufacture of Amstrad products by Far Eastern producers.

It said it sold significantly more cable TV products in the Australian market and noted that a number of new products had been introduced to the region. But "the company's focus is to enhance activities in higher-technology products".

fields.headline: Kingston raises £100m for BSkyB-by-phone
fields.standfirst:
Telecoms firm will widen its battleground against BT

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Kingston Communications, the Hull-based telecoms company, yesterday raised £100m to expand its business-to-busi ness division and fund its joint venture with pay television group BSkyB.
fields.body:
Kingston Communications, the Hull-based telecoms company, yesterday raised £100m to expand its business-to-busi ness division and fund its joint venture with pay television group BSkyB.

The company placed almost 9m shares at £11.50 each, seizing on the soaring value of Kingston stock. The shares climbed 26% on Wednesday on confirmation of the venture with BSkyB to offer digital TV and internet services down telephone wires, although yesterday they slipped back 45p to £12.37.

Kingston-upon-Hull city council which still owns 45% of the company and is sitting on a stake worth £2bn has guaranteed not to sell any of its shares at least until the beginning of June.

Kingston said capital expenditure plans outlined at flotation seven months ago of £250m over three years had been increased to £400m. Further funds might be required to take advantage of the opening up of British Telecommunications' local network to competition next year.

"It is in shareholders' interests, at a time of enormous change and development in the telecoms industry, for the company to continue in a very strong financial position so we can take advantage of the outstanding opportunities," said Ross Cope, Kingston's chief financial officer.

Kingston launched its 60-channel pay-TV service to 170,000 homes in Hull and parts of the surrounding region in October. It is using a technology called asymmetric digital subscriber line (ADSL) which upgrades conventional copper phone wires for high bandwidth applications such as digital TV or high-speed internet.

The company aims to extend its coverage outside Hull to 50,000 homes and businesses by March next year, the majority of which will also be targeted jointly with the interactive pay-TV service. A pilot area outside Hull comprising 7,000 homes has seen Kingston take 44% of BT's customers in the area.

Some £80m of the extra cash will be used to expand Torch, its telecoms business targeting corporate clients. Torch will expand into three regions in addition to existing services on offer in the East Midlands, Yorkshire, the south-west and south Midlands.

Kingston is also seeking a deal with an existing mobile phone network to launch its own branded services in a deal likely to be modelled on the Virgin Mobile service.

Kingston was formed through an anomaly which saw it remain in local council hands after the rest of the nation's network was nationalised, forming BT.

webTitle: No merger for me, says Murdoch

fields.headline: No merger for me, says Murdoch
fields.standfirst: Time Warner/AOL merger: special report
fields.trailText: Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation yesterday said the merger of Time Warner and internet business America Online had failed to persuade him to link with a similar new media company.
fields.body:
Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation yesterday said the merger of Time Warner and internet business America Online had failed to persuade him to link with a similar new media company.

Shares in News Corp have increased in value by 50% since the Time Warner-AOL deal in anticipation of a tie-up but Mr Murdoch said the company had put well in place its own strategy for capitalising on the internet. "We have built and are building a global digital platform to deliver multiple services to customers around the world," he said. "In parallel, we are building multimedia, multi-revenue businesses around our core content and business categories, including news, sports, classifieds, health and entertainment."

The worldwide success of News Corp's special-effects-laden Titanic during 1998 cast the group's second-quarter results in a poor light by comparison. The company's filmed entertainment division reported income of $31m (£19m) against $162m in the same quarter of 1998.

Anna and the King, the retelling of the story of a Victorian Englishwoman teaching the King of Siam's children, had proved to be this year's biggest disappointment at the box office. Group earnings were $510m, down from $556m, on revenues of $3.9bn for the quarter.

Mr Murdoch highlighted double-digit growth in most of the group's businesses, including television, newspapers and book publishing. Its most successful shows made by 20th Century Fox Television include the X Files and The Simpsons.

But he described the success of BSkyB, the UK pay-TV business in which News Corp has a 40% stake, as "bittersweet". The launch of Sky Digital has driven strong growth in subscriber numbers which have reached 4m in Britain but acquisition costs, including the free set-top box offer, pushed BSkyB into the red in the first half of the year.

fields.headline: Falconer struggles with an albatross
fields.standfirst: The millennium: special report
fields.trailText: Lord Falconer of Thoroton must rue the day he took over the dome - as the Greenwich white elephant threatens to halt his meteoric political rise.
fields.body:
Lord Falconer of Thoroton must rue the day he took over the dome - as the Greenwich white elephant threatens to halt his meteoric political rise.

Tony Blair's former flatmate, officially the government's shareholder in the New Millennium Experience Company, is the cabinet office minister who chairs the Whitehall committee, bangs heads together, sweet talks sponsors and faces the public flak.

The successful QC, who endured a £450,000 pay cut to become one of "Tony's cronies", knows it is make or break time for his career.

Groomed to eventually take over as Lord Chancellor from Derry Irvine, Charlie Falconer is battling to save his own as well as New Labour's credibility.

Tony Blair ennobled his old friend after the election when the father-of-four opted not to stand for the Commons.

A plan to parachute him into a safe seat in Dudley was ditched amid fears that the lawyer's fondness for private education would backfire. Blair loyalists told him to tell constituency activists that he would have sent his children to state schools if they were good enough but he told them he preferred to pay.

The PM's "eyes and ears" in Whitehall, he sits on 14 cabinet committees and admiring colleagues acknowledge that he is a formidable opponent.

Mr Blair initially appointed Lord Falconer, now 49, as solicitor-general before switching him to the cabinet office in summer 1998 to replace Peter Mandelson.

He is officially charged with co-ordinating government policy and regularly speaks with his old flatmate around the corner in Downing Street.

The dome was added to his portolio amid fears it would not open on time.

The last big event Lord Falconer organised was nearly 25 years ago on a Cambridge May ball committee that booked Hot Chocolate. One of the group's biggest hits was Everyone's A Winner.

webTitle: Al Fayed 'made up' story of son's ring

fields.headline: Al Fayed 'made up' story of son's ring
fields.standfirst: Hamilton, Al Fayed libel trial
fields.trailText: Harrods owner Mohamed Al Fayed "fabricated" a story that he paid for an engagement ring for Princess Diana and his son Dodi, and also his version of the events surrounding their deaths, a court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
Harrods owner Mohamed Al Fayed "fabricated" a story that he paid for an engagement ring for Princess Diana and his son Dodi, and also his version of the events surrounding their deaths, a court heard yesterday.

Lord Justice William Aldous told the appeal court that in a book entitled Death of a Princess, the Harrods owner made a series of inaccurate assertions and claimed the couple were preparing for a new life together and that a conspiracy existed to kill them in order to stop their marriage.

Lord Aldous made the statement in a written ruling in favour of Mr Fayed and against the Sun Newspaper.

The court found the Sun was not justified in publishing still pictures of Diana and Dodi taken by a security camera at Al Fayed's Villa Windsor in Paris hours before they died in a 1997 car crash.

The newspaper contended it had printed the stills to help disprove Mr Fayed's claim that his son and the princess planned to marry and set up home there.

Three judges ordered Reuben Murrell, the security man who sold the stills to The Sun for £40,000, to give the court £20,000 in case Mr Fayed seeks damages.

 The former Tory MP Neil Hamilton was yesterday told to pay £500,000 towards the legal costs of Mohamed Al Fayed following his failed libel action against him. He was given 14 days to pay.

fields.headline: Venture capitalists lose their inhibitions
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Britain's venture capital industry has struggled to keep pace with the internet revolution. Start-ups with big ideas claim leading investors have kept true to their conservative image, unlike the United States, where venture capital firms are pouring money into e-businesses.
fields.body:
Britain's venture capital industry has struggled to keep pace with the internet revolution. Start-ups with big ideas claim leading investors have kept true to their conservative image, unlike the United States, where venture capital firms are pouring money into e-businesses.

But, with more than $10bn (£6bn) of investment funds at stake, British private equity firms have been reviewing their investment strategies.

Ronald Cohen, founding partner of Apax, considers that at least half of his firm's $4.5bn in European/Israeli investment funds are backing internet-related companies.

"The net is revolutionising everything with well over half of our portfolio being net-related and probably a quarter dependent on the existence of the net alone," he said.

Apax has been on top of the technology sector since 1981, but concedes that the industry has been doing quite a bit of catching up in the e-commerce world over the past 12 months. He said at least a third of Apax's 130 staff focus on the technology and telecoms sector.

Other firms have been setting up specific funds to look at these sectors and splashing about huge remuneration packages to attract expert staff in an area where there are enormous shortages.

Martin Gagen, chief executive of 3i's American arm, said: "The venture capital industry is changing a lot faster because of the internet. Internet investing has affected business models and people have underestimated the effect this has had on the globalisation of the venture capital industry."

At least 30% of the $1bn-plus a year invested by 3i is in the internet, Mr Gagen said.

Executives in the private equity industry agree the emergence of cash-hungry and loss-making start-up internet companies has forced a rethink and change in attitude of traditional venture capitalist investment criteria.

The same model by which an engineering or hotel firm is assessed cannot be applied to internet and technology firms which might rack up losses for five years or more before, or if ever, a profit is achieved.

"You have to really appreciate the future opportunities of these firms as the historic precedent of profit flows on which you may have backed a company don't exist. So you have to look for milestones that have been achieved and judge them on that," said Mr Gagen.

The recurring theme that venture capitalists speak of when investing in these new-age companies is management, particularly given that the age of some executives in these businesses can be as young as 15.

Ian Oxley, investment manager for European internet investments at Chase Capital Partners, said: "When we are looking at management teams we are looking for a mixture of industry experience and the industry in which they are trying to compete."

Mr Oxley is in charge of at least £200m earmarked for European internet investments as well as a further £100m in Britain. The latter is in a fund established earlier this month called Chase Episode 1 and is being managed by Simon Murdoch who was nabbed from Amazon.com.

Next on Mr Oxley's investment criteria list is the need for an internet or technology firm to be the first in its chosen market. There is also the requirement for the product or concept to be unique.

Mr Cohen offers an example from the 1980s to support the need for a company to be a "first mover" in its market.

He said that in the 1980s there were 93 venture-backed companies trying to be number one in the personal computer market. The four to have survived are leading brands in today's PC market.

"There are more internet companies being funded than eventually will exist," said Mr Cohen. "It's like 100 horses entering a race and each has the same odds as the favourite."

Another criterion is speed.

"The failure may be that somebody did not get there first and not that it wasn't a good idea," Mr Gagen said. "In the end in any market there will only be one or two players of real scale."

webTitle: Report signals end to cuts in hospital bed numbers

fields.headline: Report signals end to cuts in hospital bed numbers
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: A 40-year trend of cuts in hospital bed numbers was pronounced over yesterday when a government report declared it impossible to meet growing health care needs by making any greater use of existing wards.
fields.body:
A 40-year trend of cuts in hospital bed numbers was pronounced over yesterday when a government report declared it impossible to meet growing health care needs by making any greater use of existing wards.

But hopes were dashed that the long-awaited report would automatically lead to a big increase in the stock of traditional hospital beds.

Of three options for the future set out in the consultative report, one would raise acute care bed numbers by more than 25% or 35,000 beds over the next 20 years. But a second would raise them less than 6% - 8000 beds - and a third, premised upon a huge expansion of community health and social care services, would mean a further cut of almost 9% - 12,000 beds.

Signals from Whitehall suggested that the government would be most likely to steer a mid course, with modest increases in acute beds and a greater expansion of "intermediate" care provision for elderly patients no longer needing acute care but not fit enough to go home.

Alan Milburn, health secretary, said: "What really counts is what we have got across the whole health care system. Everybody falls into the trap of looking at the hospital in isolation from the rest."

The report, by a team led by Clive Smee, chief economic adviser at the department of health, shows that the number of general and acute hospital beds in England fell from 219,000 in 1970 to 136,000 early last year.

Contrary to widespread belief, the report shows that acute beds have not been cut any faster than have those in other leading industrial countries - although the NHS has consistently had fewer beds than average.

The team also concludes that there is no clear link between greater bed availability and an individual hospital's ability to respond better to emergency pressures - although low availability is associated with longer queues for routine operations.

In the short term, the report projects a need for a marginal increase in beds by 2004. The number of general and acute beds should rise 2,000 (1.5%) to 138,000 and the number of beds in the health and social care system as a whole - including care homes - should rise 4,000 (0.7%) to 576,000.

Beyond that, the three alternative options would all mean an increase in overall bed numbers, taking the total to between 582,000 and 629,000, but the number of general and acute beds would rise either to 144,000 or 171,000, or fall to 124,000.

All the options would demand more care workers, though in greatly differing combinations. The alternative requiring fewest beds would mean 10,000 more GPs and a near doubling of district nurses and home helps.

By contrast, the option providing for most beds would need only 4,000 extra GPs and very little, if any, change in numbers of community health and care staff.

Mr Milburn said the report, which is open for consultation until May 15, marked "a distinct break with the past". Without pre-judging the consultation, the idea that "beds are bad" had been buried.

"My personal view is that as far as hospital beds are concerned, it doesn't seem viable to go on reducing them in the way that has been happening in the last few decades."

The report was widely welcomed. The NHS Confederation, representing health authorities and trusts, said the findings endorsed its warnings during the recent flu outbreak that hospitals now had too little excess capacity to cope with peaks of demand.

Nigel Edwards, the confederation's policy director, said: "The NHS needs the ability to bring beds on line during periods of high demand."

Donna Covey, director of the Association of Community Health Councils, said she hoped the report would trigger a debate on the long term future of the health service. "The shortage of beds identified in this report is not just about furniture, but about staffing issues."

Liam Fox, Conservative shadow health secretary, said: "If the government are serious about restoring bed numbers, Alan Milburn must begin by guaranteeing that no beds will be lost by any health authority as a result of the governmment's failure to fund the pay award for doctors and nurses."

Beyond that, the three alternative options would all mean an increase in overall bed numbers, taking the total to between 582,000 and 629,000, but the number of general and acute beds would rise either to 144,000 or 171,000, or fall to 124,000. All the options would demand more care workers, though in greatly differing combinations. The alternative requiring fewest beds would mean 10,000 more GPs and a near doubling of district nurses and home helps. By contrast, the option providing for most beds would need only 4,000 extra GPs and very little, if any, change in numbers of community health and care staff. Mr Milburn said the report, which is open for consultation until May 15, marked "a distinct break with the past". Without pre-judging the consultation, the idea that "beds are bad" had been buried. "My personal view is that as far as hospital beds are concerned, it doesn't seem viable to go on reducing them in the way that has been happening in the last few decades." The report was widely welcomed. The NHS Confederation, representing health authorities and trusts, said the findings endorsed its warnings during the recent flu outbreak that hospitals now had too little excess capacity to cope with peaks of demand. Nigel Edwards, the confederation's policy director, said: "The NHS needs the ability to bring beds on line during periods of high demand." Donna Covey, director of the Association of Community Health Councils, said she hoped the report would trigger a debate on the long term future of the health service. "The shortage of beds identified in this report is not just about furniture, but about staffing issues." Liam Fox, Conservative shadow health secretary, said: "If the government are serious about restoring bed numbers, Alan Milburn must begin by guaranteeing that no beds will be lost by any health authority as a result of the governmment's failure to fund the pay award for doctors and nurses."

webTitle: Sponsors confused by dome boss hype

fields.headline: Sponsors confused by dome boss hype
fields.standfirst: The millennium: special report
fields.trailText: Lord Falconer, the minister in charge of the dome, rang several of its disgruntled sponsors and left them believing the saviour of Euro Disney had been secured to turn around the millennium showcase, it emerged last night.
fields.body:
Lord Falconer, the minister in charge of the dome, rang several of its disgruntled sponsors and left them believing the saviour of Euro Disney had been secured to turn around the millennium showcase, it emerged last night.

The call left some of them believing Phillipe Bourguignon, the man who dragged the theme park back from the brink in 1994, and who left to head Club Med two years later, had been hired. The fact that such a high-profile troubleshooter had been appointed was the reason at least one sponsor did not object to the sacking of Jennie Page, the dome's chief executive, who delivered the £765m project on time.

What two sponsors who talked to the Guardian did not know at that stage, was that Ms Page, 55, had been dismissed the evening before by the chairman of the dome's board, Bob Ayling. She was replaced by the relatively unknown 34-year-old Frenchman, Pierre-Yves Gerbeau, the man whom dome executives sold at the weekend as Disney's saviour.

Lord Falconer's spokesman last night confirmed that "he does speak directly to sponsors from time to time but he did not bill [Gerbeau] as the saviour of Disneyland Paris..." He refused to be drawn on how Lord Falconer described him. "We can't confirm the substance of his conversations with sponsors. The news of Mr Gerbeau's appointment came from Bob Ayling."

However, one senior source at one of the main sponsors said yesterday, "Lord Falconer personally called several sponsors late on Friday afternoon to say they had the saviour of Disneyland. Everyone thought it was Phillipe Bourguignon. Now we find out this guy isn't half as senior as we thought."

He said they would have been less happy about Ms Page's departure if they had known how limited Gerbeau's experience was. "It's a massive cock-up. Nice one Bob," he added.

Another sponsor last night confirmed they had a "call from Lord Falconer's office late on Friday, but weren't given a name". They too had no idea Ms Page was going. "Two days earlier Ms Page and Lord Falconer had told us at a sponsors meeting that the management team was being strengthened."

Last night a dome spokesman conceded they had "somewhat overhyped" Mr Gerbeau's arrival. "Let's get real. We had to make an impact. A low key one would have been a disaster. Brunswick [the public relations company brought in over the head of NMEC staff to handle the annoucement] got a little carried away."

The admission comes after the Guardian raised serious questions about the claims being made for Mr Gerbeau. Disney reports covering his time there do not list him as a vice-president, as dome publicity material claims, and his ex-colleagues insist he was merely a director of operations looking after ticket booths, rides, parking and basic customer relations like lost children and first aid.

Mr Gerbeau had been out of work since September after finishing an MBA course in Paris. During his time at Disneyland sources estimate he earned around £35,000 a year - a somewhat samller sum than the £100,000 with the prospect of the same amount in bonus for a year's work in London.

Bob Ayling, who is also chairman of British Airways, denied Mr Gerbeau's qualifications for the job had been exaggerated. "The information given to Brunswick and disseminated by them fairly describes the calibre and character of Pierre-Yves Gerbeau." He said the confusion over whether Mr Gerbeau was a vice president of Disney or an operations director was understandable. "Disney had a very flat structure. He was a vice president. It may seem confusing to the outside world, but inside the company he was a director and outside he was a vice president.

"He had a VP card for outside and another one for inside. This was authorised by chief executive officer, so his colleagues would not have known about it. PY feels that these quibbles over titles are irrelevant. What is important is that he is endorsed by the two most important people in the Disney organisation."

Asked about why he was not named with other vice presidents in the Disney annual report, he said, "He was away the day the photo was taken."
