webTitle: Rollercoaster ride of Disney whizz kid

fields.headline: Rollercoaster ride of Disney whizz kid
fields.standfirst:
How 'bossy' Jennie Page was sacrificed for the man from Paris

The millennium: special report
fields.trailText: When Liam Kane - who was last night still managing director of the dome - appeared before the press last Friday to confirm that the first month at the dome had a been flop, his face was as grey and crumpled as his suit.
fields.body:
When Liam Kane - who was last night still managing director of the dome - appeared before the press last Friday to confirm that the first month at the dome had a been flop, his face was as grey and crumpled as his suit.

But it was not just the miserable figures, or the fact that he was having to keep a straight face as he explained how the break-even target had been dropped from 12m to 10m visitors, which shook him.

It was one fairly innocent question which twisted his guts. "Where's Jennie?"

The dome's bustling, bossy, school marmish chief executive, Jennie Page, had been a fixture of briefings in the large windowless room inside a box of prefabricated offices at north Greenwich. Ms Page had relished these encounters with the carpers and doubters of the press. But bluff Ms Page was at that very moment uncharacteristically crying her eyes out as she cleared her desk at the New Millennium Experience Company's headquarters near Victoria.

The night before she had had a meeting with Bob Ayling, the chairman of the dome board, which even by her standards was stormy. Mr Ayling had delivered an ultimatum: resign or be sacked.

Having come through a hostile meeting with sponsors the evening before, and survived another clash with Lord Falconer, the minister for the dome and her biggest shareholder, Ms Page was taken completely by surprise. Although she knew that Mr Ayling had given young Pierre-Yves Gerbeau a tour of Greenwich the previous week, she had no idea that he was her replacement. The plan, insiders say, was for Mr Gerbeau to work alongside her.

Precise accounts of what passed between Ms Page and Mr Ayling are hard to come by, but what is clear is that "voices were raised and the language was lively". In the confusion of their heated exchange, Ms Page left the room without having either resigned or been sacked, and is believed to have retreated to her bungalow on Rutland Water. Many, including present and ex-members of the dome board, felt she had been made a scapegoat for an "impossible brief" from Peter Mandelson, the minister who at the start had taken a huge interest in the dome's controversial contents.

A week later, it is her replacement, 34-year-old ex-Disney "whiz kid" PY Gerbeau, who is about to do the bloodletting. A dome spokesman said last night he was preparing "very big changes", and hinted that there would be high-level casualties.

However, with questions about his own track record mounting, and the dome board admitting that they may have "overhyped" his abilities, many are asking will he himself survive.

PY, as he likes to be called, had started so well, with glowing recommendations from his friend and mentor Philippe Bourguignon, the man who really did save Disneyland Paris, and his successor at the theme park, Gilles Pelisson. He had a stroke of great "luck" when the French film star Gerard Depardieu and his model-turned-actress wife Carole Bouquet turned up at the dome "by accident" to say that it was "fantastic", and that PY was the man for the job.

Depardieu is in London working on a new Disney film, 102 Dalmations, and has made numerous promotional appearances at Disneyland Paris.

Mr Gerbeau had been wooed by Mr Ayling a fortnight ago, the dome confirmed last night, on the recommendation of Mr Bourguignon, now the head of Club Med. Mr Gerbeau had done his MBA dissertation on the miracle his hero had worked at the failing holiday firm.

He accepted the post from Mr Ayling a week later - while riding on the London Eye wheel, rumour has it.

Even for a man who had shot up the ranks at Disney "like an Exocet", as one of his former colleagues termed it, this was dizzying indeed. For the Guardian has learned that Mr Gerbeau was earning a salary of around £35,000 when he left the theme park in December 1998 to go back to college. Now he was being paid £100,000, with the promise of the same again if he succeeded.

"If anyone can do it, PY can," a colleague who worked alongside him at Disney until his departure said. "I wish him the best. But I just wish these claims were not made for him. They are disrespectful to other people. I like PY, he was a great motivator - his team adored him - but he was power-hungry. He can be ruthless."

Last night, Mr Gerbeau's spokesman admitted that "he says himself, 'I have big mouth and I fired a few people, and that doesn't make you popular.' But Disney was a very competitive organisation and he had to get things done."

Tall and well-built, Mr Gerbeau got his sharp elbows from playing professional ice hockey in his early 20s. "Slamming" opponents against rink walls is almost a part of the rules.

All of his colleagues at the park, where he rose in quick succession from a poorly paid assistant manager, to an attraction manager and then director of operations earning around £25,000, speak with admiration of his management skills, how he would volunteer to work every New Year's Eve, and even sleep in the park.

"PY's problem, however", said one, "is that he burns bridges wherever he goes. With American companies you can get promoted very quickly if you step on enough heads, but PY stepped on too many. He got rid of a lot of people who were more intelligent than him, who might put him in the shade. That is his weakness. That said, I hope he does turn around the dome."

Rumours flew when he left in November 1998 to do the nine-month MBA course at Sciences Po, one of France's leading "grandes ecoles". Unusually, Disney paid for the £10,000 course.

Mr Gerbeau has made no secret of the fact that he actually applied to do an MBA at the top-of-the-rung Insead institute in Fontainebleau, but he was still happy to be accepted at Sciences Po.

There, he was by all accounts, a model student. "PY was very, very hard working and even more ambitious than most of the people who do this course," said one fellow graduate who asked not to be identified. "He was very people-oriented. You could tell he worked for Disney because he often wore Mickey Mouse ties and had a Mickey pencil case too."

He finished in September, since when he has been unemployed, though he claims he was offered several jobs before the dome one came up. "Disney wanted to get him back," a dome spokesman said, "though they could not find a senior enough post for him. The reason he did the MBA was that if you want to go up in the Disney organisation you need one."

When he graduated in November, it was as second in his class, the university say, though Mr Gerbeau insists he was joint first. "The other guy had only 0.04 or so more marks," the dome spokesman said. Even so, it was quite an achievement.

He will have to defy the odds again if he is to save the dome.

The puzzles around Pierre

 Why was Pierre-Yves Gerbeau described by dome executives as "the saviour of Disneyland Paris" when he was not even a member of the the Challenge 94 team who rescued the theme park?

 Why was he described in the official announcement of his appointment on behalf of the New Millennium Experience Company as "working across the entire range of management functions relevant to running a world-class visitor attraction"? In fact, his job involved ticketing, parking, running the attractions and customer relations. He was not responsible for strategy, marketing, pricing, merchandising or public relations, all areas where the dome is seen to be wanting.

 Why was he described as being promoted five times at Disney "culminating in his role as vice-president"? Annual reports for the time he was there do not list him among the vice-presidents.

 Why was he described as "heading a team of six directors managing a team of up to 2,000 people"? Company management structures preclude directors being in charge of other directors.

 Why was he said to have been "awarded an MBA at Sciences-Po (college) Paris achieving the top position in his class"? The college has confirmed that he came second.

 Why was his salary in the region of £35,000 when he finished at Disney?

 Why was he "let go" by Disney in 1998 to enrol on the MBA course and then not re-employed upon graduation?

 Why did it take him five months to find a job after finishing the course?

webTitle: An everyday story of complacent folk

fields.headline: An everyday story of complacent folk
fields.standfirst: Life in parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Gay week continued in parliament yesterday, with a debate on the homosexual age of consent. When the topic was last considered, under the Tories, most MPs declared themselves to be "speaking for common sense", backing the silent majority, that noisiest of pressure groups.
fields.body:
Gay week continued in parliament yesterday, with a debate on the homosexual age of consent. When the topic was last considered, under the Tories, most MPs declared themselves to be "speaking for common sense", backing the silent majority, that noisiest of pressure groups.

Yesterday they told us, at considerable length, how tolerant and inclusive they were. One, John Bercow, a Tory who always looks as if he is tugging at an imaginary Rottweiler on a piece of string, announced his conversion to the lower age with all the gusto of a Millwall hooligan who's switched to Charlton.

This new touchy-feely, caring Commons makes a most satisfactory change, but to an old cynic like me is just further proof that political fashions change almost as quickly as hemlines.

In the last debate, Edwina Currie was the heroine, speaking bravely against the jeers of openly bigoted colleagues. Yesterday I felt a quiet spasm of admiration for Teresa Gorman's speech against change. I thought she was wrong, but it takes guts to stand up against the complacent majority.

Before the debate we heard Nick Brown, the agriculture secretary, answering questions for the first time since he was attacked by a woman wielding a chocolate eclair. And I'm afraid that there is something that makes one yearn to assault Mr Brown with baked goods.

Perhaps it's that round, bland, expressionless moon face. Perhaps it's his failure to get aroused by anything apart from the failures of the Tories. There is nothing more infuriating than someone who is never infuriated.

Take, for example, the question asked by the admittedly overexcited Tim Yeo, the Tory agriculture spokesman. He wanted to know what Mr Brown planned to do about reports from France that BSE safeguards are inadequate. For years there has been a drip of evidence suggesting that the French have handled their mad cow crisis by the handy expedient of pretending it doesn't exist.

But it would take a line of demented French cattle doing a conga down the Channel tunnel for Mr Brown to admit there was a problem, still less tackle it.

"These issues are not easy," he said. "The answer is to work constructively with people who understand these things and work towards a solution."

"Supine!" shouted a Tory, and one sometimes suspects that Mr Brown does suffer from a disease called supine boviform encephalopathy. He roused himself to a mild state of peevishness: "I think remarks like that do not come easily from the Conservative party," he muttered. Personally, I would have been tempted to slap him in the chops with a Black Forest gateau, box his ears with vanilla slices, decorate his head with a pavlova, and pour a jug of cream over the whole thing.

Mr Yeo had another pop, over the labelling of overseas pork, long promised but not delivered.

"Perhaps the minister is too busy writing scripts for the Archers!" said Mr Yeo sarcastically, a reference to the way the show's characters were lavish in their praise for Tony Blair the very day he was being booed and jeered by real farmers.

Frankly, if I wanted to put a Downing Street spin into The Archers it would be more fun. Take the notorious shower scene of a fortnight ago, in fact a discussion of plumbing problems which made the fatstock prices sound like Lady Chatterley.

In my version Jolene is soaping her naked body with gel. "Ooh, Sid, in this steam you look all different, you do!"

"That's because I am not Sid, but Tory spokesman Tim Yeo, planning to father a third love child!"

Mr Yeo had another pop, over the labelling of overseas pork, long promised but not delivered. "Perhaps the minister is too busy writing scripts for the Archers!" said Mr Yeo sarcastically, a reference to the way the show's characters were lavish in their praise for Tony Blair the very day he was being booed and jeered by real farmers. Frankly, if I wanted to put a Downing Street spin into The Archers it would be more fun. Take the notorious shower scene of a fortnight ago, in fact a discussion of plumbing problems which made the fatstock prices sound like Lady Chatterley. In my version Jolene is soaping her naked body with gel. "Ooh, Sid, in this steam you look all different, you do!" "That's because I am not Sid, but Tory spokesman Tim Yeo, planning to father a third love child!"

webTitle: Israel and Syria jostle for the best view from Golan

fields.headline: Israel and Syria jostle for the best view from Golan
fields.standfirst:
Israeli soldiers quit south Lebanon this summer. Much is left to do

Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: An Israeli conscript in south Lebanon told a journalist this week: "Nobody wants to be the last soldier to die in Lebanon." Another said that "the sooner we fly away from here the better". Such sentiments reveal a young Israel that has no answer to the question: "Why are we in Lebanon?"
fields.body:
An Israeli conscript in south Lebanon told a journalist this week: "Nobody wants to be the last soldier to die in Lebanon." Another said that "the sooner we fly away from here the better". Such sentiments reveal a young Israel that has no answer to the question: "Why are we in Lebanon?" and wants no more of an endless war in a zone which could have been designed expressly to demonstrate the limitations of military power.

The Israelis effectively annexed this slice of Arab territory in 1984 as they withdrew after the Lebanon war. It became a theatre in which the Israelis and their south Lebanese allies contended with the increasingly well-equipped Hizbullah militia, which also developed over those years into a political and social movement throughout Lebanon. The zone has been as much fly paper for Israel's own young men as it has been a deterrent to attacks on northern Israel. Ehud Barak, the Israeli prime minister, is committed to withdrawal from Lebanon by this summer with or without a peace agreement between Syria and Israel. But he desperately needs that agreement because, without it, withdrawal might simply set the stage for a new war on the border with Hizbullah.

Peace with Syria is of course a prize whose value goes far beyond ending the bloodletting in the security zone. Together with a consequential agreement with the Lebanese and with a final settlement with the Palestinians, it would complete the long, halting movement away from war that began with the Israeli-Egyptian peace in 1979. It would not end hostility between Arabs and Israelis, but, especially if the Palestinian settlement is crafted more justly than at the moment seems likely, it would make the Middle East a more comfortable place for Israel. For Syria, peace is almost equally desirable. The loss of the Golan Heights in the 1967 war compromised the legitimacy of a regime which had spoken grandly of liberating all Palestine but instead failed to protect its own territory, and Hafez Assad inherited that problem when he became undisputed Syrian leader. By the early 90s, after the Russians ceased to be a factor, it was clear to him that the Golan could only be restored to Syrian rule through a new relationship between Syria and the United States and a settlement with Israel. For America an Israeli-Syrian bargain would crown years of mediation efforts, and it would help sustain President Clinton's claim to have been successful in international affairs, and, by extension, buttress Gore's campaign.

If Barak, Assad, and Clinton all want a peace agreement, why are we in the present mess? The talks that began hopefully, if belatedly, in Washington in December had by January been suspended by Israel, on the grounds, apparently, that Syria would not discuss issues of security and water until absolute clarity had been achieved on the territory it would receive in the event of an agreement. The Israelis want arrangements on permitted military deployments and on surveillance which would make surprise attack difficult, and they want a bargain on the Golan's substantial water resources. The Syrians see Israel's demands on these matters as excessive, but in any case will not talk in detail until the territorial issue is locked up. The suspension was followed by a sudden flurry of Hizbullah attacks, and those attacks led to Israeli retaliation, including the bombing of Lebanese power stations.

There is controversy over who broke the "rules" of engagement between Hizbullah and the Israelis. This code permits action against military targets, as long as it is not launched from civilian settlements, and forbids action against civilian targets inside and outside the zone, like Israeli towns, or Lebanese power stations. Israel may or may not be right in saying that Hizbullah attacks came from villages, which would be a violation, but most agree that the Israeli reaction was grossly disproportionate. A round of hostilities could develop which would diminish the chances that the negotiations will resume. A peace which had seemed close might then be added to the Middle East's long list of "missed opportunities", for Clinton will soon be a lame duck even in foreign affairs, Assad is ailing, and Barak has been weakened by scandal, as has his ally on Syrian peace, President Ezer Weizman.

It is hard to believe that Syria was completely unaware of Hizbullah's dispositions. But Damascus did not necessarily plan the attacks as a means of putting pressure on the Barak government. Hizbullah has had new weapons from Iran, its other outside patron, in recent months. The arrival of new weapons with better range and penetration could, conceivably, have set all this off as Hizbullah fighters saw and seized tactical opportunities.

There is another explanation. US intelligence, according to the Washington Post, has noted a pattern of increased Iranian support for both Hizbullah and Hamas consistent with an effort to disrupt the peace process. As usual with Iran, such actions are rarely undertaken by the whole government, and they could even be part of the manoeuvring over elections there. It would not be the first time the Iranians have acted in such a way. Their encouragement of Hizbullah and Hamas in 1996 helped bury an earlier effort to achieve an Israeli-Syrian peace agreement.

One of those involved in that effort was Itamar Rabinovich, the chief Israeli negotiator. He wrote later, in his study of why the four years of negotiations between 1992 and 1996 failed, that "for adversaries like Israel and Syria to make the difficult decisions that produce an agreement, a combination of pain and hope is required. The pain makes the status quo unbearable, the hope and vision of a better future facilitate the decision".

This time round there is both more pain and more hope, and thus a better chance of success. But Rabinovich also marked a difficulty touching both sides, which is that peace has to be presented to the public in each country in a way that meets their preoccupations and prejudices, or as he put it with regard to the Syrians, with "a very particular definition of peace and the procedure that led to it". What the two sides demand, in other words, may be less what they objectively need than what they think their publics can bear. Syria's preoccupation with territory and sovereignty clashes with Israel's preoccupation with highly visible arrangements for security. It may well be possible to close off the present round of violence and get back to the table, but unless these critical differences of presentation can be finessed, what both countries want may nevertheless continue to elude them.

The Brink Of Peace by Itamar Rabinovich is published by Princeton University Press.

fields.headline: Straw hard line on hostages
fields.standfirst:
Free to stay? Home secretary to decide personally on asylum claims

Stansted hijack: special report
fields.trailText: Jack Straw last night promised he will personally decide the asylum claims of more than 70 of the hostages who were aboard the hijacked Afghan Boeing 727 but warned that he wanted to see all those who were on the plane removed from Britain as soon as practicable.
fields.byline: Alan Travis, Will Woodward and Paul Kelso
fields.body:
Jack Straw last night promised he will personally decide the asylum claims of more than 70 of the hostages who were aboard the hijacked Afghan Boeing 727 but warned that he wanted to see all those who were on the plane removed from Britain as soon as practicable.

Although home office sources last night were close to ruling out a forced return of any of the hostages to the Taliban regime in Afghanistan, it is clear the home secretary believes the asylum claims are bound to fail because the hijacked plane started as an internal flight. Pakistan is a possible destination as a "safe third country" but officials indicated it will be difficult to persuade Islamabad to take the hostages.

Mr Straw's tough stance came in the face of accusations that the hijacking was an elaborate scam to claim asylum in Britain. But the home secretary was also warned by human rights groups that the Taliban regime's record of massacres, executions and amputations of political opponents meant he should give careful consideration to each case. It could take eight weeks to decide the fate of those hostages who apply for asylum but the process may drag on for months if cases become bogged down in repeated appeals.

Home office sources confirmed there will be difficulties in persuading a third country to take them and some lawyers may allege that Mr Straw's Commons statement yesterday prejudged their legal cases.

"While I must act in accordance with the law, I am determined that nobody should consider that there can be any benefit to be obtained by hijacking," he told MPs.

"Subject to compliance with the legal requirements I would wish to see removed from this country all those on the plane as soon as practicable. This was an internal flight from Kabul to Mazer-e-Sharif, a small centre without any connections anywhere outside Afghanistan. In such circumstances it seems inconceivable that persons on the flight intended to claim political asylum unless of course they were complicit in the hijacking."

The 21 people arrested yesterday for being directly involved in the hijacking were last night being questioned by Essex police. Some face a life sentence in a British prison. The remaining 130 passengers were being cared for and interviewed by police at the Stansted Hilton hotel across the road from the hijacked aeroplane. All are being treated as potential witnesses for any criminal prosecutions and police said there could be more arrests.

Sixty people and 14 of their dependents yesterday announced their intention to seek asylum. Another 72 of the passengers "have not yet made their wishes clear," the home office said.

A Kampuchea Air plane is expected to fly from Bangkok to return those former hostages who want to go back to Afghanistan, although no firm timetable has been fixed.

Police were still trying to establish whether the former passengers of the Ariana jet include members of a 35-strong family who were reportedly on their way to a wedding in northern Afghanistan.

Sources said some of those arrested had been pointed out by other passengers. Others gave themselves up as members of the hijack team, which until yesterday was believed by police to number between six and 10. But there are suspicions that some of those who identified themselves as being involved with the hijacking may have done so because they believed it would be easier to claim asylum.

The 727 jet remained on the tarmac at Stansted last night and was undergoing forensic examination. Police found four handguns, one knuckle-duster, two grenades and two detonators on board.

Essex police were jubilant about the peaceful resolution of the hijacking crisis, the third major one at Stansted, London's designated hijacking airport, since 1982.

Police negotiators were in almost constant contact with the hijackers since the plane arrived at Stansted at 2.01am on Monday.

About 190 people, including 15 crew, boarded the plane at Kabul at 5.30am, British time, on Sunday. The plane was hijacked shortly afterwards and taken to Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan and Moscow, before leaving for London on Sunday night.

When the plane arrived at Stansted, 164 people were on board. Before yesterday, 10 had been released by negotiation and four crew, including the captain, had escaped.

fields.headline: Biased towards the bully
fields.trailText: Commiserations on the most lopsided leader I have seen in 25 years of Guardian reading (All losers in Lebanon, February 9). You seem to forget that the Golan Heights are Syrian territory illegally occupied by Israel, as is the so-called "security belt" in southern Lebanon.
fields.body:
Commiserations on the most lopsided leader I have seen in 25 years of Guardian reading (All losers in Lebanon, February 9). You seem to forget that the Golan Heights are Syrian territory illegally occupied by Israel, as is the so-called "security belt" in southern Lebanon. You also seem to forget that Israel has ignored numerous UN resolutions calling on it to withdraw from both territories. (Remember what happened to Iraq when it ignored UN resolutions?)

The hatred in southern Lebanon is largely a byproduct of 25 years of illegal Israeli occupation. I am no apologist for the Syrian president, Hafez Assad, (my memory of what he did to the Palestinians in Tal el-Zaater in 1976 and to his own people in Hama in 1982 is too fresh for that) but facts are facts. It may be fashionable these days to see the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, as an enlightened liberal who is genuinely interested in peace, but he differs from his predecessor, Binyamin Netanyahu, only in style. There can be no genuine and lasting peace in the Middle East as long as the military balance between Israel and its Arab neighbours is as lopsided in Israel's favour as your leader.

As for the Syrian newspaper Tishreen's comments about the Holocaust, most of us Arabs rarely read, let alone take seriously, any state-owned newspaper in the Arab world.

We too have suffered from the consequences of what the Nazis did to the Jews, because their murderous actions gave a boost to the Zionist movement. But, stripped from its insensitive language, Tishreen does have a point, one with which many Jews would agree. The Holocaust memorial, museum etc are part of what Dr Norman Finkelstein (a Jew whose parents are survivors of Maidanek and Auschwitz) calls the Holocaust industry, which uses the memory of Nazi victims to bludgeon critics of Israel. That is it in a nutshell.
Dr Mohamed El-Doufani
Berks

 How can you argue that Syria has been inflexible in its negotiating stance when your very own correspondent, David Hirst, wrote on the same day (Analysis, February 9), apropos the recent Syrian-Israeli talks in Shepherdstown that "a leaked US document showed that while Syria has become much more conciliatory on most issues, the Israelis would not even use the word 'withdraw' only 'redeploy'. And 'redeployment' would exclude civilians which appeared to mean that Israeli's Golan settlements would remain".

Not only do you distort the facts relating to the stalling of the Syrian-Israeli negotiations (the most important being Israel's refusal to seriously discuss withdrawal from the Golan, the sine qua non for any peace agreement) but you also, incredibly, appear to justify Israel's recent attacks on civilian targets in Lebanon.

These attacks are in so-called retaliation for the Lebanese resistance's successes against military targets in the area of south Lebanon occupied by Israel. Such resistance is legitimate and accepted as such even by Israel which, with the United States, France, Syria and Lebanon was a party to the "April understanding" reached nearly four years ago to govern the rules of engagement in south Lebanon.
Ghayth N Armanazi
Head of London Mission, The League of Arab States

 Western press coverage of the Middle East is like coverage of South Africa used to be: massive, largely sympathetic coverage if whites were killed or maimed, and indifference or no coverage at all when it was blacks.
Janet Salmon
Richmond, Surrey

fields.headline: Good day, bad day
fields.standfirst: Life in Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Good day
fields.body:
Good day

Mo Mowlam. She added to her reputation as a populist politician with an appearance on Channel 4's So Graham Norton comedy chat show to be broadcast tonight. Aside from giving away a bearded collie in a bizarre dog "wedding", Mo slipped up when talking about the responsibilities of her current role as cabinet office minister by saying: "I've got a very demanding job now. I do drugs."

Quote of the day

"I wonder whether for the benefit of those of us who've led a sheltered life you would describe the act of buggery so that the house and the public ... know exactly what we are talking about?" Tory Christopher Gill, raising the tone with a question to Jack Straw in the age of consent debate.

Today

Commons: Second reading of licensing (young persons) bill, and sex discrimination (amendment) bill.

fields.headline: Facing both ways
fields.standfirst:
Tony Blair is the push-me-pull-you premier, half devolutionist, half control freak.

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair is the push-me-pull-you premier, half devolutionist, half control freak.
fields.body:
Oh the glee! The joy of most commentators was unconfined at the spectacle of the prime minister's white-faced loss of grip at the dispatch box, tripped up at last by his personal fatal flaw - control freakery. The fall of his man in Wales was the ultimate symbol of Blair's push-me-pull-you control dilemma. How can the same man want the tightest grasp on the reigns of power and yet also be the great devolver who has thrown Westminster power to the winds? It has been the unresolved puzzle of Blairism from the start.

New Labour was forged from the instinct to control, the force that powered the electoral chariot sweeping them all into Westminster. Its discipline is still the wonder of a Europe made up of diverse coalition governments. When Tony Blair looks across the Channel he celebrates a control that is the envy of most other democratic leaders.

And yet now it is rebellion against that controlling impulse that is causing him his worst problems and losing him support where he needs to nurture it. Half his character is the great controller, driving his project onwards; the other half is the inclusive, flexible, pro-electoral reformer, devolver of power to levels where people can identify with it again: powerful independent mayors in the cities will each be a guaranteed thorn in the side of Westminster.

But if New Labour is ambivalent about control, so are the people. They may like to give prime ministers a good kicking in byelections and they may grumble about Westminister's monstrous power, but when it comes to general elections they love the thwack of firm government most of all. They admired Mrs Thatcher for the strength of her handbag arm more than anything she did. Pollsters note how voters score leaders for their authority not for their pluralism: "They like them to kick arse" - the way Tony Blair does and John Major didn't.

This government remains the most phenomenally popular since polls began - Mori's aggregate for the last quarter is 54% for Labour to the Tories' 27%. Tony Blair's personal rating dipped a bit but not significantly - 57% in December to 53% in January. Mid-term blues? Maybe, but less than ever recorded. As for control freakery, it barely features in public perception. It is just a chattering classes, Westminster, nerdy, party activist thing. The people actually like it, say the pollsters. Though how they will square desire for a strong prime minister with desire for a strongly independent local mayor is yet to be resolved.

In the end strength is the single most important quality in a government, a sine qua non. How else can they push through their manifesto on which the voters elected them? Without a strong, clear, central platform how do you know what you are voting for? Representative democracy depends on MPs obeying the party whip except in extremis: most people can't name their MP, but they know the party they voted for. This government has followed its manifesto pretty faithfully, which is the most democratic way to wield its power, and quite right too.

But none the less, over-reaching its wish to control everything that moves and breathes has led directly to the recent spate of disasters that begin, ironically, to suggest a government losing its grip. In the last week Number 10 has had so many wake-up calls the place is ringing like a demented alarm clock. The humiliation of "Welsh lackey" Alun Michael followed hard on the heels of Peter Kilfoyle's march back to Liverpool. Ceredigion voted Labour into fourth place. The "reformed" gay-bashing House of Lords turned out to be as disgusting and unrepresentative as before. Even if Dobson squeaks into London, he will now limp home as a duck lamed by the heavy-handed support of his leader.

Are lessons being learnt? Number 10 is navel gazing, asking the unthinkable - how could we still lose? No one in their right mind thinks they could, but it is the right question to ask. And some of the answers they are getting warn them that control freakery is a danger. Number 10 replies: "Control freaks? Us?" They protest they have far too little control over the message they try to put out. An almost wholly hostile press stands as a formidable barrier to any of the government's natural supporters knowing what is happening. How do you tell the world about your good works against this foghorn of abuse? Compare this with Mrs Thatcher's adoring media claque. All that is quite true. Despite its reputation, Labour is bad at spin and media control increasingly eludes their grasp. But if the total control model isn't working, it may be time to consider a different approach - letting go a bit and winning back some friends.

What might letting go mean? Take this example: Number 10 is beginning to worry that the government lacks endorsement from influential third parties. There are no longer any independent voices out there to support them. A large chunk of the voluntary sector and sympathisers from professions or other organisations have all been brought into the big tent, suborned and incorporated. Most are now directly in Labour's pay, sit on their task forces and think tanks or receive research funds from them.

But once inside the tent, the New Labour law of omerta is absolute. Criticism is not permitted. Rapid telephone calls expressing anger, suspicion or hurt follow any whisper of anything less than total support. It is astonishing how many basically Labour people no longer dare voice criticism except in an off the record whisper. This rebounds in the end on the government, because those who dare not criticise are also lost to the government as good, independent witnesses who can also offer their endorsement. More healthy and open debate from within the tent would strengthen, not threaten, Labour. And that includes the most important voluntary organisation of them all - the Labour party itself.

Democracy depends on elected government keeping control, but the worry is that this government squanders it recklessly, instead of saving it for the things that really matter. If the government itself cannot distinguish between the two, how will its supporters? By trying to control everything they risk endless petty rebellions that give out a dangerous impression of chaos. While pushing through key policies with an iron fist, Labour can let a few thousand flowers grow round the edges.

fields.headline: Fur flies
fields.trailText: Surely there is no ethical difference between farming animals for fur or for leather and meat and therefore anyone who is happy to wear leather shoes and eat meat should feel equally happy to wear farmed fur (This time it's for real, February 10).
fields.body:
Surely there is no ethical difference between farming animals for fur or for leather and meat and therefore anyone who is happy to wear leather shoes and eat meat should feel equally happy to wear farmed fur (This time it's for real, February 10). Should not campaigners be working for better conditions for farmed animals?
Helen Brophy
Etchingham, E Sussex

 The fur trade has succeeded in persuading a large number of fickle and callous designers to include some fur in their collections, but there is no evidence, in the UK at least, that fur sales are up. The fur trade should take note - Goliath came a poor second in their final showdown.
Mark Glover
Respect for Animals

fields.headline: Cannabis, that miracle medicine
fields.trailText: I am a 52-year-old male with multiple sclerosis and I've taken cannabis for therapeutic use for many years (Polly Toynbee, February 9). Before I used cannabis, I was prescribed a multiplicity of drugs, some of which left me at best disorientated, at worst, psychotic.
fields.body:
I am a 52-year-old male with multiple sclerosis and I've taken cannabis for therapeutic use for many years (Polly Toynbee, February 9). Before I used cannabis, I was prescribed a multiplicity of drugs, some of which left me at best disorientated, at worst, psychotic.

Last July I appeared as a witness for the defence in the trial of Colin Davies, from Stockport, who admitted growing and using cannabis to relieve pain from spinal injuries. He successfully pleaded a defence that he took the drug through medical necessity after suffering side effects from conventional drugs. During the trial, local public houses did a healthy trade, patronised by witnesses, solicitors, the police, and others.

Davies was arrested five days after Jack Straw rejected the recommendations of a House of Lords select committee that the use of cannabis should be allowed for medical reasons. Since then, ill people have continued to be prosecuted for using cannabis. A fellow MS sufferer in Cumbria is now awaiting trial. Criminalising ill people is in itself criminal.

Cannabis works for me and thousands of other ill people. Are we to be tainted with criminality? Will I have to buy medication of variable quality from drug peddlers?
Andrew Coldwell
Alliance for Cannabis Therapeutics Huddersfield

 Let people grow a couple of marijuana plants in their cupboards. Then there would be fewer greedy dealers to grow rich from prohibition and encourage people to try harder drugs. Moreover, a healthy supply of homegrown would end the need to add tobacco to joints. The many thousands of people who become hooked on nicotine through smoking spliffs would be spared. Student funding, meanwhile, would also become less of a problem.

As for ecstasy, lighter penalties for dealers who sell clean pills would be a cheap and intuitive move. Anyway, the police should be out catching real villains rather than swooping for soft target loved-up ravers. Polly Toynbee's article was inspired. Let us campaign to end this ridiculous prohibition.
Adam Mitchell
Nottingham university

webTitle: Young people need an even better deal

fields.headline: Young people need an even better deal
fields.trailText: Having been involved in the setting up of New Deal for Young People in one of London's most deprived boroughs, I agree with Mark Atkinson (One stop job shop, February 10) that the programme has been successful in enabling young people to secure employment. However, it could be even better if some small changes were made.
fields.body:
Having been involved in the setting up of New Deal for Young People in one of London's most deprived boroughs, I agree with Mark Atkinson (One stop job shop, February 10) that the programme has been successful in enabling young people to secure employment. However, it could be even better if some small changes were made.

First, the government needs to acknowledge that people with limited basic skills, particularly refugees, are highly unlikely to be job ready within a year. It is unrealistic to expect people to make up for 11 years' compulsory schooling in a one-year programme.

Second, the government should allow people to study for higher-level qualifications. It is perverse to deny motivated young people the opportunity to achieve higher-level qualifications and go to college simply because they are claiming Job Seekers' Allowance, particularly when the government has set targets for increasing the proportion of the adult population with level 3 and level 4 qualifications.

One early entrant to New Deal was a 19-year-old Somali youth who was studying science A-levels with the aspiration of going to medical school; he was allowed to continue his studies after the local college persuaded the Employment Service.

In another case, the college was not successful: a single parent who wanted to be a primary school teacher did sufficiently well on the pre-entry tests to be offered a place on an Access to Teaching course, but the ES refused to allow her to take the course because it would not lead directly to a job.
Sally Prentice
London

fields.headline: Disciplining doctors
fields.trailText: The General Medical Council president, Sir Donald Irvine, does its members a disservice by his description of it as having "a cosy club atmosphere". ('Cosy club' of doctors, February 10) When I joined as an elected member 11 years ago, I was impressed by the calibre of the members, both lay and medical, but despite pleasant lunches and conversations during tea and coffee breaks, I saw this as a bureaucratic but essentially serious organisation.
fields.body:
The General Medical Council president, Sir Donald Irvine, does its members a disservice by his description of it as having "a cosy club atmosphere". ('Cosy club' of doctors, February 10) When I joined as an elected member 11 years ago, I was impressed by the calibre of the members, both lay and medical, but despite pleasant lunches and conversations during tea and coffee breaks, I saw this as a bureaucratic but essentially serious organisation. Maybe as a woman (or seen as an outsider) I was not admitted to the "cosy club".

My experience of the professional conduct committee was not that doctors were being protected or that the medical members were "softer" on doctors than the lay members. There are problems with the process, and I have argued that we should make the reasons for our decisions clear so that both the doctor and the public would understand why some penalties were more severe than others.

One major problem with the GMC is that too much power is invested in the office of president. Although in recent years attempts have been made to involve ordinary members, the structure makes this difficult and I am glad that a review has been agreed. However, knee-jerk reactions to exceptional cases such as that of Dr Shipman and seeking to extend the power from parliament to suspend a doctor who has been accused of serious professional misconduct before this has been proved is a civil liberties issue. In such cases there should be a fast-track procedure to enable the evidence to be heard rather than depriving a doctor who may be found innocent of his or her livelihood and reputation.
Wendy Savage
St Bartholomew's, London
W.D.Savage@qmw.ac.uk

fields.headline: It's all in the gender
fields.trailText: The whole issue of compensation is indeed a queer one (Polly Vernon, February 10). A woman can be awarded more for the outrage of being denied the right to wear trousers to work than had she been raped
fields.body:
The whole issue of compensation is indeed a queer one (Polly Vernon, February 10). A woman can be awarded more for the outrage of being denied the right to wear trousers to work than had she been raped.
Douglas Porter
Norfolk
www.mimesweeper.com

 Re Lynn Walker's false allegation of rape: isn't it the case that where men are found to be lying or guilty as charged, the fact of their gender tends to be viewed as a neutral factor? Women found wanting, or worse, find their gender regarded as an exacerbating factor and punished as much for their unfeminine (aggressive, violent) or too "feminine" (catty, bitchy, "hell hath no fury") behaviour as for the crime itself.
Jackie Turner
Brighton

 One could say that the achilles heel of Sinn Fein is arms (Letters, February 9).
John O'Byrne
Dublin
haroldx@eircom.net

 I can remember one report of a few archaic arms being handed over by unionist paramilitaries. Have I missed all the other reports of their decommissioning?
John Williams
Lymington, Hants

 Andy Winter complains about the rip-off cost of a notepad from the Millennium Dome (Letters, February 10). At least it presumably still works. My daughter bought a cute little calculator for £2. It was broken by the time she got home.
Mike Crabtree
London

 "As zealous as a Zwinglian" indeed (Smallweed, February 5)! Any fule kno that it is "as zealous as a Zwinglist". (It declines as in Calvin. "Lutheran" is of course irregular. "Lutherist" would be daft.
Simon Lawton Smith
London

fields.headline: All eyes and ears
fields.standfirst:
Some snooping is justified, some is not

Freedom of information: special report
fields.trailText: With the heavy breath of the European court of human rights on its neck, a Conservative government back in 1985 belatedly agreed to bring state interception of communications under statutory control. Since then, both communication and interception techniques have grown beyond all recognition, so it makes good sense to update the 1985 law, as Jack Straw seeks to do in his regulation of investigatory powers bill.
fields.body:
With the heavy breath of the European court of human rights on its neck, a Conservative government back in 1985 belatedly agreed to bring state interception of communications under statutory control. Since then, both communication and interception techniques have grown beyond all recognition, so it makes good sense to update the 1985 law, as Jack Straw seeks to do in his regulation of investigatory powers bill.

If the process involves still further incursions into privacy, as it certainly does, the home office offers strong justifications. Take encryption. People we fear and detest - terrorists, dealers in deadly drugs, paedophiles - use codes to communicate. So methods for catching them at it must also advance, with those who defend our security given access to encrypted data. But the process, the home office promises, will be bulwarked with safeguards. All sorts of people snooping on us will be brought under control: employers, for instance, who monitor office switchboards to discover who is spending company money ringing bookies, or lovers. And where powers are misused, we have Lord Nolan as interception commissioner, overseeing the issue of warrants and inspecting the service; though it cannot be said that these forms of defence have looked watertight in the past.

We have to ensure the citizen's protection, but also the citizen's privacy, Mr Straw told us yesterday. His bill, he said, would do both. That claim must be rigorously tested when the bill comes to parliament. Authority to carry out surveillance looks to be spread disturbingly wide, extending to ill-defined areas not just in the police, the security, intelligence, customs and excise and other services, but in a string of government departments too, as well as the inland revenue and local authorities. Governments are usually keener on knowing all about us than they are on letting us know all about them. This one is no exception. We have been warned.

webTitle: Israeli government report admits systematic torture of Palestinians

fields.headline: Israeli government report admits systematic torture of Palestinians
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: The Israeli internal security service, Shin Bet, used systematic torture against Palestinians and regularly lied about it, according to an Israeli government report which has been released five years after it was written.
fields.body:
The Israeli internal security service, Shin Bet, used systematic torture against Palestinians and regularly lied about it, according to an Israeli government report which has been released five years after it was written.

The report covers the period 1988-1992, when Palestinian youths were mounting a sustained street revolt known as the Intifada. In response, Shin Bet ignored government interrogation guidelines allowing "moderate physical pressure" and went much further, with the worst abuses committed in prisons along the Gaza Strip.

The Israeli human rights organisation, B'Tselem, estimates that thousands of Palestinian detainees - some 85% - were subjected to torture. B'Tselem said that since the beginning of the Intifada, 10 Palestinians have died and hundreds have been maimed as a result of Shin Bet torture.

The Israeli state comptroller, Miriam Ben-Porat, conducted a study of Shin Bet practices and produced her report in 1995, blaming the chain of command under its director, Yaakov Peri.

"The irregularities were not, for the most part, the result of not knowing the line between the permissible and the forbidden, but rather were committed knowingly," the report says. "Veteran and even senior interrogators in the facility in Gaza committed severe and systematic deviations [from the regulations]."

But Mr Peri rejected the report's criticisms, saying that any violations of Shin Bet guidelines were dealt with and corrected at the time.

Gideon Ezra, a member of Likud, the rightwing opposition party, said: "The state comptroller had no way of knowing the impossible task facing the Shin Bet during that period."

The Ben-Porat report was presented in 1995 to a parliamentary sub-committee, which kept it secret until Wednesday, when a supreme court recommendation led to the publication of a brief summary. No Shin Bet officers were ever prosecuted for the abuses committed during the Intifada.

"It's better late than never," Bassam Eid, a Palestinian human rights activist, said of the report. "I really appreciate the Israeli state comptroller for researching it and bringing out. It proves what the human rights organisations were talking about - torture was systemic during the Intifada."

The published summary of the Ben-Porat report does not go into details about Shin Bet torture methods. But according to B'Tselem, which has interviewed hundreds of ex-detainees, the most common techniques were violent shaking, tying up prisoners in painful positions, subjecting them to extreme heat or cold, beating and kicking.

B'Tselem blames the widespread abuses on the government's 1987 Landau commission report, which allowed the use of "moderate physical pressure", including shaking of detainees, if investigators believed that the interrogation would uncover terrorist plots.

Yael Stein, a B'Tselem researcher, said yesterday: "We claimed for years that the minute you allow a little amount of physical pressure you can't limit that amount. Very quickly interrogators are going to use interrogation that is very much more severe."

The Landau commission rules were overturned last September by the Israeli supreme court. But some Israeli MPs are backing a new bill to reinstate the use of "moderate pressure" to help the security forces combat terrorism. The prime minister, Ehud Barak, has also expressed support for such a law.

B'Tselem has issued a policy paper opposing the reintroduction of physical interrogation techniques. It argues: "The supervisory mechanisms will not stop the slide down the slippery slope, which turns democracies into abhorrent regimes where security forces are above the law and immune from punishment whenever acts against Palestinian interrogees are involved."

Ms Stein said that since last year's supreme court ruling, they have not confirmed cases of Shin Bet use of torture. But B'Tselem is investigating claims that some interrogation is being "contracted out" to Palestinian collaborators not bound by Israeli law.

Mr Eid said he was investigating reports of torture of three Palestinian men from Bethlehem by Shin Bet officers. He said it was too early to judge whether the overturning of the Landau rules had led to the complete cessation of the Israeli use of torture.

Meanwhile, the use of torture by Yasser Arafat's Palestinian Authority is alleged to have become common in recent years.

"The irregularities were not, for the most part, the result of not knowing the line between the permissible and the forbidden, but rather were committed knowingly," the report says. "Veteran and even senior interrogators in the facility in Gaza committed severe and systematic deviations [from the regulations]." But Mr Peri rejected the report's criticisms, saying that any violations of Shin Bet guidelines were dealt with and corrected at the time. Gideon Ezra, a member of Likud, the rightwing opposition party, said: "The state comptroller had no way of knowing the impossible task facing the Shin Bet during that period." The Ben-Porat report was presented in 1995 to a parliamentary sub-committee, which kept it secret until Wednesday, when a supreme court recommendation led to the publication of a brief summary. No Shin Bet officers were ever prosecuted for the abuses committed during the Intifada. "It's better late than never," Bassam Eid, a Palestinian human rights activist, said of the report. "I really appreciate the Israeli state comptroller for researching it and bringing out. It proves what the human rights organisations were talking about - torture was systemic during the Intifada." The published summary of the Ben-Porat report does not go into details about Shin Bet torture methods. But according to B'Tselem, which has interviewed hundreds of ex-detainees, the most common techniques were violent shaking, tying up prisoners in painful positions, subjecting them to extreme heat or cold, beating and kicking. B'Tselem blames the widespread abuses on the government's 1987 Landau commission report, which allowed the use of "moderate physical pressure", including shaking of detainees, if investigators believed that the interrogation would uncover terrorist plots. Yael Stein, a B'Tselem researcher, said yesterday: "We claimed for years that the minute you allow a little amount of physical pressure you can't limit that amount. Very quickly interrogators are going to use interrogation that is very much more severe." The Landau commission rules were overturned last September by the Israeli supreme court. But some Israeli MPs are backing a new bill to reinstate the use of "moderate pressure" to help the security forces combat terrorism. The prime minister, Ehud Barak, has also expressed support for such a law. B'Tselem has issued a policy paper opposing the reintroduction of physical interrogation techniques. It argues: "The supervisory mechanisms will not stop the slide down the slippery slope, which turns democracies into abhorrent regimes where security forces are above the law and immune from punishment whenever acts against Palestinian interrogees are involved." Ms Stein said that since last year's supreme court ruling, they have not confirmed cases of Shin Bet use of torture. But B'Tselem is investigating claims that some interrogation is being "contracted out" to Palestinian collaborators not bound by Israeli law. Mr Eid said he was investigating reports of torture of three Palestinian men from Bethlehem by Shin Bet officers. He said it was too early to judge whether the overturning of the Landau rules had led to the complete cessation of the Israeli use of torture. Meanwhile, the use of torture by Yasser Arafat's Palestinian Authority is alleged to have become common in recent years.

webTitle: Money can buy you death, Serbia's new rich discover

fields.headline: Money can buy you death, Serbia's new rich discover
fields.standfirst:
Shootings a lifestyle downer for gangster society

Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: The killing this week of the Yugoslav defence minister, Pavle Bulatovic, is the latest in a series of mafia-style hits that have spread fear and panic through the political and financial elite of Belgrade.
fields.body:
The killing this week of the Yugoslav defence minister, Pavle Bulatovic, is the latest in a series of mafia-style hits that have spread fear and panic through the political and financial elite of Belgrade.

The absence of a ready explanation for the assassination and the fact that it happened less than a month after the killing of the paramilitary leader and gangster, Zeljko "Arkan" Raznatovic, has left Serbs asking, "Who next?"

Nerves are particularly frayed among the nouveaux riches of Belgrade. These are people who have made their money in the last 10 years through dubious deals and by busting sanctions imposed on Serbia by the United States and the European Union for the role played by Belgrade's leadership and military in promoting the ethnic war that ravaged Bosnia after 1992.

They call themselves "businessmen" but their business often consists of smuggling and running black market and protection rackets.

"To get really rich in Serbia you need good connections within the authorities and you should have good contacts with some gangs," said Bratislav Grubacic, a journalist and political analyst. "The only problem is that the money you earn is not just yours. You have to share it with those who protected you or those who gave you the opportunity to do the job."

The huge wealth amassed by this small group of individuals has given them considerable power and led them to believe that they are beyond the law. The rash of shootings since the start of the year has broken this illusion of invulnerability.

The new rich like to flaunt their wealth but they also like their privacy. Arkan had the money to buy himself the veneer of respectability and could be seen in public places such as the Intercontinental hotel where he met his death.

Lesser hoodlums prefer to lurk in private clubs, like La Coste in the affluent suburb of Dedinje. A couple of bruisers with thick necks and golden chains guarantee the screening of clientele.

A safer way to brush shoulders with the nouveaux riches is in the City Passage shopping centre. In these calm, marble-clad halls, exclusive Italian designer boutiques offer the monied of Belgrade a number of solutions to the dilemma of what to do with their cash. A pair of imitation tigerskin boots can cost £100. The average salary in Serbia is about £25 a month.

There has been an upsurge of interest in cosmetic surgery among Serbian high society. A number of politicians' wives have benefited from cosmetic surgery, including breast implants, liposuction and nose jobs. "These people have so much money they don't know what to do with it," said Bratislav Grubacic. "They've bought houses, they've bought cars, now they want to buy back their youth."

There is no shortage of wannabes, young men and young women who saw Arkan and his lavish lifestyle as a model to aspire to. Many girls have embarked on careers as models in the hope that their looks will take them places, preferably away from Serbia. In the meantime, there is at least the chance of earning some decent money: a model can earn more in a day than a factory worker can in a month.

"Unfortunately education and spiritual values don't matter in Serbia today," said Nebojsa Grncarski, a successful male model. "All that counts is money and material things. It doesn't matter how you get them: the end justifies the means."

A visit to the studios of TV Pink provides an introduction to the get-rich-quick values of Serbia under the Yugoslav presidency of Slobodan Milosevic. The television station belongs to a crony of the president's wife, Mira Markovic. Arkan's widow, the top folk singer, Ceca, used to make regular appearances. For aspiring actors and pop stars there's a simple lesson: if you want to get ahead, get on TV Pink.

"There's no big deal about being a celebrity in Yugoslavia," insisted a TV Pink presenter, Ivana Bojic, somewhat disingenuously. "But on the other side there is another level of the jet-set, people that I don't know and who don't want to be known."

And then, of course, there are the newly poor of Serbia. These are people who used to have a middle-class lifestyle, but whose standard of living has fallen steadily during the 10 years of Milosevic's rule.

They see no way out of the poverty trap and long for political change. But as long as the system continues to serve those who are rich and powerful now, things are likely to stay just as they are.

webTitle: UN fears Lebanon will be hit again - harder than ever

fields.headline: UN fears Lebanon will be hit again - harder than ever
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: "Do the Israelis think anyone with a beard belongs to Hizbullah?" asked Hassan al-Haj, a citizen of sedate and gentlemanly appearance I ran into just outside a building whose topmost, eleventh-floor apartment an Israeli helicopter rocketed on Tuesday night.
fields.body:
"Do the Israelis think anyone with a beard belongs to Hizbullah?" asked Hassan al-Haj, a citizen of sedate and gentlemanly appearance I ran into just outside the tallest building on Tyre's seafront corniche. This was the edifice whose topmost, eleventh-floor apartment an Israeli helicopter rocketed on Tuesday night.

Remarkably, the three residents were only wounded. They wore beards, said Mr Haj, because they were students in a local Shi'ite Muslim seminary; they were Lebanese, he said, but might just as well have been some of the Senegalese or Malians who study there too.

It would have been an odd place for Hizbullah militants to live, he noted, perfectly visible to the naked eye from a nearby Israeli-occupied area.

"I've nothing to do with Hizbullah," said Mr Haj, "but the fact is that they fight like men; they only kill Israeli soldiers in land that doesn't belong to them, while the Israelis don't care who and where they kill."

It is remarkable that no civilians on either side died in the past week's Israeli-Lebanese blow-up. But that is about the only positive element. The confrontation is cooling off now - after Hizbullah guerrillas killed several Israeli soldiers in occupied south Lebanon and Israel retaliated by bombing Lebanese power plants and other buildings including the Tyre high-rise. But almost all the auguries suggest that there will be more, and incrementally worse, to come.

Officials of the long-standing UN monitoring operation in southern Lebanon, Unifil, seem gloomily persuaded of that.

"The bombing of the power stations", said one, "was just the first shot in Barak's campaign to withdraw his army by July." As Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak has constantly reiterated that deadline for ending his country's occupation of south Lebanon; this has created expectations among soldiers and civilians alike.

"For the Israeli public", said another Unifil official, "Israel is just about out of Lebanon already. A prime minister can make excuses about many things but not about 'failing to bring the boys home' ... He must have a pull-out by July, or at most two months after that, or they'll bury him politically."

For logistical reasons, July means a decision by April. Mr Barak wants a withdrawal "by agreement", as an integral part of a peace settlement with Syria. Only with that can he hope for indispensable Syrian cooperation in the quelling of Hizbullah. But, with peace negotiations with Damascus deadlocked, the chances of such a withdrawal pact look slim indeed.

Another dilemma is Hizbullah's conduct - above all the fact, as Mr Haj said, that the guerrillas have been killing soldiers not civilians. "You can't say they [Hizbullah] now have a complete upper hand on the ground," said a Unifil official, "but when they really put their mind to it they achieve what they want."

Hizbullah's fighters have just made another very important gain, replacing their obsolescent Russian-made Sagger anti-tank missiles with American-made TOWs, and "they sure know how to handle them."

When the Israelis hit the power stations this week they anticipated Hizbullah would respond with its traditional weapon of last resort, Katyusha rocket salvos into northern Israel. But it didn't - and didn't need to. Within hours the guerrillas used a TOW to kill a sixth Israel soldier in a heavily defended hill-top post.

They will concentrate exclusively on military targets now: so Unifil officials predict, arguing that this is the smart thing to do and Hizbullah has been showing "amazing political maturity."

"Both sides do abuse the April [1996] understandings," said one official, referring to the American-brokered "rules" meant to confine the south Lebanon conflict to the occupied zone and exclude civilian targets. But whatever Israel and Washington may say, he added, Hizbullah stuck to those rules in its last four successful attacks.

This fits in with the Syrian and Lebanese governments' wishes. It looks much better internationally. And it does the least to alienate a Lebanese public deeply resentful at the way it is expected to suffer for other people's - including Syria's - purposes.

By not using Katyushas Hizbullah kept Israel's northern inhabitants in bunkers or in domestic exile, and the local economy paralysed, far longer than if it had. This economic toll on Israel was reported to be $2.4m (£1.5m) a day - small compared with Lebanon's endless ordeal, but significant for a society accustomed to much lower levels of pain.

And Hizbullah's discipline denied Israel the pretext to unleash its air force on even more devastating raids. "Actually," confided a Unifil official, "I think the Israelis didn't like the unexpected restraint at all."

Barring a breakthrough in the peace process, the only way, Unifil believes, that Israel can break a cycle of violence which, unchecked, risks turning any withdrawal into a humiliating shambles, is to secure a change in the "rules", making even military targets off-limits for Hizbullah. It is pressing for that.

The other way is to break the rules more drastically than the power stations blitz. Indeed, the deputy defence minister, Ephraim Sneh, yesterday asserted that Israel "has changed the rules". But it would have to use far greater force to make a unilateral withdrawal safe. "They'll have to hit Hizbullah, Lebanon, and Syria-in-Lebanon," said a Unifil official,"so very hard that they dare not raise their heads for another 20 years."

webTitle: Doctors warn of herb remedy risks

fields.headline: Doctors warn of herb remedy risks
fields.trailText: St John's wort, a herbal remedy used to treat skin injuries, burns and depression, is not as harmless as assumed, according to doctors who have found that it can react dangerously with Aids drugs and caused two transplant patients to reject their new hearts.
fields.body:
St John's wort, a herbal remedy used to treat skin injuries, burns and depression, is not as harmless as assumed, according to doctors who have found that it can react dangerously with Aids drugs and caused two transplant patients to reject their new hearts.

Two accounts are published in this week's Lancet medical journal warning that it is dangerous to assume complementary remedies are safe and will not interact with medicinal drugs.

Two Swiss heart transplant patients in their early 60s found their bodies began to reject the new organs when they took St John's wort for mild depression, one on the advice of a psychiatrist.

In each case, write Frank Ruschitzka and colleagues at the university hospital in Zurich, the patient was admitted for tests after three weeks on the herbal remedy. Doctors eventually found that the St John's wort was lowering the level of cyclosporin, an anti-rejection drug, in the blood. The situation was remedied when use of the herbal medicine ceased.

"The common misconception that herbs always equate with no risk must be effectively disproved," said the authors. "Hence, authorities should reconsider whether herbal medicines [as conventional drugs] need regulation and should be tested for safety, tolerability and efficacy".

Stephen Piscitelli and colleagues from the US National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Maryland, studied whether use of St John's wort would affect people who were HIV-positive and taking the protease inhibitor indinavir daily to keep the virus in check and prevent Aids. St John's wort was found to lower the concentration of indinavir in volunteers taking it for the tests, although they themselves were not HIV-positive.

It was important for patients to tell their doctors if they were taking any herbal remedies, said the researchers, but it was not just patients who believed herbs were harmless.

"Many clinicians consider complementary medicines to be inert. These products are rarely thought a cause of adverse effects or treatment failure, and often are not included in a drug history [the patient notes].

"This study shows that drug interactions with these products do occur and might have profound clinical consequences, especially in HIV-infected patients."

fields.headline: UK roundup
fields.trailText: War crimes conviction is upheld
fields.body:
War crimes conviction is upheld

Anthony Sawoniuk, 78, yesterday lost an appeal against his conviction for murder in the only successful war crimes prosecution in Britain. He stood impassive in the court of appeal as the lord chief justice, Lord Bingham, sitting with Mr Justice Tucker and Mrs Justice Hallett, ruled that the trial last year, under a law passed in 1991, for crimes committed in 1942 had not been an abuse of process.

Sawoniuk, a retired rail worker from Bermondsey in south London, was given two life sentences. He had killed 18 Jews in his home town of Domachevo in Belarus, while serving in a police force set up by the Nazis. Childhood friends of Sawoniuk flew to London to give evidence against him, and the jury visited Domachevo.

William Clegg, representing Sawoniuk, told the appeal court he had been convicted chiefly on the accounts of two local men. One, Alexander Baglay, had been 13 at the time and had not mentioned the shootings to anyone, including Soviet war crimes investigators, until 1996.

In a written judgment dismissing the appeal, the justices ruled that the trial judge, Mr Justice Potts, was right to proceed, even though the alleged crimes took place in 1942; they did not find the convictions unsafe on any of the grounds put forward.

Referring to Mr Baglay, Lord Bingham said: "It is not easy to imagine any event which, if witnessed, would impress itself more indelibly on the mind of a 13-year-old boy. The jury had to consider whether the witness was honest and reliable. They concluded that he was both."

He refused leave to appeal to the Lords, but Sawoniuk's lawyers can make an application direct. Nick Hopkins

Man facing custody loss killed son

A father who strangled his son aged seven "to put him out of his misery so he couldn't go anywhere else" was found guilty of murder and jailed for life yesterday.

Karl Hammersley-Baker, 31, a care assistant of Stoke-on-Trent, told Stafford crown court he had not intended to kill his son, Kirk.

Mr Justice Kay criticised his assertion that his son "would be alive now" but for a letter from a social worker, Richard Keane, which suggested he could lose custody of Kirk to the boy's mother.

The judge said: "Nothing in this case in any way makes me anxious about the conduct of social services." Mr Keane "was on the ball. He could never have known that this was going to happen."

The court heard that Kirk had been on a child protection register due to physical abuse by his mother's boyfriend and emotional abuse from his father. He was killed as he slept on March 19 last year.

Nigel Baker QC, prosecuting, said Hammersley-Baker "entertained" two gay lovers at his home as his son's "trussed-up" body lay in an outhouse. It was found by police on March 22.

Crackdown on housing associations

Measures aimed at preventing financial scandals that have bedeviled some publicly funded housing associations were announced by a government agency yesterday.

More searching inspections and a strict codes of ethics will be introduced, the housing corporation announced after a policy review. The corporation, which has placed 44 associations on so-called "special measures" because of financial problems, said it would not tolerate bad management.

Concern about associations, increasingly the main provider of public housing, has mounted as more councils prepare to sell their housing stock. Encouraged by the government, "stock transfers" will double in three years as cities such as Birmingham and Liverpool transfer houses to associations or non-profit making community companies; it is estimated that by 2005 they will own 2.5m homes.

The corporation, chaired by the former union leader, Baroness Dean, makes grants of £750m annually. In turn, the associations raise a similar amount from the private sector. Peter Hetherington

Nigel Baker QC, prosecuting, said Hammersley-Baker "entertained" two gay lovers at his home as his son's "trussed-up" body lay in an outhouse. It was found by police on March 22. Crackdown on housing associations Measures aimed at preventing financial scandals that have bedeviled some publicly funded housing associations were announced by a government agency yesterday. More searching inspections and a strict codes of ethics will be introduced, the housing corporation announced after a policy review. The corporation, which has placed 44 associations on so-called "special measures" because of financial problems, said it would not tolerate bad management. Concern about associations, increasingly the main provider of public housing, has mounted as more councils prepare to sell their housing stock. Encouraged by the government, "stock transfers" will double in three years as cities such as Birmingham and Liverpool transfer houses to associations or non-profit making community companies; it is estimated that by 2005 they will own 2.5m homes.
