webTitle: 'Thirty years of struggle are wasted if they have to hand over a single bullet'

fields.headline: 'Thirty years of struggle are wasted if they have to hand over a single bullet'
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Mention IRA decommissioning in republican south Armagh and eyes narrow. Handing in weapons would be tantamount to forcing the surrender of an army undefeated for 30 years, people say, and would leave them defenceless against loyalist death squads. And, they argue, the IRA guns are silent anyway.
fields.body:
Mention IRA decommissioning in republican south Armagh and eyes narrow. Handing in weapons would be tantamount to forcing the surrender of an army undefeated for 30 years, people say, and would leave them defenceless against loyalist death squads. And, they argue, the IRA guns are silent anyway.

They prefer to talk of demilitarisation, and they mean the British. They are fed up with 33 army and RUC bases ruining the stunning landscape, particularly since several were summarily placed on people's land in return for £89 annual rent.

As last-minute efforts to avert suspension of the assembly at Stormont seek to link IRA decommissioning to cuts in troop levels and military installations, many of south Armagh's 23,000 residents claim the benefits of the Good Friday agreement have passed them by. They suggest army and police training patrols have increased.

Henry McElroy, 39, points to the Glassdrummond installation at the bottom of his field, on the border with the Irish Republic. He says security forces have been building it up, rather than showing any signs of dismantling it.

Mr McElroy, who has logged more than 5,000 helicopter flights into the base since the IRA's second ceasefire in July 1997, says: "I've lost more than 400 sheep in the past few years. The army flies in and the helicopters scatter the animals. They run and get caught in fences or die terrified or get drowned."

His neighbour, beef farmer Peter Caragher, 41, says: "There was never any problem in this area until one day in 1972, three years after the Troubles started. Some bright spark looked at a map and decided to bring the army here. That was what created the IRA here, and the British security forces are the ongoing cause of tension."

His wife, Toni, 38, says: "All these lookout towers have been a failure anyway. All they have done is create targets. We are living in a war zone and have got nothing out of the agreement."

Mrs Caragher, an insurance broker, is secretary of the South Armagh Farmers and Residents Committee, set up two years ago to campaign for the closure of army and RUC bases. She is prepared to countenance IRA decommissioning only after the withdrawal of troops and bases and the introduction of an accountable police force.

"They have increased the training here," she says. "A helicopter will quite often come in low and lads too young to shave will clamber down a rope ladder, check a few cars, and then run 50 yards to a different spot to climb back inside. It is driving us mad."

The army disputes it is using south Armagh as a training area, and says it would cut its presence if the perceived security threat was lower. It points out that it now has 15,000 troops in Northern Ireland, the lowest number since 1970.

One source said: "Army foot patrols in Northern Ireland are one-quarter what they were at the time of the agreement. They now accompany police in four out of the RUC's 12 divisions. Helicopter flights have been halved. We've closed 35 bases out of 100.

"We believe the surveillance towers in south Armagh work. When they went up, the murder rate plummeted."

The army says it has returned land confiscated a quarter of a century ago from Crossmaglen Rangers, the Gaelic football side. But four families are still waiting to hear when they might get their land back.

One senior republican indicated the Irish government's attempts to link decommissioning and demilitarisation were doomed. He said there was no point in comparing army installations with IRA guns. "They can build a camp in two hours. How long would it take us to get 1,000 guns?"

Fergus Finlay, adviser to the former Irish foreign affairs minister Dick Spring, key architect of the Downing Street declaration and the joint framework documents, which were to lead to the agreement, said: "Those who have been trying to persuade the IRA to start the process of decommissioning know they are dealing with an entity to which nothing makes sense if the word 'undefeated' is taken away from them. In their terms, 30 years of struggle are wasted if they have to hand over a single bullet to the enemy."

Mr McElroy said: "There should be no attempt to link the issues. Demilitarisation should happen because the army is not welcome here. But to seek decommissioning is to demand IRA surrender.

"Why not let them leave the guns where they are? They have, after all, been out of commission for five years."

webTitle: We're fed up with waiting, both sides say

fields.headline: We're fed up with waiting, both sides say
fields.standfirst:
As frantic efforts continue to try to resolve the impasse over IRA decommissioning, loyalists and republicans give their views

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: When the 860 delegates of the Ulster Unionist council reconvene tomorrow at the Waterfront Hall in Belfast, there will be no one more moderate than Chris McGimpsey. He has backed the push towards devolution at every turn. No longer.
fields.body:
When the 860 delegates of the Ulster Unionist council reconvene tomorrow at the Waterfront Hall in Belfast, there will be no one more moderate than Chris McGimpsey. He has backed the push towards devolution at every turn. No longer.

Mr McGimpsey, 47, a father of four, says: "We have got to the point where enough is enough. We have done absolutely everything asked of us, and still we are waiting on republicans.

"I still believe the [Good Friday] agreement can work. But the institutions are worthless if the foundations are false. Everyone has to live up to their obligations, just as we have lived up to ours."

Mr McGimpsey's ties to the party are strong. His father was a councillor in Newtonards, Co Down, and he attended his first meeting when he was 12, three years before the Troubles started.

But he is a maverick within the party, a staunch socialist who disagrees with almost all its policies except on the constitutional issue. He is from middle class stock, but represents on Belfast city council the loyalist heartland of the Shankill Road, a working class area crucial in pushing unionism to deal with paramilitaries.

He doesn't chat much with Sinn Fein councillors, but he was one of the first Ulster Unionists to deal with them. He describes his relationship with them as business-like.

"I supported the agreement on balance," he said. "I had been proposing the general thrust of it 10 or 15 years ago, but I was concerned that because there was no linkage between decommissioning and the early release of paramilitary prisoners, it meant there was no sanction.

"We have moderated our position on decommissioning time after time, at risk to ourselves, to make it easy for republicans to comply with the agreement, and they keep shifting the goalposts. Remember Gerry Adams [the Sinn Fein president] telling David Trimble he wanted to jump together?

"We jumped first in November, believing we had a tacit agreement on IRA decommissioning in January. It now looks like republicans have been chancing it all along with Adams failing to show leadership. It really is an important issue. We know we would never get every bullet and every gun, but it would be a step of massive psychological importance. If a local commander hands in rifles, how can he then tell a volunteer to shoot a kid for joy riding?

"This isn't about surrender. It's about paramilitaries having the confidence and courage to move forward into a democratic future without Semtex and guns. And they want to hold on to them because it gives them social control of their own communities.

"If you are going to hop over the fence into democratic fields, you have to leave guns behind. They want to bring their weapons with them so that they can have it both ways.

"We can't make decommissioning happen. All we can do is create the conditions which will allow it to happen. You would be hard pushed now to find anyone who has the heart to continue. We feel we have been had."

webTitle: TV drag queens wince and bare it

fields.headline: TV drag queens wince and bare it
fields.trailText: Lady Miss Tiffany Delicious seems to be having a bit of trouble with her fishnets - but with thighs like hers, it's hardly surprising.
fields.body:
Lady Miss Tiffany Delicious seems to be having a bit of trouble with her fishnets - but with thighs like hers, it's hardly surprising.

In the cruel world of drag, a hole in your stockings could be the end of your career: for Miss Delicious this unforgivable sartorial imperfection cost her a place in the final of Tranny of the Year, where even the beads of sweat dripping down the back of the stage sparkle with glitter.

At the London club Heaven in the early hours of yesterday, twin-set transvestism was being firmly laid to rest. "It's not like Lily Savage, it's not Danny La Rue, these are gorgeous people," said Katherine Allen, producer of the event.

Channel 5 is staging the show - next month's final will be screened as part of a cross-dressing theme night on March 10. Producers have scoured the country in search of the best of the nation's guys who want to be girls.

"There are three types of transvestites: there are those who are married with kids, and none of their friends or family know; there are guys who want to be girls; and there are drag queens who get off on looking fab. It's the last of these who we are celebrating," said Ms Allen.

Before the contestants went on stage, they had been rehearsing for 12 hours. Of the eight who took part, only four would be selected for the final.

The youngest was 18-year-old David (Davina) Willis, who has been cross-dressing since he was at sixth-form college.

Evita Clitorina (really Alberto Rodriguez, 27), claims that straight men have a fascination with drag queens. "It is a turn-on for them, it's a fantasy, a woman with a dick."

For those of us judging, it was a cruel choice. It was decided to award top marks to two contestants - to Dee Chanell for realism ("She looks like real fish, man," screamed hostess Miss Kimberley) and to Evita for showwomanship.

She got my vote, if only for her reply to the crucial question - "What do you do with, you know, 'it'?"

In a grimace to make any man wince, she drawled: "Look at my face dar-link, am I smiling?"

fields.headline: Ministers seek wide bugging powers
fields.standfirst: Freedom of information: special report
fields.trailText: Sweeping powers allowing the intelligence services and other government agencies to conduct covert surveillance, including bugging phones and property, were proposed by the government yesterday.
fields.body:
Sweeping powers allowing the intelligence services and other government agencies to conduct covert surveillance, including bugging phones and property, were proposed by the government yesterday.

For the first time, they would have a statutory power to intercept pagers, mobile and satellite phones, and email, as well as private networks, including office switchboards.

They would also be able to require people to provide the key or the plain text of encoded internet communications if there were "reasonable grounds" to believe these were related to criminal acts. But critics of the regulation of investigatory powers bill said the new power could be open to abuse.

Charles Clarke, the home office minister, said the measure would allow the police and other agencies to keep up with the increasingly sophisticated technology used by organised criminal gangs.

It would also place covert activities already undertaken by the security and intelligence services on a regulated, statutory basis, to make them compatible with the European convention on human rights, which will be incorporated into English law on October 2.

There were some "extremely fuzzy" areas which could now be open to challenge under the convention, said Mr Clarke.

The bill covers a wide range of intrusive surveillance techniques, including systematic targeting of an individual over a period of time in order, as the home office puts it, "to obtain a picture of his life, activities and his associates". It includes the bugging of private property and cars, and the use of "covert human intelligence sources" - informants or undercover officers.

It will include activities well beyond those of the security and intelligence services and the police. Ministers will be able to issue orders allowing many other agencies to undertake covert surveillance.

They include the departments of health and social security, the ministry of agriculture, and the department of trade and industry as well as local authorities.

While the bill says that warrants for intercepting communications would still be signed by cabinet ministers, authorisation for other forms of surveillance would be given by senior police officers or even local authority officials.

Mr Clarke concentrated on what he called "sophisticated international organisations" with access to the most powerful technologies. Paedophile networks, for example, were using encryption to protect material on computers. The home office, meanwhile, said that phone tapping had enabled customs officers to seize 1.25 tonnes of class A drugs during a recent 12-month period.

The bill sets up the post of a covert investigations commissioner to monitor the issuing of warrants and a new complaints tribunal.

Liz Parratt, for Liberty, the civil rights group, said that the European court of human rights had always emphasised the importance of prior judicial sanction for warrants rather than authorisation by a politician or police officer.

"And in their current form powers to recover encryption keys risk reversing the burden of proof. But, overall, efforts to introduce a consistent regulatory framework in this area should be welcomed."

webTitle: Women and wealthy crowd football clubs

fields.headline: Women and wealthy crowd football clubs
fields.trailText: Football is becoming the province of the well-paid middle class who spend a small fortune each year pursuing their hobby, according to a survey of Premier League fans published yesterday.
fields.body:
It has always been known as the beautiful game but now, it would appear, it is becoming the province of the beautiful people. They are the well-paid middle class and spend a small fortune each year pursuing their hobby, according to a survey of Premier League fans published yesterday.

But while the wealthy are pouring into the country's top football stadiums, particularly in London and southern England, ethnic minorities are keeping away, along with the poor fans, who are being driven out by high ticket prices.

More women than ever before are attending football matches. The annual Premier League survey found that 14% of all fans watching matches in England's top division were women. The survey also found that 33% of all new fans - those who started watching football in the past five years - were women, with some teams, such as Leeds United, selling almost 50% of new season tickets to women.

Other clubs with a large number of female season ticket holders include Derby County, Leicester City and Nottingham Forest.

About 22,000 fans took part in the survey, which was conducted during the last football season and also included Scotland's two big clubs, Celtic and Rangers.

The findings show that many fans are being priced out of football. While the average cost of a season ticket in the Premier League is £317, London clubs in particular are expensive to watch. The average cost of a season ticket at Chelsea is £594, followed by Tottenham Hotspur at £526 and West Ham United at £484.

Wimbledon has the cheapest season ticket in the Premier League, at £200, followed by Sheffield Wednesday, at £213, and Everton, where a season ticket costs an average of £225.

Not surprisingly, Chelsea fans are among the wealthiest in the country, with 60% of all season ticket holders at the west London club earning more than £30,000 a year. An average of 58% of season ticket holders at Tottenham earn more than £30,000, followed by 50% of Wimbledon fans.

Chelsea fans spend an average of £1,306 a season following their team, which includes the cost of buying merchandise, while Tottenham fans spend an average of £1,285. Wimbledon's fans only spend £590 a season, while those at Everton, Sheffield Wednesday and Coventry spend around £680.

John Williams of the Sir Norman Chester centre at Leicester university, which carried out the survey for the Premier League, said: "While the game is recruiting at the top end of the scale it is losing fans at the bottom end of the socio-economic scale.

"There are some clubs that are doing quite well, but ticket price is always the one thing that worries most fans."

Richard Scudamore, chief executive of the Premier League, said clubs did not want to drive poor fans away. "We do not want to outprice ourselves and lose touch with our traditional heartland and supporter base. We want to promote accessibility."

The survey also found that football supporters are shedding their macho, lager-drinking image, particularly at southern clubs. A third of all male fans attend Premier League games with female friends or partners.

Mr Williams said: "There is a trend towards more mixed-sex groups at games, particularly at provincial and some London clubs. There's some resistance and all-male groups are still popular at northern, working class football clubs."

But ethnic minority fans continue to stay away, despite the fact that many Premier League grounds are located in the areas in which they live.

Only 0.9% of season ticket holders are black or Asian. The survey concedes that some clubs are making attempts to recruit non-white fans, with 1.3% of Leicester City and Wimbledon season ticket holders describing themselves as British Asian. Not a single black Briton could be found in the sample of season ticket holders at Everton, Blackburn Rovers, Celtic or Rangers.

The survey found that racism is still present at many grounds, with 24% of fans saying they had heard racist comments towards players and 26% reporting other forms of racist behaviour.

Piara Powar, national coordinator of Kick It Out, football's anti-racism campaign, said: "These statistics indicate a level of alienation of black and Asian fans from the live game, and touches on their reluctance to allow themselves into an environment that has historically been perceived as hostile and dangerous."

There's some resistance and all-male groups are still popular at northern, working class football clubs." But ethnic minority fans continue to stay away, despite the fact that many Premier League grounds are located in the areas in which they live. Only 0.9% of season ticket holders are black or Asian. The survey concedes that some clubs are making attempts to recruit non-white fans, with 1.3% of Leicester City and Wimbledon season ticket holders describing themselves as British Asian. Not a single black Briton could be found in the sample of season ticket holders at Everton, Blackburn Rovers, Celtic or Rangers. The survey found that racism is still present at many grounds, with 24% of fans saying they had heard racist comments towards players and 26% reporting other forms of racist behaviour. Piara Powar, national coordinator of Kick It Out, football's anti-racism campaign, said: "These statistics indicate a level of alienation of black and Asian fans from the live game, and touches on their reluctance to allow themselves into an environment that has historically been perceived as hostile and dangerous."

webTitle: Silence from Whitehall spin machine on damning report

fields.headline: Silence from Whitehall spin machine on damning report
fields.trailText: It is not often that Britain hosts an international conference without the government milking it for maximum publicity.
fields.body:
It is not often that Britain hosts an international conference without the government milking it for maximum publicity. But when education and employment ministers from the West's richest countries met for two days this week in London to discuss how to get young people from school to work there was total silence from the Whitehall spin machine.

A confidential report presented to the meeting by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development explains the government's reticence. The survey of education and training systems in the developed world puts Britain close to the bottom of the class.

The transition from school to work was tougher in the UK than in other wealthy countries. More than a quarter of young people who stayed on at school after the end of compulsory education dropped out within a year, 10% disappeared somewhere between education, training and work and were deemed to be "at risk", and 40% of 19 to 24-year-olds had failed to achieve the minimum qualifications deemed necessary for holding down a job.

The figures relate to the last days of the Conservative government. Since then, the education and employment secretary, David Blunkett, has launched a wide range of initiatives designed to deal with the shortcomings of the UK system.

OECD researchers were impressed by the government's energy since coming to power nearly three years ago, but the stream of reforms had made an already confused situation even more complex.

A young person leaving school could be caught up in a tangle of public and private bodies all supposedly there to help them. These included 150 local education authorities, 100 training and enterprise councils, more than 400 further education colleges and 1,000 job centres, as well as some local regeneration partnerships and the chambers of commerce network.

It was a mistake to have so many competing bodies, and the relative success of the new deal programme for the long-term unemployed was the result of it being administered by a single organisation, the employment service.

Britain's problems stemmed from the combination of an education system biased towards obtaining academic qualifications and an inadequate regime for vocational training. Noting that secondary education in the UK tends to be of a traditional academic nature, the OECD adds: "This inevitably leads to problems of motivation, truancy and a difficult transition into work for a substantial minority.

"It seems obvious that the future economic and social progress of the country could be negatively affected by such a large minority with low performance in education, high rates of unemployment and social or delinquency problems."

Britain's vocational system had been extensively remodelled since the early 1980s, with the introduction of modern apprenticeships, TECs and new qualifications such as GNVQs, designed to have the same status with employers as GCSEs and A-levels.

"The results achieved are far from negligible. From a qualitative point of view, consciousness has been raised with regard to the fundamental importance of education, training and work in the life of individuals and the importance of enterprises for the future of the country."

While the OECD was also impressed by the enthusiasm of training bodies and acknowledges that - in line with global trends - the average level of qualification of young people has improved rapidly, it says there is still a long way to go.

"What remains to be improved is the learning environment and the level and quality of qualifications of many young people in compulsory and post-compulsory initial education and training, as well as the access to further education for those most in need of upgrading both their basic skills and their vocational qualifications."

Some countries represented in London this week could be forgiven for feeling miffed that they were not able to proclaim publicly their achievements because of the government's sensitivity on the issue. But the amount of political capital being invested in education, re-skilling and lifelong learning indicates that privately the lessons of the study are being taken on board.

webTitle: UK fails to provide path from school to work

fields.headline: UK fails to provide path from school to work
fields.standfirst: Confidential study criticises 20% drop-out rate and poor quality of young workforce as among the worst in the industrialised world
fields.trailText: Britain has one of the worst records in the industrialised world for getting young people successfully from school into work, according to a confidential report from the West's leading thinktank.
fields.body:
Britain has one of the worst records in the industrialised world for getting young people successfully from school into work, according to a confidential report from the West's leading thinktank.

The Paris-based Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development said that Britain was performing badly on a wide range of measures - including drop-out rates from education and the poor quality of much of its young workforce.

In a report discussed privately by ministers including the education secretary, David Blunkett, in London this week, the OECD said that of 14 countries studied in depth only Hungary and Portugal had a record as poor as the UK for smoothing the transition to work.

A wider study involving all 29 members of the OECD found that in only four countries - Spain, Hungary, the UK and Mexico - did 20% or more of young people drop out of education within a year of the end of compulsory schooling.

In addition, there was no trace of 10% of young people who found their way into neither work nor training after leaving education. The number of young people "at risk" was the worst in the OECD alongside Portugal.

While the report, based on data relating mainly to the years of Conservative government, said that steps had been taken to remedy the UK's deficiencies, it suggested there was still much to be done to devise a coherent framework.

"The new government has ... already put into place an impressive number of reforms, studies, strategies, programmes, and new bodies concerning education and training. But as the new government's process of policy development and implementation has only recently started, the picture becomes even more complex."

Outlining the government's challenge for the future, the OECD said Britain would benefit from a "more qualitative, less mechanistic and bureaucratic" form of steering young people from school to work.

It criticised the private sector-led system for delivering vocational training inherited by Labour from the Conservatives, saying there was evidence of people being paid too much for doing too little. Moreover, the payments by results system encouraged "providers to focus upon maximising the number of lower level qualifications".

One result was that 40% of British young people aged 19 to 24 had not reached what the OECD considered to be a minimum level of qualification.

A spokesman for the department for education and employment commented that the government was aware of the numbers slipping through the net - a third were either dropping out of education or failing to reach their learning goals - and was "putting a lot more money into further education" to improve participation and retention. Under the latest initiative, those aged 13 to 19 would have their own mentors to provide support in making the transition between education and work.

The OECD's review, done in September 1998, praised devolvement to local bodies such as training and enterprise councils for creating inventive opportunities for young people. However, "it has led to sometimes excessive competition between training providers and between intermediary bodies which can be costly and which raises equity problems with regard to access to further and higher education and training."

webTitle: Tokyo insists Britain must take back suspect nuclear fuel

fields.headline: Tokyo insists Britain must take back suspect nuclear fuel
fields.trailText: Britain has been dealt a humiliating blow by the Japanese government, which is insisting that a consignment of suspect nuclear fuel is returned to Sellafield.
fields.body:
Britain has been dealt a humiliating blow by the Japanese government, which is insisting that a consignment of suspect nuclear fuel is returned to Sellafield.

Tokyo's decision is a blow for senior British trade representatives, who have spent the past week apologising on behalf of British Nuclear Fuels.

The UK firm drew the ire of Japan at the end of last year, when it admitted that its workers fabricated safety data for a shipment of mixed-oxide fuel due to be used in Japanese reactors.

The brusque reply to British pleas for a second chance may also be a killer blow for a new £300m reprocessing plant that BNFL has built, but is still waiting for permission to open.

The UK government delegation, headed by Anna Walker, director general in charge of energy at the trade and industry department, expressed "deep regret" at the falsification.

But the Japanese government reply, issued late last night, said: "In our view, the UK side is responsible for what happened to the fuel. We have requested that Britain send the fuel back to the UK."

For the first time this represents government support for Kansai Electric, a local power company that is the biggest single client of BNFL's reprocessing business.

Last month Kansai Electric called for the suspect fuel to be returned to Sellafield, a scenario that Britain has done everything in its power to resist because it will cost millions of pounds, raise safety concerns and stir up another diplomatic storm among countries on the route.

On its journey to Japan last September the shipment raised protests from anti-nuclear campaigners and Pacific nations.

They expressed fears that the weapons-grade nuclear cargo could cause an environmental catastrophe or be the target of terrorists.

The response is another setback for BNFL's new reprocessing plant in Sellafield, which must prove that it is commercially viable to win an operating licence.

Japanese companies were expected to account for more than half of the business of the plant.

With French and Belgian reprocessing companies waiting in the wings, BNFL's chances of rescuing its relations with Japan are fading fast.

Next Friday the Nuclear Installations Inspectorate will issue its final report on how the fabrication scandal happened and what its safety implications might be.

If, as looks likely, the report states that the falsified data raised quality rather than safety concerns, a gleam of hope will remain for BNFL.

webTitle: Girl's E coli death 'due to sewage' by prize beach

fields.headline: Girl's E coli death 'due to sewage' by prize beach
fields.trailText: An eight-year-old girl who died of E coli poisoning could have caught the infection from sewage discharged into the sea near the beach where she played, an inquest heard yesterday.
fields.body:
An eight-year-old girl who died of E coli poisoning could have caught the infection from sewage discharged into the sea near the beach where she played, an inquest heard yesterday.

Heather Preen, from Rednal, Birmingham, died on August 8 last year, two weeks after contracting E coli 0157 while on a family holiday at Dawlish Warren, in Devon.

The youngster played on a beach awarded the EU blue flag for cleanliness after travelling to the resort with her parents and sister, Suzanne, 10, on July 24. She became ill with diarrhoea and blood loss a week later.

She was prescribed anti-sickness tablets by a GP and later admitted to the Royal Devon and Exeter hospital. Heather was transferred to Bristol Children's hospital, where her parents agreed to switch off her life support machine after she suffered brain damage and kidney failure.

Heather was one of four primary cases of E coli 0157 contracted at the resort, who were linked by the fact that all four people visited the same beach on the same day, July 28, the inquest at Teignmouth heard.

The environment agency had received complaints on July 22 and 24 as well as one on July 29, about sewage discharges at the Black Bridge combined sewer overflow - two kilometres from the beach - last July, the hearing was told.

Heather Barker, the agency's environmental protection manager for East Devon, said that it was "possible but unlikely" that any solids released from the overflow had reached the beach at Dawlish Warren.

The Preen family swam in the sea covered by the blue flag cleanliness and safety certificate but, because the beach was busy, had sat on a section not covered by the award on to which dogs were allowed.

The hearing was shown a video of a BBC documentary which featured the girl's parents, Mark and Julie Preen, returning to the beach three months after the death of their daughter.

A tearful Mrs Preen, 32, said: "She was the heart and soul of us. Now that she is dead something is gone. It was like a bomb blast - one minute she was standing next to me and the next was total devastation."

On the video, a microbiologist, Professor Hugh Pennington, Britain's foremost expert on the disease, said that if someone wanted to design a "nasty bug", E coli 0157 would be it, as eating only a microscopic amount of contaminated soil could kill.

He said that a theory suggesting that dog faeces could have been the source was "as good as he had heard and possibly better".

But giving evidence, Mr Preen, 37, said that he was "very sceptical" because he did not see any dog faeces on the beach. He said that his family had jumped across an open sewage outfall, with a smelly puddle and pieces of toilet tissue at the bottom, on their way to the beach.

He said that he also saw sanitary towels on the beach.

Mrs Preen criticised the health team investigating the outbreak for asking questions about what the family had eaten but not about environmental matters.

South and West Devon health authority failed to identify the source of the E coli outbreak, despite tests of sea water, sand and seagull droppings as well as local food outlets, the hearing was told.

The Preens, who have set up a trust to raise money for research into a cure for E coli, called for a database of E coli incidents. The couple condemned Teignmouth council last week for applying to keep the beach's blue flag award.

The hearing continues.

webTitle: Elite academy tests both will and strength

fields.headline: Elite academy tests both will and strength
fields.trailText: The Royal Military Academy at Sandhurst was founded in 1801 and is now the army's sole officer training establishment.
fields.body:
The Royal Military Academy at Sandhurst was founded in 1801 and is now the army's sole officer training establishment.

Every serving general went to the neo-classical academy in Berkshire, and old boys include Winston Churchill and Field Marshall Montgomery. Nearly 90% of the annual intake of 800 are graduates, and 42% are from public schools. The army's website warns the 44-week-long course is "physically, mentally and emotionally" challenging. One graduate, who has since left the army through injury, confessed: "They're not only testing your fitness but your will - they make it as hard as they can to see if you will crack."

Inculcating leadership is the main emphasis, but each cadet must pass the combat fitness test, and this was what Graham Holmes was training for. A ministry of defence source said: "You have to be as fit as the men you're going to command and, if you're going to be commanding a hundred men, you want to be in the top 20 in terms of fitness."

The ministry said: "The regime is progressive. At the beginning, people do runs in shorts and T shirts, and won't do the actual test until the third term."

The graduate agreed but added: "You may have problems if you've got an injury.

"I did it when there was a heatwave - and some suffered. Occasionally they'd be chucked in the army ambulance following us. Usually the commanders were very good in forcing us in the ambulance, but they're not medics."

fields.headline: Shipman struck off medical register
fields.standfirst: Shipman trial: special report
fields.trailText: Harold Shipman was suspended from the medical register yesterday and his name is expected to be erased at a special session of the General Medical Council today, which will finally bar the Hyde GP from practising as a doctor 10 days after he was convicted of mass murder.
fields.body:
Harold Shipman was suspended from the medical register yesterday and his name is expected to be erased at a special session of the General Medical Council today, which will finally bar the Hyde GP from practising as a doctor 10 days after he was convicted of mass murder.

The GMC's lawyers advised the regulatory body last summer that Shipman could not be suspended while a criminal investigation was under way, and negotiations began at that time with the department of health to change the rules.

After his conviction, the health secretary, Alan Milburn, told the House of Commons that Shipman was still licensed to practise medicine even though he was in jail.

The GMC has moved as fast as its cumbersome regulations allow to bring about the interim suspension of Shipman. The rules dictate that a doctor must have six weeks' notice between the preliminary stage of the disciplinary process and the final public hearing. But the GP's solicitors have written to the GMC to waive the period of notice, which paves the way for his immediate erasure from the register.

The move suggests there may be no appeal against conviction. On Wednesday, the GMC's chief executive, Finlay Scott, said Shipman would have to remain under interim suspension if there was any chance of his lawyers taking his case to the appeal court.

webTitle: MP says ex-wife invented assault to make money

fields.headline: MP says ex-wife invented assault to make money
fields.trailText: A Labour MP yesterday claimed that his former wife was a pathological liar who had fabricated allegations that he had beaten her and held a knife to her throat to make money from a newspaper.
fields.body:
A Labour MP yesterday claimed that his former wife was a pathological liar who had fabricated allegations that he had beaten her and held a knife to her throat to make money from a newspaper.

Jimmy Wray, who represents Glasgow Baillieston, said she would sleep with a knife under her pillow and would routinely brandish it at him during heated arguments.

Mr Wray, 64, told the court of session in Edinburgh that he had not been violent towards her, but, rather, it was Catherine Wray who was physically and verbally aggressive during their 12-year marriage.

On the third day of a defamation action, Mr Wray said he believed he would still be married to Ms Wray were it not for the "humiliation" of her excessive drinking. He is seeking damages of £1.5m from the publishers of the Mail on Sunday over his former wife's account of their marriage, which appeared in the newspaper in 1998. The newspaper maintains its story is true.

The article alleged that Mr Wray was a "foul-mouthed control freak" who had beaten his wife on more than one occasion. But yesterday he claimed the description could more properly be applied to his former wife. "It's the other way around," he said.

Ms Wray, who was paid about £25,000 for the article, claims that her former husband was a "Jekyll and Hyde" character who once punched her with such force that she required hospital treatment for a vision problem.

Leslie Quinn, a GP, said that when Ms Wray came to his surgery in February, 1990, her injury was so severe that he feared she would lose her eye. Ms Wray had claimed her husband had inflicted the injury.

But Mr Wray said his former wife's injury was the result of her banging her head.

On the night of the incident, he had returned home to find her lying in bed looking dishevelled and smelling strongly of alcohol. When he attempted to raise Ms Wray she awoke startled.

"She jumped up and her head went back. She hit her head on the headboard. There was quite a thud."

She had regarded him as a "meal ticket" and he denied that he had ever struck her. The newspaper's allegations were the product of her avarice.

He said: "This story was about greed, it was about money only. I never, ever punched Catherine in my life, I swear to God, and I don't take that lightly."

He had met her in a casino and, as he had only divorced his first wife seven weeks earlier, he was not initially keen to marry.

webTitle: Army lambasted for cadet training death

fields.headline: Army lambasted for cadet training death
fields.trailText: Officer cadets at the Royal Military Academy in Sandhurst are dying needlessly on a gruelling training exercise that is an irrelevance to modern warfare, a doctor said yesterday.
fields.body:
Officer cadets at the Royal Military Academy in Sandhurst are dying needlessly on a gruelling training exercise that is an irrelevance to modern warfare, a doctor said yesterday.

Alan Porter, a former GP in Camberley, Surrey, and a specialist on the effects of endurance training on soldiers, wrote in the Lancet medical journal this week a damning critique on the death of an officer cadet from heat illness.

Graham Holmes, 23, an Edinburgh university graduate, collapsed in July 1998 at the end of a training exercise which alternated running and fast marching over six miles, followed by an assault course. He was carrying a 40lb kit and wearing a double layer of battle-fatigue clothing: trousers, T-shirt and combat jacket.

The inquest jury, which last June returned a verdict of accidental death, was told the cadet was building up to a combat fitness test requiring him to cover eight miles in less than one hour 36 minutes while carrying 44lb of equipment and a rifle.

Cadet Holmes had driven himself psychologically to the point of no return. His core body temperature reached 43C - no mammal can survive above 44C. He died after two weeks in hospital.

Dr Porter wrote: "I do not know the number of officer cadets with EHI [exertional heat illness] admitted to hospital for observation and treatment, but at least three since 1994, including the cadet who died, have been sufficiently ill to require admission to an intensive care unit."

Cadet Holmes was fit and a keen sportsman, but he had collapsed before with EHI while on a run of about two miles. His core temperature reached 42C, and he spent four days in hospital.

Cadets have it instilled into them that they must drink water during endurance training, but Dr Porter believes this to be "largely irrelevant" and "a dangerous distraction from the real issue". Marathon runners can lose up to four litres of sweat with no ill effect.

"Soldiers in training who collapse and die from heat illness have not had time to become severely dehydrated," he wrote. "They collapse because, with occlusive clothing, their sweat cannot evaporate."

Dr Porter said the type of exercise training required of officer cadets was an "irrelevance" in place since the second world war. "In the Falkland Islands the British paratroopers and marines had the fitness and mental stamina to slog on with heavy loads. They did not alternate running with fast marching so they were never at risk of heat illness."

Cadet Holmes's father Frank, a property consultant in Edinburgh, said yesterday the family did not blame the army for his death. "I don't think he found the regime harsh. He was a very fit young man and he wanted to do this."

He and his wife were satisfied with the accidental death verdict. "All we want is to be left with his memory." But he said he would welcome Dr Porter's criticism if it prevented another cadet from dying.

webTitle: New deal 'less likely' to benefit ethnic minority youths

fields.headline: New deal 'less likely' to benefit ethnic minority youths
fields.trailText: Young people from ethnic minorities are less likely than their white counterparts to move on from the new deal employment scheme to permanent jobs, despite having better qualifications, according to figures released yesterday.
fields.body:
Young people from ethnic minorities are less likely than their white counterparts to move on from the new deal employment scheme to permanent jobs, despite having better qualifications, according to figures released yesterday.

A government analysis of the progress of ethnic minority trainees taking part in the programme reveals that they are eight percentage points less likely than white youngsters to move into work, though once in work they are more likely to stay there rather than drop out. A report in Labour Market Trends, published by the office for national statistics, acknowledges that part of the gap may be down to other factors, mainly the fact that many black and Asian young people live in inner city areas where the chance of finding work is lower for everyone.

But it concludes that "if higher qualifications are an indicator of better employability, one might expect that ethnic minority participants should actually do better than whites".

Paul Convery, director of the unemployment unit, said the imbalance between ethnic minority and white participants partly reflected "widespread discrimination" in the wider labour market, though the gap was significantly less on the scheme than in the open market.

The government yesterday moved to stress efforts to achieve equality under the scheme. The employment minister, Tessa Jowell, yesterday said the government was working with equality groups and employers to prepare a campaign to persuade employers that "diversity pays".

Details of racial discrepancies under the new deal emerged as the government moved to toughen the flagship scheme with plans to cut benefits for up to six months for young people who turn down three offers of training or jobs.

The plan immediately provoked concerns. The TUC general secretary, John Monks, warned that, faced with six months without benefit, many young people would turn to crime.

fields.headline: Trimble sounds note of hope
fields.standfirst:
On eve of arms deadline, leader says crisis is not terminal

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: First minister David Trimble sounded a reassuring note yesterday on the future of the Good Friday agreement as the British, Irish and US governments battled round the clock to save the fledgling power-sharing government in Northern Ireland from suspension ahead of today's effective deadline for a breakthough on IRA decommissioning.
fields.body:
First minister David Trimble sounded a reassuring note yesterday on the future of the Good Friday agreement as the British, Irish and US governments battled round the clock to save the fledgling power-sharing government in Northern Ireland from suspension ahead of today's effective deadline for a breakthough on IRA decommissioning.

As Irish officials continued to press republicans for a start date to arms decommissioning in return for moves on dismantling of army bases and withdrawal of troops in Northern Ireland, Mr Trimble, leader of the Ulster Unionists, hinted he was keeping an open mind ahead of tomorrow's crucial meeting of his party's ruling council. He is expected to meet this morning with Gerry Adams, Sinn Fein president.

Downing Street said last night that suspension was virtually inevitable. But there was optimism in Dublin that a breakthough may yet be possible. One talks insider said: "This is now 10 times as important as the day of the Good Friday agreement."

Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, may meet today with the UUP president, Sir Josias Cunningham, who holds Mr Trimble's unopened letter of resignation.

There is speculation that if there is an offer from republicans which falls short of decommissioning but which Mr Mandelson sees as progress, he will ask Sir Josias not to effect Mr Trimble's notice to quit as first minister. He is reluctant to suspend the new institutions of government after only 71 days, knowing it will provoke republican ire and a probable Sinn Fein legal challenge.

But Mr Mandelson recognises the alternative, to allow Mr Trimble to quit or see him lose a humiliating vote at tomorrow's meeting of the 860-strong council, would be a fatal blow to the agreement. Under the cross-community voting rules, it is impossible to see how he could be re-elected or replaced as first minister, sparking fresh assembly elections likely to see hardliners make big gains.

Mr Trimble, speaking after meeting the Irish prime minister, Bertie Ahern, in Dublin, said: "No one can predict exactly how things will develop over the next few days. We know the problems - but I do have to emphasise they are just problems and that people would be wrong to regard this as being a terminal crisis in the agreement."

Irish officials hope to entice the IRA into agreeing to begin decommissioning before May 22, the aspirational deadline in the agreement for completion of paramilitary disarmament.

Mr Trimble promised his 860-strong ruling party council in November that he would quit as first minister before Saturday's reconvened meeting if the IRA had failed to start arms decommissioning.

Sir Josias agreed to hold on to his resignation letter pending this weeks' diplomacy, but made clear he would effect it if General John de Chastelain, chairman of the international commission on decommissioning, was unable today to report that the IRA had begun "actual decommissioning".

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Last year Liverpool and Shanghai declared themselves "sister cities", celebrated in Shanghai by soccer matches against Liverpool FC and on Merseyside by Chinese builders putting up a vast ornamental archway in the Chinese quarter. But, as Nick Baker reveals in Shanghai Scouse (11.0am, Radio 4), there is rather more to the relationship than was officially acknowledged. He hears the story of the Chinese merchant seamen who found themselves stranded in Liverpool after Mao's 1949 revolution.
fields.body:
Last year Liverpool and Shanghai declared themselves "sister cities", celebrated in Shanghai by soccer matches against Liverpool FC and on Merseyside by Chinese builders putting up a vast ornamental archway in the Chinese quarter. But, as Nick Baker reveals in Shanghai Scouse (11.0am, Radio 4), there is rather more to the relationship than was officially acknowledged. He hears the story of the Chinese merchant seamen who found themselves stranded in Liverpool after Mao's 1949 revolution.

Since geometry pupils no longer understand what QED means we must assume that "Cogito ergo sum" is about the last Latin tag familiar to a wider world. Still, even that is a bizarre sort of tribute to René Descartes on the 350th anniversary of his death. He did, after all, insist on publishing his first philosophical work in French, rather than Latin, so that "all who had good sense, including women, could read it". Paul Allen explores the Cartesian legacy in Night Waves (9.30pm, Radio 3).

webTitle: Portillo forced to toe Hague line

fields.headline: Portillo forced to toe Hague line
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: Michael Portillo was last night forced to demonstrate his loyalty to William Hague by accepting one of the Conservative leader's high-flying aides as his private secretary in the Tory treasury team.
fields.body:
Michael Portillo was last night forced to demonstrate his loyalty to William Hague by accepting one of the Conservative leader's high-flying aides as his private secretary in the Tory treasury team.

The new shadow chancellor also bowed to demands that all his media announcements are cleared by Amanda Platell, Mr Hague's fiercely loyal communications director at party HQ.

The concessions came after a week in which Mr Portillo has been seen to be publicly at odds with Mr Hague.

The infighting has brought a crackdown at party HQ in Smith Square, Westminster, with staff being warned they will be sacked for bad-mouthing shadow ministers.

But the disciplinarians' task was made no easier yesterday by the simultaneous publication of a cautious attack on the party's dependence on focus group research by John Redwood and an uninhibited version of the same attack by his ally, the political commentator Simon Heffer.

Mr Redwood, whose dismissal last week struck many Tory MPs as unfair and unwise, used the Daily Telegraph to praise Mr Hague's policy decisions while mocking "parties that spend a fortune on pollsters and focus groups to chart every shift in their image".

Mr Heffer, biographer of Enoch Powell, used the New Statesman magazine to depict a "Portillista" plot to get rid of Mr Redwood as one of several steps necessary to ensure Mr Portillo's succession. He attacked focus groups and implied that their findings had been doctored.

Mr Portillo welcomed the appointment of ex-civil servant, Paul Raynes, to his staff. "I am delighted that Paul has agreed to take on this key role. I saw his policy-making abilities and organisational skills at first hand when he worked for me at the treasury," Mr Portillo said in a statement.

Mr Raynes is an ex-treasury official and diplomat who became deputy to the Tory research department chief, Danny Finkelstein, last summer. He played a leading role in coordinating Mr Hague's Common Sense Revolution on policy, including the controversial tax guarantee.

Yesterday Mr Portillo backtracked on his apparent doubts about the wisdom of a cast-iron pledge to cut taxes in the lifetime of a parliament which Labour is trying to present as a formula for cutting public services.

"The Conservative party's tax guarantee stands. William Hague and I have both made it clear," he said in a separate statement. Tory MPs took last night's developments to mean that he realises that he would be wise to place himself in Mr Hague's protective custody, safe from the well-meaning attention of his friends.

webTitle: Watch this: satellite, cable and digital

fields.headline: Watch this: satellite, cable and digital
fields.trailText:
The Craft (Andrew Fleming, 1996)

8pm, FilmFour
fields.body:
The Craft (Andrew Fleming, 1996)

8pm, FilmFour

Before Buffy and Charmed, wicca-curious teens made do with this Eastwick-style trio - Neve Campbell, Fairuza Balk and Rachel True - who help new girl Robin Tunney fit in when she moves to LA. High-school shenanigans give way to supernatural special effects as the coven take revenge on their enemies - local jock Skeet Ulrich, for instance - though, inevitably, they're meddling with powers they don't understand, with Balk ending up like a cross between Regan from The Exorcist and Ruby Wax.

Titanic (James Cameron, 1997)

8pm, Sky Premier

A timely showing for James Cameron's blockbuster, given that Leonardo DiCaprio's new film, The Beach, opens today. This is a blockbuster in every sense. With dizzying special effects Cameron depicts the full tragedy of the Titanic's meeting with the iceberg. DiCaprio as penniless Jack and Kate Winslet's rich, spirited Rose are irresistible as the star cross'd lovers.

Eagle's Wing (Anthony Harvey, 1978)

1.15am, Carlton Cinema

An odd but excellent British excursion into western territory, with Martin Sheen's naive trapper and Sam Waterston's Kiowa brave in a protracted duel/chase for possession of a beautiful white horse. Think white, think Moby Dick and abstract entities; it's an idiosyncratic, obtuse vision of the west, though rich in character and filmed with a fine eye for landscape. Harvey Keitel is briefly involved.

Planet Of The Apes (Franklin J Schaffner, 1968) 1.35am, FilmFour

Classic sci-fi from Pierre Boule's novel Monkey Planet, with three US astronauts crash-landing on a world ruled by apes. Charlton Heston's Taylor, captured by thuggish gorillas, rescued by more civilised chimps Roddy McDowall and Kim Hunter, stumbles towards the awful truth. Full of suspense and satirical intelligence.

fields.headline: Stranger than fiction
fields.standfirst: Remember Den being gunned down by a bunch of daffodils? Or the episode where everyone walked backwards? As EastEnders celebrates its 15th birthday,  Jake Lushington  relives the moments that would have left Salvador Dalí reeling
fields.trailText: Remember Den being gunned down by a bunch of daffodils? Or the episode where everyone walked backwards? As EastEnders celebrates its 15th birthday, Jake Lushington relives the moments that would have left Salvador Dalí reeling
fields.body:
For some it will be Den serving Angie the divorce papers on Christmas Eve, for others it will be Grant pushing bruvver Phil down the garage pit after learning that he had slept with his wife, or maybe even Pauline smashing adulterous Arthur over the head with a frying pan. But for me EastEnders has often been as memorable for its comical, even surreal moments. Surely not, I hear you cry? Not humour in that dull, dank Square of misery? Apart, of course, from Pat Butcher's choice of earrings.

Look a little closer, however, among those moments of high passion and drama, and you may be surprised. What about those endless far-fetched theme nights in the Vic? The Wild West evening with Pete Beale in a Stetson as wide as his toothy grin, while his son Ian emerged breathless out the back of a pantomime horse and Wicksy pretended he could actually play the pub piano. Or the Caribbean cocktail extravaganza with Bianca turning up as Carmen Miranda, the contents of Mark's fruit and veg stall finely balanced on her head.

Far-out costumes haven't ended there. Remember Arthur dressed as a baby being pushed round the Square in a pram by Pete and Den? No one could forget Sanjay's teddy boy quiff at the community play - it nearly had someone's eye out. And even the normally down-to-earth Michelle once turned up in a tie-dye kaftan to impress her mate Rachel's middle-class friends.

From fashion shows to slug races, eel fishing to sculpture exhibitions in Kath's caff, EastEnders has always caused hilarity to millions precisely because humour often sits so uncomfortably with the Greek tragedies that surround it. That isn't to say the writers can't write comedy. The likes of Tony Jordan, Tony MacHale and Annie Wood can lay down patter as good as any sitcom, but their best one-liners are normally overshadowed by news of someone bombing the Arches or burning down the portakabin for the 15th time.

Sometimes, like in all soap operas, it gets a too surreal. What did all those people mean when they said they wanted to get Dr Legover? Why did Wendy Richard go from having to hear every day about Mrs Slocombe's pussy in Are You Being Served to nursing a gin and orange in the Queen Vic listening to Ethel's complaints about her little Willie? How could Felix the Barber (of the butterfly collection and holocaust tales) persuade Blossom (devoted West Indian grandmother) to emigrate with him to Israel, when they had never even kissed. I often wonder about their life together in Tel Aviv to this day.

All of this pales in comparison when one suddenly stumbles upon a UK Gold repeat of the infamous Walking Backwards episode. In this tribute to the works of Salvador Dalí, Gill, soon to die movingly of Aids, awakes and tells boyfriend Mark that in the time she has left she is going to start doing things differently, things she has never done before. This involves defying convention by wearing her clothes back to front, slicing bread with the wrong hand and walking backwards. Mark is understandably bemused. Not so the other inhabitants of Walford. Gill's new approach to life inexplicably catches on. Soon Pat is leading a conga backwards out of the café and the pub regulars are drinking their pints from the wrong side of the glass, covering their faces in froth. Were this madness not enough, in the same episode Dot Cotton, devout Christian, for some reason decides to convert to Judaism. She spends the whole episode making lamb sandwiches and then hands them out in the Vic to celebrate Passover. I sometimes tell people about this episode and they are convinced I'm making it all up, or at least the episode isn't as bizarre as I describe it. Believe me, it's weirder.

Even in the most dramatic scenes I have succumbed to unintentional giggles. Look back to the moment when Dirty Den finally met his grizzly end and you will be amazed to find out that he was shot not by a gun, but by a bunch of daffodils. And for every climactic revelation leading into those familiar drums, there have always been some that have struck the wrong note. The news that Alan Jackson had resigned from making bacon sarnies for the night café was hardly earth-shaking. The all-time favourite amongst the cast for sheer anti-climax was when Kathy and Michelle were hard at work making up 200 dresses for Mehmet. Suddenly a crunching sound brought them to a grinding halt and Kathy had to utter the thrilling final line: "Oh, no the knitting machine has broken." Pause. "What are we going to do?" Cue drums, credits and millions of viewers recovering from side-splitting disbelief.

fields.headline: Death's rich pageant
fields.trailText: Despite its unpromising subject-matter, Great Undertakings (C4) probes into the death-and-burials business with insight and even a certain amount of taste. Partly, this is due to Bill Paterson's delightfully lugubrious voice-over, in which he sounds as though he's pounding his pulpit on a damp Sunday in South Uist, reminding his listeners that all flesh is as grass, this brief life is but a vale of tears, and remember to drop a quid in the box on the way out.
fields.body:
Despite its unpromising subject-matter, Great Undertakings (C4) probes into the death-and-burials business with insight and even a certain amount of taste. Partly, this is due to Bill Paterson's delightfully lugubrious voice-over, in which he sounds as though he's pounding his pulpit on a damp Sunday in South Uist, reminding his listeners that all flesh is as grass, this brief life is but a vale of tears, and remember to drop a quid in the box on the way out.

Also, there is a grim fascination in seeing how other people cope with death and bereavement, although why they would want to cope with it in front of a television camera passeth all understanding. And the topic has undeniable merits from a TV crew's point of view, not least the way death tends to be a great springer of surprises, unlocking secrets about people which went unsuspected during their lives.

Marguerite Van Ooren, the Funerals Officer of Westminster Council, described how she has to become "a bit of a detective" when people die without family, friends or a will. She trawls for clues in their financial records and personal effects to try to build some semblance of a life round the unmourned corpse, as she did in the case of John. Though John died alone and apparently skint in a rooming house, Van Ooren discovered he had inherited hundreds of thousands of pounds from his mother. He died intestate, so the Treasury will collect the loot.

Football fans will have been intrigued by the case of Mike, a fanatical Chelsea supporter who wanted to be interred at Stamford Bridge. His widow and a small posse of mourners trekked down to the ground one sodden day and buried Mike's ashes close to the touchline. It was hard to believe this happens very often - grouchy Chelsea chairman Ken Bates surely doesn't want his ground littered with corpses, while his players can hardly relish the prospect of breaking an ankle in a minefield of buried urns - but it made for a touching little scene.

Death, self-righteousness and melodrama continue to stalk the corridors of Holby City (BBC1). I was particularly smitten by the newspaper headline, DOCTOR FACES SUSPENSION AFTER DEATH, supposedly describing an alleged incident of malpractice but startlingly suggestive of a bizarre NHS death ritual.

This week, the writers had been working overtime to cram enough suitably fantastic entertainment within the hospital walls. In Holby, no cliché need ever fear being denied admittance. Bill, the hospital chaplain, was lined up for a major heart operation after a bit of preamble about the agonising chest pains he'd been suffering lately. "It's just a touch of indigestion", he gasped absurdly, though once he'd received his diagnosis of an aortic aneurysm, his embarrassingly pitiful attempts at humour instantly gave way to bitterness and self-pity. "I've done God's work all my life," he whined. "I don't deserve this." Sure about that, Bill? Infuriatingly, a golden opportunity to write this repulsive character out of the story was sabotaged by the healing hands of Dr Meyer, the Nosferatu of consultants. Meyer is played with a kind of ominous oiliness by George Irving, who has come a long way from the shifty, dog-eared cop he used to play in Dangerfield. Or perhaps not.

Then there was the storyline about the mad woman suffering from Munchausen's syndrome by proxy who kept poisoning her daughter, but your credulity has already been stretched far enough. For real science fiction, there was Horizon's trek through the difficult history of the Hubble telescope (BBC2), which made for mostly fascinating viewing, even if you began to suspect its true purpose was to plead for more funding for NASA.

Certainly NASA's top ologists didn't shrink from making apocalyptic claims for Hubble. It would reveal how evolution began! We would be able to tell the age of the universe! And, amazingly, some of their dreams came true, as Hubble - ingeniously corrected after "spherical aberration" had made its early photographs look like something shot in a Woolworths photo-booth - started beaming back mind-blowing panoramas of galaxies, nebulae, federation starships etcetera. And the age of the universe is 12 billion years. The boffins seemed to think that was OK.

fields.headline: Behind the screen
fields.standfirst: Janine Gibson's TV gossip
fields.trailText: Janine Gibson's TV gossip
fields.body:
Dispatches from the world of development hell revealed this week that, like Frankenstein's monster, Hammer Films is to be revived, doubtless in some highly technical experiment involving a freak bolt of lightning and some misappropriated body parts.

In its new incarnation it will fall victim to some sort of hideous mutation, to emerge as the home of TV horror with such media luminaries as Charles Saatchi, ex-Warner Music chairman Rob Dickins and the British film commission chairman Larry Chrisfield behind the sick and sinister plot. The long-term aim is to launch a digital television channel devoted to bloodthirsty tales along the model of the Sci Fi Channel.

At over 65 years old, the Hammer brand was one of the world's oldest studios, and the source of over 250 films and TV programmes including The Curse Of Frankenstein, The Mummy, The Hound Of The Baskervilles and The Plague Of The Zombies, as well as our personal favourite, the chilling Twins Of Evil. After hitting a peak, though, in 1971, the company got cocky and began to diversify into film versions of 70s "classics" such as On The Buses and Man About The House. It was, predictably, all downhill from there.

Meanwhile as reports circulate that the BBC's increasingly reluctant Castaways are being airlifted off the island yet again - this time under the threat of meningitis, the people behind the BBC's gripping fly-on-the-wall tale are moving into drama. Lion Television is investing £500,000 in a new drama division and has poached two EastEnders scriptwriters to staff the unit. Rumours that the writers have been urgently commissioned to come up with storylines for a group of ordinary members of the public cast adrift for a year on a remote Scottish island couldn't, we are assured, be further from the mark.

webTitle: Nasa: No problems, good weather for Friday shuttle launch

fields.headline: Nasa: No problems, good weather for Friday shuttle launch
fields.trailText: With only one day left until lift off, Nasa said Thursday it's tracking no problems with space shuttle Endeavour and the weather looks excellent.
fields.body:
With only one day left until lift off, Nasa said Thursday it's tracking no problems with space shuttle Endeavour and the weather looks excellent.

Forecasters said there is a 90 percent chance the weather will cooperate for Endeavour's second launch attempt, at 12:30 pm (17:30 GMT) Friday. The only concern, and a slight one at that, is crosswind.

Last week, rain and thick clouds, along with a computer problem, prevented Nasa from sending Endeavour on a long-delayed mission to create the finest map ever of the Earth. The 11-day mission had been planned for last September, but was put on hold because of damaged shuttle wiring.

The computerised unit that malfunctioned in the final minutes of the countdown January 31 has since been replaced with a spare.

Nasa has replaced a few other components aboard Endeavour, namely a cable and a navigation-satellite receiver.

During the past week, shuttle managers also made progress in their investigation into engine pump seals.

A seal that should have been thrown away as a factory reject somehow ended up flying aboard Discovery in December. Nasa was able to verify the quality of all but two of the 18 metal seals in Endeavour's engine fuel pumps, but decided to proceed with last week's launch attempt anyway given the unlikelihood of another defective seal turning up.

Engineers have since found the paperwork exonerating one of those two remaining seals, and no more defective parts have popped up although the search continues, said shuttle program manager Ron Dittemore.

Because of all the repairs and the extra attention to shuttle wiring in recent months, Endeavour is in "tiptop shape," Dittemore said.

Nasa grounded the shuttle fleet after an exposed wire caused a short circuit during Columbia's launch in July. Damaged wiring was found in all four shuttles.

fields.headline: Dobson camp blunders over GMB 'backing'
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Supporters of Frank Dobson embarrassed their candidate yesterday when they claimed that John Edmonds had decided to endorse his London mayor campaign, only to find that the GMB leader was determined to remain neutral.
fields.body:
Supporters of Frank Dobson embarrassed their candidate yesterday when they claimed that John Edmonds had decided to endorse his London mayor campaign, only to find that the GMB leader was determined to remain neutral.

The Dobson camp was forced to issue a humiliating apology last night after the GMB insisted that its leader had no intention of supporting any candidate. The setback came as Ken Livingstone warned that Labour would lose the mayor election in May if Mr Dobson is selected as the party's candidate in a "Millbank stitch-up".

The deadline for ballot papers closes next week and Mr Livingstone believes that Labour could suffer catastrophic damage if Mr Dobson is handed victory with the support of Labour MPs, rather than individual party members. The votes of London Labour MPs are worth the votes of 1,000 party members.

"It would be even worse in London [than in Wales]," Mr Livingstone told BBC News Online. "The backlash will come on polling day for Labour. If Londoners are unhappy with the way the contest has been run, they will punish Labour."

Mr Livingstone was also scathing about the bungled attempt by the Dobson camp to sign up Mr Edmonds. "It would be mad for John Edmonds to support Frank and I know that John is not mad," he said. "I suppose this all adds to the gaiety of nations."

The GMB affair started yesterday morning when Mr Dobson's camp briefed journalists that Mr Edmonds would throw his weight behind the former health secretary at a meeting in London. It was said that Mr Edmonds would conduct individual interviews over the telephone after the meeting which was attended by 50 members of the GMB.

Just before 4pm, however, the Dobson camp said that Mr Edmonds would not conduct any interviews but would issue a statement instead. Less than an hour later, Dobson supporters were forced to admit that Mr Edmonds would not be endorsing Mr Dobson or any of Labour's three other candidates.

A member of the Dobson camp said: "We were told that John Edmonds was going to say that Frank was the man for the job. But John did not say what we expected him to say. John has come under pressure from the GMB's regional committee which insisted that the union would not endorse any candidate."

This interpretation was challenged by the GMB which said that Mr Edmonds had never intended to endorse Mr Dobson because it is one of the few unions which will cast its vote proportionately for each candidate based on the results of its ballot. "The GMB has always made clear that it will make no recommendation to its members because we will be splitting our vote," a spokesperson said. "That seems the fairest way."

Mr Dobson's embarrassment over the non-endorsement by the GMB is likely to sound alarm bells in Downing Street and Millbank, which are both fighting "down to the wire" to block a Livingstone victory.

In recent days, a number of Labour MPs have claimed that they are facing intense pressure to support Mr Dobson. Rudi Vis, MP for Finchley and Golders Green, told his local party last week that he had been offered numerous incentives to back Mr Dobson.

Mr Vis, who announced that he would abstain after his local party declared for Mr Livingstone, was told that ministers would visit his constituency during the general election campaign if he supported Mr Dobson. He was also told that ministers would be less supportive of a city farm in his constituency, which is threatened with closure, if he abstained.

webTitle: Morgan begins search for truce in Wales

fields.headline: Morgan begins search for truce in Wales
fields.standfirst:
New Labour leader will 'bust a gut' in cash talks with treasury

Devolution in Wales: special report
fields.trailText: Less than 24 hours after being catapulted into place as Labour's first secretary-in-waiting, Rhodri Morgan moved swiftly yesterday to prepare the ground for a much needed period of stability in the troubled Welsh assembly.
fields.body:
Less than 24 hours after being catapulted into place as Labour's first secretary-in-waiting, Rhodri Morgan moved swiftly yesterday to prepare the ground for a much needed period of stability in the troubled Welsh assembly.

With the dust barely settled on the acrimonious no confidence debate that triggered the resignation of his predecessor, Alun Michael, the acting leader of the minority Labour admininstration began meetings with opposition leaders in Cardiff in an attempt to find common ground on ways to make the assembly work.

Mr Morgan was careful to make no firm commitments ahead of his expected election as first secretary early next week. But he pledged to "bust a gut" to get the top deal for Wales in any negotiations with the treasury over European funding, the issue that ostensibly led to Mr Michael's downfall.

He refused to be drawn on the prospect of a formal coalition with the six strong Liberal Democrat group but defused speculation about the possibility of sweeping cabinet changes. "I am very, very happy with the members of the cabinet that I have got at the moment and how, if I were elected, I will fill that one vacancy is not something I have given any thought to as yet."

Mr Morgan will be officially endorsed as the Welsh Labour leader and its candidate for first secretary at a meeting of the party's executive in Cardiff this afternoon. Plaid Cymru confirmed yesterday that it will accept his nomination as first secretary when the assembly meets next Tuesday.

As Mr Michael warned him to "watch his back" to avoid the fate that he had suffered, Mr Morgan stressed in interviews that the assembly had to have stability "to deliver the better health and the better wealth that the Welsh assembly should deliver for the people of Wales".

Whether that stability could be achieved by coalition along the Scottish route, through a Lab-Lib pact or through some other means, he did not yet know.

Despite Downing Street's previous opposition to his attempts to become party leader in Wales Mr Morgan is confident that relations with the Labour hierarchy in London will be good. "This idea that you should be aggressive and do all your negotiations with Tony Blair and Gordon Brown by megaphone is completely absurd. You can fight very hard for Wales to get additional resources but you have got to do it by having very good relations with Westminster."

As his successor prepared formally to take over the reins in Cardiff, Mr Michael launched a ferocious attack on the conduct of Plaid Cymru and one of the party's leading peers, the assembly's presiding officer, Lord Dafydd Elis Thomas.

Mr Michael warned his successor: "I am absolutely certain that Plaid Cymru will look for an excuse for a repeat run at some point in the future. That would obviously create problems for Rhodri and any future leader, but it will also again risk the reputation and the standing of the assembly.

Mr Michael claimed Lord Elis Thomas had changed the rules over the timing of the re-election of the first secretary in a way that would have caused considerable difficulty to the 28-strong Labour group, who would have been faced with a series of further votes without having the opportunity to reflect or consult the wider party. "I felt that was intolerable, I also think it is wrong. And I thought it was time to cut through this sort of dictatorship from the smaller parties by allowing the Labour party to take a decision."

Having given up the top job in Welsh politics Mr Michael said it was too early to talk about his political future. He said he did not regret having given up his home office position to take on the role of first secretary in Wales. He believed he had achieved a great deal in his time in the post.
