But he pledged to "bust a gut" to get the top deal for Wales in any negotiations with the treasury over European funding, the issue that ostensibly led to Mr Michael's downfall. He refused to be drawn on the prospect of a formal coalition with the six strong Liberal Democrat group but defused speculation about the possibility of sweeping cabinet changes. "I am very, very happy with the members of the cabinet that I have got at the moment and how, if I were elected, I will fill that one vacancy is not something I have given any thought to as yet." Mr Morgan will be officially endorsed as the Welsh Labour leader and its candidate for first secretary at a meeting of the party's executive in Cardiff this afternoon. Plaid Cymru confirmed yesterday that it will accept his nomination as first secretary when the assembly meets next Tuesday. As Mr Michael warned him to "watch his back" to avoid the fate that he had suffered, Mr Morgan stressed in interviews that the assembly had to have stability "to deliver the better health and the better wealth that the Welsh assembly should deliver for the people of Wales". Whether that stability could be achieved by coalition along the Scottish route, through a Lab-Lib pact or through some other means, he did not yet know. Despite Downing Street's previous opposition to his attempts to become party leader in Wales Mr Morgan is confident that relations with the Labour hierarchy in London will be good. "This idea that you should be aggressive and do all your negotiations with Tony Blair and Gordon Brown by megaphone is completely absurd. You can fight very hard for Wales to get additional resources but you have got to do it by having very good relations with Westminster." As his successor prepared formally to take over the reins in Cardiff, Mr Michael launched a ferocious attack on the conduct of Plaid Cymru and one of the party's leading peers, the assembly's presiding officer, Lord Dafydd Elis Thomas. Mr Michael warned his successor: "I am absolutely certain that Plaid Cymru will look for an excuse for a repeat run at some point in the future. That would obviously create problems for Rhodri and any future leader, but it will also again risk the reputation and the standing of the assembly. Mr Michael claimed Lord Elis Thomas had changed the rules over the timing of the re-election of the first secretary in a way that would have caused considerable difficulty to the 28-strong Labour group, who would have been faced with a series of further votes without having the opportunity to reflect or consult the wider party. "I felt that was intolerable, I also think it is wrong. And I thought it was time to cut through this sort of dictatorship from the smaller parties by allowing the Labour party to take a decision." Having given up the top job in Welsh politics Mr Michael said it was too early to talk about his political future. He said he did not regret having given up his home office position to take on the role of first secretary in Wales. He believed he had achieved a great deal in his time in the post.

fields.headline: Marc Davis
fields.standfirst: Energetic pen behind Disney cartoon figures, nasty and nice
fields.trailText: The great film animator Marc Davis, who has died aged 86, was the creator of Walt Disney's loveable cartoon characters Bambi and Thumper, and also of that magnificent incarnation of evil, Cruella de Vil, in the 1966 movie 101 Dalmatians
fields.body:
The great film animator Marc Davis, who has died aged 86, was the creator of Walt Disney's loveable cartoon characters Bambi and Thumper, and also of that magnificent incarnation of evil, Cruella de Vil, in the 1966 movie 101 Dalmatians. After that, alas, he devoted his energies to devising installations at Disney's theme parks until his retirement in 1978, but he undeniably became a great influence on the Disney renaissance figures of the 1990s, Little Mermaid, Beauty And The Beast and Aladdin.

One of his greatest creations, however, remained unmade. In 1910, Disney had bought the rights of Edmond Rostard's popular play, Chanticleer, about a rooster who believes that his crowing makes the sun rise; the plan was to combine this with Reynard the Fox.

Chanticleer was, undoubtedly, Davis's best work, but each time a production was mooted, there was a dismal reaction from the Disney management. As he recalled: "We had all the artwork up on the walls, and the money people at the studio came in like it was a funeral. We went all the way through the presentation and met with silence. Then a voice at the back of the room said, 'You can't make a personality out of a chicken.' They all filed out and that was the end of it."

Davis's surviving drawings for Chanticleer reveal some of the century's finest illustrations, and his watercolour design for the barnyard became a direct inspiration for those working on the opening sequence of Beauty And The Beast (1991).

Born in Bakersfield, California, Davis went to Kansas school of art before returning to the west coast for further study. Much of his skill derived from his student days spent sketching animals at the Los Angeles zoo, while he was at the Otis art institute in the late 1920s, and studying anatomy.

He began work for Disney in 1935 and was assigned to the pioneering project, Snow White And The Seven Dwarves (1937) as assistant animator. Disney recognised his talent and he went on to work on the major characters in Bambi (1942).

During the second world war, the studio also made training films for the military. Davis worked on many of these, including the item which, mindful of the fact that 7m fighting days had been lost to venereal disease in the first world war, made use of Hitler and Hirohito to urge sexual caution among the troops.

This work had an indirect influence upon the style of the Disney studio's postwar movies, such as Cinderella (1949), Alice In Wonderland (1951) and the underrated Sleeping Beauty (1959), for all of which Davis created the eponymous characters, as well as the chilling Maleficent and the charming Tinkerbell.

Davis's memory should now be honoured by unfreezing the perfect fowl that was his Chanticleer.

 Marc Frasier Davis, film animator, born March 13 1913; died January 12 2000

webTitle: Housing chief chosen to help mayor get London moving

fields.headline: Housing chief chosen to help mayor get London moving
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: The government has chosen a former civil servant, Anthony Mayer, present chief executive of the housing corporation, to head Transport for London, the high-profile quango which will be responsible to the new mayor of London for freeing the capital of congestion.
fields.body:
The government has chosen a former civil servant, Anthony Mayer, present chief executive of the housing corporation, to head Transport for London, the high-profile quango which will be responsible to the new mayor of London for freeing the capital of congestion.

Barring any last-minute hitches on his contract, Mr Mayer, 54, is expected to take up his six-figure appointment in the summer, soon after the mayoral election in May.

He takes on the duties performed by London Transport plus a wider view of the relationship with other modes of transport, such as rail.

Mr Mayer will eventually take over direction of the Underground under John Prescott's private-public partnership.

However, this is not expected to happen until next year when London Underground has completed the £15bn deal.

The plan has already been held up by Railtrack's failure to secure control of the Underground's sub-surface stations.

This has delayed the project for at least six months. The government's aim is to complete the transfer by next year, but some of the consortiums bidding for the project are pressing for big sections of the Underground to be closed while they modernise track and tunnelling.

Mr Mayer has been chosen because he has a wide experience of dealing with Whitehall as a civil servant during the Thatcher years.

He spent five years of his Whitehall career in the department of transport and then went into banking as a director of finance and administration at NM Rothschild.

This dual experience in the private and public sectors could be invaluable experience when the public-private partnership on the Underground is finally realised.

Under Mr Mayer's guidance, the various consortiums will have the opportunity to run one of the world's largest metro systems for at least 15 years before it is handed back to the state.

He will in effect carry out the wishes of the new mayor, advising him on key issues such as how to make buses run more freely.

One of the most immediate decisions will be whether London will become the first city to respond positively to the government's proposals to introduce congestion and workplace charging to clear clogged roads.

A new survey by the Institution of Civil Engineers shows fewer and fewer cities in favour of the idea.

Only the London boroughs are keen on the plan. It must first be debated at borough level.

The mayor and Mr Mayer will have to persuade them that the plan is not only workable but also will allow the revenue raised to be ploughed back into improving public transport in the capital.

fields.headline: Maude calls for EU 'no-go' issues
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday signalled his enthusiasm for the next round of EU reforms by declaring himself "an unwavering pro-European", despite coming under renewed Tory pressure not to commit Britain to any more integration.
fields.byline: Ian Black  in Brussels and Michael White
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday signalled his enthusiasm for the next round of EU reforms by declaring himself "an unwavering pro-European", despite coming under renewed Tory pressure not to commit Britain to any more integration.

Francis Maude, making his first visit to Brussels as shadow foreign secretary, said the prime minister should rule out any more concessions which would erode democratic control of the nation's destiny at a key European Union reform conference starting next week. Mr Blair's remarks are made in a foreword to the official white paper setting out Britain's goals for the fourth EU inter-governmental conference which meets to start tackling the reform agenda on Monday in Brussels.

Mr Blair will accept the need to give up one of Britain's two posts as EU commissioners - currently Neil Kinnock and Chris Patten - as part of the price of enlarging the EU to the east and south. But he will join bigger EU countries in demanding a fairer share of voting power in EU decision-making, at the expense of smaller states.

He will also press for a speeding-up of the decision-making process in the European court of justice in response to the expected two-year delay in a verdict on France's refusal to accept British beef now that it has been declared BSE-free. Mr Blair's intention is to go into the conference - the first since Amsterdam in 1997 - "on the front foot, not the back foot", eager to embrace reform, not resist it.

The white paper will concede the need to increase majority voting in some areas, though Labour will "red line" sensitive policy areas - notably tax, border control and defence - where Britain will wield its national veto rather than give way.

Mr Maude was addressing Conservative Euro MPs the day after the European Commission president, Romano Prodi, set out his five-year strategy for more European "governance".

Mr Maude said: "There is already growing concern in Britain about laws being imposed from Brussels which Westminster would never have agreed to. The government should today set out no-go areas."

Mr Prodi, seeking to dismiss claims that he has displayed no coherent sense of direction since taking office last year, said he wanted national governments and regional and local authorities to be more closely involved in shaping Europe's future.

But Mr Maude warned that a united states of Europe was still on the agenda. "The public sent Tony Blair a clear message at the European elections last year - they think European integration has gone far enough."

Next Monday Robin Cook joins fellow EU foreign ministers at the formal launch of a year-long "inter-governmental conference" on the union's future.

The talks are designed to streamline decision-making and cut red tape to make the EU manageable as it expands to include up to a dozen new members, mostly from the former Eastern European block. Talks with six new candidates begin next week.

Expressing strong backing for the idea of flexibility, Mr Maude said: "We want to see a provision incorporated into the Treaty to allow countries not to participate in new legislative actions at a European level which they wish to handle at national level."

fields.headline: Leslie Parris
fields.trailText: The art historian Leslie Parris, who has died suddenly aged 58, was, for 35 years at the Tate Gallery, one of the principal custodians of the most comprehensive collection of the country's art. He became an assiduous and ingenious advocate of the material, and of Constable in particular.
fields.body:
The art historian Leslie Parris, who has died suddenly aged 58, was, for 35 years at the Tate Gallery, one of the principal custodians of the most comprehensive collection of the country's art. He became an assiduous and ingenious advocate of the material, and of Constable in particular.

After Maidstone grammar school, where he was inspired by his history teacher, Leslie went to the Courtauld Institute in London. He was among the few undergraduates of his day to seek a wider cultural context for the artists he studied, while revelling in "Courtauldism" - that meshing of finely focused analysis with the close reading of primary documents, such as contracts and contemporary accounts. Very early on, Leslie established a relationship with the Constable family, who allowed him to go through all their papers.

Like our teacher at the Courtauld, Johannes Wilde, he carried common sense to the point of genius in the interpretation of such things, but was also sensitive to the fundamental question about art's why and wherefore, which Ernst Gombrich, visiting from the Warburg Institute, put before us.

Leslie's first job was as a freelance. He revised, most scrupulously, Sir John Rothenstein's two volumes, British Painting, before joining the Tate in 1964 as assistant keeper. There, in a series of shows, he opened up to intelligent review the whole business of depicting the "natural world" in paint.

First, there was The Art Of Nature (1971). Cheeky and earnest in equal measure, he set Constable's art firmly within the complex circumstances of its production. Landscape In Britain: 1750-1850 demonstrated in 1973 the sheer variety and multi-purposiveness of its matter. It was itself a landmark.

Then came the Constable bicentennial exhibition of 1976. This not only challenged current assumptions about what actually was by the artist, but demanded critical engagement with the ideas and emotions which the paintings embody. A further presentation in 1996 extended the oeuvre significantly and provoked argument of novel intensity between Constabelians.

Leslie was responsible for a number of shows on his own, of which the most remarkable was that devoted to the Pre-Raphaelites (1983).

In a substantial list of publications, he also revealed the most scrupulous scholarship and elegance of argument. He was the modern master of the catalogue raisonné, and The Tate Gallery Constable Collection is a masterpiece. That the texts which accompanied the exhibitions will always be consulted by those interested in their subjects is largely due to Leslie's work.

When we were preparing the last volume in the Suffolk Record Society's Constable documents series, I saw at close quarters Leslie's ability to track down information and to construct a case: his forensic skills left me breathless. In public, shy almost to the point of self-effacement, in private he had a rebarbative wit and could be extravagantly funny. He would devote days on end, and all his scholarly resources, to the creation of an elaborate art historical parody.

He is survived by his first wife, Gill Platt, a son and daughter; and his second wife, Pippa Rogers.

 Leslie Parris, art historian and museum curator, born July 18 1941; died January 6 2000

fields.headline: Bill Epstein
fields.standfirst: Uncovering the conditions of black workers in colonial Africa
fields.trailText: Bill Epstein, who has died aged 75, was one of the last of a generation of social anthropologists who pioneered research in central Africa as part of the then Rhodes Livingstone Institute in Lusaka, Northern Rhodesia.
fields.body:
Bill Epstein, who has died aged 75, was one of the last of a generation of social anthropologists who pioneered research in central Africa as part of the then Rhodes Livingstone Institute in Lusaka, Northern Rhodesia. He returned to Britain as a member of the Manchester school of anthropology, headed by Max Gluckman, and in subsequent fieldwork in New Guinea, focussed on the resilience of the Tolai people's cultural institutions and the vitality of their culture.

Bill took his law degree at Queen's University, Belfast, in 1944 before joining the navy as a coder. He never practised law. Instead, in 1948, he won a colonial social science scholarship at the London School of Economics to research the urban courts of what was then Northern Rhodesia. The study led to the publication of The Administration Of Justice And The Urban African (HMSO, 1953).

Bill then returned to what is now Zambia to study the new organisations and social relationships forming among migrant African labourers in the copperbelt, where, due to what was later called "a series of unfortunate misunderstandings", he was branded a subversive.

It was a volatile period, characterised by strikes in the copper mines by black workers supporting the African National Congress's campaign of political opposition. Trade union leaders invited Bill to address a public meeting in Kibemba, but his speech was reported back to the authorities in a garbled fashion and, accused of siding with the trade union, he was refused access to the mines for research.

Nonetheless, work in difficult circumstances seemed to enhance Bill's personal and academic stature. He later worked in the highly-charged anthropology departments at Manchester and the Australian National University, both dominated by men of large professional ego. Somehow he always stood above the politics, and his careful scholarship impressed. His anthropology and his person were reflected in a dual concern with aspects of social continuity and the effects of rapid social change.

Bill's students and colleagues always found him approachable, and those attending his seminars in the 1960s and 1970s greatly appreciated his detailed accounts of central African urban life. The research was published as Politics In An Urban African Community (1958), The Craft Of Social Anthropology (1967), Urbanisation And Kinship (1981), and Scenes From African Urban Life (1992).

In 1957, he married Scarlett, a fellow member of the Manchester school. They went to the Australian National University and together undertook fieldwork among the Tolai, of New Britain; Scarlett at a distant rural site and Bill in a village close to the town of Rabaul. His study of Tolai land rights, kinship and local social organisation was published as Matupit: Land, Politics And Change Among The Tolai Of New Britain (1969).

Increasingly, and against the instructions of his mentor Max Gluckman, Bill's attention turned to the social and emotional bases of identity, in which he sought insights from psychology. While his Zambian research had revealed the importance of ethnic and occupational identities, among the Tolai he was to explore the expression and power of effect across a range of social contexts. He began to undertake comparative research on ethnicity after he arrived in Sussex in 1972, work which led to Ethos And Identity (1978), perhaps his most widely read book. One of the chapters, about Jewish identity in the United States, uses ethnographic data as a cypher for an exploration of aspects of his own identity as a son/grandson.

After retirement from Sussex in 1982, Bill published monographs on the Tolai. In The Midst Of Life (1992) and Gunantuna: Aspects Of The Person, Self And Individual Among The Tolai (1998) contain detailed analyses of emotion and of Tolai concepts of affect. His contributions to anthropological theory were honoured last year by a festschrift volume of essays by former colleagues and PhD students.

Those who knew, worked with, or studied under Bill Epstein recognised his ability and the depth of his character, even if we never fully appreciated the complexity and subtlety of his person.

He is survived by his wife, two daughters and three grandchildren.

 Arnold Leonard (Bill) Epstein, social anthropologist, born September 13 1924; died November 9 1999

Those who knew, worked with, or studied under Bill Epstein recognised his ability and the depth of his character, even if we never fully appreciated the complexity and subtlety of his person. He is survived by his wife, two daughters and three grandchildren.  Arnold Leonard (Bill) Epstein, social anthropologist, born September 13 1924; died November 9 1999

fields.headline: Jack Scott
fields.standfirst: Radical race and sports campaigner tainted by Patty Hearst link
fields.trailText: The death of the American radical, Jack Scott, at the age of 57, came as defence counsel were seeking his testimony in a trial that revives the notorious Patty Hearst case. To his irritation, the episode overshadowed Scott's life, and his true legacy lay in his accomplishments in the fields of race relations and sports health.
fields.body:
The death of the American radical, Jack Scott, at the age of 57, came as defence counsel were seeking his testimony in a trial that revives the notorious Patty Hearst case. To his irritation, the episode overshadowed Scott's life, and his true legacy lay in his accomplishments in the fields of race relations and sports health.

He fought all his life against racism and drugs in sport, but it cost him dearly. During the 1970s, when blacks and women were excluded from sports management and coaching, Scott was a lonely and courageous pioneer. He wrote a book, The Athletic Revolution, that became a required text on exploitation in athletics, and established the Institute for the Study of Sport and Society in Oakland, California. Yet for years he was hounded by the FBI in a pattern of harassment of radicals that has become wearily familiar to Americans.

Scott was born in the conservative town of Scranton, Pennsylvania. He went to university at Stanford and Syracuse, New York, before getting his PhD in education at Berkeley. He specialised in the new subject of sociology of sport, and is now regarded as its founding father. In his early years, he was a superb sprinter, and he continued jogging into his 50s.

Scott's politics were formed in the turbulent 60s, during which he became sports editor of the left-wing San Francisco magazine, Ramparts. But he began to make real changes when a new and liberal chancellor of Oberlin College, Ohio, appointed him as athletics director and chairman of physical education in 1972. Scott immediately hired a black football coach, the first in a non-black university in American history, then a black basketball coach, a trampoline champion, and a woman to coach women's sports - appointments the like of which were unheard of at the time.

Amid great controversy, he next hired, as head track coach, Tommy Smith, who had created a sensation as one of two black American sprint medallists at the 1968 Olympics to raise clenched fists in a racial protest on the Mexico City podium. Smith was then a pariah in America - he was washing cars - but he turned out to be an excellent coach. The black football trainer, criticised as unqualified, fielded a Mexican-American as a key player and brought in Oberlin's first winning season for 25 years - the college has not had another since.

A conservative faction gained power and Scott was forced out of Oberlin, but not before he had broken the coaching colour barrier in American collegiate athletics. Back in Berkeley, with his lifelong partner Micki, he befriended survivors of the urban guerrilla group, the Symbionese Liberation Army, after six members were burned to death in a shocking 1974 police shoot-out in Los Angeles.

The group had earlier kidnapped the newspaper heiress Patty Hearst from Berkeley. Fearing more deaths on both sides, Scott smuggled Hearst and two comrades to a secret address on the other side of the country after persuading them to disarm. They stayed together for months, and Scott later said that Hearst had been an eager SLA convert and had declined his offer to let her go. "Patty was a rebel," he asserted.

At that time, Scott also met Kathy Soliah, who in 1975 allegedly placed bombs under two police cars to avenge an SLA friend who had died in the Los Angeles blaze. The bombs did not explode. Last year, police arrested Sara Jane Olson, a middle-aged mother and doctor's wife in Minnesota, and unmasked her as Soliah. She is to go on trial later this year, and Scott was to have given evidence, although prosecutors had successfully delayed a request to videotape his testimony.

For years after the SLA episode, Scott was blacklisted in academia and was even refused a job at a steelworks. Both the FBI and the media harassed him, but he was never charged with assisting the SLA fugitives. "He challenged the FBI to try him," said Micki Scott, who married Jack last January. "But they feared what would come out in a trial and backed down."

Scott finally got a job treating sports injuries with a new therapy technique that used a micro-current machine called a myomatic. He and Micki became international distributors of the device, and formed a successful clinic in Eugene, Oregon, America's athletics capital. He also published scores of magazine articles dealing with the abuse of drugs in sport and its racism. Among athletes he treated for injuries was Carl Lewis, the Olympic champion runner and jumper.

Scott is survived by his wife and their three children.

 Jack Scott, sports administrator and healer, born March 3 1942; died February 6 2000

fields.headline: Bright spark
fields.standfirst: British architect gives French pylons electrifying new look
fields.trailText: A new breed of curvaceous, aesthetically pleasing pylon, designed by a British architect, will soon be marching across the French countryside as the national electricity board replaces thousands of its old, ugly and widely detested models blown down in winter storms.
fields.body:
A new breed of curvaceous, aesthetically pleasing pylon, designed by a British architect, will soon be marching across the French countryside as the national electricity board replaces thousands of its old, ugly and widely detested models blown down in winter storms.

Ian Ritchie Architects, a London-based firm with offices in Paris, submitted one of two models selected by the French electricity board, EDF, from a field of 121 entrants that included such luminaries as international design guru Philippe Starck and the Italian car designer Roberto Giugiaro.

Mr Ritchie's winning entry - christened "Fern" because of its curvaceous, tapering design - will be used in sloping valleys and on hillsides. It can be painted green or yellow to blend in with natural vegetation, an EDF spokesman said yesterday.

"It's a very organic form that will integrate comfortably into the environment by virtue of its design and its colouring," the spokesman said. "As Mr Ritchie said in his design statement, a pylon should be more sculptural than industrial, and that is just what this is."

The second winning design, from the French architect Marc Mimram, will be used on large, flat areas of open country and will be most at home on the plains of northern France, where the first examples will be installed between Arras and Amiens later this month.

Called a "Reed", it consists of two slim uprights joined by a trio of elegant crossbars and closely resembles the mast of a square-rigged sailing vessel. "I wanted a pylon that would be as transparent as possible," Mr Mimram said. "The eye should scan straight across it, without stopping for a second."

That is certainly not the case with EDF's existing very high tension (VHT) pylons - towering, girder-built structures that have been a target of abuse from French countryside activists since they started disfiguring beauty spots in the early 1950s.

The two new designs were given a vigorous testing by EDF engineers and declared safe last month after withstanding pressures 15 times higher than existing norms. "They have to be tough as well as beautiful," the spokesman said. "Otherwise they're no good to anyone."

He added that EDF launched its design competition before the December storms, which have merely accelerated its pylon replacement programme.

fields.headline: Foreign news in brief
fields.trailText: Islamist group bombs Istanbul
fields.body:
Islamist group bombs Istanbul

Four bombs exploded in Istanbul yesterday, damaging four buildings, including a museum on Ataturk, the founder of secular Turkey, police said. There were no injuries.

The Great Eastern Islamic Raiders' Front, a secretive Islamic group, claimed responsibility. AP, Istanbul

Former minister faces trial

The Paris public prosecutor has recommended that Roland Dumas, 76, a former foreign minister and close friend of the late president François Mitterrand, stand trial accused of corruption involving the oil multinational Elf Aquitaine.

Judicial sources said five other suspects, including his ex-mistress Christine Deviers-Joncour, may have to answer charges. Jon Henley, Paris

Prodi moves on Chechnya

The European commission wants to send a new mission to Chechnya to investigate the case of the missing Russian journalist Andrei Babitsky. "Our commission was not admitted four days ago to visit Chechnya. We are insisting on sending [another]," Romano Prodi, the commission president, said. Reuters, Riga, Latvia

Belgium targets Cresson

Belgian judicial authorities have asked the European commission to lift the immunity of the French former prime minister Edith Cresson in connection with a cronyism scandal that helped bring down the EU executive, Belgian officials said yesterday. AP, Brussels

Priest held in murder inquiry

Guatemalan police have rearrested a Catholic priest accused of taking part in the 1998 bludgeoning to death of the human rights crusader Bishop Juan Jose Gerardi.

Father Mario Orantes - held in July 1998 but released for lack of evidence - was arrested in a Guatemala City hospital on Wednesday, police said. Reuters, Guatemala City

Benetton in death row suit

Missouri is suing Benetton, claiming the Italian clothing company deceived the US state when it used death row inmates in an advertising campaign. The state thought the inmates were being interviewed for a project on the death penalty. Benetton has said the pictures in this month's Talk magazine "aim at giving back a human face to the prisoners". AP, St Louis

webTitle: California judge annuls ban on straight-gay clubs at school

fields.headline: California judge annuls ban on straight-gay clubs at school
fields.trailText: Two controversial legal decisions from opposite ends of the United States are being hailed by gay rights campaigners as advances in civil rights.
fields.body:
Two controversial legal decisions from opposite ends of the United States are being hailed by gay rights campaigners as advances in civil rights.

In Vermont, a state supreme court ruling that gay relationships should be accorded equal status to heterosexual ones could make Vermont the first state in the country where gay marriages are legally recognised.

A US district court judge in Santa Ana, California, has ruled that schoolchildren in Orange county are entitled to hold meetings of Gay-Straight Alliance clubs on school premises. This is seen as a breakthrough for the groups which number more than 600 nationwide.

The clubs, which homosexual and heterosexual students belong to, were formed as an act of solidarity with gay teenagers who suffered persecution. According to members, their meetings are mainly social. A number of school districts have banned meetings by them at schools.

Judge David Carter's written judgment against Orange County's ban is the first time such an injunction has been won in America.

"Though the state education system has the awesome responsibility of inculcating moral and political values," said the judgment, "that does not permit educators to act as 'thought police', inhibiting all discussion that is not approved by, and in accord with, the official position of the state."

The judge turned down a request for leave to appeal made by the school district, which last night was considering its next legal move. One of the Gay-Straight clubs quickly held a meeting at a school, to vocal protests from opponents.

Utah had already banned all extra-curricular meetings at schools to stop Gay-Straight Alliance gatherings, but it is unclear how other states will react to the California ruling.

At the north-eastern corner of the country, in the Vermont state capital of Montpelier, thousands have attended public hearings in the past week on the issue of gay marriage, after the state supreme court ruled in December that gay couples were entitled to the same rights and benefits as heterosexual couples.

The state's judiciary committee now has to draft a bill on the subject. It is considered possible that Vermont could be the first state to recognise gay marriage - though it may stop short and instead recognise domestic partnership, in terms of property and health benefits, as California and Hawaii do.

On March 7, Californian voters will decide whether to support Proposition 22 which would explicitly deny recognition to gay marriages wherever they had been carried out.

webTitle: Misery of immigrants 15 to a cell in Italy's jails

fields.headline: Misery of immigrants 15 to a cell in Italy's jails
fields.standfirst: Despite official promises of reform following violent protests, conditions remain squalid for the 'guests' of Sicily's reception centre
fields.trailText: The squalor, riots and fatal fire that triggered street battles and uprisings in Italy's immigrant jails have forced the government into announcing sweeping reforms.
fields.body:
The squalor, riots and fatal fire that triggered street battles and uprisings in Italy's immigrant jails have forced the government into announcing sweeping reforms. But there is no cheering from the inmates at Trapani, where it all began.

Crammed 15 to a cell, unable to phone home and ignorant of their fate, they hear hammering and smell fresh paint - and guess, correctly, that this jail is to be expanded, not closed.

The Mediterranean, which carried them here, laps 200m (650ft) away. But through their bars they see only guards with machineguns and the rooftops of Trapani, a town on Sicily's western tip.

The December fire that killed four inmates and injured dozens more convulsed Italy with recrimination. It prompted an official inquiry, published this week, which yielded a charter of living conditions and the promise to close two of the country's 11 immigrant jails, which were opened only two years ago.

Human rights groups are furious that the bars, guards and batons will remain in place to quell inmates, who because they have committed no crime, are officially known as "guests" living in "reception centres".

Critics inside and outside Italy say they are little more than concentration camps. But the authorities insist that conditions are humane and that those suspected of entering the country illegally must be detained while their cases are investigated - otherwise they would melt away and never be found again.

European Union partners are anxious that Italy, a gateway for north Africa and the Balkans, holds firm.

But opposition to the centres is swelling. Both sides are pumping out propaganda. Further unrest could crack the government's resolve.

To the bodies slumped inside Trapani's jail, this was news. All they knew was that the demonstrators who shouted encouragement from the street and promised to close it have failed. Another centre is being built in the town in anticipation of ever-greater numbers.

Around 100 inmates are usually kept here. But while carpenters and painters repair damage from the fire - started deliberately by inmates in an attempt to divert guards during an attempted breakout - the number has shrunk to 49, all north African men. They are corralled in four cells on the third floor of what was built in 1927 as a retirement home.

Two fountains, a pond, geranium plants and four police cars fill the yard. Brown, 12ft grilles have been bolted onto the third-floor balcony. Four metal doors stand between the cells and the yard. There is also an exercise yard, concrete and empty except for weeds.

Breakfast is bread, water and coffee. Lunch and dinner is a polystyrene plate of hot meat, fish and rice delivered by charity workers and eaten in a separate dining area.

The government tried to defuse criticism by offering to let the charities take over administration; but they refused, saying they wanted no part in repression.

Guards patrol the balcony and are able at a glance to inspect each cell, because the facades are grilles, from which sprout dozens of hands and feet.

Tabib Rafik, a Tunisian, paid £160 to smugglers and landed on a beach. Like his 14 cellmates, he was quickly arrested under a 1998 law passed after pressure from the EU.

There were no jobs at home and Mr Rafik, 35, had heard there was work in Sicily as a farm labourer or, if he was lucky, in a restaurant.

Inmates must be released or deported after 30 days. Fear that they would be sent back home, and not the living conditions, explained the four riots and repeated escape attempts, said Leonardo Cerenzia, Trapani's prefect.

Mr Rafik and other inmates said different. The guards were not brutal, but the confinement made people desperate. Their cells had beds and toilets but little else. They felt trapped, cramped, dirty, bored and angry. One man displayed a collapsed nostril and complained that he had not been able to see a doctor.

Of the 8,000 detained in centres last year, 44% were deported.

"We have not stolen anything or hurt anyone - so why are we here? We just want to work," said Mr Rafik.

Critics say the centres are unconstitutional because entering Italy illegally is technically not a crime.

Zitouni Kamel, 43, claimed he faced persecution if deported back to Algeria. Thousands of protesters demanding reform have clashed with police in Rome, Milan and Florence. Authorities accused them of political opportunism, but promised to build better centres.

The government this week also announced that it would allow 63,000 non-EU people to enter legally this year. However, the UN estimated that Italy needs 300,000 every year just to replace its ageing workforce.

A two-week lull in disruption has bolstered the government's claim that its policies are working and that the centres are under control.

A guard at Trapani smiled in agreement. "Sure, everything is quiet. At the moment."

fields.headline: Archaelogists feud over oldest Americans
fields.standfirst: US doubts over prehistoric relics in Brazil reopen colonial wounds
fields.trailText: In the most underdeveloped state of Brazil, Piaui, lies one of the richest prehistoric archaeological sites in the world.
fields.byline: Alex Bellos  in Sao Raimundo Nonato, Piaui, Brazil
fields.body:
In the most underdeveloped state of Brazil, Piaui, lies one of the richest prehistoric archaeological sites in the world. Pedra Furada is also one of the most controversial sites in the Americas - splitting archaeologists into two emotionally charged camps and threatening to rewrite the history of the continent's colonisation.

A thinly inhabited, semi-arid area of sandstone rock shelters, 500 miles west of the coastal city Recife, Pedra Furada contains more than 400 prehistoric sites, including 340 stone walls full of ancient paintings. Researchers are still finding new remains at the rate of 40 a year.

But it is not the vast number of archaeological discoveries that has the academic world excited. It is their age.

Brazilian excavators, led by Niede Guidon, claim to have proved the existence of the oldest Americans. Ms Guidon claims that charcoal that she says is the remnant of camp fires has been carbon dated to 50,000 years ago.

This makes it the most ancient site in the Americas by a long chalk - about 40,000 years - and if true, poses fundamental questions about how humans arrived in South America well before it is believed they arrived in the North.

"There is a feeling that it's a blow against US imperialism. The evidence is open to different interpretations, so people tend to choose their favourite interpretation in terms of their biases. There is a certain tendency to cast aspersions on other people's excavation techniques.

"The whole thing is very fraught. People get very defensive and sensitive."

webTitle: Game pits EU force against its biggest enemy: red tape

fields.headline: Game pits EU force against its biggest enemy: red tape
fields.standfirst: A make-believe war next week could tell whether Europe's intervention scheme is just a fantasy
fields.trailText: It is a military planner's nightmare: two simultaneous crises on two different fronts.
fields.body:
It is a military planner's nightmare: two simultaneous crises on two different fronts.

In make-believe Yellowland, not a million miles from real-life Libya, long-range ballistic missiles threaten the cities of southern Europe; vital shipping lanes could be affected.

At the same time - further afield, but well within range of CNN - a civil war is raging in Kiloland, somewhere vaguely in the vicinity of Africa.

Thousands have been killed and injured in clashes between this fictitious country's rival factions - the Adonians and the Butonians. Hungry, frightened refugees are fleeing.

At an emergency meeting in New York, the UN security council has authorised international intervention to deal with an increasingly grave humanitarian situation.

But Nato cannot handle both problems at once. The US congress - recalling its troops' unhappy experience in Somalia when they and other foreign forces tried to bring aid and peace to areas terrorised by fighting warlords in 1992-94 - is unwilling to get sucked into a Kiloland quagmire. So in theory the hour of Europe has finally come.

No real soldiers, ships or planes are involved in Crisex 2000, beginning next week at Nato headquarters in Brussels and a few miles across town, at the Western European Union, the EU's long established but very untried defence arm.

But testing how these two military organisations will respond to this pair of notional crises is an unprecedented event in Europe's slowly emerging "defence identity".

Crisex's outcome will be an important first indication of whether the EU can acquire the military clout to match its economic power - and to act if the real moment comes.

"We want to get the EU and Nato, these two big sumo wrestlers at either end of Brussels, to talk to each other without it being a threat to each other's virility," says one diplomat. "We need to see how something like this actually works in practice."

Learning from the bloody lessons of Bosnia and Kosovo, the EU has at last begun to make progress on defence. At December's Helsinki summit, the Union pledged to build a 60,000-strong rapid reaction force for peacekeeping and humanitarian tasks, able to act where Nato as a whole is not engaged.

Throughout the long and tortuous process, the EU has had to keep Nato happy, to assuage fears - especially in Washington - that Europe is trying to undercut or duplicate what Nato does best.

British critics - including former foreign secretaries David Owen and Malcolm Rifkind - voiced similar fears on Wednesday.

Crisex is about the nuts and bolts of how the WEU, with almost no operational military experience or permanently available troops, would "borrow" Nato assets and capabilities - such as the heavy transport aircraft and satellite reconnaissance needed to deal with a Kiloland situation.

The six-day command post exercise will involve Nato's 19 members and the 11-strong WEU, which takes in neutral Ireland, Sweden, Finland and Austria. Europe will be led by a French admiral, Jean-Marie Ziriot; Nato by its deputy supreme commander, Rupert Smith, a British general. It is going to be a complex business.

The planners, poring over organisational diagrams and acronym-heavy flow charts, say that no less than 49 separate stages of consultation will be required before the hard decisions can be made.

Nato is not holding its breath. The US - as its defence secretary, William Cohen, stated bluntly last weekend at an international security gathering in Munich - fears that the European partners may be doing little more than building another unwieldy bureaucratic structure, while they go on slashing their military spending.

No one even expects WEU forces to be able to handle Yellowland - a clear projection of the "Club Mad" idea that sees a threat from a North African pariah like the Libyan leader Muammar Gadafy, whose state is a major oil supplier to several European countries. Nor could the EU deal with a big and difficult crisis on the scale of a future Kosovo.

But Europe might manage the sort of limited role envisaged in Kiloland, clearly inspired by recent African crises: Sierra Leone, say, or Rwanda, where international intervention was a bitter failure in 1994. "The scenario is entirely fictitious, but it contains all the generic elements to provide a realistic test in the real world," said a spokeswoman for the WEU.

Under current plans it will be 2003 before a European rapid reaction force might come into existence. Possible future roles could include peacekeeping in Cyprus, if the parties agreed, or even helping to police a Syria-Israel deal on the Golan Heights.

Next week EU foreign ministers are due to approve the first permanent committees to steer EU defence efforts. So Crisex comes at a key moment.

webTitle: River of cyanide runs through Europe

fields.headline: River of cyanide runs through Europe
fields.trailText: An Australian-owned gold mine in western Romania has disgorged 378,500 litres (100,000 gallons) of cyanide-contaminated water into the rivers of central Europe, triggering an ecological "catastrophe", according to Hungarian and European Union officials.
fields.byline: Nick Thorpe  in Budapest and agencies
fields.body:
An Australian-owned gold mine in western Romania has disgorged 378,500 litres (100,000 gallons) of cyanide-contaminated water into the rivers of central Europe, triggering an ecological "catastrophe", according to Hungarian and European Union officials.

Drinking-water supplies for 2.5m people have been threatened by the poison spill from the Aurul gold mine - near Baia Mare in the north of the country - which began 10 days ago. It is now heading downriver towards the Danube and has reached Yugoslavia.

On some sections of the river Tisza, 80% of fish have died.

But Esmeralda Exploration, the Perth-based company that owns 50% of the mine - 45% is owned by the Romanian government and 5% by foreign investors - has denied responsibility and claimed that reports of a disaster were "grossly exaggerated".

Ukrainians call the river the black Tisza, as it swells from mountain stream into medium-sized river and twists through ancient willow forests, touching Slovakia before straightening and broadening out to flow due south, through Hungary.

Hungarians call it the blonde Tisza, as the sand on its bed turns the water a yellow-brown.

But now it is the dead Tisza. Fishermen and local volunteers have been hauling dead fish from the river in large numbers to save the river birds which normally feed off them. Candle-lit vigils have been held beside the river. The full extent of the damage may not be known until new vegetation appears in early spring.

The Hungarian and Romanian environment ministers met yesterday to discuss the consequences of the accident and investigate who is responsible for it. There is no agreement on compensation for environmental damage between the two countries.

Zoltan Illes, the chairman of Hungary's environment committee, accused Esmeralda Exploration of engaging in "eco-colonisation".

"Nature is being destroyed here in central Europe," he said. "The health of hundreds of thousands is being endangered with technologies which may not be permitted in ... Australia or ... in western Europe."

The contaminated water was first discharged on January 30 when a sewage reservoir overflowed after a heavy snowfall, with the water making its way into the river Somes. From there, the polluted water flowed west into Hungary's river Tisza.

The Romanian media have since reported two other, smaller leaks of the poison and cyanide levels have been recorded at 700 times the permitted level in one river, according to the Romanian environment ministry.

The Tisza flows from Hungary into Yugoslavia, where the first traces of cyanide were detected yesterday. "The tip of the pollution spill has been monitored entering our territory," the Serbian agriculture, forestry and water management ministry said in a statement. "The ministry warns all users of the waters, the population living along the banks of the river Tisza, that water cannot be used for any purposes, nor can they fish."

By the time the poison reaches the Danube, they hope it will be sufficiently diluted not to cause further harm.

The EU commissioner for transport and energy, Loyola de Palacio, held talks in Budapest with Hungary's foreign minister, Janos Martonyi, and other officials and warned that "it's a European-dimension catastrophe". She is to seek extra funds to help Hungary clean up the pollution.

Esmeralda Exploration's chairman, Brett Montgomery, said in Perth yesterday that the incident had been grossly exaggerated and he did not expect his company to face compensation claims.

webTitle: Aboriginal boy's death in custody fuels debate on sentencing

fields.headline: Aboriginal boy's death in custody fuels debate on sentencing
fields.trailText: The death of a 15-year-old aboriginal boy in custody yesterday has given a tragic boost to an international campaign being fought by churches and civil libertarians against what they describe as unjust and draconian mandatory sentencing laws.
fields.body:
The death of a 15-year-old aboriginal boy in custody yesterday has given a tragic boost to an international campaign being fought by churches and civil libertarians against what they describe as unjust and draconian mandatory sentencing laws.

In the latest chapter of one of Australia's most acrimonious human rights debates, the unnamed orphan, who came from the remote community of Groote Eylandt, was five days away from the end of a mandatory 28-day sentence for stealing £35-worth of pens and paint when he hanged himself in a Darwin juvenile detention centre.

He was found unconscious with a bed sheet around his neck on Wednesday night, a correctional services spokesman said. He did not regain consciousness.

The already highly sensitive issue of indigenous deaths in jails and a current senate inquiry into the controversial sentencing laws of the Northern Territory and Western Australia mean the boy's death has caused an outcry around the country.

"Today is a day of shame for all Territorians," said the president of the outback territory's law society, Jon Tippett, following warnings that the laws could lead to such a death.

"We stand in breach of our international obligations at law, and we stand in breach of our obligations to children."

The North Australian aboriginal legal aid service is planning international legal action against the laws, which it says breach international human rights covenants ratified by Australia and do not deter crime.

The laws have been widely condemned by human rights groups, including Amnesty International.

Under the regime introduced in 1997 to counter rising crime against property, juveniles aged 15 or 16 are jailed for 28 days or sent on diversionary programmes for any second property crime.

But the boy, like many aboriginal youths, lived in an isolated area where there were no programmes, and detention was the only alternative.

The boy had been found guilty of breaking into an aboriginal community office and stealing pens, pencils and texts. He was also convicted of breaking into a local primary school and stealing pens and paint.

Selwyn Hausman, the director of the Miwatj aboriginal legal service, said the boy's offences of petty theft and damage would not have put him in a cell were it not for the legislation.

"He was still distressed. Within the context of the communities, they [the offences] are annoying but not something to go to jail for."

The Green party senator Bob Brown has introduced a bill to use federal powers to override the mandatory sentences. He has also spurred on the official inquiry, which is hearing evidence around the country, and wants the prime minister, John Howard, to intervene.

"While the horrible reality is we cannot restore life to this young indigenous person, the prime minister has a heavy responsibility to ensure a death doesn't occur in these circumstances," Mr Brown said.

Last April an aboriginal man, Kevin Cook, was jailed for one year for stealing a towel, as was a 17-year-old boy for stealing a packet of biscuits - in both cases because they were their third convictions.

But the Northern Territory government said the boy's death had nothing to do with mandatory sentencing and everything to do with youth suicide. It also claims the laws have not affected the rate at which aboriginal people go to jail.

The Northern Territory's chief minister and attorney general, Denis Burke, said: "We are dealing with self-destructive behaviour in youth which is very complex. To suggest this child died because of mandatory sentence is grotesque.

"We have mandatory sentencing laws up here because we treat property offences very seriously. They don't target indigenous children, and we don't believe aboriginal people should be given some separate system of justice."

fields.headline: Hillary outraged at Giuliani letter
fields.trailText: An angry Hillary Clinton, levelling her most direct attack yet against Rudolph Giuliani, her rival in the race for a New York senate seat, said she was "appalled" at a fund-raising letter signed by the mayor that accused her of "hostility to American religious traditions".
fields.byline: Michael Ellison in New York and the Washington Post
fields.body:
An angry Hillary Clinton, levelling her most direct attack yet against Rudolph Giuliani, her rival in the race for a New York senate seat, said she was "appalled" at a fund-raising letter signed by the mayor that accused her of "hostility to American religious traditions".

A story about the eight-page letter, which was written at the height of the controversy over the Sensation exhibition by British artists at Brooklyn museum of art in October, was published in the New York alternative weekly, the Village Voice, on Wednesday.

In the letter, the mayor describes Mrs Clinton as "an agent of the ultra-left" and says the "leftwing elite" supports "liberal judges [who] have banned the posting of even the ten commandments in our public schools".

Yesterday, Mrs Clinton responded, saying: "I am outraged that he [Mr Giuliani] would inject religion into this campaign in any form whatsoever. And to do it in a way to raise money for his campaign is something that he should take responsibility for.

"As a person of faith, I am appalled that he would make statements about me and my respect for religion."

Mr Giuliani said: "Not only do I stand by the letter, I'd like everyone in New York state to read it. If teachers want to put up the ten commandments they should be allowed to do that. The ten commandments is [sic] part of our tradition. It's part of western civilisation."

Ms Clinton believes displaying the ten commandments in classrooms contradicts the constitutional separation of church and state.

fields.headline: 'I'll have the beansprout salad, please'
fields.standfirst: Prisoner  Erwin James, serving a life sentence, reports on the revolution that has taken place in the kitchens of British jails - and reveals the scams and culture clashes that persist
fields.trailText: Prisoner  Erwin James, serving a life sentence, reports on the revolution that has taken place in the kitchens of British jails - and reveals the scams and culture clashes that persist
fields.body:
Contemplating the possibility of a prison sentence? A bit anxious about it? Don't worry - it's not all bad news. Sure, there are still elements of imprisonment which remain somewhat less than salubrious (menacing neighbours, lonely nights, sporadic violence, not to mention strange men in uniform). But when it comes to the food - relax.

The days of UFOs (unidentified floating objects) in stews and soups, and "surprise pie" (often rumoured to contain pigeon whenever a jail's resident flock had grown to proportions which necessitated a cull) are over. The fact is that, for some years now, a quiet revolution has been taking place in the kitchens of Britain's prisons.

Up and down the country, prison chefs have been devising new strategies and applying novel techniques in their quest to propitiate the prisoner's palate. Inmates who make up the kitchen workforce have finally acknowledged that hygiene is a legitimate concept (courses in which cookhouse etiquette is rigorously taught are almost universally standard) and health and safety regulations are strictly applied and adhered to.

In short, jail cuisine has at long last been rehabilitated. Unlike their counterparts from days gone by, those who enter Her Majesty's penal establishments nowadays have little to fear when they reach the "hot plate" (food serving counter). "Choice" has replaced "take it or leave it" as the new mantra of prison service dieticians, while imaginative catering staff go out of their way to promote the merits of "the healthy option" (always marked with a little star on the menus posted each week on the wing bulletin board).

There are limitations of course. Even the most fertile culinary imagination is going to be constricted by a budget of £1.38 per person, per day. In spite of this, however, 14 and in some cases 28 day menus are now being produced which include such delights as Portuguese beansprout salad, Hawaiian rice, and pomme de terre au gratin, regularly followed by fresh fruit or yoghurt.

Chicken and fish provide most of the protein and, in recent years, beef has become more conspicuous - although there is some suspicion that this has been as a result of a surplus due to mad cow disease (rather than society's generosity). So it is only really trusted when marinated in the fiercest Vindaloo sauce. But, overall, the old cliched portrayal of prison food can no longer be justified. Of course, there are detractors. You can never please all of the people all of the time, and prisoners can be notoriously fickle. But some of us remember the old days when the majority of hot plates were staffed by rows of defeated-looking men with grey eyes and greyer skin who served grey food to their isotropic fellows.

It was a time when the cabbage routinely had the genetic code boiled right out of its heart, and when the only hope you had of seeing anything green on your stainless steel tray (anything edible anyway) was to send your £1 subscription to the Vegan Society and then present your membership card when it arrived to the cook by way of "proof" that you were a bona fide vegan, in which case you were given a modicum of lettuce and tomato every other teatime; and as a bonus they even threw in a jar of yeast extract once a week.

Another good wheeze was to declare yourself a Mormon when asked your religion on first entering the jail. For reasons never ascertained, this entitled you to a pint of hot cocoa at suppertime, while all other religions had to make do with "tea" - actually a greasy, tobacco tinctured liquid served lukewarm from buckets and affectionately known as "diesel". You had to be quick off the mark with the Mormon wheeze, however, as "miraculous conversions" after tasting the diesel were greeted with little sympathy.

As for food hygiene, one lunchtime in a northern jail I thought I noticed a foreign body in the spaghetti.

"What the hell's that?" I said to the fellow with the ladle.

"What?" he said, scrutinising the translucent strands from behind blue tinted glasses.

"That!" I said pointing vigorously.

He reached in to retrieve the offending object. "Oh that?" he said. "It's only a matchstick. Look, it's not even been used," he continued gleefully, before depositing it in the top pocket of his once-white cotton serving jacket. "I'll dry that and save it for later." There were no lighters in prison then and individual matches were often split into as many as eight slithers to make them last.

In the long term jails, the introduction of "cooking facilities" (small kitchenettes on the end of landings) emerged as a saviour for many of those serving the heftiest sentences. On a spur, or a landing, food boats were formed, comprising three or four associates who pooled their prison wages and purchased meat and vegetables. This meant that at least two or three hearty meals a week could be enjoyed, which worked wonders for morale.

Then things escalated. Cookery books were borrowed from the prison library and cookery classes attended in education departments. Before long, some prisoners had become adept at preparing gourmet dishes arguably on a par with many of London's West End eateries. But it was bound to end in tears. Private parties graduated into bacchanal events where (yes, it's true) lobster and steaks were regularly consumed in vast quantities, washed down with gallons of vintage "hooch" (illicit fermenting liquid, usually orange flavoured). The attempted breakout at Whitemoor maximum security prison in 1992 brought the situation to a head. Following the inquiry into the escape attempt and the "revelations" that prison officers were ferrying in hampers of luxury food in prison vans, clampdowns were ordered in jails throughout the country.

For some years post-Whitemoor, all hungry convicts had to rely on for tucker treats at the hot plate were royal visits - or acts of God. On one occasion, a local fish farmer who had gone bust offered several hundred prime trout to the cook in a jail in which I was temporarily lodged. Most residents appreciated this unexpected gesture of benevolence, although one inmate, known as Brummie Bob, threatened to instigate a full-blown food strike if he wasn't provided with "proper scran, right fookin' now".

"But fresh trout baked whole is a delicacy," explained the cook.

"I don't give a fook," said Bob. "I'm not eating fish with staring eyes." (This from a man who once won a cannabis joint after having been dared to eat a live beetle).

It was inevitable that trouble at t'hot plate would increase with the proliferation of the prison population. Violent incidents spiralled, including assaults on kitchen staff, and even mini riots were not unusual in protest at being served "anaemic chips" or undercooked "duff" (a half brick of stodge covered in runny custard and alleged to be "the sweet").

Thankfully, collecting a meal from the hot plate today is a much less dramatic experience. For all that, I can guess what your thinking: what about the porridge? It's still available. When I went to collect my breakfast this morning, there was a choice of Cornflakes, Branflakes, Weetabix - or porridge, along with hot, buttered toast and fresh boiling water to make a refreshing cup of tea .

For lunch I'll be having baked fish. I've no idea what kind, but delicious - with diced carrots and petit pois. And for tea, I'll be having a stir fry, followed by peaches and jelly. Not too fancy, but really quite pleasant all the same.

So if anyone is considering a stretch soon, I hope these words have provided a morsel of reassurance concerning at least one aspect of what may be in store. By the way, may I recommend the healthy option? And bon appetit.

fields.headline: Toxic shock
fields.standfirst: For decades, the local ICI complex tipped poison into a huge chemical dump. Now, 25 years after it was sealed off, a lethal gas is seeping into nearby houses and residents are being evacuated.  John Vidal  reports from a village staring death in the face
fields.trailText: For decades, the local ICI complex tipped poison into a huge chemical dump. Now, 25 years after it was sealed off, a lethal gas is seeping into nearby houses and residents are being evacuated.  John Vidal  reports from a village staring death in the face
fields.body:
This is a toxic nightmare. You live cheek-by-jowl with one of the world's largest chemical complexes. You respect the people working there. You trust the company when it says it is cleaning up its act. You live in a tight, friendly community. You raise your children in the shadow of the stainless steel chimneys and tanks, the pylons and gantries, the waste ground, the lagoons and walkways that stretch three miles along the grey Mersey estuary.

And then there's a knock at the door. A man from ICI Runcorn says traces of a gas called HCBD have been detected in some of the boreholes they have drilled on the edge of two old quarries behind your house. The quarries, as you know, were once company waste dumps, but they were capped decades ago and are now a pleasant place where horses graze.

The man says there's nothing to worry about, but would you like your house monitored for the gas, just to be safe? Of course you agree. It all seems routine, like the company's "dear neighbour" letters that are dropped round every few months warning you what to do if you hear the sirens wail. But the sirens don't sound these days and you're not bothered.

So they put the monitors in to check for this HCBD, and three days later they call by and tell you that, bad news, your house has tested positive and the local health authority is advising you to move out immediately. They are reassuring, but in the next breath they say that they will buy your house if you like. And not just yours, but all those in the street and most of the several hundred others in the village.

And then you discover that HCBD is a really evil toxic gas that leaves a build-up of poison in your kidneys, and that one in five of all the houses they have tested is showing positive.

So you start thinking. What else is in those waste tips? Why are there so many serious illnesses in the village? What are they not telling you? What about all those other pollution incidents? Is there another agenda? Why must we go so quickly if we have been living here so long? Why does Friends of the Earth call ICI Runcorn Britain's second most polluting factory? What is the real toxic legacy of Britain's oldest chemical complex? And the stories of what went on in the old days all start coming out...

The village of Weston, population around 1,000, with its good housing, good schools, good church and people, is deep in this nightmare. Ever since ICI knocked on 120 doors along Weston Road in the first week of January, the stress levels have been rising. So far, 19 out of 104 properties in the street tested near the two linked waste tips have proved positive for HCBD, and more than 50 people have been evacuated to local hotels.

Many more people are expecting to leave when they have been tested, and everyone is considering whether or not to move permanently. The special health phone line has been jammed. The scout hut has been condemned. All the neighbouring communities as far away as Runcorn are fearful about the possible effect on property prices, and the village, which is mentioned in the Domesday book, faces disintegration.

With ICI not able to answer all the questions, with so many conflicting reports and little in writing, the rumours are flying - massive public meetings are being held every week and lawyers are touting for business. What will happen to the council tenants, the old and the ill? Can people sue? The questions from every quarter to the company, the local council, and the health authority are deafening.

"Some people are panicking," says David Farrimond, who owns the old British Legion club and a bungalow on Weston Road. It hasn't been tested yet, but the sale of his two-acre property has already fallen through and he's worried about his health.

"How can they find somewhere equivalent for me? What about my dogs? They can't go to a hotel. There's real fear, confusion and uncertainty. People are calling this place the 'village of the damned'. Friends and neighbours are phoning in, which just adds to the stress. We don't know what is happening."

"It's a really difficult time," says Brian Johnstone, a young civil servant whose house, also on Weston Road, was declared fit last week, but who reluctantly thinks he will have to sell because of his two young children. He is on the hastily set-up village action committee and is in regular talks with ICI. The worries, he says, are turning to anger, and the trust is going. The mood, he and others say, is that no one wants to go but few people will want to stay if the village is deserted.

"We're ordinary people, with families and jobs. None of us has ever faced a situation like this before. Everyone's livelihood is at stake," he says. Like most people, he doesn't blame ICI for trying to be responsible, only for the way they seem to be handling the crisis. "The company is only doing its moral duty, but facts are few and far between," he says.

ICI has never been in this situation before, either. The irony is that it was genuinely trying to be responsible and, as part of a corporate policy, to clear up the mess that it thought earlier chemical industry generations had made. Since 1993 it has been investigating the tip and the complex surrounding geology and poring over its old records to see if there is anything down there that could be affecting today's environment for people.

Having checked the aquifers - where they found no problems - they dug the boreholes. "It was a shock to find the HCBD in the quantities we did. We did not expect to find it at all," says a spokesman. He knows that if the company hadn't looked, no one would have been the wiser.

But ICI is not saying precisely what quantities of the gas it has found, except that it varies from house to house, with the majority of positive readings in the range of 2.0 to 2.8 parts per billion. However, it admits there were two houses where the readings were almost three times this level. The acceptable occupational exposure rate is 20 parts per billion for an eight-hour day, but in many cases people have lived in these houses for years.

ICI will have to continue monitoring the village, because it believes the release of gas could also depend on the season and atmospheric pressure. Moreover, the company has no idea how much gas is there, where it is going, how long it will continue to leach out, how far it could spread or how dangerous it is. More than a dozen ICI staff and members of the British Geological Survey, the Building Research Establishment and others scientists in the US and Britain are trying to predict, analyse and verify the results so far, but vapour transport is complex. "But we strongly believe this is a localised problem", says a spokesman, before adding that nothing surprises him any more.

Nor is ICI saying what else is in the tip, or what precisely they were looking for when they dug the boreholes. It leaves the suspicion, say many in the village, that there is far worse down there, and this is why they are offering to buy up the houses immediately.

Not true, says the company, which knows it would also have been damned had it not made the offer to buy everyone out immediately. "Every way we turn, there is an upside and a downside. But there is no concern that we are hiding. The nightmare is what is happening now - disrupting the community. We deeply regret this," says a spokesman.

Nevertheless, the mea culpas are falling on deaf ears and there is little local sympathy for the company; it may have to pay many millions to sort this out, but ICI and the chemical industry in general went unchecked and unregulated for years.

The Weston pits are stockpiles of 50 or more years of chemical production. ICI's records show there have been up to 10,000 chemical processes on the site in that time, and the old-timers in the village say that just about every imaginable nasty has been dumped there.

Some, such as Bruce Nicholson, remember playing with the mercury that appeared on the surface of the waste tips. "There are whole train carriages, whole laboratory cell rooms - like vast batteries of mercury there," says Derek Smith, who worked for ICI for years. He and others remember ICI dumping toxic waste, quite legally, in lagoons, on marshland, in the river and in just about every hole in the vicinity.

The bulk of the several million tons of waste in the two quarries is rubble, lime, chlorinated solvents, chemical catalysts and general industrial waste. But also known to be dumped were large amounts of highly toxic mercury, sodium, perchlorethylene, trichlorethylene, carbide and lime slurry, and thousands of unmarked steel drums whose contents are unknown. The site made chlorine gas during the second world war, then helped make atomic bombs. More recently, it was one of the world's largest producers of CFCs - the propellants and coolants that destroy the ozone layer. It is now one of Britain's greatest producers of deadly cancer-causing dioxins and is hounded by Friends of the Earth for its pollution record.

The full name of the chemical now leaching into the sandstone rock outside the quarry is hexachloro-1,3-butadiene, HCBD for short. It is not found naturally in the environment, but is created in industrial chemical processes and used mainly in the manufacture of rubber compounds and, in liquid form, as a solvent and lubricant.

HCBD is toxic and known effects include shortened lifespan, reproductive problems, lowered fertility and changes in appearance and behaviour. If ingested, it concentrates in the kidney.

The solutions to Weston's nightmare are far from obvious. Remedial work could, theoretically, be done. It may be possible, says ICI, to dig up the foundations of every house in the neighbourhood and put a membrane in, or they could try to reline the waste tips. No decisions are being made yet but the likelihood is that just as ICI built houses for so many of its workers 100 years ago, so it will have to destroy much of Weston.

This is a problem that councils, companies and individuals are going to have to face increasingly often. Britain's toxic legacy is huge and nasty, and there are hundreds of communities living on or near similar waste tips. In April, local authorities will be forced to assess all their toxic liabilities and, according to ICI, many other companies will be in the same position as they are in five years' time.

"ICI made this town," says Minnie, at 83 the second-oldest living inhabitant. She has lived in Weston for 60 years and has just been to one of the almost daily drop-in sessions that the company is holding in the church hall. She wants a gas monitor in her home, though it is not near the worst affected area. "This used to be such a lovely little village," she says. "There were five farms here. Then the war came and the motorway and now we've got this. You know, we didn't have the word environment then. It was so nice."
