"But we strongly believe this is a localised problem", says a spokesman, before adding that nothing surprises him any more. Nor is ICI saying what else is in the tip, or what precisely they were looking for when they dug the boreholes. It leaves the suspicion, say many in the village, that there is far worse down there, and this is why they are offering to buy up the houses immediately. Not true, says the company, which knows it would also have been damned had it not made the offer to buy everyone out immediately. "Every way we turn, there is an upside and a downside. But there is no concern that we are hiding. The nightmare is what is happening now - disrupting the community. We deeply regret this," says a spokesman. Nevertheless, the mea culpas are falling on deaf ears and there is little local sympathy for the company; it may have to pay many millions to sort this out, but ICI and the chemical industry in general went unchecked and unregulated for years. The Weston pits are stockpiles of 50 or more years of chemical production. ICI's records show there have been up to 10,000 chemical processes on the site in that time, and the old-timers in the village say that just about every imaginable nasty has been dumped there. Some, such as Bruce Nicholson, remember playing with the mercury that appeared on the surface of the waste tips. "There are whole train carriages, whole laboratory cell rooms - like vast batteries of mercury there," says Derek Smith, who worked for ICI for years. He and others remember ICI dumping toxic waste, quite legally, in lagoons, on marshland, in the river and in just about every hole in the vicinity. The bulk of the several million tons of waste in the two quarries is rubble, lime, chlorinated solvents, chemical catalysts and general industrial waste. But also known to be dumped were large amounts of highly toxic mercury, sodium, perchlorethylene, trichlorethylene, carbide and lime slurry, and thousands of unmarked steel drums whose contents are unknown. The site made chlorine gas during the second world war, then helped make atomic bombs. More recently, it was one of the world's largest producers of CFCs - the propellants and coolants that destroy the ozone layer. It is now one of Britain's greatest producers of deadly cancer-causing dioxins and is hounded by Friends of the Earth for its pollution record. The full name of the chemical now leaching into the sandstone rock outside the quarry is hexachloro-1,3-butadiene, HCBD for short. It is not found naturally in the environment, but is created in industrial chemical processes and used mainly in the manufacture of rubber compounds and, in liquid form, as a solvent and lubricant. HCBD is toxic and known effects include shortened lifespan, reproductive problems, lowered fertility and changes in appearance and behaviour. If ingested, it concentrates in the kidney. The solutions to Weston's nightmare are far from obvious. Remedial work could, theoretically, be done. It may be possible, says ICI, to dig up the foundations of every house in the neighbourhood and put a membrane in, or they could try to reline the waste tips. No decisions are being made yet but the likelihood is that just as ICI built houses for so many of its workers 100 years ago, so it will have to destroy much of Weston. This is a problem that councils, companies and individuals are going to have to face increasingly often. Britain's toxic legacy is huge and nasty, and there are hundreds of communities living on or near similar waste tips. In April, local authorities will be forced to assess all their toxic liabilities and, according to ICI, many other companies will be in the same position as they are in five years' time. "ICI made this town," says Minnie, at 83 the second-oldest living inhabitant. She has lived in Weston for 60 years and has just been to one of the almost daily drop-in sessions that the company is holding in the church hall. She wants a gas monitor in her home, though it is not near the worst affected area. "This used to be such a lovely little village," she says. "There were five farms here. Then the war came and the motorway and now we've got this. You know, we didn't have the word environment then. It was so nice."

Sandwich bar with sonic sandwiches, quiches, pizzas, salads and other bits and bobs side by side with neighbourhood restaurant, a sort of small-scale bistro with nice, clean-cut lines and proper food, from Cumberland sausage, black pudding, leek mash and onion gravy to canneloni with spinach, mushrooms, ricotta and tomato for vegetarians, by way of grilled sardines and gremolata, Thai green chicken curry and ciabatta steak sandwich and fries. fields.headline: Petronella Wyatt
fields.trailText: Age: 31 going on 60.
fields.body:
Age: 31 going on 60.

Occupation: Comely yet bufferish controversialist and former deputy editor of the Spectator.

Any relation to the bow tie-toting diarist, eccentric and bon viveur of the same name? His daughter and literary eulogiser.

So why do I need to know about her? Because she has just submitted her considered contribution to the debate about section 28.

And? "Section 28 works me up into a hot lather and I am filled with loathing and disgust for anyone who favours its repeal," she writes in this week's Spectator.

Goodness. Why is she so exercised? Because she's "drowning in a sea of homosexuality".

Eh? "It is like the Invasion of the Body Snatchers - sinister gay militants with self-righteous brimstone in their hearts are taking over the world."

But I thought some of Petsy's best friends were gay. They are, and she still worships "those ne plus ultra of gays, Cole Porter and Noel Coward".

Sorry to be dim but remind me what ne plus ultra means. "Extreme or perfect state", as in "my friend Tessa Keswick, the ne plus ultra of the distaff set."(P Wyatt in the Spectator, December 4 1999.)

Anyway, what is Petsy's evidence for this gay conspiracy? A good-looking chap she dated a number of times declined to take the relationship further, explaining that he had a boyfriend.

Fair enough, surely. Not according to Petsy: "Imagine saying to a black man you wouldn't go to bed with them because you didn't fancy blacks... you'd be arrested."

It does sound a bit rum when you put it like that. "The most colossal case of sexist discrimination imaginable", to be exact.

Has Petsy had trouble finding male companions then? Not exactly, though she's always "found them lacking" compared to her father.

Not to be confused with: Cardinal Thomas Winning.

Do say: Petsy's the ne plus ultra of comely, bufferish controversialists.

Don't say: I'm sorry Petsy, but I dance to the beat of a different drum.

fields.headline: Chaos looms for impotent Wahid
fields.standfirst:
Indonesian president blames economic woes on former military leader's refusal to stand down

Indonesia and East Timor: special report
fields.trailText: The Indonesian president, Abdurrahman Wahid, yesterday accused his rebellious security minister, General Wiranto, of undermining efforts to revive the country's economy by refusing to resign despite having being ordered to do so half a dozen times.
fields.body:
The Indonesian president, Abdurrahman Wahid, yesterday accused his rebellious security minister, General Wiranto, of undermining efforts to revive the country's economy by refusing to resign despite having being ordered to do so half a dozen times.

But social workers and analysts in Jakarta are warning that Mr Wahid's own failure to tackle major socio-economic issues is risking a social explosion greater than the one which toppled the dictator Suharto in May 1998.

Speaking in South Korea, on the penultimate leg of a 16-day overseas tour, Mr Wahid said that Gen Wiranto's intransigence was stifling Indonesia's recovery after more than two years of economic turmoil.

"Because of him - his refusal to step down, to resign voluntarily - the country loses the opportunity to have investors, the chance to have an economic comeback," the president said.

Gen Wiranto was first asked to resign 12 days ago after Indonesia's human rights commission implicated him in crimes against humanity in East Timor.

But he insists he is innocent of any wrongdoing and has said he will not step down until he has discussed the matter with Mr Wahid, who is due home from a 16-day overseas tour on Sunday.

The stand-off has sparked fears of a coup, which the armed forces commander, Admiral Widodo Adi Sutjipto, yesterday again stressed would never happen.

The uncertainty has hit Jakarta's financial markets and increased foreign investors' reluctance to commit funds to Indonesia.

"Until the political situation is resolved, I'm telling people to stay away from Indonesia and maintain a wait-and-see attitude," one Singaporean investment consultant said.

But he added that there was much more to Indonesia's "political situation" than the Wahid-Wiranto confrontation.

"Much of the government does not seem to be functioning properly. Many of the ministers don't know what to do and the result is inaction."

Forestry, education, health, the alleviation of poverty and the legal system are all areas where reform is crucial if Indonesia is to recover from the political and economic turmoil of the last two years.

But little is being done. "How can I comment [on his record]? The minister of national education has not yet done anything," the education expert Utomo Danaanjaya said. The education department's funding has been cut by more than 20% in the next financial year.

Similar accusations of inaction are levelled at the health ministry, which has slashed its budget by almost a third to fund debt repayments.

Most people blame Mr Wahid for the inertia. Since coming to office he has been preoccupied with defusing the threat posed by the military and religious militants, and winning foreign support and investment.

"He also likes to let them guess, keep them confused," Harry Tjan Silalahi, a political analyst and long-time friend of the president, said of the cabinet. "For if they don't know what he wants, then the ministers won't act against him."

This is at the heart of Mr Wahid's problems. He does not know who he can trust.

When he became president in October he was forced to create a cabinet of national unity and appoint people who were not his natural allies.

The result is that the silent majority at the bottom of Indonesia's social ladder are being neglected.

"Tens of millions of people are getting practically no help to fill their stomachs," said Bambang Rustanto, who helps women in Jakarta's slums set up community financing schemes. "The social safety net does not reach them and local government officials take much of the aid," he claimed.

Conditions are equally bad in rural areas, according to the social commentator Wimar Witoelar. "We've underestimated the urgency of the problem of the 'traditional [rural] people'," he said. "We have to shift the role of the 'traditional people' out of the shadow and deal with them as equals."

If Mr Wahid does not act soon to alleviate poverty he will run the risk of social unrest, believes Harry Tjan Silalahi, a political analyst and a long-time friend of the president.

"The oil of discontent is everywhere," he said. "It's the residue from former regimes and it's not been cleaned yet."

Violence has already flared this year on the island of Lombok and briefly in the city of Yogyakarta. But worse strife is brewing, Mr Rustanto said.

"It might not happen for more than a year," he said. "But when it does it will be worse than in May 1998 when Suharto fell and hundreds of people died."

 Indonesian prosecutors yesterday named Mr Suharto as a suspect in a corruption investigation and summoned him for questioning on Monday.

Lawyers representing Mr Suharto, 78, said he was too frail to answer questions about allegations that he misused tens of millions of pounds amassed by charities he controlled during his 32-year regime.

Mr Suharto is also accused of stealing billions of pounds for himself and his family while he was president.

fields.headline: Food on the net
fields.trailText: www.foodferry.co.uk
fields.body:
www.foodferry.co.uk

Promising to take all the hassle away from the weekly shop, but not confining you to one supermarket, the Food Ferry offers to bound around the capital in search of the freshest fruit and veg (from Covent Garden market), meat, fish and general groceries and deliver them to your door.

Pros: Paper catalogue can save time online. Extensive range of organic and fresh produce. Drivers will unpack your groceries.

Cons: Operates in central London only - but try www.groceries.org and www.mylocalshop.co.uk for other areas.

Delivery: Next day is standard but they can do same day. Charges start at £2; the more you pay, the more precise the delivery time.

fields.headline: Jungle fever
fields.standfirst: He is one of the last great explorers. In 40 years of adventuring in Latin America, he has discovered more than 20 new plant and animal species. On the eve of his latest Amazon expedition, Charles Brewer-Carias talks to  Alex Bellos  about mortality, survival and eating the intestines of the tapir
fields.trailText: He is one of the last great explorers. In 40 years of adventuring in Latin America, he has discovered more than 20 new plant and animal species. On the eve of his latest Amazon expedition, Charles Brewer-Carias talks to  Alex Bellos  about mortality, survival and eating the intestines of the tapir
fields.body:
If the British Council ever decided to sponsor a competition to find the Latin American who is most quintessentially English - in name, looks and spirit - then the wise money would be on the Venezuelan Charles Brewer-Carias. When I first met him, on a suffocatingly hot Caracas afternoon, he was wearing a tweed jacket with leather elbow patches, a monogrammed belt, circular-rimmed glasses and had a handlebar moustache in spiffing Terry-Thomas style.

Brewer-Carias is an explorer, in the tradition of the great gentlemen explorers of the Empire. Perhaps more than any living Englishman, he fulfils the romantic stereotype of the swashbuckling jungle adventurer - bold, intrepid and impeccably proper. He politely cut short our first interview, giving possibly the most exotic excuse ever given to a journalist - he had to get back home because a taxonomist was waiting to name a frog after him.

Grandson of the Victorian British vice-consul to La Guaira, the port serving Caracas, Brewer-Carias seems to have lived a life frozen in the era of Charles Darwin and David Livingstone. Now aged 61, he has made 148 expeditions into the Amazon jungle, lived with two Indian tribes, designed an army-standard jungle fighting knife (the Brewer survival knife) and discovered more than 20 types of plant, insect, bird and reptile that now bear his name. In March he will make his 149th, to the Autana Lake, an unexplored black water lake where according to local myths Loch Ness-style monsters lurk in the deep.

For foreign explorers arriving in Caracas, Brewer-Carias is the first man to call. Redmond O'Hanlon, who describes him as a "popular hero", needed his services when planning In Trouble Again, his account of a daredevil trip up the Orinoco. Brewer-Carias sorted out the writer's jungle permits, against his better judgment. "It is sheer luck that they came back alive," he says. "They did things much more dangerous than I would have gone through. [O'Hanlon] was absolutely crazy."

Brewer-Carias lives in a house overlooking Caracas that he built himself. A table of 23 machetes welcomes you as you come through the door. Display cases of beetles and butterflies adorn the walls. A pet snake sleeps on a table. Four tarantulas stand menacingly still in separate glass boxes.

"It took me a while to get used to the tarantulas," says his wife, Fanny, aged 34. "But they are very easy to look after. You only need to feed them one mouse a month."

In the 70s, Brewer-Carias made several excursions to La Gran Sabana, a mountainous area in the south of Venezuela that was first reached - but never scaled - by Sir Walter Raleigh in the 16th century and became immortalised in Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's classic The Lost World. Brewer-Carias discovered huge sinkholes in the jungle - holes 350m deep and of a similar diameter - which he abseiled down and lived in for five days.

He made his name internationally by leading the largest natural history expedition ever carried out, to the Cerro de la Neblina (the Misty Mountain) in the southwest of Venezuela, which lasted from 1983 to 1987 and involved 127 scientists from several institutions, including Kew Gardens.

For our second meeting, he chose the Caracas Country Club - a pocket of colonial opulence in an otherwise slum-covered city. Around us, rich Venezuelans were playing golf as he regaled me with his jungle tales. "The trick of survival is to know everything around you," he said, pointing at a cultivated tree overlooking a well-tended green. "That one is extremely poisonous. It will help you stun fish to kill them in the water." He then sipped his mineral water.

Lunch arrived, which provoked conversation about Amazonian cuisine. "The worst thing I've eaten was the boiled guts and shit of the tapir," he said. "It looks like shit. It smells like shit. But you have to be objective. The tapir only eats leaves. You have to tell yourself that it's just vegetables."

Despite approaching retirement age, Brewer-Carias shows no sign of slowing down. He is working on several projects, including setting up a biological station and compiling a detailed catalogue of the 250,000 pictures he has taken of the flora and fauna of the Venezuelan Amazon. A tough, spindly-looking man, he remains in enviable shape for his age. Especially since his medical history is a textbook of tropical diseases - including the non-healing ulcer leishmaniasis, and a sting by the "24-hour ant", a wasp-sized ant whose bite is the most-feared pain in the jungle. And of course malaria, several times. "Malaria is so common I don't even count it as a sickness any more," he shrugged.

When it comes to his physical performance, however, his Latin machismo eclipses his gentlemanly reserve. To every younger man that passed our table he would make a cheeky boast about how he could swim faster, run quicker or push heavier weights.

He does 120 chin-ups every day and is current holder of Venezuela's over-40s freestyle swimming record - the same time he swum as 100m national champion in the 1950s. "Put your fingers here," he challenged as he led them to the middle of his chest and flexed his pectorals, trapping my hand in his taut cleavage. "See how strong I am?"

Brewer-Carias trained as a dentist and despite his vast extracurricular knowledge it remains his only professional scientific expertise. His first jungle trips were funded by the dental practice he ran in Caracas during the 1960s and 70s. When, in 1960, he spent a year living with the Yekuana Indians, he made the first studies of Amazonian Indians' teeth, which resulted in his first book. He has since published six more, and more than 10 articles for academic journals.

"Charles is not an academic, but he has tremendous first-hand knowledge of the Venezuelan Amazon," says Brian Boom, vice-president for botanical science at the New York Botanical Garden. "He is self-taught through reading, talking and travelling with lots of academics in a variety of fields over the years, but mostly from his own explorations. He views himself as a modern-day Humboldt, and I would wager he knows his way around the southern part of Venezuela as well as anyone alive."

Brewer-Carias has kept contact with the Yekuana - whose language he speaks fluently - and the Yanomami, the world's largest Stone Age tribe, since he first met them. He finds it disturbing, however, going back to the Indian villages he went to as a young man. "I am struck by the Indians who were young in 1960 and now are very old. I feel perfect. It is a shocking experience.

"You are confronted with your own mortality. This drives a lot in my life. I am running away from mortality by having these fulfilling experiences."

However, Brewer-Carias's work with Napoleon Chagnon, whose book on the Yanomami is now a standard anthropological text, has led both men to be banned from a large part of the Venezuelan Amazon. He says it is because they have campaigned against the work of missionaries, and upset the vested interests of landowners. The accusations by regional politicians are that Brewer-Carias has enslaved and sexually abused Indians as well as dealing in their plasma.

The international academic community sides with the explorer. Roy McDiarmid, chief US government herpetologist at the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, is convinced of Brewer-Carias's good intentions. He says: "I have always found him very sincere. But I can understand why people would find him offensive. He can get things done when other people can't. Part is his political connections. Part is just him: he never accepts no for an answer. He does piss people off."

Brian Boom adds: "It is nonsense that he 'enslaved' indians. I have been with Charles in the Yanomami area, and I have only seen him behave in a completely considerate fashion with the Indians. Charles admires and respects indigenous people, and I cannot imagine for an instant that there is any truth to these allegations.

"I have known Charles for some 15 years, and there always seems to be someone at odds with him or what he is doing. I think it has a lot to do with jealousy: he is athletic; he is smart; he is comfortable financially; he has published successful books and spectacular photographs; he is a character with charisma and he tells it like it is. All of these traits combine to make him a target for others."

Brewer-Carias has always been controversial. In 1979 he was made Minister for Youth Affairs. He is remembered for the "frontier camps" he set up - "a cross between a kibbutz and the Foreign Legion", he says - which enabled 250,000 boys to visit Venezuela's remote borders. On one occasion he took a group of 40 boys and invaded territory disputed with Guyana, creating an international diplomatic incident, and in the process earning himself a military award. He has also infuriated environmentalists by buying a gold mine from the government, which critics believe goes against his environmental credentials.

Brewer-Carias ripostes that you have to be realistic. "A single 20-mile road does more damage than all the mines that have been dug in Venezuela in the last 100 years," he says.

"Charles is not a specialist in birds, or botany or geology," says Juan Carlos Ramirez, an Amazonian tour operator. "But he knows a lot about a lot of things and he is able to put these things together. He is absolutely the greatest explorer in Venezuela alive today."

Roy McDiarmid believes his expertise has furthered understanding of the jungle: "He has learnt a lot from his connections with the native people and with scientists. He knows enough to be able to provide an interface between the public and the scientific sides. There is not enough of that sort of stuff going on. He has been able to popularise Venezuela's national, natural heritage."

Brewer-Carias's English heritage dates back to his paternal grand-father, Mathias Brewer, who was made vice-consul in at La Guaira in 1895 and served for half a century. It perhaps explains Charles's look. Always sporting stiff collars, a black hat and an umbrella, Mathias was a well-known sight in Caracas until his death in 1967.

"I think that my grandfather was more Victorian than the people from the island," says Charles, "because he considered himself a foreign example or showcase of the Empire abroad, and he behaved in a very stiff and ethical way. We were all educated believing in the greatness of the Empire."

The Anglophile feelings remain in his blood. "I would surely love to be regarded as English. I would love to recover that part of my ancestry," says Brewer-Carias, his thick South American accent the only hint that he is not in fact a Home Counties grandee.

Grandson of the Victorian British vice-consul to La Guaira, the port serving Caracas, Brewer-Carias seems to have lived a life frozen in the era of Charles Darwin and David Livingstone. Now aged 61, he has made 148 expeditions into the Amazon jungle, lived with two Indian tribes, designed an army-standard jungle fighting knife (the Brewer survival knife) and discovered more than 20 types of plant, insect, bird and reptile that now bear his name. In March he will make his 149th, to the Autana Lake, an unexplored black water lake where according to local myths Loch Ness-style monsters lurk in the deep. For foreign explorers arriving in Caracas, Brewer-Carias is the first man to call. Redmond O'Hanlon, who describes him as a "popular hero", needed his services when planning In Trouble Again, his account of a daredevil trip up the Orinoco. Brewer-Carias sorted out the writer's jungle permits, against his better judgment. "It is sheer luck that they came back alive," he says. "They did things much more dangerous than I would have gone through. [O'Hanlon] was absolutely crazy." Brewer-Carias lives in a house overlooking Caracas that he built himself. A table of 23 machetes welcomes you as you come through the door. Display cases of beetles and butterflies adorn the walls. A pet snake sleeps on a table. Four tarantulas stand menacingly still in separate glass boxes. "It took me a while to get used to the tarantulas," says his wife, Fanny, aged 34. "But they are very easy to look after. You only need to feed them one mouse a month." In the 70s, Brewer-Carias made several excursions to La Gran Sabana, a mountainous area in the south of Venezuela that was first reached - but never scaled - by Sir Walter Raleigh in the 16th century and became immortalised in Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's classic The Lost World. Brewer-Carias discovered huge sinkholes in the jungle - holes 350m deep and of a similar diameter - which he abseiled down and lived in for five days. He made his name internationally by leading the largest natural history expedition ever carried out, to the Cerro de la Neblina (the Misty Mountain) in the southwest of Venezuela, which lasted from 1983 to 1987 and involved 127 scientists from several institutions, including Kew Gardens. For our second meeting, he chose the Caracas Country Club - a pocket of colonial opulence in an otherwise slum-covered city. Around us, rich Venezuelans were playing golf as he regaled me with his jungle tales. "The trick of survival is to know everything around you," he said, pointing at a cultivated tree overlooking a well-tended green. "That one is extremely poisonous. It will help you stun fish to kill them in the water." He then sipped his mineral water. Lunch arrived, which provoked conversation about Amazonian cuisine. "The worst thing I've eaten was the boiled guts and shit of the tapir," he said. "It looks like shit. It smells like shit. But you have to be objective. The tapir only eats leaves. You have to tell yourself that it's just vegetables." Despite approaching retirement age, Brewer-Carias shows no sign of slowing down. He is working on several projects, including setting up a biological station and compiling a detailed catalogue of the 250,000 pictures he has taken of the flora and fauna of the Venezuelan Amazon. A tough, spindly-looking man, he remains in enviable shape for his age. Especially since his medical history is a textbook of tropical diseases - including the non-healing ulcer leishmaniasis, and a sting by the "24-hour ant", a wasp-sized ant whose bite is the most-feared pain in the jungle. And of course malaria, several times. "Malaria is so common I don't even count it as a sickness any more," he shrugged. When it comes to his physical performance, however, his Latin machismo eclipses his gentlemanly reserve. To every younger man that passed our table he would make a cheeky boast about how he could swim faster, run quicker or push heavier weights. He does 120 chin-ups every day and is current holder of Venezuela's over-40s freestyle swimming record - the same time he swum as 100m national champion in the 1950s. "Put your fingers here," he challenged as he led them to the middle of his chest and flexed his pectorals, trapping my hand in his taut cleavage. "See how strong I am?" Brewer-Carias trained as a dentist and despite his vast extracurricular knowledge it remains his only professional scientific expertise. His first jungle trips were funded by the dental practice he ran in Caracas during the 1960s and 70s. When, in 1960, he spent a year living with the Yekuana Indians, he made the first studies of Amazonian Indians' teeth, which resulted in his first book. He has since published six more, and more than 10 articles for academic journals. "Charles is not an academic, but he has tremendous first-hand knowledge of the Venezuelan Amazon," says Brian Boom, vice-president for botanical science at the New York Botanical Garden. "He is self-taught through reading, talking and travelling with lots of academics in a variety of fields over the years, but mostly from his own explorations. He views himself as a modern-day Humboldt, and I would wager he knows his way around the southern part of Venezuela as well as anyone alive." Brewer-Carias has kept contact with the Yekuana - whose language he speaks fluently - and the Yanomami, the world's largest Stone Age tribe, since he first met them. He finds it disturbing, however, going back to the Indian villages he went to as a young man. "I am struck by the Indians who were young in 1960 and now are very old. I feel perfect. It is a shocking experience. "You are confronted with your own mortality. This drives a lot in my life. I am running away from mortality by having these fulfilling experiences." However, Brewer-Carias's work with Napoleon Chagnon, whose book on the Yanomami is now a standard anthropological text, has led both men to be banned from a large part of the Venezuelan Amazon. He says it is because they have campaigned against the work of missionaries, and upset the vested interests of landowners. The accusations by regional politicians are that Brewer-Carias has enslaved and sexually abused Indians as well as dealing in their plasma. The international academic community sides with the explorer. Roy McDiarmid, chief US government herpetologist at the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, is convinced of Brewer-Carias's good intentions. He says: "I have always found him very sincere. But I can understand why people would find him offensive. He can get things done when other people can't. Part is his political connections. Part is just him: he never accepts no for an answer. He does piss people off." Brian Boom adds: "It is nonsense that he 'enslaved' indians. I have been with Charles in the Yanomami area, and I have only seen him behave in a completely considerate fashion with the Indians. Charles admires and respects indigenous people, and I cannot imagine for an instant that there is any truth to these allegations. "I have known Charles for some 15 years, and there always seems to be someone at odds with him or what he is doing. I think it has a lot to do with jealousy: he is athletic; he is smart; he is comfortable financially; he has published successful books and spectacular photographs; he is a character with charisma and he tells it like it is. All of these traits combine to make him a target for others." Brewer-Carias has always been controversial. In 1979 he was made Minister for Youth Affairs. He is remembered for the "frontier camps" he set up - "a cross between a kibbutz and the Foreign Legion", he says - which enabled 250,000 boys to visit Venezuela's remote borders. On one occasion he took a group of 40 boys and invaded territory disputed with Guyana, creating an international diplomatic incident, and in the process earning himself a military award. He has also infuriated environmentalists by buying a gold mine from the government, which critics believe goes against his environmental credentials. Brewer-Carias ripostes that you have to be realistic. "A single 20-mile road does more damage than all the mines that have been dug in Venezuela in the last 100 years," he says. "Charles is not a specialist in birds, or botany or geology," says Juan Carlos Ramirez, an Amazonian tour operator. "But he knows a lot about a lot of things and he is able to put these things together. He is absolutely the greatest explorer in Venezuela alive today." Roy McDiarmid believes his expertise has furthered understanding of the jungle: "He has learnt a lot from his connections with the native people and with scientists. He knows enough to be able to provide an interface between the public and the scientific sides. There is not enough of that sort of stuff going on. He has been able to popularise Venezuela's national, natural heritage." Brewer-Carias's English heritage dates back to his paternal grand-father, Mathias Brewer, who was made vice-consul in at La Guaira in 1895 and served for half a century. It perhaps explains Charles's look. Always sporting stiff collars, a black hat and an umbrella, Mathias was a well-known sight in Caracas until his death in 1967. "I think that my grandfather was more Victorian than the people from the island," says Charles, "because he considered himself a foreign example or showcase of the Empire abroad, and he behaved in a very stiff and ethical way. We were all educated believing in the greatness of the Empire." The Anglophile feelings remain in his blood. "I would surely love to be regarded as English. I would love to recover that part of my ancestry," says Brewer-Carias, his thick South American accent the only hint that he is not in fact a Home Counties grandee.

fields.headline: On the menu: Hoki
fields.trailText: Is it a bird? Is it a plane?
fields.body:
Is it a bird? Is it a plane?

No, it's a fish.

By hokey, it's not, is it?

It is, and it comes from New Zealand, whose native sons and daughters, it appears, don't eat a lot of it.

And we do?

We do, because it's white, bland and relatively bone free.

Ah, the poor man's monkfish?

Not so poor as rock cod or coley, and it's packed with omega oil - and other healthy matters.

So go easy with the cooking and heavy with the sauce?

Precisely. Fry it, steam it, poach it, and then zap it with something serious.

And then do the hokey-cokey all about?

Yessirree Bob!

fields.headline: The problem
fields.standfirst: Is it possible for me to stay in touch with my ex-partner's friends?
fields.trailText: Is it possible for me to stay in touch with my ex-partner's friends?
fields.body:
I recently split up with a partner of three and a half years. We have friends in common, who are more her friends than mine, but are still people I consider friends. At present, I am obsessed with the thought that they are all doing things together and not inviting me. I don't know how much this is true and how much paranoia, but I suspect it is true. For example, none of these people has phoned to ask how I am. I feel isolated by this silence. I recently contacted them to go out to celebrate finishing a dissertation, but I am wary of always being the one who calls them. I am stymied and ineffectual, because I'm depressed and wanting some signs of caring from this group of friends. My inclination is to get them all together and tell them what I am feeling - but I am hesitant to do this, because it will seem to heavy and they'll just dismiss it. I would appreciate some creative suggestions.

Carry on as normal

It is not clear if the split with your partner was amicable, but from the way you describe things, I assume that it is not appropriate to meet up with this group of friends whilst they are with your ex. I would suggest, having been in a very similar situation, that you try not to make a big thing about being the person that calls to organise things. It is often the case anyway, especially with a large group of friends, that one person must instigate a meeting. What I did when I was in this situation was carry on as normal. I tried to avoid my ex as much as possible, and see the group of friends at the same time, mostly by swallowing my pride and being the "instigator" - organising drinks out, etc (something my ex wasn't good at). It's not very creative, but it does work.

The most important thing is to be honest. Tell the friends (start with the ones you are closest to) how you feel. If they are true friends, they will understand. They may all be feeling that they have to make a choice between you and your ex, so if you can avoid making them decide, so much the better. They will also appreciate not having to be the person to bring up the subject of your ex in front of you. I am sure that, if they have been avoiding calling you, it is because they don't know what to say about the break-up.
Name and address withheld

Make new friends

I was once in a similar situation. After splitting up with my fiancé, I was upset by the lack of interest and support from a bunch of people I considered good friends. But they were more his friends than mine, and I think the truth is that they found it easier in the circumstances just to see him. People do revert to their older loyalties. You are not being paranoid, although they are probably not being deliberately hurtful, just avoiding awkwardness for themselves. It can be horribly painful, especially on top of losing your relationship.

The good news is that you can now move on and make new friends who are really your own - and look up old friends you might have neglected. Three years on, I have a new circle of friends, as well as some of my old ones, and a new partner (I met them through sharing flats, joining a band, doing a course, that kind of thing). It takes time, but you'll feel better if you start rebuilding your life now. Don't confront these people - you can't force them to include you. If any of them are worth having, they'll stay in touch individually.
Name and address withheld

Say how you feel

Like you, I was in a relationship for four years and socialised with my partner in the same group of friends. I also had feelings of paranoia and exclusion after we split. Luckily, I had friends who knew how upset I was. Nevertheless, I was insecure about my position.

I suggest you bite the bullet and tell them how you feel. Not as a group but individually. It is better to get these feelings out in the open. If they feel uncomfortable about going out with you, then socialise with other people more. I did this and gained another group of friends. My old friends gathered round me more because they realised I had got on with my life and was self-reliant, rather than them feeling they had to invite me out because they were sorry for me.

If you talk to them individually, you are more likely to get an honest answer. Try not to feel too sorry for yourself. As I've now realised, everyone goes through this from time to time.
G, Liverpool

Next week

Our son, who is nearly 23, has had a drug problem for the past three and a half years. This has included heroin dependency and has led to two prison sentences for shoplifting. Over the past six months, he has managed to look after himself in his own flat while living on state benefits and some personal savings. He is very low in self-confidence and does not believe he can hold down a job. He is also socially isolated, but so far has not wanted to use the help offered by either voluntary or statutory agencies on a sustained basis.

As parents, we have gone through a huge learning curve during this time and try - with difficulty at times - to practice 'tough love'. Our son has abused our support many times but at other times is appreciative and wants to keep in touch and be helped. He has two brothers who seem happy with their lives.

Our problem is that a family trust has been set up by grandparents from which our son could receive up to £30,000. This would be at the discretion of the trustees and has to be passed on to our son by his 25th birthday. Until now, any excess money over his basic living costs is usually spent on drugs. The trustees have asked us, as parents, for advice. We do not want our son to be deprived of money that is due to him but are afraid that it might create far more serious problems. We would welcome any suggestions.

 Private Lives appears every Friday. Each week we publish a letter to which readers are invited to respond. Replies, giving an account of your personal experience, should reach us by Thursday. Readers are also welcome to propose other problems, of around 300 words. Write to Private Lives, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, fax 0171 239 9935, email privatelives@theguardian.com (please do not send attachments).

webTitle: Quick bites... where to eat out in under 15 minutes

fields.headline: Quick bites... where to eat out in under 15 minutes
fields.standfirst: The Pepper Tree, 19 Clapham Common South Side, London SW4. Tel: 0171-622 1758
fields.trailText: The Pepper Tree
fields.body: Fast, furious, fun and really rather fabulous. Oh, and full. Well, maybe not so much at lunchtime, but of an evening, the mobile phone brigade move in by the battalion. Very sensible of them. This is jim-dandy Thai grub cooked by an all-woman equipe who know what they are about - spring rolls, green prawn curry, Pepper Tree salad, noodles in every combination. Short menu zips through familiar territory, but it delivers the fine fresh flavours at fine fresh prices. It's difficult to spend much more than £10 on food, although you can get stuck into a short, sensible wine list. Communal eating at refectory tables with bench seating.

fields.headline: Praise be to Godard
fields.standfirst: The eternally radical director tells Jonathan Romney about his latest film - and problems with the ironing
fields.trailText: The eternally radical director tells Jonathan Romney about his latest film - and problems with the ironing
fields.body:
In a recent film by French Romany director Tony Gatlif, the hero, bored with handing out political pamphlets on the Champs-Elysées, starts hailing passers-by with a mocking cry of "New York Herald Trib-u-u-ne!" The fond reference is to a turning point of modern cinema - Jean-Luc Godard's 1959 debut feature A Bout de Souffle (Breathless), in which crop-haired Jean Seberg brought an ambivalent blast of US culture to the boulevards. The rest of Gatlif's film is equally Godard-fixated - in one scene, a film critic rubber-stamps a programme of the director's work with the single word "God".

Such homages show that Godard's influence in France is still inescapable. As one of the key figures - many would say, the key figure - of the nouvelle vague, Godard was the cultural polymath who practically invented French screen modernism, using a vast repertoire of cinematic, literary, artistic and historical references to forge an ideal of a demanding, militant, hyper-serious yet hyper-playful cinema. On French TV, comedians still get a laugh imitating his rasping, doom-laden voice-overs; young populist auteurs still routinely disparage him as the pope of "nombriliste" (navel-gazing) art cinema.

Yet Godard has long been a phantom presence. Once at the centre of world film culture, he has been through several forms of quasi-exile since the mid-60s. First he abandoned the commercial cinema world for revolutionary avant-gardism with the Dziga Vertov group, founded with Jean-Pierre Gorin, in the late 60s and early 70s. Then he returned to Switzerland, where he grew up, retreating to Rolle on Lake Geneva with his personal and professional partner, film-maker Anne-Marie Miéville. After a brief semi-commercial comeback in the 80s, he has now retreated to the margins, pushing the structural complexities of his work so far that even an averagely committed art-cinema audience declines to follow him.

Godard may no longer fill cinemas, but for many admirers he's more godlike than ever. Some recent work for film and TV may demand a leap of faith - for example, is Hélas Pour Moi, made in 1993, radical experimentation or just plain incoherent? But for the most part, Godard's enigmas continue to fascinate: his films, more essayistic, less narrative than ever before, have become a continuous free-form commentary on art, society, memory and, above all, cinema. Much of it is autumnal, melancholic, and at the very least, suggestive of profundity. If his series Histoire(s) du Cinéma - (Hi)stories of Cinema - is, as some feel, cinema's answer to Finnegans Wake, then the 1995 "autoportrait" JLG/JLG is surely its Krapp's Last Videotape.

British audiences may not know it - he hasn't had a film released here since the mid-80s - but Godard at 70 is still going strong. But there's always some mystery surrounding his current activity. That's why I'm surprised to get the call to interview him in his producer's office in Paris: the deal is that he'll talk only for half an hour, and specifically about his new film, Eloge de l'Amour (In Praise of Love), which will premiere in Venice this autumn. That makes Godardian sense - an interview about a film that no one's seen, and that, most likely, will only vaguely resemble the sketchy script-cum-treatment that I get to read. What the hell. It has to be worth the trip.

The audience turns out to be with a man exactly like the "Jean-Luc Godard" character he often plays in his and Miéville's films - mad Uncle Jean in Prénom: Carmen, or the slogan-muttering narrator of Histoire(s) du Cinéma. Godard is as much a self-created cartoon as Woody Allen: unshaven jaw, unkempt brush of wiry hair, TV-screen glasses, and the huge cigar, his perennial tribute to the old Hollywood mandarins. He's friendly, but to the point: a handshake, a cough, and we begin. I ask whether his new film will resemble its script much: he once claimed film scripts were invented by Mafia accountants to keep the books regular. "That's just a historical hypothesis," he says, the baleful gravelly voice emerging from way back in his throat.

"There comes a time when things have to be made regular - you can see it in films today. Accountancy has a huge influence. It's the same in war - one soldier, 10 accountants behind him." In Praise of Love will be in two parts, half 35mm, half digital video. Half of it involves a man working on a vague project (a film? an opera? who knows) called In Praise of Love; half is about two Resistance veterans whose story Steven Spielberg wants to make into a movie. Juliette Binoche will appear, but only as a voice on the phone: "But just for two minutes. Not even that - 30 seconds. All I want is for us to hear her voice, rather than pretend that it's Julia Roberts or whoever."

Whatever the film becomes between now and Venice, it won't be exactly what Godard first envisioned. "I wanted to do a picture of love, between young people, between adults, and between the old, but with the adults it didn't really work. You can film a first kiss between the young, or even the old, but adults - not really. I just kept that as a framework, so it's the story of someone who has that project in mind but can't carry it out."

The dominant subject may turn out to be Godard's long-running animus against Spielberg, whose crime in this film is to turn a real-life drama into "une histoire de Hollywood." Godard has complained that Schindler's List was "du Max Factor" and once challenged Spielberg to a showdown debate at the Locarno film festival. (He declined). In Histoire(s) du Cinéma, he coins the portentous formula, "Power of Hollywood. Power of Babylon." Does he see Spielberg as being on the side of Babylon? "I don't know about Babylon. But at any rate it's a rather tyrannical power."

Godard has long entertained an ambivalent relationship with American cinema. As a critic on Cahiers du Cinéma in the 50s, along with auteurs-to-be Truffaut, Chabrol, Rohmer and Rivette, he helped reinvent Hollywood history as an alternative Great Tradition - although he confesses, "We defended a lot of film-makers, even some who weren't really that wonderful." On the business front, there was a flirtation with Hollywood in the late 70s, when he was briefly affiliated with Francis Coppola's Zoetrope company. And in the 90s, no one would have been terribly surprised if Quentin Tarantino, who raved about Godard to anyone who'd listen, had wangled him a deal with Miramax. Godard shrugs.

"Tarantino named his production company after one of my films. He'd have done better to give me some money." He displays a peppery attitude to his young acolytes. Hal Hartley recently offered him a part playing "a monster." Will he accept? "It depends how much he's paying, and if it doesn't take up too much time. I probably won't. Unless he pays me a fortune. And he's not rich, so he probably won't." He gives a sly cackle and puffs on his cigar.

Godard's recent work may have a hardcore audience among a coterie of critics and academics, especially in the US. But in France, his audience is nothing like it once was, and he's reconciled to his marginal status. "In France there are perhaps 100,000 or 200,000 people more or less like me, who might go and see my films. They're fewer than they used to be, because it's too difficult, because the world has changed. They go to the cinema a lot less, and so do I. But if they do go, they'll give 80% of themselves to the film. If you go and see Titanic, you only give the film 10% of your personality. Good films get smaller audiences, but more of the viewer."

Who, then, are Godard's faithful few? "They're probably people of my age, who are a bit nostalgic, who feel the world's going wrong. Younger people may sense there's a struggle going on, maybe it's not really their film, but they see the struggle and they respect it. They're glad to see it. It's like going to the museum. People will queue three hours in the rain to see an exhibition, for the sense of images, of a look - they know that's something you can't see every day, and they need that. They know that's where the treasure is. You can go and see Titanic - but from time to time, you go and see the treasure."

"Yes, it felt strange, and it was awkward for me in my private life. But it started to change in 1968 - I began to realise it was a label. I'm glad to have made lots of more or less successful films - but especially ones which weren't successful, because that helps you to see yourself more or less normally." I can't imagine myself as his equal in cinema. For me he represents a certain cinema that's way up above."

Although he has been vocal in his praise of such film-makers as Abbas Kiarostami, Godard admits he's much less of a cinephile these days. "I hate watching films on TV. I have to see them on a big screen, but if a film disappears, then it disappears. Sometimes if you're really missing a film badly, then OK - the only way to watch a film in prison is on video. TV is a mechanism of transmission, not of creation - but if you need something, then it comes to you like a ray of sunshine through a prison window. From time to time, I'll dig out a tape and watch it the way I'd listen to a record."

Godard may sound like a peevish Luddite, yet he was pioneering the use of video in the mid-70s. The Histoire(s) series is a technological tour de force, mixing sound, text and image into a kind of utopian Gesamtkunstwerk. You'd imagine he'd take naturally to new multimedia, like his contemporary and kindred spirit Chris Marker, but he's a sceptic.

"CD-Rom isn't that interesting. There's that Borges labyrinth side to it, but all that's over and done with. The technicians have taken it all - they create, but they don't have that much talent." He shrugs, and launches into a codger's lament on the condition of the techno-world. "I used to iron my shirts - I can't do it any more, because the iron's got too many buttons on it. I live in a little village and the laundry has closed down. We're going back to the Middle Ages in a different way - everything takes a long time, even if it happens quickly. If you write to me in Switzerland, and you're in a hurry, don't do it by courier, it takes too long - use the normal post. In France, Switzerland and Germany, the postal service still works."

Time's up. Godard gives a brisk, courteous "OK" and shakes my hand. He puts on his overcoat and scarf, hangs a rolled-up umbrella on his arm and leaves, cigar in mouth. I watch him shuffle off down the road, looking exactly like the testy philosopher uncle of his films. We're only a minute's walk from the spot on the Champs-Elysées where Jean Seberg once peddled her papers, but that's in the other direction, not to mention 40 years ago, and in another history of cinema entirely.

Godard: a life in movies

Early Godard

A fiery, polemical critic on the film magazine Cahiers du Cinéma, Godard made several shorts in the 50s. His first feature A Bout de Souffle (Breathless) in 1959 established Jean-Paul Belmondo and Jean Seberg as the iconic bohemian screen couple. His early 60s work was a fevered deconstruction of film styles and genres - musical (Une Femme Est Une Femme), sci-fi (Alphaville), war film (Les Carabiniers), and film-about-film (Le Mépris).

Political period

Godard's first overtly political film was Le Petit Soldat (1960), banned in France for its commentary on Algeria. His 60s films became increasingly concerned with politics and sociology, culminating in the Maoist student cell of La Chinoise (1967), which anticipated events of the following year. In reaction to May '68, Godard founded the Dziga Vertov group with Jean-Pierre Gorin: the mission was not just to make political films, but to "film politically". He continued in this direction with his 70s video work with Anne-Marie Miéville.

The comeback

Sauve Qui Peut (La Vie) (1979) was Godard's return to the big screen, the first of a series of complex, playful films that reinvented the tradition of the de luxe art movie: Passion, Prénom: Carmen, Détective, and Hail Mary, which sparked a wave of Catholic outrage. But by 1987's King Lear, Godard had effectively alienated his new mainstream audience.

The 90s

Godard's major project in the 90s was the eight-part Histoire(s) du Cinéma, but there were also several cinema features hardly or never seen in Britain: the elegantly enigmatic Nouvelle Vague (1990); the entirely mystifying Hélas Pour Moi (1993); and For Ever Mozart (1996), his controversial take on Bosnia.

Godard et les stars

Radical he may be, but Godard has always had box-office appeal. He played Svengali to his own iconic star, his first wife Anna Karina, from Le Petit Soldat through to Pierrot le Fou (1965) and Made in USA (1966). He also uses stars with an ironic eye for their public image: Brigitte Bardot and Jack Palance (Le Mépris), Alain Delon, rocker Johnny Hallyday, even the Rolling Stones in his 1968 One Plus One. Jane Fonda starred in his Marxist melodrama Tout va Bien, but he repaid her by deconstructing her militant chic in Letter to Jane. Norman Mailer, Molly Ringwald and Woody Allen were inveigled into his King Lear.

The fond reference is to a turning point of modern cinema - Jean-Luc Godard's 1959 debut feature A Bout de Souffle (Breathless), in which crop-haired Jean Seberg brought an ambivalent blast of US culture to the boulevards. The rest of Gatlif's film is equally Godard-fixated - in one scene, a film critic rubber-stamps a programme of the director's work with the single word "God". Such homages show that Godard's influence in France is still inescapable. As one of the key figures - many would say, the key figure - of the nouvelle vague, Godard was the cultural polymath who practically invented French screen modernism, using a vast repertoire of cinematic, literary, artistic and historical references to forge an ideal of a demanding, militant, hyper-serious yet hyper-playful cinema. On French TV, comedians still get a laugh imitating his rasping, doom-laden voice-overs; young populist auteurs still routinely disparage him as the pope of "nombriliste" (navel-gazing) art cinema. Yet Godard has long been a phantom presence. Once at the centre of world film culture, he has been through several forms of quasi-exile since the mid-60s. First he abandoned the commercial cinema world for revolutionary avant-gardism with the Dziga Vertov group, founded with Jean-Pierre Gorin, in the late 60s and early 70s. Then he returned to Switzerland, where he grew up, retreating to Rolle on Lake Geneva with his personal and professional partner, film-maker Anne-Marie Miéville. After a brief semi-commercial comeback in the 80s, he has now retreated to the margins, pushing the structural complexities of his work so far that even an averagely committed art-cinema audience declines to follow him. Godard may no longer fill cinemas, but for many admirers he's more godlike than ever. Some recent work for film and TV may demand a leap of faith - for example, is Hélas Pour Moi, made in 1993, radical experimentation or just plain incoherent? But for the most part, Godard's enigmas continue to fascinate: his films, more essayistic, less narrative than ever before, have become a continuous free-form commentary on art, society, memory and, above all, cinema. Much of it is autumnal, melancholic, and at the very least, suggestive of profundity. British audiences may not know it - he hasn't had a film released here since the mid-80s - but Godard at 70 is still going strong. But there's always some mystery surrounding his current activity. That's why I'm surprised to get the call to interview him in his producer's office in Paris: the deal is that he'll talk only for half an hour, and specifically about his new film, Eloge de l'Amour (In Praise of Love), which will premiere in Venice this autumn. That makes Godardian sense - an interview about a film that no one's seen, and that, most likely, will only vaguely resemble the sketchy script-cum-treatment that I get to read. What the hell. It has to be worth the trip. The audience turns out to be with a man exactly like the "Jean-Luc Godard" character he often plays in his and Miéville's films - mad Uncle Jean in Prénom: Carmen, or the slogan-muttering narrator of Histoire(s) du Cinéma. Godard is as much a self-created cartoon as Woody Allen: unshaven jaw, unkempt brush of wiry hair, TV-screen glasses, and the huge cigar, his perennial tribute to the old Hollywood mandarins. He's friendly, but to the point: a handshake, a cough, and we begin. "I wanted to do a picture of love, between young people, between adults, and between the old, but with the adults it didn't really work. You can film a first kiss between the young, or even the old, but adults - not really. I just kept that as a framework, so it's the story of someone who has that project in mind but can't carry it out." Godard has complained that Schindler's List was "du Max Factor" and once challenged Spielberg to a showdown debate at the Locarno film festival. (He declined). As a critic on Cahiers du Cinéma in the 50s, along with auteurs-to-be Truffaut, Chabrol, Rohmer and Rivette, he helped reinvent Hollywood history as an alternative Great Tradition - although he confesses, "We defended a lot of film-makers, even some who weren't really that wonderful." On the business front, there was a flirtation with Hollywood in the late 70s, when he was briefly affiliated with Francis Coppola's Zoetrope company.
