fields.headline: Down in the Valley
fields.standfirst: Chinatown and Boogie Nights dramatised San Fernando's murky history. Magnolia mythologises its present
fields.trailText: Chinatown and Boogie Nights dramatised San Fernando's murky history. Magnolia mythologises its present
fields.body:
Early on in Kathryn Bigelow's surfers-and-bankrobbers thriller Point Break, rookie wave-rider Keanu Reeves breaches a cardinal tenet of surf-rat etiquette by stepping into another man's wave. Bad idea. They collide and both wipe out horribly. As Reeves emerges dazed and breathless from the foam, the offended surfer swims toward him and punches him hard in the face. As he swims out again, he looks over his shoulder and delivers a deathless insult that indicts Reeves's perceived amateurishness, his essential hickhood, and his thousand-percent lameness: "Get back to the Valley, man! "

To hear people tell it, the San Fernando Valley has never been cool, never even come close. In southern California terms, it's long been a patronising synonym for everything that's the polar opposite of cool. It is to LA, its parent conurbation, what north New Jersey and Long Island are to Manhattan: far from the main action, way back in the boonies, the place where the maids and the pool cleaners live because they can't afford those steep uptown rents, and all-round shorthand for dweeb, geek, butthead and dipshit.

When John Travolta and Samuel Jackson find themselves with a friend's brains all over their car's upholstery in Pulp Fiction, they're stuck in the Valley. "Man, I ain't got no motherfuckin' contacts in 818!" howls Jackson, citing the Valley's area-code. If he didn't need help right now, if he was back in a bar in Inglewood with his boys, those words would be uttered with unconcealed pride.

But just as The Sopranos has recently lent an unexpected cultural cachet to the characterless, mall-blighted landscape of north Jersey, so too is the Valley acquiring its share of intoxicated residents, like Magnolia director Paul Thomas Anderson, eager to proselytise on its behalf, to hymn its lily-white weirdness, and mine its rich seams of inch-deep history and suburban surrealism.

The San Fernando Valley is actually, in legal terms, a part of the city of Los Angeles; but it's a distinctly separate place, cut off both mentally and geographically from the fleshpots of Hollywood, the corporate eyries of downtown LA, and the Speedo-clad, Coppertone-marinated democracy of the city's 40-mile ribbon of golden beaches. The catalogue of differences extends to the Valley's beleaguered suburban homesteader mindset, its near-Iowan racial homogeneity, and even its climate. The Santa Monica mountains which form the Valley's southern boundary help shield it from the coastal breezes that cool Los Angeles proper, and in summer it's never less than 10 degrees hotter, and exponentially more humid.

The Valley - LA's neglected stepchild - has something of a municipal inferiority complex. LA politicians hold its purse strings, and Valley powerbrokers have long complained about getting short shrift when it comes to the disbursement of funds. For a few years now there has been a small but growing movement to secede from Los Angeles and establish a separate city. If that happened the resulting metropolis would be the nation's seventh largest, and by some considerable measure its whitest. And in the eyes of its detractors, the most boring.

Those are the cliches. Closer examination reveals that in many ways, the history of southern California is better encapsulated by the Valley than by LA itself. From orange grove to urban nightmare, it is truly a place shaped by the 20th century, its destiny inextricably intertwined with the great technological advances of the last 100 years: aviation, the automobile, the movies and TV (and their bastard offspring, the porn industry), space flight, defence manufacturing and massive residential housing developments. And without the massive engineering project that brought water to LA from the Owens River Valley in the mid-teens, and the invention of the affordable air-conditioning unit after the second world war, the Valley (and much of the American southwest) as we know it might never have come into being.

As anyone who's seen Chinatown knows, the powerbrokers of LA essentially stole the Owens Valley water supply. Today the once fertile area is a dustbowl. William Mulholland, head of LA's Department of Water and Power (Chinatown's original title was Water and Power), in concert with an informal consortium of super-wealthy Angelenos, including Los Angeles Times owner Otis Chandler, agitated for a municipal bond issue to finance the 200 miles of aqueducts and pipelines needed to bring the water to the city.

Earlier, they had secretly bought huge parcels of then arid Valley land at rock-bottom prices, knowing the killing they'd make when irrigation and agriculture became feasible. The San Fernando Valley's very existence is thus based on a massive act of environmental piracy, a gigantic landgrab and a kind of Wild West boomtown corruption. The taxpayers of LA thus paid dearly for the means to enrich even further its very wealthiest robber barons.

On the other hand, no water, no city. For better or worse, it takes visionary, greedy bastards like these to build cities where before there were only sand and rattlesnakes. And from the 1920s until the beginning of the second world war, the Valley was something like a paradise. This mythical heaven could not last though. It was hustled out of existence by industrialisation and the outbreak of war.

Industrial growth was hugely spurred by the need for ships and weapons with which to fight the Pacific campaign. The sudden influx of steel plants and armaments manufacturers (and the rise of the automobile) poisoned the air and led to agriculture's steep decline. Before and during the war, farmland and unincorporated tracts were bought up en masse by prescient developers and private investors (perhaps the most famous were Bing Crosy and Bob Hope) in preparation for the need to house millions of returning GIs. Demobbed in Long Beach or San Pedro, Okie soldiers who'd starved during the Depression took one look at the sunshine and the limitless possibilities and never went home.

Financed by cheap loans available through the postwar GI Bill, the Valley started to fill up. The new cities didn't emerge organically, though. Huge amalgamations of erstwhile farmland were subdivided into streets and neighbourhoods by massive development and construction corporations. The period is well portrayed in the sequel to Chinatown, The Two Jakes, much of whose action takes place in a model home on such a development. Where its lawn ends, there the desert begins, and periodically the ground underfoot emits terrifying tremors.

Even today, the Valley is, to quote California historian Peter Schrag, "an amorphous collection of developer-spawned post-office addresses in the northwest corner of Los Angeles - Northridge (epicentre of the devastating 1994 quake), Pacoima, Chatsworth, Canoga Park, Van Nuys, North Hollywood, Encino (the Valley's Beverly Hills), Panorama City, Studio City, Woodland Hills - that really has no identity beyond its resentment of downtown." Forget LA, the Valley better suits Raymond Chandler's adage about "70 suburbs in search of a city."

Be that as it may, the 1950s are now fondly remembered as the second period in which the Valley was close to very heaven. Returning GIs and those Easterners who made the trek west after Eisenhower's 1955 Federal Highways Act linked up the country found more space than they could have imagined back in their cramped eastern and midwestern tenements and farms. With Depression and war fading from their memories, they built a life of swimming pools, backyard barbecues and two-car garages, becoming a new version of Thomas Jefferson's ideal American, the freeholding yeoman-farmer (or yeoman-worker bee) in a landscape of single-family dwellings.

But as urban theorist Mike Davis has pointed out, this "endless summer" was a whites-only phenomenon: restrictive covenants were the order of the day. If you signed a property deed, it was likely to include the phrase "No one whose blood is not entirely of the Caucasian race will be permitted to own property in this subdivision." Hence the number of primarily Jewish enclaves that inserted themselves in the cracks between such racially monitored new cities. Throughout the 1960s Klan membership in southern California was highest in the Valley.

In the 1970s the Valley's only unifying political issues were its opposition to the busing of black children to white Valley schools, and the passage of Proposition 13, which aimed to cut disproportionate property taxes, but ended up starving California's schools and infrastructure. And more recently Rodney King was beaten up on the Valley's Foothill Boulevard as 17 policemen watched. Just up the freeway is the Spahn Movie Ranch near Chatsworth, whence Charles Manson - another avowed white supremacist - dispatched his robot-hippie murderers on their dreadful missions.

The spectre of tackiness reared its ugly head again in the late 1970s, when it became apparent that the Valley was suddenly America's porn headquarters. Back then, in the period covered by Paul Thomas Anderson's epic Boogie Nights, "the Industry", as it is euphemised by its participants was made up of tiny owner-operated companies, some with a foot in gangland, filming on the lam and making a packet.

The video revolution did to porn what the CD did to the music industry and since the mid-80s the small fry of years gone by have grown into immensely rich entrepreneurs with names like John "Buttman" Stagliano, Max Hardcore, John T Bone and Seymour Butts. The upshot - despite the occasional kerfuffle over backyard sex-shoots - is a semi-respectability that's prompted a surreptitious, previously inconceivable crabwalk into the fringes of the mainstream.

Without equating the area solely with porn - though plenty of folks do - the Valley itself has also recently become cooler than once it was. America's late discovery of irony hasn't hurt - ie, liking something for the very reasons other people despise it - and neither have a slew of movies like California Man (in which a defrosted caveman is capable of becoming Prom King), and Todd Haynes's Safe, which proves that the spirit of Michelangelo Antonioni can be invoked in these unpromising surroundings. And the wildly underrated Two Days in the Valley makes eloquent use of a slew of Valley stereotypes and grotesques.

If there is a single sight that sums up the Valley for me, it is a swimming pool I once visited in the town of Tarzana, which was originally an estate founded by Edgar Rice Burroughs in 1911 and named for his most famous creation. It was the first pool ever built in the San Fernando Valley, and was a gift to Burroughs from Otis Chandler, made possible in part by his sudden enrichment after the water hijack in 1913. When I saw it a few years ago, it was just a trash-filled, tiled hole in the ground.

For me it represents both the Valley's freebooting, obscenely wealthy origins, and its potential apocalyptic future conjoined in a single image. Five well-placed bombs on the Owens Valley pipeline and the whole region might soon seem this desolate, with the city that shouldn't be here slowly reclaimed by the desert, and jaguars once again roaming Magnolia Boulevard. A mile or so away Burroughs is buried under a tree outside his old house. Ten feet from his resting place, the traffic roars by on Ventura Boulevard.

The Valley, like much of California, is a state of mind made up of equal parts false memory and outrageous optimism. It contains as many defoliated Edens as it does the remnants of utopias strangled in their cradles. The Valley is dead; long live the Valley!

 Magnolia is released on March 17.

Valley movies

California Man

Two semi-literate Valley teenagers defrost a caveman (the always hysterical Brendan Fraser) - and he feels right at home.

Chinatown/The Two Jakes

The murky history of the San Fernando Valley's origins, in violent detail.

Boogie Nights

A sprawling epic of the late 70s and 80s Valley porn industry - and about the first movie that does not despise and condescend to the place.

Two Days in the Valley

Midnight-black comedy thriller that takes every imaginable Valley stereotype and chucks them into a boiling stew of murder plots, ripoffs and double-crosses.

Safe

Queasy portrait of a bourgeois Valley housewife (Julianne Moore) who contracts an undiagnosable ailment. I think what's doing her in is the Valley itself.
fields.bodyText: Early on in Kathryn Bigelow's surfers-and-bankrobbers thriller Point Break, rookie wave-rider Keanu Reeves breaches a cardinal tenet of surf-rat etiquette by stepping into another man's wave. Bad idea. They collide and both wipe out horribly. As Reeves emerges dazed and breathless from the foam, the offended surfer swims toward him and punches him hard in the face. As he swims out again, he looks over his shoulder and delivers a deathless insult that indicts Reeves's perceived amateurishness, his essential hickhood, and his thousand-percent lameness: "Get back to the Valley, man! " To hear people tell it, the San Fernando Valley has never been cool, never even come close. In southern California terms, it's long been a patronising synonym for everything that's the polar opposite of cool. It is to LA, its parent conurbation, what north New Jersey and Long Island are to Manhattan: far from the main action, way back in the boonies, the place where the maids and the pool cleaners live because they can't afford those steep uptown rents, and all-round shorthand for dweeb, geek, butthead and dipshit. When John Travolta and Samuel Jackson find themselves with a friend's brains all over their car's upholstery in Pulp Fiction, they're stuck in the Valley. "Man, I ain't got no motherfuckin' contacts in 818!" howls Jackson, citing the Valley's area-code. If he didn't need help right now, if he was back in a bar in Inglewood with his boys, those words would be uttered with unconcealed pride. But just as The Sopranos has recently lent an unexpected cultural cachet to the characterless, mall-blighted landscape of north Jersey, so too is the Valley acquiring its share of intoxicated residents, like Magnolia director Paul Thomas Anderson, eager to proselytise on its behalf, to hymn its lily-white weirdness, and mine its rich seams of inch-deep history and suburban surrealism. The San Fernando Valley is actually, in legal terms, a part of the city of Los Angeles; but it's a distinctly separate place, cut off both mentally and geographically from the fleshpots of Hollywood, the corporate eyries of downtown LA, and the Speedo-clad, Coppertone-marinated democracy of the city's 40-mile ribbon of golden beaches. The catalogue of differences extends to the Valley's beleaguered suburban homesteader mindset, its near-Iowan racial homogeneity, and even its climate. The Santa Monica mountains which form the Valley's southern boundary help shield it from the coastal breezes that cool Los Angeles proper, and in summer it's never less than 10 degrees hotter, and exponentially more humid. The Valley - LA's neglected stepchild - has something of a municipal inferiority complex. LA politicians hold its purse strings, and Valley powerbrokers have long complained about getting short shrift when it comes to the disbursement of funds. For a few years now there has been a small but growing movement to secede from Los Angeles and establish a separate city. If that happened the resulting metropolis would be the nation's seventh largest, and by some considerable measure its whitest. And in the eyes of its detractors, the most boring. Those are the cliches. Closer examination reveals that in many ways, the history of southern California is better encapsulated by the Valley than by LA itself. From orange grove to urban nightmare, it is truly a place shaped by the 20th century, its destiny inextricably intertwined with the great technological advances of the last 100 years: aviation, the automobile, the movies and TV (and their bastard offspring, the porn industry), space flight, defence manufacturing and massive residential housing developments. And without the massive engineering project that brought water to LA from the Owens River Valley in the mid-teens, and the invention of the affordable air-conditioning unit after the second world war, the Valley (and much of the American southwest) as we know it might never have come into being. As anyone who's seen Chinatown knows, the powerbrokers of LA essentially stole the Owens Valley water supply. Today the once fertile area is a dustbowl. William Mulholland, head of LA's Department of Water and Power (Chinatown's original title was Water and Power), in concert with an informal consortium of super-wealthy Angelenos, including Los Angeles Times owner Otis Chandler, agitated for a municipal bond issue to finance the 200 miles of aqueducts and pipelines needed to bring the water to the city. Earlier, they had secretly bought huge parcels of then arid Valley land at rock-bottom prices, knowing the killing they'd make when irrigation and agriculture became feasible. The San Fernando Valley's very existence is thus based on a massive act of environmental piracy, a gigantic landgrab and a kind of Wild West boomtown corruption. The taxpayers of LA thus paid dearly for the means to enrich even further its very wealthiest robber barons. On the other hand, no water, no city. For better or worse, it takes visionary, greedy bastards like these to build cities where before there were only sand and rattlesnakes. And from the 1920s until the beginning of the second world war, the Valley was something like a paradise. This mythical heaven could not last though. It was hustled out of existence by industrialisation and the outbreak of war. Industrial growth was hugely spurred by the need for ships and weapons with which to fight the Pacific campaign. The sudden influx of steel plants and armaments manufacturers (and the rise of the automobile) poisoned the air and led to agriculture's steep decline. Before and during the war, farmland and unincorporated tracts were bought up en masse by prescient developers and private investors (perhaps the most famous were Bing Crosy and Bob Hope) in preparation for the need to house millions of returning GIs. Demobbed in Long Beach or San Pedro, Okie soldiers who'd starved during the Depression took one look at the sunshine and the limitless possibilities and never went home. Financed by cheap loans available through the postwar GI Bill, the Valley started to fill up. The new cities didn't emerge organically, though. Huge amalgamations of erstwhile farmland were subdivided into streets and neighbourhoods by massive development and construction corporations. The period is well portrayed in the sequel to Chinatown, The Two Jakes, much of whose action takes place in a model home on such a development. Where its lawn ends, there the desert begins, and periodically the ground underfoot emits terrifying tremors. Even today, the Valley is, to quote California historian Peter Schrag, "an amorphous collection of developer-spawned post-office addresses in the northwest corner of Los Angeles - Northridge (epicentre of the devastating 1994 quake), Pacoima, Chatsworth, Canoga Park, Van Nuys, North Hollywood, Encino (the Valley's Beverly Hills), Panorama City, Studio City, Woodland Hills - that really has no identity beyond its resentment of downtown." Forget LA, the Valley better suits Raymond Chandler's adage about "70 suburbs in search of a city." Be that as it may, the 1950s are now fondly remembered as the second period in which the Valley was close to very heaven. Returning GIs and those Easterners who made the trek west after Eisenhower's 1955 Federal Highways Act linked up the country found more space than they could have imagined back in their cramped eastern and midwestern tenements and farms. With Depression and war fading from their memories, they built a life of swimming pools, backyard barbecues and two-car garages, becoming a new version of Thomas Jefferson's ideal American, the freeholding yeoman-farmer (or yeoman-worker bee) in a landscape of single-family dwellings. But as urban theorist Mike Davis has pointed out, this "endless summer" was a whites-only phenomenon: restrictive covenants were the order of the day. If you signed a property deed, it was likely to include the phrase "No one whose blood is not entirely of the Caucasian race will be permitted to own property in this subdivision." Hence the number of primarily Jewish enclaves that inserted themselves in the cracks between such racially monitored new cities. Throughout the 1960s Klan membership in southern California was highest in the Valley. In the 1970s the Valley's only unifying political issues were its opposition to the busing of black children to white Valley schools, and the passage of Proposition 13, which aimed to cut disproportionate property taxes, but ended up starving California's schools and infrastructure. And more recently Rodney King was beaten up on the Valley's Foothill Boulevard as 17 policemen watched. Just up the freeway is the Spahn Movie Ranch near Chatsworth, whence Charles Manson - another avowed white supremacist - dispatched his robot-hippie murderers on their dreadful missions. The spectre of tackiness reared its ugly head again in the late 1970s, when it became apparent that the Valley was suddenly America's porn headquarters. Back then, in the period covered by Paul Thomas Anderson's epic Boogie Nights, "the Industry", as it is euphemised by its participants was made up of tiny owner-operated companies, some with a foot in gangland, filming on the lam and making a packet. The video revolution did to porn what the CD did to the music industry and since the mid-80s the small fry of years gone by have grown into immensely rich entrepreneurs with names like John "Buttman" Stagliano, Max Hardcore, John T Bone and Seymour Butts. The upshot - despite the occasional kerfuffle over backyard sex-shoots - is a semi-respectability that's prompted a surreptitious, previously inconceivable crabwalk into the fringes of the mainstream. Without equating the area solely with porn - though plenty of folks do - the Valley itself has also recently become cooler than once it was. America's late discovery of irony hasn't hurt - ie, liking something for the very reasons other people despise it - and neither have a slew of movies like California Man (in which a defrosted caveman is capable of becoming Prom King), and Todd Haynes's Safe, which proves that the spirit of Michelangelo Antonioni can be invoked in these unpromising surroundings. And the wildly underrated Two Days in the Valley makes eloquent use of a slew of Valley stereotypes and grotesques. If there is a single sight that sums up the Valley for me, it is a swimming pool I once visited in the town of Tarzana, which was originally an estate founded by Edgar Rice Burroughs in 1911 and named for his most famous creation. It was the first pool ever built in the San Fernando Valley, and was a gift to Burroughs from Otis Chandler, made possible in part by his sudden enrichment after the water hijack in 1913. When I saw it a few years ago, it was just a trash-filled, tiled hole in the ground. For me it represents both the Valley's freebooting, obscenely wealthy origins, and its potential apocalyptic future conjoined in a single image. Five well-placed bombs on the Owens Valley pipeline and the whole region might soon seem this desolate, with the city that shouldn't be here slowly reclaimed by the desert, and jaguars once again roaming Magnolia Boulevard. A mile or so away Burroughs is buried under a tree outside his old house. Ten feet from his resting place, the traffic roars by on Ventura Boulevard. The Valley, like much of California, is a state of mind made up of equal parts false memory and outrageous optimism. It contains as many defoliated Edens as it does the remnants of utopias strangled in their cradles. The Valley is dead; long live the Valley!  Magnolia is released on March 17. Valley movies California Man Two semi-literate Valley teenagers defrost a caveman (the always hysterical Brendan Fraser) - and he feels right at home. Chinatown/The Two Jakes The murky history of the San Fernando Valley's origins, in violent detail. Boogie Nights A sprawling epic of the late 70s and 80s Valley porn industry - and about the first movie that does not despise and condescend to the place. Two Days in the Valley Midnight-black comedy thriller that takes every imaginable Valley stereotype and chucks them into a boiling stew of murder plots, ripoffs and double-crosses. Safe Queasy portrait of a bourgeois Valley housewife (Julianne Moore) who contracts an undiagnosable ailment. I think what's doing her in is the Valley itself.

fields.headline: Director's final cut
fields.standfirst: Brian Pendreigh investigates the mysterious death of the fabled Alan Smithee
fields.trailText: Brian Pendreigh investigates the mysterious death of the fabled Alan Smithee
fields.body:
One of Hollywood's most prolific and underrated directors is dead. You won't find it him the obituaries, because no body has been found. The guys with the inside gen are sworn to secrecy. But one man is talking. Joe Eszterhas claims he put Alan Smithee "under the ground", though other evidence points to a mystery man called Thomas Lee. Smithee was a shadowy figure himself. But in a career spanning 30 years and 40 films, he earned the right to call himself a director's director. Some say he had no style of his own, others say you could smell a Smithee film a mile away.

Supernova has all the hallmarks of an Alan Smithee film. A sci-fi saga, it cost $65m and opened in more than 2,000 US cinemas last month without any press previews. Many believe Supernova is Smithee's work, though the name on the credits is Thomas Lee. MGM refuses to talk about it and the US Directors Guild also refuses to comment, though it doesn't discount a Lee-Smithee connection.

So did Lee murder Smithee and steal his film? He is part of a conspiracy of silence and lies that goes right to the heart of Hollywood. In the beginning, Supernova was by Walter Hill, the director of 48 Hours and Southern Comfort. But those familiar with Smithee will know his habit of taking over others' films. Smithee made his debut with Death of a Gunfighter in 1969. It began under director Robert Totten, but three-quarters of the way through the shoot its star, Richard Widmark, refused to go on working with him.

Don Siegel, under contract to Universal, was ordered to finish the picture. He thought Totten's footage "damn good", and simply picked up where he left off. Totten did not want his name on it. Nor did Siegel, but the Guild insisted someone be credited. The name Smith was suggested, until it was pointed out that there were several directors called Smith. Someone suggested Smithe, which evolved into Smithee, with two Es. And so Alan Smithee, or Allen Smithee, was born.

When Death of a Gunfighter was released, critics hailed Smithee as a bright new talent. "I told all my young friends who wanted to become directors to change their name to Smithee and take credit," Siegel wrote in his autobiography.

The DGA called on Smithee regularly over the years when production companies sacked directors or re-edited films. There was dross like The Shrimp on the Barbie and a sequel to The Birds, but there was the occasional rough diamond too, such as Catchfire, a thriller with the stylistic weirdness of Dennis Hopper. Michael Mann got the credit for Heat, but Smithee directed a TV version; Martin Brest directed Scent of a Woman, but Smithee was responsible for the version shown on planes.

Smithee was more than a pseudonym - he became the means for directors to let the industry know they were disowning a film, while observing a vow of silence at the insistence of studios, who had to sell the film to a gullible public and did not want the director bad-mouthing it.

But then Smithee got ideas above his station. No longer content with his role as a director's director, he wanted a public profile too and teamed up with Joe Eszterhas, the writer who received a record $3m fee for Basic Instinct.

Eszterhas promised him star billing on An Alan Smithee Film: Burn Hollywood Burn, a comedy in which a man called Alan Smithee (Eric Idle) discovers the only way he can disown his film is by turning over his credit to Alan Smithee.

It was relatively simple for director Arthur Hiller to do just that, after falling out with Eszterhas over the final shape of the film. It flopped at the US box office in 1998 and went straight to video in the UK, but it prompted widespread discussion in the media and on the internet.

"After Alan Smithee became known to the movie-going public, as opposed to just inside the industry, it became problematic," one insider told me earlier this week. "It would somehow represent the film as damaged goods."

Other pseudonyms have been used, though the DGA refuses to name names. "That's the whole point - anonymity," says a source. Smithee was no longer anonymous, so they gave his Supernova credit to Thomas Lee. UK audiences will have to wait to see if Lee measures up to his predecessor, as UIP has postponed Supernova's UK release, originally scheduled for this month.

Smithee became a celebrity and Hollywood would never stand for that. But the question remains, what exactly happened to him? Eszterhas told the LA Times: "Burn Hollywood Burn was the ultimate Hollywood in-joke and I guess this is the punchline... as a writer in the age of the director as auteur, I feel a great sense of satisfaction putting the Directors Guild pseudonym under the ground."

I have a theory that Smithee asked for his name to be removed. I believe he looked at Death of a Gunfighter and Burn Hollywood Burn, reflected on the downward spiral of his career, and then, one bright Californian morning, walked out into the Pacific ocean, never to be seen again.

Did Eszterhas kill Smithee? Yes and no. Smithee committed suicide the day he agreed to work with Eszterhas. After that it was just a matter of time. It is a modern Hollywood tragedy.

fields.headline: Silent witness
fields.standfirst: Documentary film-maker Kim Longinotto doesn't like voiceovers - she prefers to let her subjects speak for themselves
fields.trailText: Documentary film-maker Kim Longinotto doesn't like voiceovers - she prefers to let her subjects speak for themselves
fields.body:
Perhaps it was an experience at boarding school that made Kim Longinotto a woman who would spend her life watching others. She was 13. There was a school trip. She became separated from the group and, in the confusion, the teachers of Hampden House, a private school in Buckinghamshire, were made to look fools. By the time she was found, they had raised her offence from accidental straying to wilful truancy and all future trips were banned. Longinotto was sent to Coventry for two years. "Nobody talked to me. Not once. The teachers were angry because I got lost, and embarrassed the school. The students were angry because the trips got cancelled. I was completely isolated."

In her television documentaries, Longinotto protects the isolated voice from obscurity by projecting it over the heads of its censors. Iranian women, conventionally portrayed in the west as weeping fundamentalists or mute victims of domestic violence, find their tongues in Divorce Iranian Style, the riveting film she made over five weeks in a Tehran divorce court. "He has sexual problems," rages one furious wife in court. "I found out on our wedding night but kept it quiet not to shame the family." "He is mad," spits another. "He has been from the beginning. God punish the liar."

"Women can't win against Iranian law," says Longinotto. "But they can win against the judge who feels sympathetic towards them. You get a sense of their power, but it's not a legal power, it's their own power." It is a combination of rhetorical and theatrical power - the same elements that make up Longinotto's films and have won her awards at the Paris and San Francisco film festivals.

She started her career, improbably enough, on the camera crew for the early 80s Madness biopic Take It or Leave It; and her first solo project proper was shot at Hampden House - "revenge" she called it. But it was The Good Wife of Tokyo, a film she made in 1992, about the mother of Frank Chickens singer Kazuko Hohki, that brought her to public attention. More acclaim followed in 1993, for Dream Girls, covering the fortunes of the Japanese pupils studying to be stars in the popular revue show Takarazuka; while its follow-up, Shinjuku Boys, examined the lives of three "onnabes"- women living lives as men.

Longinotto doesn't like voiceovers. It is important the development of her characters emerges through their own dialogue. "You have to be very patient. You have to give up your own life and totally wait for their life to take you in. There are times when I'll say, we are just going to sit here for a bit and the sound recordist will say, what for? It's a frame of mind. To get to those moments where things are revealed, you have to be quite lazy."

Longinotto speaks softly and a little nervously, which has the effect of accentuating her thinness. The lower her voice gets, the more you notice her posture, too, sloping a little to the floor, perhaps from years behind the camera or her habit of watching, patiently, in the background for a story to unfold.

At 48, she is editing her 15th film, Fighting Women, a portrait of a Japanese school for women wrestlers. There are Polaroids of them on the table. They are wearing make-up and are a strange mixture of the glamorous and the truck-like. The school, just outside Tokyo, accepts girls between the ages of 15 and 21, and Longinotto's original plan was to film the new recruits as they arrived, again after six weeks, and then return for some final shooting when they stepped into the ring for the first time after six months. But when the recruits were delayed for four weeks, Longinotto and her small team began filming some of the existing first-years and found the story there.

"By the time the others arrived, we had fallen in love with one of the girls who had been doing it for a year and was going to get thrown out. That was a risk because, if she had got thrown out, we wouldn't have a story. But you work out very quickly where your characters are, and have to be dogged about it."

Female wrestling in Japan routinely attracts audiences of 8,000 and the participants become superstars - as famous as the male WWF contenders in the US. Their stage act is just that - a choreographed sequence that ensures the throws and headlocks they perform on each other won't permanently damage them.

This was one of Longinotto's conditions for making the film. She has no taste for violence. "My mum used to watch wrestling when I was a kid and I used to absolutely hate it. It seemed so cruel. But they assured us that, although it was very skilled, no one would get hurt. We got very into it. We'd be screaming for our girls and they'd all look at us. But I wasn't screaming for anyone to get hurt. That's why I don't like boxing."

What drew Longinotto to the girls was the same spirit of rebellion that attracted her to the wives of Tehran. In both cases, it is rebellion defined by a resistance to the overarching patriarchy. The conceit of this approach is that you learn more about a country from its outsiders than its establishment. Outsiders, for Longinotto, are merely the future come early.

"There has been a change going on in Iran. As women become more educated, they become more confident. You really get a sense of a place in transit. The modern Iranian woman wants everything: a divorce, a new husband, her kids and she wants to work."

In Japan, too, there is a notable progression in attitude between the women Longinotto filmed in Dream Girls, her documentary about the students at Takarazuka - a sort of Japanese Royal Ballet school meets the Parachute Regiment - all of whose careers were forcibly ended at 25 with the expectation they would marry, and the female wrestlers. "The girls at the wrestling school were all saying they didn't want to get married, that this was the best thing they had ever done and that if they'd got married, they would have been fed up. One girl said to her mother, it would be very difficult for me to get married because if my husband hit me, I'd punch him back. Her mother said, well, you can't get married then."

Longinotto's own relationship with authority has strongly influenced her film-making. When she was nine, her parents, who lived in London, sent her to Hampden House as a boarder. "I loathed every second of it. And what I hated was the meaningless little tasks that they made you do - just like in Takarazuka, which reminded me very much of my boarding school. They were to do with teaching you not to have self-respect. Things like cutting the lawn with nail scissors. It was like the wearing away of your self-worth."

The reason her parents sent and kept her there when she was so miserable, particularly during the two years of isolation, was not malice, she suggests, but lack of interest. "I think that, now, people like my parents wouldn't have had kids. I think then you just did because that's what everybody else did."

Longinotto repays their neglect with a coldness that might be shocking if you couldn't see her struggling a little to pull it off. "My mother had a business, but I never quite worked out what it was," she says with a light sneer. Is she still in touch with her parents? "No, well it was my mother's funeral - yesterday? No hang on, what day is it? Tuesday, Tuesday." The tone is breezy, but her eyes are on the floor.

When she left school, she discovered her father had Italian roots and, after a bit of digging, she took up the abandoned family name of Longinotto. "A new name with no baggage." Rather than go home to her parents, she became homeless, first in London, then in a dusty traipse around Europe. "It wasn't so bad..." she begins, before stopping herself. "No, it was. It was terrible. I was starving. I wouldn't beg, so it was a case of..." she trails off. Dustbins? "Mmm. One of my first films was about homeless women in a hostel near Greek Street."

When she returned to London the prospect of chancing it on the streets once again had lost its charm. She applied and was accepted at Essex university, where she studied English and European literature for three years and decided that she wanted to be a writer. A PhD loomed - she considered doing one on the novel and cinema - but she was saved from it at the 11th hour by Lambeth council. "I was doing a library project for them, where you go round parks and tell people stories with a microphone and at the end say to them that if they want to read the stories, they should go to the library. But no one ever wanted to go to the library."

Since one of her main interests was bringing society's marginal figures to a wider audience, she started re-considering her choice of medium. And, after those terrible two years at boarding school, she had a fear of living the life of an isolated writer. "Also, I'm not very good at writing," she whispers. "That was the main reason, really." Instead, she enrolled at film school in Beaconsfield and decided that what she wanted to do was make documentaries about people whom others always presumed to speak for. This is what she saves her quiet urgency for.

"What I love about making documentaries is that I can disappear. It is getting involved in a situation and letting it speak for itself. I love the way you go somewhere and get into another world and lose yourself and discover things you couldn't have imagined. I love that moment when you film something and it unfolds in front of you and it's a privilege to be there and your heart goes and you think, this is happening and I'm filming it. The whole of the Japanese shoot was like that. We'd go back and lie on our beds and go, I can't believe it."

Gentleness and kindness are not the same thing, but Longinotto has both. We are walking through Soho after the interview when she pulls up sharply to give money to a man under a blanket. This isn't surprising since she has been there herself, but she is mindful of all the characters in the scene. While fishing about in her bag she half turns to me and mumbles "sorry" for the delay. "Sorry, I have to..." she tails off without finishing, but the story has told itself.

 Kim Longinotto introduces extracts from Fighting Women tonight at 9pm at the Lux Cinema, Hoxton Square, London N1 (Box office: 0171-684 0201).

Iranian women, conventionally portrayed in the west as weeping fundamentalists or mute victims of domestic violence, find their tongues in Divorce Iranian Style, the riveting film she made over five weeks in a Tehran divorce court. "He has sexual problems," rages one furious wife in court. "I found out on our wedding night but kept it quiet not to shame the family." "He is mad," spits another. "He has been from the beginning. God punish the liar." "Women can't win against Iranian law," says Longinotto. "But they can win against the judge who feels sympathetic towards them. You get a sense of their power, but it's not a legal power, it's their own power." It is a combination of rhetorical and theatrical power - the same elements that make up Longinotto's films and have won her awards at the Paris and San Francisco film festivals. She started her career, improbably enough, on the camera crew for the early 80s Madness biopic Take It or Leave It; and her first solo project proper was shot at Hampden House - "revenge" she called it. But it was The Good Wife of Tokyo, a film she made in 1992, about the mother of Frank Chickens singer Kazuko Hohki, that brought her to public attention. More acclaim followed in 1993, for Dream Girls, covering the fortunes of the Japanese pupils studying to be stars in the popular revue show Takarazuka; while its follow-up, Shinjuku Boys, examined the lives of three "onnabes"- women living lives as men. Longinotto doesn't like voiceovers. It is important the development of her characters emerges through their own dialogue. "You have to be very patient. You have to give up your own life and totally wait for their life to take you in. There are times when I'll say, we are just going to sit here for a bit and the sound recordist will say, what for? It's a frame of mind. To get to those moments where things are revealed, you have to be quite lazy." Longinotto speaks softly and a little nervously, which has the effect of accentuating her thinness. The lower her voice gets, the more you notice her posture, too, sloping a little to the floor, perhaps from years behind the camera or her habit of watching, patiently, in the background for a story to unfold. At 48, she is editing her 15th film, Fighting Women, a portrait of a Japanese school for women wrestlers. There are Polaroids of them on the table. They are wearing make-up and are a strange mixture of the glamorous and the truck-like. The school, just outside Tokyo, accepts girls between the ages of 15 and 21, and Longinotto's original plan was to film the new recruits as they arrived, again after six weeks, and then return for some final shooting when they stepped into the ring for the first time after six months. But when the recruits were delayed for four weeks, Longinotto and her small team began filming some of the existing first-years and found the story there. "By the time the others arrived, we had fallen in love with one of the girls who had been doing it for a year and was going to get thrown out. That was a risk because, if she had got thrown out, we wouldn't have a story. But you work out very quickly where your characters are, and have to be dogged about it." Female wrestling in Japan routinely attracts audiences of 8,000 and the participants become superstars - as famous as the male WWF contenders in the US. Their stage act is just that - a choreographed sequence that ensures the throws and headlocks they perform on each other won't permanently damage them. This was one of Longinotto's conditions for making the film. She has no taste for violence. "My mum used to watch wrestling when I was a kid and I used to absolutely hate it. It seemed so cruel. But they assured us that, although it was very skilled, no one would get hurt. We got very into it. We'd be screaming for our girls and they'd all look at us. But I wasn't screaming for anyone to get hurt. That's why I don't like boxing." What drew Longinotto to the girls was the same spirit of rebellion that attracted her to the wives of Tehran. In both cases, it is rebellion defined by a resistance to the overarching patriarchy. The conceit of this approach is that you learn more about a country from its outsiders than its establishment. Outsiders, for Longinotto, are merely the future come early. "There has been a change going on in Iran. As women become more educated, they become more confident. You really get a sense of a place in transit. The modern Iranian woman wants everything: a divorce, a new husband, her kids and she wants to work." In Japan, too, there is a notable progression in attitude between the women Longinotto filmed in Dream Girls, her documentary about the students at Takarazuka - a sort of Japanese Royal Ballet school meets the Parachute Regiment - all of whose careers were forcibly ended at 25 with the expectation they would marry, and the female wrestlers. "The girls at the wrestling school were all saying they didn't want to get married, that this was the best thing they had ever done and that if they'd got married, they would have been fed up. One girl said to her mother, it would be very difficult for me to get married because if my husband hit me, I'd punch him back. Her mother said, well, you can't get married then." Longinotto's own relationship with authority has strongly influenced her film-making. When she was nine, her parents, who lived in London, sent her to Hampden House as a boarder. "I loathed every second of it. And what I hated was the meaningless little tasks that they made you do - just like in Takarazuka, which reminded me very much of my boarding school. They were to do with teaching you not to have self-respect. Things like cutting the lawn with nail scissors. It was like the wearing away of your self-worth." The reason her parents sent and kept her there when she was so miserable, particularly during the two years of isolation, was not malice, she suggests, but lack of interest. "I think that, now, people like my parents wouldn't have had kids. I think then you just did because that's what everybody else did." Longinotto repays their neglect with a coldness that might be shocking if you couldn't see her struggling a little to pull it off. "My mother had a business, but I never quite worked out what it was," she says with a light sneer. Is she still in touch with her parents? "No, well it was my mother's funeral - yesterday? No hang on, what day is it? Tuesday, Tuesday." The tone is breezy, but her eyes are on the floor. When she left school, she discovered her father had Italian roots and, after a bit of digging, she took up the abandoned family name of Longinotto. "A new name with no baggage." Rather than go home to her parents, she became homeless, first in London, then in a dusty traipse around Europe. "It wasn't so bad..." she begins, before stopping herself. "No, it was. It was terrible. I was starving. I wouldn't beg, so it was a case of..." she trails off. Dustbins? "Mmm. One of my first films was about homeless women in a hostel near Greek Street." When she returned to London the prospect of chancing it on the streets once again had lost its charm. She applied and was accepted at Essex university, where she studied English and European literature for three years and decided that she wanted to be a writer. A PhD loomed - she considered doing one on the novel and cinema - but she was saved from it at the 11th hour by Lambeth council. "I was doing a library project for them, where you go round parks and tell people stories with a microphone and at the end say to them that if they want to read the stories, they should go to the library. But no one ever wanted to go to the library." Since one of her main interests was bringing society's marginal figures to a wider audience, she started re-considering her choice of medium. And, after those terrible two years at boarding school, she had a fear of living the life of an isolated writer. "Also, I'm not very good at writing," she whispers. "That was the main reason, really." Instead, she enrolled at film school in Beaconsfield and decided that what she wanted to do was make documentaries about people whom others always presumed to speak for. This is what she saves her quiet urgency for. "What I love about making documentaries is that I can disappear. It is getting involved in a situation and letting it speak for itself. I love the way you go somewhere and get into another world and lose yourself and discover things you couldn't have imagined. I love that moment when you film something and it unfolds in front of you and it's a privilege to be there and your heart goes and you think, this is happening and I'm filming it. The whole of the Japanese shoot was like that. We'd go back and lie on our beds and go, I can't believe it." Gentleness and kindness are not the same thing, but Longinotto has both. We are walking through Soho after the interview when she pulls up sharply to give money to a man under a blanket. This isn't surprising since she has been there herself, but she is mindful of all the characters in the scene. While fishing about in her bag she half turns to me and mumbles "sorry" for the delay. "Sorry, I have to..." she tails off without finishing, but the story has told itself.  Kim Longinotto introduces extracts from Fighting Women tonight at 9pm at the Lux Cinema, Hoxton Square, London N1 (Box office: 0171-684 0201).

fields.headline: Video releases
fields.standfirst: Rushmore | Among Giants | A Cool, Dry Place
fields.trailText: Rushmore | Among Giants | A Cool, Dry Place
fields.body:
Rushmore
Rental and DVD £15.99
Buena Vista Cert 15
****

An absorbing, wildly unpredictable and superbly acted comedy with a skewed sensibility. Rushmore is a school, the elite alma mater of precocious pupil Max, a 15-year-old playwright who is facing expulsion despite his perfect attendance and punctuality awards, since he's so busy being a teen entrepreneur that his grades are suffering.

Max (Jason Schwartzman) falls in love with a teacher (Olivia Williams) who is also being courted by Max's friend, the school's millionaire benefactor (Bill Murray). Since Williams is 30ish and Murray 50ish, Rushmore takes the most cavalier attitude to age and romance since Harold and Maude, but somehow, with immaculate playing by all three principals, it manages to be touching as well as very funny. I especially loved Max's school production of Serpico.

It's unusual too in its mix of accents: Williams, a Cambridge graduate, gets to remain English and there's an extremely Scottish Scot (Stephen McCole) as the pupil who is the bane of Max's life. Director and co-writer Wes Anderson is a Texan and clearly a Britophile (the soundtrack includes Donovan, The Who and, most relevantly, the Faces' Ooh La La).

Everything about Rushmore is fresh and original, including Anderson's direction, which features a bravura shot right across the audience at Max's production that forms the film's denouement. Schwartzman is the son of Talia Shire, and related to both Francis Coppola and Nic Cage. His performance of manic intensity contrasts with Murray's underplayed air of bafflement. It's hard to think of a less starry star turn.

Among GIants
Rental
Fox Pathé Cert 15
**

The Yorkshire moors are the real stars of Among Giants. The "giants" are a series of electricity pylons which a team of very laddish lads are commissioned to paint. Cue dizzying vertigo and long-distance views from a job more like mountaineering than painting and decorating. Pete Postlethwaite is the foreman who finds a surprise addition to the team when an Australian hitchhiking climber (Rachel Griffiths) asks for a job.

Postlethwaite and Griffiths (especially in Hilary and Jackie) have been reliably watchable but before long they're climbing over each other too in an unlikely relationship (firmly-rooted bloke, rootless woman). Simon Beaufoy's script doesn't provide much to make this believable and, increasingly, the characters' sudden changes of mood seem to rely on script whim rather than character development. Directed by Sam Miller, from This Life, the film's philosophy seems to be that pleasures are fleeting. The same goes for the film: there's a pleasing feeling of campfire camaraderie at times but a more interesting story, including the political aspects to this non-union operation, slip by unnoticed.

A Cool, Dry Place
Rental
Fox Pathé Cert 15
**

Vince Vaughn is trapped amid multiple plots in this straight-to-video slice-of-life drama. There's the barmy lawsuit his firm has put him on to; the promising new girlfriend he's begun to date; the son he's bringing up as a single parent; the basketball team he's coaching; and the long-absent ex-wife who has suddenly turned up again. It's a bit too much to pack in and the most promising element - the lawsuit - is mysteriously dropped once it's been nicely set up dramatically.

It's there just to point up the sacrifice our hero has made, leaving a smart Chicago practice for no-hope cases in the sticks for the sake of getting time to be a Dad. Women tend to complain that Hollywood drama treats a man juggling job and family as wildly heroic while a woman doing the same is shown as normal life, and I think they have a point. Before long, the film gives Vaughn some more moral dilemmas to mull over but neither girlfriend (Joey Lauren Adams) nor wife (Monica Potter) strike many sparks with the actor, who was far more convincing as a party animal in Swingers.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In an article headed Try plan B for birth control, pages 10 and 11, G2, February 8, we twice miscalled the "new morning-after pill" Levonette-2, only revealing its real name Levonelle-2 halfway through the piece. We said Levonelle-2 had no side effects and no medical contra-indications. Neither of those statements is true. The manufacturers tell us that in trials 23.1% experienced nausea (compared with 50.4% on the traditional morning-after pill PC4), and it caused 5.6% to vomit (18.8% on PC4). Breast tenderness is also experienced by some women who take the new pill. The contra-indications, apart from pregnancy, include an abnormal menstrual cycle, unexplained vaginal bleeding and allergy to any of the ingredients.
fields.body:
In an article headed Try plan B for birth control, pages 10 and 11, G2, February 8, we twice miscalled the "new morning-after pill" Levonette-2, only revealing its real name Levonelle-2 halfway through the piece. We said Levonelle-2 had no side effects and no medical contra-indications. Neither of those statements is true. The manufacturers tell us that in trials 23.1% experienced nausea (compared with 50.4% on the traditional morning-after pill PC4), and it caused 5.6% to vomit (18.8% on PC4). Breast tenderness is also experienced by some women who take the new pill. The contra-indications, apart from pregnancy, include an abnormal menstrual cycle, unexplained vaginal bleeding and allergy to any of the ingredients.

James Naughtie, whose deal to write a book that will look at the relationship between Tony Blair and Gordon Brown we reported on page 5, yesterday, has asked us to clarify one point. He says although he and Gordon Brown may both be Scotsmen they have never shared a flat.

In a piece headed All together now, page 4, G2, February 10, we gave the first line of The Battle Hymn of the Republic as "Mine eyes hath seen the coming of the glory of the Lord ..." That should be "Mine eyes have seen the glory of the coming of the Lord ..." We said that in the film Casablanca the song the Germans sing in Rick's Cafe is Deutschland über Alles. It is Die Wacht am Rhein (The watch on the Rhine). The words of the Star-Spangled Banner were written by Francis Scott Key, not King.

In a report headed Clue to Romans' head start on Columbus, page 2, yesterday, we said that archaeologists had concluded that a Roman terracotta discovered in Mexico could not have been interred "earlier" than 1510. We meant to say "later".

In an article on languages headed Britannia needs linguists to push cool image, p2H, Guardian Higher, February 8, we wrongly made Zazie a French popstar. In fact she is the fictional heroine of Zazie dans le métro by Raymond Queneau.

It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. fields.headline: Green abandons M&S bid
fields.standfirst: Tycoon's decision to avoid 'slanging match' drives shares to 10-year low
fields.trailText: Multi-millionaire entrepreneur Philip Green ditched his plans to mount a hostile takeover bid for Marks & Spencer yesterday, saying he was shocked at the tactics the retailer had employed to block his challenge.
fields.body:
Multi-millionaire entrepreneur Philip Green ditched his plans to mount a hostile takeover bid for Marks & Spencer yesterday, saying he was shocked at the tactics the retailer had employed to block his challenge.

He said "the recent barrage in the press" was "an unjustified attempt to discredit me" and claimed he did not want to damage the M&S brand or undermine staff morale.

In a statement to the stock exchange he said a bid would be "bitterly and publicly fought" and "very damaging" to M&S and its employees.

He added: "There are certain ways that I want to do business and ways I do not. I don't want personality battles. If this was going to turn into a slanging match then I did not want to know."

His decision wiped nearly £600m off the value of M&S as the shares tumbled 8% to 233p - their lowest level in 10 years. The shares had risen rapidly in the wake of Mr Green's announcement on December 13 that he was considering a bid. But, as hopes dwindled that the Monaco-based businessman would ever come up with any solid proposals, they slipped back, and are now changing hands at some 100p below their December peak.

Many analysts said they were not surprised that Mr Green had withdrawn, because there has been increasing speculation that he had not been able to raise the finance or attract the highest calibre of management to join his team.

One quipped: "He doth protest too much. All this stuff about it would have got messy had he proceeded with the bid - that would have been the case anyway."

But yesterday Mr Green said he did have the financial backing and would have offered a cash and shares deal.

Nevertheless he had decided on Wednesday evening to pull out because the bid would have been "a lot of aggravation and cost a lot of money". It is understood he was facing advisers' fees of £35m to mount the bid.

Over the past few days M&S's advisers had mounted a high-profile campaign to get Mr Green to put up or shut up. They sent section 212 notices - which require them to reveal if they own any M&S shares - to three key retail executives tipped to be ready to join Mr Green. The response to a 212 notice sent to Mr and Mrs Green was leaked to a Sunday newspaper, revealing that Mrs Green had bought £25m of M&S shares just before her husband announced he was considering a bid.

The leak suggested insider dealing, but Mr Green said his wife's purchase - made over three days in 45 different lots through a raft of nominee accounts - was completely legal, that she was acting in concert with him and that the takeover panel had been informed of the purchase.

One analyst, Richard Ratner of broker Seymour Pierce, backed Mr Green's allegations of M&S dirty tricks, describing the newspaper leak as "disgraceful". He added: "It was a non-story, but the inference was that he was insider dealing. Yet what he did was quite normal. You do it to cover your costs if you are outbid. It was a hatchet job."

Yesterday M&S said it was pleased Mr Green had pulled out - although he has retained the right to counterbid if another predator emerges.

A spokeswoman said: "We do not think we used dirty tactics. We sent out legitimate requests and he obviously made a mistake on the response by saying that the shares were held on his wife's behalf, and not as part of a concert party. We were just after clarifying the position."

She added: "But we are pleased with today's developments. The potential bid has been interfering with the way we have been operating. Obviously the share price has dropped considerably because it was being held up by the bid speculation. Now we have to prove that our management is good enough and that the changes we are making are good enough."

Still waiting for the cavalry

Marks & Spencer's stalker has gone and the store is now left with a sagging share price, unsupported by any takeover speculation, writes Julia Finch.

The 105-year-old group, valued at nearly £19bn three years ago, is now worth little more than a third of that and retail specialists expect the share price to tumble to 200p.

"People have been waiting for some while for the cavalry to appear over the hill in the shape of bidders. But all we've had is Mr Green and now he's gone," said Ian MacDougall, retailing analyst at Williams de Broe.

Mr MacDougall and other analysts now believe M&S investors will give the group some time to show what its new strategy and new Belgian chairman, Luc Vandevelde, can do - but not much.

There are still vague suggestions that another bidder might emerge - Sainsbury has thought about it and François Pinault's French fashion and retail group PPR might be interested. What next for Mr Green? He will turn his attention to other bid targets. "I am going to have a rest and another look at the world," he said. And he and his wife might still make a few more millions out of M&S. Mrs Green still has 9m M&S shares, just waiting for the Vandevelde effect.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: UK hails first net billionaire
fields.body:
UK hails first net billionaire

Mike Lynch, founder of Cambridge-based intelligent software company Autonomy, has become Britain's first self-made internet billionaire with his personal wealth totalling £1.02bn yesterday.

Mr Lynch, 34, started the company in 1991 with a £2,000 loan. In July 1998 he became worth £19m after the company listed on Easdaq, the pan-European technology exchange. Autonomy hit the big time recently when it signed a worldwide partnership agreement with Intel, the world's largest chip manufacturer, to revolutionise business systems on the internet.

The company's technology allows computers to "understand" text they come across on the internet or see key words in context.

For example, if a company receives email from a customer, the software identifies it as a complaint, inquiry or one of several other categories. It sends an appropriate reply and directs the email to the department best placed to deal with it.

No direct ECB help for euro

European Central Bank president Wim Duisenberg said the ECB will not undertake any direct action to support the euro, but he reiterated his view that the single currency would rise without any direct intervention from the central bank.

In an interview with the Sueddeutsche Zeitung Mr Duisenberg said the decline in the euro, which has seen the single currency slip below parity with the dollar in recent weeks, has affected the image of the ECB.

"But if you're asking me what I am doing against the exchange rate weakness, the answer is, nothing directly," he said.

"We cannot and should not try to influence the exchange rate level directly."

Mr Duisenberg said the ECB did not rule out direct intervention on the foreign exchange markets, but he said the bank was aware of the limited effect such intervention has.

"If we could co-ordinate such a step with the United States and Japan, that would certainly be a possibility at some time. But at present I see no reason for it," he said.

Goldman takes fund from P&D

Goldman Sachs Asset Management has snatched a £225m pension fund mandate from Phillips & Drew and Gartmore.

The decision by London Borough of Hammersmith and Fulham to transfer its assets to Goldman continues a trend to take business away from firms which had periods of ropey performance. Legal & General will also manage funds for local authority in its "index-tracking" funds.

New head for JellyWorks

JellyWorks said Ed Guinan is stepping down from his role as chairman of the company and that Graham Robeson has been appointed as his successor.

Mr Guinan will continue to identify suitable transactions for JellyWorks' investments and he and his family remain significant shareholders in the firm and remain long-term investors, the company said.

fields.headline: Focus Gold
fields.trailText: Gold may, as its supporters are so fond of reminding us, have held its purchasing value since the days of King Nebuchadnezzar (deceased 562BC), but events yesterday proved that, in the here and now, bullion prices are hitched to a high-speed version of the London Eye and one, moreover, equipped with five reverse gears and operated by an ultra-gullible gossip addict.
fields.body:
Gold may, as its supporters are so fond of reminding us, have held its purchasing value since the days of King Nebuchadnezzar (deceased 562BC), but events yesterday proved that, in the here and now, bullion prices are hitched to a high-speed version of the London Eye and one, moreover, equipped with five reverse gears and operated by an ultra-gullible gossip addict.

First thing in the morning and the hot rumour in Australian markets was that the British treasury was halting its controversial gold sales programme. Evidence? None. Reaction? A $5 surge to $311 an ounce.

Sceptics might have been having none of it, but tailor-made for their consumption was hot rumour number two, that big gold producers had repented of their unpatriotic "hedging" programmes and were planning buybacks.

The big wheel rolled up, and seemed for a moment about to lurch sickeningly groundwards only to hold steady as the world's largest miner, AngloGold, trundled out strong full-year figures complete with predictions of happier times ahead. On further reflection, however, the market clearly found the AngloGold statement a little too factual for its taste, and bullion slipped again, to below $311. Come close of play in London, it was back at $311.25, helped by interest in New York, where, doubtless, another interesting tale was doing the rounds.

Those with long memories might recall - incredible as it may seem - that advocates of a free market in gold blamed government controls for such episodes as the 1968 bullion turmoil. Unfettered trading, they said, would smooth out price fluctuations. Since then the price - $35 an ounce during 30 years of official intervention - has touched $1,000 and plumbed, last year alone, $250.

True goldbugs won't give a hoot, pointing to a 2,500-year history of stability in the long term. But those tempted by a shorter-term punt should remember the dictum of gold's great enemy, Lord Keynes: in the long run, we are all dead.

fields.headline: Bailiffs caught in £1.5m debt trap
fields.trailText: One of Britain's largest firms of certificated bailiffs yesterday found itself in a position only too familiar to the people with whom it has dealt over the years - that of insolvency.
fields.body:
One of Britain's largest firms of certificated bailiffs yesterday found itself in a position only too familiar to the people with whom it has dealt over the years - that of insolvency. Jefferies & Pennicott collapsed with debts of £1.5m and administrators were appointed by the High Court.

The group's troubles will leave up to 100 local authorities out of pocket, because Jefferies is thought to have used some of the arrears collected for clients to meet its mounting trading losses.

There was, said a source close to the administrators, some "mixing of monies". However, magistrates courts - another major client group for Jefferies - will be paid in full, because all bailiffs working for the court system have to take out insurance bonds guaranteeing the money collected on the courts' behalf.

The 12-year-old firm, with offices across the country, was last night in the hands of accountants Pannell Kerr Forster, who will try to find a buyer. It is thought that although the group's internal controls were poor - hence the use of client funds that ought to have been segregated to meet losses - its reputation as a debt collector was high.

Jefferies employed 160 staff and had offices in London, Stafford, Bedford, Plymouth and Cardiff. Its rapid expansion is believed to have triggered its financial problems.

Since the heyday of poll tax collection in the early 1990s, the bailiff business has experienced heavy downward pressure on fees and intensified competition for work.

Jefferies collected council tax, business-rates and rent arrears on behalf of 100 local authorities, but it is not known how many may be owed money.

fields.headline: Royal Mail's pay shake-up agreed
fields.trailText: Britain's 160,000 postal workers yesterday voted narrowly in favour of a radical pay and conditions package hailed as the biggest shake-up in the Royal Mail's collective bargaining since the war.
fields.body:
Britain's 160,000 postal workers yesterday voted narrowly in favour of a radical pay and conditions package hailed as the biggest shake-up in the Royal Mail's collective bargaining since the war.

On a record 70% turnout, just short of 100,000 of the 140,000 balloted, members of the Communication Workers Union voted 52% to 48% - 49,592 to 48,066 - to accept the Way Forward, a system of flexible working arrangements that has been in negotiation for 10 years.

The package, which prompted a strike in 1996, coincides with government moves to turn the Post Office into a more commercial organisation and European measures to promote competition.

Under the package, costing £80m, the postal workers get an average 2% increase in gross pay with rises in the hourly flat rate from £4.86 to £6.07 and in basic weekly pay from £201.63 to £242.76 (or £291 in inner London), a cut in the basic working week from 41.5 to 40 hours, including meal breaks, and up to six weeks' annual leave. The deal enables a worker to decide whether to take extra holidays or pay in lieu but it also includes a substantial cut in overtime, the traditional source of enhanced earnings among postal workers and one denounced by the CWU leadership as "unhealthy and excessive".

This is a move that prompted the stiff resistance to the package shown in the slight majority for acceptance.

John Keggie, CWU deputy leader, said the new way of working was essential to face future competition and protect jobs. The package, he added, would help eliminate outdated cultures which had meant postal workers "have been compelled to work excessive hours to secure a living wage".

Royal Mail said the greater flexibility would enable it to compete with the six foreign postal services already operating in Britain.

fields.headline: Tradepoint raises stakes
fields.trailText: Tradepoint - the London-based stock exchange backed by a consortium of investment banks - yesterday announced plans to launch the first integrated pan-European exchange.
fields.body:
Tradepoint - the London-based stock exchange backed by a consortium of investment banks - yesterday announced plans to launch the first integrated pan-European exchange.

It has signed agreements with the London Clearing House and the Euroclear Operations Centre to allow "straight through" cross-border clearing and settlement.

The move will intensify the developing battle for a share of the pan-European equity market.

Earlier this week OM Group, which owns the Swedish stock exchange, and Morgan Stanley Dean Witter unveiled a pan-European structure - to be called Jiway - which will trade in some 3,000 shares, joining a field already crowded with an alliance of eight traditional stock markets, including Nasdaq from the United States, Brussels-based Easdaq and Tradepoint.

But while Jiway is aimed at retail investors and small institutional trades Tradepoint, which has less than 1% of the London market, is looking to launch a challenge to the established big players, trading up to 400 of Europe's largest stocks.

According to Duncan Paterson, chief operating officer of the controlling consortium, which includes banks such as ABN Amro, Merrill Lynch, Morgan Stanley, CSFB, as well as Reuters' broking arm, Instinet, the aim was to develop Tradepoint as " the core of a consolidated European equity exchange marketplace".

The partnership with LCH and Euroclear would offer efficient, liquid and low-cost trading and settlement.

"We believe that it is these characteristics that will enable Tradepoint's European equity trading platform to be the basis of the principal marketplace in Europe by the end of 2001," Mr Paterson said.

The move will increase pressure on the other contenders - especially the traditional stock exchanges. But it will also intensify concerns that rival systems will mean liquidity is fragmented.

Liquidity - sufficient shares available to meet demand flows - is crucial to stock exchanges because a lack of liquidity can lead to greater price volatility.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: With two major mergers - Vodafone/Mannesmann and the siege of NatWest - limping to to the end of their respective roads and a third, Marks & Spencer and Philip Green, being aborted, there was a definite hint of a takeover hangover yesterday. Many dealers used the opportunity to take profits.
fields.body:
With two major mergers - Vodafone/Mannesmann and the siege of NatWest - limping to to the end of their respective roads and a third, Marks & Spencer and Philip Green, being aborted, there was a definite hint of a takeover hangover yesterday. Many dealers used the opportunity to take profits.

Telecoms, hi-tech and media stocks bore the brunt of the market sell-off, and the FTSE index closed the session down 35.6 points at 6,279.8. This was, however, well above the 6,199.8 low registered mid-morning.

A futures-related sell-off in the wake of Wall Street's 258-point fall overnight took its toll on the market in early business, with technology stocks feeling the heat from the decline as Nasdaq - after its recent stellar performance - finally succumbed to profit-taking on Wednesday. Some players are increasingly concerned about the valuations seen in many sectors - particularly telecoms and technology stocks - and feel that the bubble must burst.

As the morning progressed, activity tailed off further with all eyes turning to the Bank of England and its next move on interest rates. As it was, the fourth increase in six months proved to be something of a relief.

Market heavyweight Vodafone AirTouch's offer for Mannesmann was declared wholly unconditional; most brokers reiterated their positive stance on the stock and Vodafone ended the day up 8p at 343p.

Among twists in other blue-chip bid sagas, NatWest was active as Bank of Scotland finally admitted defeat in its long-running battle for control of the UK clearer. The focus shifted to the possibility that Bank of Scotland could be vulnerable to a bid, with its shares up 6p at 677p. Presumed victor Royal Bank of Scotland shed 29p at 875p but was well above its day's lows. NatWest ended a volatile session down 3p at 1,147p.

Elsewhere on the bid front, Marks & Spencer was hit hard by retail entrepreneur Philip Green's signal that he has no intention of bidding. Marks & Spencer shares ended the day at a new low, down 19p at 233p.

Shell was one of the few bright spots in a dull market, up 33p at 450p as brokers highlighted the stock's attractions in the wake of robust fourth-quarter figures and news that it is continuing to deliver on its costs. The positive results provided a boost for rival BP Amoco , up 21p at 487p, which is due to report figures next week.

Pearson remained one of the major fallers, down 120p at £23.44, while Cable & Wireless shed 81p to £12.93 and Daily Mail & General fell 396p to £47.70.
