fields.headline: Business news in brief
fields.trailText: Gas users told to shop around
fields.body:
Gas users told to shop around

All price controls on British Gas domestic supplies will be lifted from April next year, the energy regulator, Callum McCarthy, said yesterday as he imposed an average £10 cut in bills for 9m customers.

Consumer groups and Mr McCarthy, director general of Ofgem, urged consumers to continue to shop around for better offers than those made by British Gas, the trading arm of Centrica.

BG's 5m customers who pay by direct debit, which already attracts a substantial discount, are excluded from yesterday's price cuts which take effect on April 1.

The company's other 9m customers, including those meeting bills through pre-payment meters, will see their annual charges cut by between £8 and £10 a year - and all 14m customers see standing charges lifted in the spring.

Full competition was introduced to the domestic gas market in May 1998, with consumers enjoying discounts of up to £78 a year. There are 26 suppliers chasing a market of 19m homes.

Mr McCarthy said: "The competitive market is already delivering prices below the levels Ofgem is imposing by regulation. The price cuts ... are likely to be the minimum. In practice, customers can expect better offers."

Sad days for happiness index

Twenty years of equal pay and anti-discrimination policies have left women in Britain and the US less content than their mothers were, according to a leading expert on happiness. "Whatever the consequences of female anti-discrimination policy elsewhere in society, it has apparently not been successful in either country in increasing wellbeing among women," said Professor Andrew Oswald, an economist at Warwick University.

But, although surveys show women are not as happy as they were 20 years ago, they are still more contented than men.

While money does make individuals happy, rising incomes over the past 20 years have not increased the average level of happiness among either sex in Britain or the US. Other factors like the higher divorce rate and higher unemployment have cancelled out the impact of being better off.

For individuals a lasting marriage brings as much happiness as an extra $100,000 income per year, according to Prof Oswald's work which will be presented today to a conference of economists, sociologists and psychologists in Oxford. It is the first time that economists have met with other social scientists to talk about what makes people happy.

"This is an area that economists are at long last taking an interest in. It sharply challenges conventional ways of thinking in economics, and has the potential to make economics much more relevant," said Ben Cooper of Nuffield College, Oxford, the organiser of the conference.

Most economics textbooks assume that money is the root of happiness, but as the empirical research shows, the true picture is more complicated, Prof Oswald noted. - Charlotte Denny

Ford faces white-collar strike

Ford is facing its first national pay strike, set off by thousands of white collar workers who have called five days of action in the next month.

Up to 3,000 engineers, computer and administrative staff and other white collar employees at factories across Britain will walk out on February 24 and 29 and for three days from March 6.

There will be a one hour stoppage on February 21 as the traditionally moderate staff discuss their campaign of industrial action.

Unions warned that the strikes would hit car production, but Ford said last night that it would do everything it could to minimise the impact.

The staff complain that their pay offer of 11% over three years is 4% less than the settlement for production employees. There is a separate dispute over plans to merge the pension funds of the staff and hourly-paid workers.

But Ford said the pay offer was exactly the same for both groups of workers. There had been a "misunderstanding" because production employees had had their hours cut.

Terry Pye, national secretary of the Manufacturing Science and Finance union, said: "Ford management have seriously underestimated the anger of our members over pay and pensions. By refusing to negotiate with our members they have forced them into strike action."

SocGen to float broker

French bank Société Générale announced plans to float its 100%-owned online brokerage Fimatex during the first quarter of this year. The flotation is subject to the approval of the Paris bourse authorities and will depend on market conditions, the bank stated.

Fimatex, set up in 1995, has 35,000 accounts. The bank said the move is part of its strategy of building Fimatex into one of Europe's leading online operators in competition with rivals Charles Schwab and Fidelity Brokerage.

fields.headline: Vodafone sets sights on universe
fields.standfirst: Market forces
fields.trailText: This is your early morning wake-up call. By close of play today the FTSE International will be deciding, on the basis of its closing price, the weighting Vodafone Airtouch will acquire within its indexes, notably within the premier league of the UK's top 100 companies.
fields.body:
This is your early morning wake-up call. By close of play today the FTSE International will be deciding, on the basis of its closing price, the weighting Vodafone Airtouch will acquire within its indexes, notably within the premier league of the UK's top 100 companies.

But the game threatens to be a roller-coaster ride as tracker funds pour into Vodafone to reflect its increased value - to around £200bn, or the world's fourth largest corporate group - now that its offer of 58.96 shares for every Mannesmann share has gone unconditional.

Yesterday, with Vodafone saying it had won 60.3% acceptances for its €171bn offer, the stock initially proved surprisingly sluggish before a belated surge in the afternoon produced a near-record result: 1.18bn shares changed hands compared with the 1.4bn traded in the immediate run-up to last Thursday's turning-point of a friendly merger with its German prey.

Just before 2pm the FTSE announced that the number of Vodafone shares would be increased by around 17.6bn to some 48.7bn at today's close. But, if there is a late run of acceptances before 8am, the increase will be even bigger.

There will then follow the all-important decision on weighting before Monday's opening, with the bulk of expectations settling around the 15% mark. It could be even bigger - and Chris Gent, Vodafone's chief executive, no slouch he, is already thinking of expanding his empire, into Spain first and then, no doubt, the universe.

This is already causing consternation, chaos and confusion, with the FTSE musing aloud that the weighting should be limited to 10%.

Companies with tangible assets and genuine prospects are being dumped as the funds switch to Vodafone (and other telecoms, media and internet stocks).

This trend, reinforced by Wall Street's flat opening, continued yesterday when Vodafone itself took on 8p to close at 343p. Brokers such as Dresdner Kleinwort Benson are already pencilling in a 520p target.

Mannesmann drops out of the DAX30 on Monday, to be replaced by software group Epcos which rose 23% on the news.

webTitle: Whistle stop Cherie Booth helps Dress for Success scheme

fields.headline: Whistle stop Cherie Booth helps Dress for Success scheme
fields.trailText: In the wake of Gordon Brown's call for a step change in business volunteering, Cherie Booth yesterday launched a scheme for executives to give business suits to homeless people facing job interviews.
fields.body:
In the wake of Gordon Brown's call for a step change in business volunteering, Cherie Booth yesterday launched a scheme for executives to give business suits to homeless people facing job interviews.

The prime minister's wife said her present maternity wear was not likely to be of much use but she brought an unwanted suit to the launch in London of Dress for Success.

The scheme collects office wear from businesswomen and retailers such as Arcadia, which donate clothes from the end of fashion lines. Women who have job interviews lined up can acquire a suitable outfit and have a complete makeover. If the interview is successful they get a second outfit. Support is available from business "mentors" in the volunteering network.

The scheme's director, Vince Murphy, is planning a second site in south London and the first in a similar operation for men. The scheme, backed by the Avon Foundation, is modelled on a US operation. It is associated with the homelessness campaign run by Business in the Community, which is engaging business volunteers to help homeless people move into work.

Caroline Marland, the Guardian and Observer's managing director, yesterday led a group of executives on a "seeing is believing" tour of homeless shelters and employment schemes.

fields.headline: Pay time
fields.standfirst: Moving poor parents off welfare and into jobs as children grow is a worthy aim, but the tax and benefit systems are slow to adjust
fields.trailText: Moving poor parents off welfare and into jobs as children grow is a worthy aim, but the tax and benefit systems are slow to adjust
fields.body:
Alistair Darling, the social security secretary, yesterday repeated Labour's promise to end child poverty - that ambitious target of cutting the number of poor children (4m of them in 1996) by half within 10 years and within 20 years to ensure none lives in poor households. He emphasised that resources would be channelled to that end rather than subsidising unemployment. But what has been proposed so far is unlikely to eliminate so intransigent a problem. Our research on poor families and jobs, published yesterday by his own department, suggests the government will need to be flexible about the balance of sticks and carrots in getting poor parents into jobs.

One way of tackling child poverty is simply to put more money into social security benefits. To some extent this has happened. The Tories made families a priority but Labour's increases in income support, child benefit and working families tax credit (WFTC) are expected to lift 800,000 children out of poverty before the next election.

The great majority of poor families depend entirely on benefits, because they have no job. More than half of poor families are lone parents, who until recently were not even expected to look for work. More than 1m poor children live with both parents, neither of whom is in work. A sustainable policy for abolishing child poverty could not possibly be based simply on paying more generous benefits to such a large number of non-working families. In the end, the strategy has to be to increase the number of parents in work; or at least reduce the length of time they remain outside the labour force.

So the government has put its faith in the gospel of work. The flagship policy is Gordon Brown's WFTC, providing incentives for parents to take low-paid work. Recall, though, that in 1988 Norman Fowler was making the same claims for his family credit (and Gordon Brown was vigorously opposing). It hardly solved the problem. WFTC provides rather higher incentives - typically £42 per week for a couple with two children, compared with £31 under the previous regime. Labour's various tax and benefit reforms will cut the number of non-working families, but only by a few percentage points.

Other policies are needed; they have to be based on a better understanding of why some families get jobs and others do not. The British Household Panel Survey allows us to follow changes in families' circumstances between 1991 and 1997. Only a quarter of couples with children who were out of work in any given year were in work a year later (though others may have worked for a brief period during the intervening months); the figure for lone parents is just one in ten. These low rates of movement into work suggest that the government faces an uphill struggle in achieving its poverty-reduction objective.

Look at finding work from the perspective of the family: our research shows that if one partner finds a job between one year and the next, the other is twice as likely to do so too. Although those who find work are usually better off than on benefit, a second job is often essential to lift the family clear. Child care may be critical, not just to lone parents' prospects of finding work, but also to whether workless couples can find their way out of poverty.

Fathers tend to get jobs based on classical economic factors such as qualifications, health and the availability of work. Mothers' prospects on the other hand are associated with the age of their children and their "readiness" to look for work. This is true of both mothers in couples and lone parents.

There may be periods in a family's life when a mother cannot leave her children. So the ideal policy recognises these changing family circumstances: support one-earner families when that is the main option then encourage two-earner families when that becomes a possibility, after children have reached school-age. At the moment tax and benefit systems hardly make the distinction.

Some mothers or fathers in families classified as non-working do have "mini-jobs" - they work fewer than 16 hours per week, the limit below which people can continue to claim income support. We found the more hours they put into these mini-jobs the more likely they were to get a job working more than 16 hours the following year. This kind of employment seems to boost prospects, more than going on a training course does. Why not encourage such small part-time jobs? At present, people have to declare every change in their part-time earnings; and they may work for no more than four hours at the minimum wage before losing benefit.

Moving off benefit into work is a slow process. It is obviously important that jobs are available, and the fact that unemployment is falling helps. Still, as the chart shows, the underlying rise in the number of children in out-of-work families has not been very sensitive to variations in general unemployment rates.

The signs are that the number of poor children is reducing. But we can't feel confident that progress will be fast enough. One way forward requires a clearer focus on the combined labour force options of both mothers and fathers. Another would aim to increase the use of part-time work as a route to full-time jobs. Neither will have a dramatic impact on their own but they would make significant contributions to the overall objective.

Richard Berthoud and Maria Iacovou are at Essex University's Institute for Social and Economic Research

fields.headline: The Cherry Orchard
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: A respectful, measured account of Chekhov's play
fields.body:
The Cherry Orchard is a respectful, measured account of Chekhov's play by the veteran Greek director Michael Cacoyannis. He takes the elegant, anxious murmurings of the landed classes, their periodic explosions of despair and anxiety, and the bickering of the below-stairs staff, and makes of it the traditional Chekhovian chamber music of comedy and tragedy. And, like many a stage production, his picture is happiest and most confident with the clear descant of the aristocratic women, particularly Charlotte Rampling's commanding Madame Lyubov, unable to come to terms with the fact that her bankrupt estate will have to be sold off, together with its beloved cherry orchard.

This orchard, photographed in blossom, then in fruit, then in wintry bareness, perfectly symbolises a ruling class rooted in both the land and in luxury, and delicacy. Perhaps Chekhov's broken estate speaks to the Russian soul as to no other, but Cacoyannis's reading is fluent and sympathetic, and he elicits strong performances, particularly from Owen Teale as the orchard's usurper, Lopahin.

fields.headline: Xiao Wu
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: An engrossing film that maintains a kind of intelligent, compassionate walking pace throughout
fields.body:
Jia Zhang Ke's Xiao Wu is the tale of a pickpocket in provincial China, who finds that the world has moved on while he is still plying his tatty old trade. His best friend has gone straight, become a model neo-capitalist entrepreneur and has, woundingly, not invited him to his wedding. Xiao Wu has an unrequited infatuation with a karaoke bar girl, and a police crackdown on petty crime leads to his unspeakable, face-losing humiliation.

Shot on 16mm three years ago with non-professional actors, this film has something rather too clamorous to be Bressonian, but certainly has a very ordinary, accessible human sadness. Jia Zhang Ke has produced an engrossing film that maintains a kind of intelligent, compassionate walking pace throughout. The final, lengthy shot of the incurious passers-by gazing at the hapless pickpocket, hand cuffed to a street-sign, is very disquieting.

fields.headline: The Beach
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Not the disaster that has been widely rumoured. Far from it...[But] has nothing of interest to say about the modern western experience of Asia, either as a paradigm of pure hedonism or a heart-of-darkness encounter for the Nintendo generation
fields.body:
The release of The Beach starring Leonardo DiCaprio confirms the worrying emergence of the six-pack tyranny in modern American cinema. It is now simply unacceptable for any remotely young or presentable male performer to sport abs with anything less than pin-sharp definition - unless they are supposed to be fat.

Everyone in the movies now airily ambles about with a rippling torso, though they are never shown doing the grim 800 daily sit-ups necessary for its maintenance. (Leo himself has the regulation pack, naturally, a silent transformation from the somewhat porky location photos we saw last year.)

The Beach is not the disaster that has been widely rumoured. Far from it. For the first hour or so, this movie - adapted from Alex Garland's bestseller by the Trainspotting triumvirate of Danny Boyle (director), Andrew Macdonald (producer) and John Hodge (screenwriter) - is a rattling good yarn.

Leo is Richard, the American backpacker in search of an authentic travel experience in Thailand. He hears about a perfect, unspoilt beach, the site of an Edenic traveller community with access to limitless quantities of marijuana. A sun-and-drug-crazed travel veteran called Daffy (Robert Carlyle giving a familiar ranting turn) gives him a map to find it - and then Daffy is found dead, his wrists slit. And Richard becomes obsessed with finding The Beach and its community, which hold a sinister secret.

It is an irresistible story, drawing on the perennial fascination with the mythic "island" and the possibility of reinventing society and the individual, a tale whose pedigree runs in various forms from Shakespeare to Defoe, from RM Ballantyne to JG Ballard.

The dystopian twist The Beach attempts is not precisely Lord of the Flies, but owes more to half-remembered images from America's military adventures in Indo-China. There is a touch of The Deer Hunter in the final climax, and allusions to Apocalypse Now - Leo even gets to do a bit of brooding in the dark, like Colonel Kurtz.

DiCaprio once again shows he is a perfectly good actor, and those of us who remember and admire him from what Variety magazine calls his "pre-boat" career were willing him to do something interesting with this film. But he is doggedly shallow throughout a doggedly shallow picture.

Commercial considerations presumably preclude any cruel or unpleasant side to DiCaprio's character - his gorgeous chops are darkened by nothing more than a wispy hint of a goatee. And immersion in the Beach community itself cannot enforce any "evil" transformation in our hero, because that community is simply not very excitingly "evil" in the first place.

Opposite him, the distinguished British classical actress Tilda Swinton plays Sal, the patrician, statuesque, autocratic leader of the secret community. This she plays as well as she can, although the part is bafflingly underwritten and two-dimensional: we are never told how she found the Beach, and how it is that the others unquestioningly accept her (slightly shrill) authority.

The difficulty is that the movie loses focus about halfway through, when DiCaprio is exiled from the community for having blabbed about its existence to other backpackers on the outside. Here, he has to yomp around the jungly interior, dodging the threatening guys with automatic weapons who farm the lucrative weed growing just adjacent to The Beach, and generally going a bit loco and Losing It.

But Leo's breakdown is never going to be as interesting as his relationship with the Beach community and its much-promised scariness - which, in any case, turns out to be a sort of Khmer Rouge Ultra-Lite.

It all ends very tamely indeed and has nothing of interest to say about the modern western experience of Asia, either as a paradigm of pure hedonism or a heart-of-darkness encounter for the Nintendo generation.

fields.headline: Scream and scream again
fields.trailText: Hollywood can be a harsh, cruel place indeed. You know the phrases: "Last week's hero is next week's zero" or "You're only as good as your last picture." And the flint-hearted producer who bankrolled your career-making debut isn't likely to be swayed by reminders of how rich you once made him, especially if your last two pictures stank up both the joint and the joint's toilet.
fields.body:
Hollywood can be a harsh, cruel place indeed. You know the phrases: "Last week's hero is next week's zero" or "You're only as good as your last picture." And the flint-hearted producer who bankrolled your career-making debut isn't likely to be swayed by reminders of how rich you once made him, especially if your last two pictures stank up both the joint and the joint's toilet.

Believe me, there'll be no favours coming your way. All you'll hear from him, as he deigns to return your calls from a waterraft in the pool he purchased with the profits from your last hit, are the words, "Yeah, that was then, but what have you done for me lately?"

And it's likely to be a lot more gruelling and disillusioning if you once happened, however briefly, to redefine the prevailing cultural zeitgeist. Thanks to the video generation's high levels of cine-literacy, low boredom threshold and its Internet-derived savviness on all things movie-related, the Hollywood treadmill now has to turn about three times as fast just to keep up. Which means in short: "So what if you once shook up the ground we stand on, along with all our low expectations and high hopes? Things change, pal."

Things have certainly changed for people like Kevin Williamson in the few short years since Scream, and for Quentin Tarantino since Pulp Fiction. Each in his different way was once top of the Hollywood heap. Whilst Tarantino managed to transform modern movies with his multi-referential scripts for Reservoir Dogs and Pulp Fiction, he was very soon swamped by a Gaderene rush of pale imitators and micro-Taranteenies.

In the short term these Xerox-artists did as much damage to American film-making as imitators of the late Charles Bukowski and Raymond Carver did to the modern American short story. Every idiot who could heft a copy of Syd Field's knuckleheaded scriptwriting guide - or pony up the scratch to be berated by story-structure guru Robert McKee - got in the act.

And Tarantino certainly didn't do his own reputation any favours. Originally he'd wanted to be an actor and once he'd hit the jackpot as a writer-director he indulged himself insanely. There were guest appearances in disasters like Destiny Turns On the Radio (and John Patterson Flings it Out the Bloody Window), and the rank-pulling decision to essay the second male lead in From Dusk Till Dawn.

With his immobile, banana-shaped visage and his reedy, characterless speaking voice, a movie would stop dead in its tracks once Tarantino walked from behind the camera and into the shot. Once you become as powerful as in Hollywood as Tarantino suddenly did, you will find the talent banging on your door and telling you everything you want to hear. And no one will ever, ever tell you that you've produced a canine flick that deserves nothing better than the vet's Big Needle.

Obviously there was no one around who was prepared to say anything like that about the slack, gormless Jackie Brown, which looked for all the world like the rankest kind of self-plagiarism. Hollywood lawyers have yet to find an means of extracting legal and financial penalties from those who shamelessly steal from themselves, but they'll figure it out one day and once they do, the ex-video store clerk from Manhattan Beach will find himself robbing Peter to pay off, uh... Peter.

Let me ask you, until you started reading this, when was the last time you heard the words "Quentin Tarantino"?

Been a while, hasn't it?

Not so Kevin Williamson, who despite being associated with a string of abject box office failures, has maintained his reputation as the new first tycoon of teen TV. Keeping one foot in the cinema and the other on network television has enable Williamson to keep his career on a slow simmer, but things have been getting pretty ropey of late.

His script for The Faculty, which like From Dusk Till Dawn, was brought to the screen by fellow faded indie kingpin Robert Rodriguez, felt like Kevin-by-the-numbers all the way. Audiences stayed away in their proverbial droves.

The same was true of Williamson's directorial debut Teaching Mrs Tingle, whose title was changed from Killing Mrs Tingle in order to put a million miles of daylight between it and the Littleton High School massacre in Colorado. As long as he wasn't involved with the Scream series, the IKWYDLS duo, and his TV series Dawson's Creek, Williamson couldn't get arrested.

This was recently confirmed with the cancellation of his heavily promoted TV series Wasteland (the title was the show's own best review) which features one representative dialogue sample so nauseating I feel compelled to reprint in in full.

Anthropology professor to twentysomething virgin grad student: "And your thesis will discuss the reason your generation is lost and inactive?"

"Sure. Take me for example," says our virgin. "I'm 26 today. I'm profoundly lost as a human being. I've spent my entire life in school. My parents still support me. Relationships baffle me and I'm acutely self-aware to the point where I'm clueless and slightly suicidal."

"And you represent today's generation?"

"Yes. Absolutely."

What the hell does "slightly suicidal" mean? The best definition I can come up with is the feeling of inner death I experienced as this crap soiled my eardrums and retina.

Williamson's only involvement in Scream 3 was a 20-page outline, there were no press screenings, and February's a charnel house for movies anyway, so all signs pointed to a likely nadir of creative shittiness. Thus it's a pleasure to report that Scream 3 is the best of the trilogy, an absolute riot, jammed with spicy cameos from Carrie Fisher - "no, no I just look like her" - Jay and Silent Bob, Roger Corman, Heather Matarazzo and Lance Henriksen, among others), dozens of zingers ("Wow! Deja Voodoo!" or "Ah yes, very Hannibal Lecter, very Seven"), and a cast that thinks it knows exactly what's coming.

It's set against the filming of Stab 3, the now waning hack'n'slash series derived from the events in Scream 1, and the killer's knocking off the cast in the order they die in the script ('cept there's three different drafts...). As one character says, "In the last part of a trilogy, all bets are off." Against all the odds, a wonderful capper to a clever series, well deserving of the stunning $32m it earned.

fields.headline: An unholy communion
fields.standfirst: The film of Graham Greene's novel plays down the religious angle. Peter Bradshaw   is not convinced
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: For all its stylistic felicities, intelligently calibrated performances, and period furniture, this turns out to be a bit of a travesty
fields.body:
"It's not what I wrote," whispers Maurice Bendrix, the obsessively jealous novelist in Neil Jordan's extravagant, expansive version of Graham Greene's The End of the Affair. He is wincing and grimacing in a 1940s fleapit auditorium where they are showing a (crass) adaptation of one of his books.

The hazardous transforming of literature into cinema is so important here: both as a professional preoccupation for Greene - novelist, movie critic, screenwriter - and as a metaphor for disappointed expectations, and a loss of control. It stands for a fastidious aesthetic sense of something having turned out wrong in the wide world: compromised, modified, spoilt. And it is audacious of Neil Jordan to have included the "not-what-I-wrote" moment, because this sure isn't what Greene wrote. In fact, for all its stylistic felicities, intelligently calibrated performances, and period furniture, this turns out to be a bit of a travesty.

Ralph Fiennes plays Bendrix, the tense writer in wartime London. Excused khaki because of his gammy leg, he falls into a tragic affair with Sarah, the beautiful, elegant wife of a stuffy civil servant. She is played by Julianne Moore, a very great deal of whose energies are channelled into replicating the perfect English accent. Her concentration is clearly heavily invested here and there is thus something too reticent about the rest of her performance as she glides about; even for an Englishwoman there is little abandon in her love scenes - hardly worth that 18 certificate, incidentally - and her adagio approach only really comes into its own for her final, affecting death-bed scene.

Fiennes himself is simply remarkable. There is no other actor who could have played this role and, as with his Onegin last year, there is an unmatched maturity and complexity to his screen presence: a jaggedness, a simmering amour propre, a neurotic obsessiveness, an importunate yearning. There is a great and terrible wound somewhere in his heart. Perhaps the nearest comparison I can think of is Dirk Bogarde, though, as a performer, Fiennes is the warmer and more forthcoming of the two. The cuckold himself, Henry Miles, is played by Stephen Rea, whose dopey, mopey, hangdog face perfectly conveys his hopelessness, especially under the dead weight of his Homburg hat.

Where Jordan succeeds triumphantly is in reproducing the heavy, gloomy sick-room atmosphere of guilt and shame and discomfiture in post-war Britain. The movie reeks of damp, cheap clothing drying out in front of a gas fire. It is a world of miserable, sooty pubs, cardboard bus-tickets, the weighty chink of two-bob bits and pennies the size of manhole covers - the heavy coins that told Orwell he was back home. Bendrix and Sarah have fully clothed illicit sex on her sofa, not, you feel, because it's erotic but because in an age before central heating nothing else is tolerable.

But where Jordan fails is in his diminution of the importance of God. Sarah ends their affair because she loves him so much. A cradle Catholic, she offers God a deal when she finds Bendrix's apparently dead body in the rubble caused by a V2 rocket: bring Maurice back to life, she says, and she will resume the sacrament of marriage with her husband.

In Greene's book, this is a sacrifice taken seriously; she keeps her bargain, never returns to Bendrix's bed, and doesn't tell him why. This quixotic insistence is what gives her pathos and tragic grandeur. But Jordan appears simply to tear up the betting slip that underpins that Pascal wager on God's existence. When Bendrix finally discovers the truth with the help of a private detective (the perennially excellent Ian Hart) Sarah winds up melting into his arms anyway, and Jordan awards them a vulgar sexual reunion, complete with raffish weekend away in Brighton.

There are other problems in the liberties Jordan takes. In Greene's novel, the other man Sarah has been seeing is not a lover but a rationalist thinker determined to argue her out of her faith. Jordan turns him into a solemn dog-collared priest. This paradoxically reduces the religious element; there is no worrisome, quarrelsome debate, none of the Greeneian poignancy and uncertainty.

"People go on loving God all their lives, without seeing Him." This is how Sarah tells Maurice that their love will continue after she can't see him any more. The End of the Affair conveys a terrible view of the end of love, and the need for some comforting faith in absent love, which, in turn, affords a glimpse of something other than the comforts and the trials of this world.

Neil Jordan's movie admirably conveys the secular half of this agony and, by giving their affair its Second Act, as it were, he gives it a more vivid and cinematic life. But in abolishing Sarah's bargain, he diminishes her sacrifice for God. It is a substantial loss because, without this sacrifice, The End of the Affair is, really, a little banal.

fields.headline: Noh escape from pain
fields.standfirst:
Nine Songs
City Contemporary Dance Company
Peacock Theatre, London
Rating: **
fields.trailText: Hong Kong may not feature large on the dance map but in fact there's been a busy international scene there since the 70s, with both ballet and modern dance reflecting the city's global mix of cultures. City Contemporary Dance Company was founded in 1979 by Chinese choreographer Wily Tsao, but this is its first visit to London, and to mark its debut it is staging Nine Songs, made in 1991 by Hong Kong-born Helen Lai.
fields.body:
Hong Kong may not feature large on the dance map but in fact there's been a busy international scene there since the 70s, with both ballet and modern dance reflecting the city's global mix of cultures. City Contemporary Dance Company was founded in 1979 by Chinese choreographer Wily Tsao, but this is its first visit to London, and to mark its debut it is staging Nine Songs, made in 1991 by Hong Kong-born Helen Lai.

Nine Songs is based on the romantic poetry of QuYuan (4th century BC) yet the writings are filtered through a very late and very abrasive 20th century sound score, layered in wailing dissonances, amplified percussion and minimalist chants. Lai's own choreography is also a fusion of ancient and modern, in fact it ransacks so many different traditions that it is hard to decipher a single style - other than a physicality so intense it amounts to a flagellation of the flesh.

The work is divided into nine sections, each coloured by a different physical language. The opening chorus of splenetic, regimented gesture looks as if Anne Teresa de Keersmaeker had re-located to the Red Guard, and this is followed by a slow Butoh solo in which a lone man angles his body through a Zen-like process of mortification. There are bursts of Chinese acrobat pinwheel jumps and exquisitely refined variations on t'ai chi. There are moments of Noh-like stillness and storms of technically impressive western dance. At various points in the show, a stream of sand falls very beautifully on to the stage, landing in a heap in which dancers roll around and rub their hair. They don't, for a second, flinch, even though the cloud of dust that comes floating into the auditorium has the rest of us blinking in gritty discomfort.

From the titles of the songs it seems the show is meant to modulate through a series of different emotional states, but while the dancers are powerful, controlled and committed it's difficult to make sense of what's going on. So much of the dance is performed on the edge of a self-destructive frenzy that it all starts to feel the same; so much of the sound is a featureless assault that we switch off in self- defence. Nine Songs may be an impressive exercise in choreographed extremity, but it's painful for all concerned.

Until tomorrow. Box office: 0171-863 8222.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: The easy way out
fields.standfirst: Raising interest rates will do real harm
fields.trailText: Interest rates went up yet again yesterday - this time to 6%. They were raised to deal with a threat of inflation which does not look real. And they could, by boosting the pound, make the state of some struggling industries even more desperate, while feeding the growing complaint in the regions that their interests are being sabotaged in the cause of damping down the economy of the south-east.
fields.body:
Interest rates went up yet again yesterday - this time to 6%. They were raised to deal with a threat of inflation which does not look real. And they could, by boosting the pound, make the state of some struggling industries even more desperate, while feeding the growing complaint in the regions that their interests are being sabotaged in the cause of damping down the economy of the south-east.

The Bank of England, whose monetary policy committee (MPC) now sets the rate, is concerned that a fast recovering economy, with spending fuelled by house price inflation in parts of the country, might reignite inflation. If the future were going to be a carbon copy of the past that might be true. But it is not. Three things have changed. First, there has been a return to Old Economy conditions before the oil price explosions of the 1970s ushered in an (exceptional) 25 years of inflation. Second, globalisation has given consumers and producers increased access to cheaper sources of supply. Third, and most important, the impact of the internet. For the consumer, being able to buy online not only cuts out intermediaries but enables users to trawl globally for cheaper sources of supply.

It is true, as the bank would argue, that e-commerce is a small proportion of activity, but that is not the point. Producers know that web commerce will explode and that alters their present perception of future price increases. Even more important than business to consumer trade is company to company trade. This will account for up to 80% of the impact of the internet on business. The huge cost savings generated will help firms maintain profits during a period of digital deflation when it will be difficult to raise prices. And in any case: where is the evidence of inflation? The latest figures showed a fall in wage settlements and the government's official index puts price inflation at a modest 2.2%. If the recent oil price rise is excluded, inflation would be down to only 1.5% - a level so low it would require the MPC to explain to the chancellor why they weren't nearer the official target of 2.5%. The bank is worried that the volume of retail sales has risen by 3.5% over the past year. But the value has only risen by 3.3%. Why? Because shops cannot make price rises stick.

Meanwhile the pound has soared to dizzy heights that make exporting so difficult that companies have started to source components abroad in a major way. The single biggest complaint of the farming industry is the strength of the pound, yet the government acts as though there is nothing it can do. It is wrong to suppose that interest rates have to be raised, causing serious problems for manufacturing and the regions, just because house prices soar in the south. The government could increase stamp duty or legislate to lay down minimum mortgage deposits. If interest rates were brought down to nearer European levels then the pound might fall - switching the engine of growth from imports to exports. The US realised early on that globalisation and the internet could enable economies to grow faster without running into inflationary problems. As a result the US economy has expanded 4% on average for four years without hitting the inflation buffers. There are encouraging signs of strong technological change in the UK - but we will never know whether this could have enabled the economy to grow faster without inflation because of the Pavlovian reaction of the authorities. Growth shows signs of pushing up towards 3% and what do they do? They throw in the towel.

fields.headline: Mirror's City duo face reprimands
fields.trailText: The Mirror board was last night considering disciplinary action against its City Slicker columnists as a result of its internal inquiry into the controversy surrounding their private share dealings.
fields.body:
The Mirror board was last night considering disciplinary action against its City Slicker columnists as a result of its internal inquiry into the controversy surrounding their private share dealings.

James Hipwell, one of the share-tipping duo, met Paul Vickers, the Trinity Mirror group legal director, yesterday afternoon to deliver documents detailing his share transactions over the past two years. Mr Hipwell is understood to have been courted by the Sun to sell his story.

The chairman, Sir Victor Blank, is said to be furious about the whole episode, which began when it emerged that the Mirror editor, Piers Morgan, had bought £20,000 worth of shares in Viglen Technology the day before the Slickers wrote a positive story on the company.

There is also some expectation within the Mirror that the Slickers column, which has developed a strong following with its irreverent take on the City, may be scrapped.

Mr Morgan has been cleared of any wrongdoing by a separate inquiry. However, he remains under investigation by the stock exchange, the department of trade and industry and the press complaints commission.

There have also been questions about the purchase of shares by Tina Weaver, the Mirror's deputy editor.

Anil Bhoyrul, the other half of the Slickers team, gave details of his share dealing on Wednesday, including brokers' records and bank statements. Friends of Mr Bhoyrul said he believed he would be given a reprimand and allowed to keep his £85,000-a-year job.

A Trinity Mirror spokesman said: "If any accusations are found to be true, then the company will have to take that very seriously." If the matter became a disciplinary issue it would be handled by Trinity Mirror's lawyers, Lovells.

Mr Hipwell, 34, had been reluctant to provide details of his investments, on the advice of lawyers, but met a deadline imposed for the end of yesterday. He bought shares in Dialog and Booth Industries while at the Mirror. The companies have been tipped by the newspaper, but Mr Bhoyrul and Mr Hipwell, who joined the paper in April 1998, deny doing anything wrong.

The Press Complaints Commission code states that journalists should not hold shares in companies they write about unless they have disclosed their interests to their editor.

Anil Bhoyrul, the other half of the Slickers team, gave details of his share dealing on Wednesday, including brokers' records and bank statements. Friends of Mr Bhoyrul said he believed he would be given a reprimand and allowed to keep his £85,000-a-year job. A Trinity Mirror spokesman said: "If any accusations are found to be true, then the company will have to take that very seriously." If the matter became a disciplinary issue it would be handled by Trinity Mirror's lawyers, Lovells. Mr Hipwell, 34, had been reluctant to provide details of his investments, on the advice of lawyers, but met a deadline imposed for the end of yesterday. He bought shares in Dialog and Booth Industries while at the Mirror. The companies have been tipped by the newspaper, but Mr Bhoyrul and Mr Hipwell, who joined the paper in April 1998, deny doing anything wrong. The Press Complaints Commission code states that journalists should not hold shares in companies they write about unless they have disclosed their interests to their editor.

webTitle: Dismay as interest rates rise to 6%

fields.headline: Dismay as interest rates rise to 6%
fields.trailText: Fears of an inflationary boom prompted the Bank of England to raise rates yesterday to 6%, to the dismay of business and homeowners.
fields.body:
Fears of an inflationary boom prompted the Bank of England to raise rates yesterday to 6%, to the dismay of business and homeowners.

Industry leaders immediately called on the chancellor, Gordon Brown, not to indulge in a tax-cutting budget which would add to inflationary pressure, triggering still dearer borrowing costs. The British Chambers of Commerce (BCC) urged the chancellor to protect hard-pressed manufacturers by keeping a tight rein on the public finances in March.

"The government has let interest rates take too much of the strain in controlling consumer demand over the past two years," said BCC deputy director general Ian Peters. "It is this over-reliance on monetary policy that has led to growth being spread unevenly across sectors and between regions."

The bank's monetary policy committee (MPC) offered no explanation for the quarter point rate rise, the fourth in six months. But economists said it reflected concern that the economy is growing too fast to prevent inflation rising above the government's 2.5% target in the months ahead.

The MPC is thought to be particularly concerned about the threat posed by rapidly rising house prices in London and the South-east, strong consumer demand and high earnings growth.

Banks and building societies are expected to pass on all or most of the increase to borrowers.

The rise was widely expected in the City where it caused little reaction, but industry complained of monetary overkill at a time when inflation is below the government's 2.5% target.

The Confederation of British Industry's chief economic adviser, Kate Barker, said the rise would be an "additional handicap" to exporters struggling to compete in overseas markets due to the strong pound.

"This is more bad news for manufacturers, who have had precious little to cheer about as sterling hit record highs against the euro," she said. "Many companies will find the rise hard to understand when inflationary pressure remains so low in most sectors."

Sir Ken Jackson, general secretary of Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union, warned that the rate rise would "choke" exporters in the Midlands and the North. "The strong pound is already squeezing exporters. Another rise is like pouring petrol on to the fire," he said.

Ruth Lea, head of the Institute of Directors policy unit, was among the few voices in industry to support the MPC's decision. "While we recognise the real burdens placed on business by higher interest rates, we accept they need to rise in order to maintain the low inflation stability which is essential for business to thrive," she said.

But Sir Brian Moffat, chairman of Corus, formerly British Steel, warned that manufacturing in the UK was fighting for its existence.

In a speech to MPs last night, he said: "It is extremely efficient but the impact of the continued strengthening of the pound on its cost base is remorselessly undercutting its competitiveness. To date it has fought back and hung on grimly. Indeed, some commentators are saying that is is learning to live with a strong pound. But we cannot take comfort from this, nor should we believe it."

Although City economists expect the MPC to pause for breath in March, most predict further increases in interest rates later in the year.

fields.headline: Elegant and stirring
fields.standfirst:
Nicholas McGegan
City of Birmingham Symphony Orchestra
Symphony Hall, Birmingham
Rating:*****
fields.trailText: Encores are almost the rule in modern concert life, rather than the exception they ought to be. But on Wednesday night, when just about all the audience seemed to be hoping that Andreas Scholl would give us just one more aria, we were left wanting. To make matters worse, conductor Nicholas McGegan had told us that this superb young counter-tenor might have something else for us after the official final item: Bach's Third Orchestral Suite.
fields.body:
Encores are almost the rule in modern concert life, rather than the exception they ought to be. But on Wednesday night, when just about all the audience seemed to be hoping that Andreas Scholl would give us just one more aria, we were left wanting. To make matters worse, conductor Nicholas McGegan had told us that this superb young counter-tenor might have something else for us after the official final item: Bach's Third Orchestral Suite.

But no. It could be that Scholl's last offering - the marathon Venga Pur, from Mozart's early opera Mitridate, had taken too much out of him. Or perhaps the deafening, starting-pistol-like explosion from the back of the auditorium at the beginning of the concert's second half had put him off his stride.

Whatever, Scholl obviously decided enough was enough - a judgment with which no one in the audience appeared to agree. Couldn't he have managed one more Handel aria?

Scholl's performance of Se Parla nel Mio Cor from Giustino was as elegant and stirring as his reputation would lead one to expect. But O Lord whose Mercies Numberless from Saul was exquisite - the kind of singing that makes the small hairs bristle on the back of the neck. After that, the Gluck and Mozart numbers in the second half were a tad anti-climactic.

Still, there were compensations in the Bach Third Suite: the CBSO playing crisply, stylishly and with feeling for McGegan. It doesn't matter how often one hears the famous Air, or that opening bars are now irredeemable associated with Hamlet cigars; in a good performance this beautiful instrumental song can still move - and this performance was more than good. So too were the two Handel concertos earlier on.

The horns may have taken a moment to settle into the taxing high solo writing in the Concerto a Due Cori No 2. Otherwise this was a model of fine Handel playing - alert, vivacious, witty and generally spirit-lifting.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

webTitle: Bank sees no need to explain rate rise

fields.headline: Bank sees no need to explain rate rise
fields.standfirst: Silence from MPC, squeals from both sides of industry
fields.trailText: The Bank of England was in non-communicative mood yesterday when it put up rates for the fourth time in six months. It told the waiting world that the cost of borrowing was going up from 5.75% to 6% and left it at that. No explanation, no mention of what was worrying the nine-strong monetary policy committee.
fields.body:
The Bank of England was in non-communicative mood yesterday when it put up rates for the fourth time in six months. It told the waiting world that the cost of borrowing was going up from 5.75% to 6% and left it at that. No explanation, no mention of what was worrying the nine-strong monetary policy committee.

Away from Threadneedle Street, there were plenty of people who wanted their say. The CBI and the TUC claimed that, with the pound already too strong for comfort, the result would be even more pain for manufacturers and exporters.

The chancellor attracted his share of brickbats, despite washing his hands of monetary policy in May 1997. Gordon Brown had made it clear that he wanted rates to go up, and they duly did. There were grumbles from the British Chambers of Commerce and the Engineering Employers Federation, which both want fiscal policy to be tightened in the budget to take the heat off monetary policy.

Three questions arise from the rates decision. The first - why the Bank did it - is easy to answer. Every member of the MPC has been surprised at the resilience of the economy over the past year, and fears that inflation will rise above the government's 2.5% target.

There is no shortage of evidence to back up the hawkish case. The Bank could take its pick from the strength of growth in the second half of 1999, the buoyancy of consumer spending, signs that the booming property market is triggering a wave of equity withdrawal, the tightness of the labour market following the decline in unemployment to a 20-year-low.

Suggestions that Britain is enjoying its own new paradigm, with competitive markets and new technology driving down prices, have yet to impress the MPC.

What happens next? Economists are divided between those who believe the Bank is doing too much, too soon and those who believe rates will have to rise a lot further.

Michael Saunders of Salomon Smith Barney Citibank suspected yesterday's rate rise would "not prevent domestic demand remaining very strong. Despite the very high pound, exports are benefiting a bit from the strength in world trade. As a result, overall GDP growth probably will stay above trend, causing capacity strains to worsen further." He said rates could rise to 7% by the end of 2000 and peak at 7-8% next year.

Given that next year is election year, the third question is whether Mr Brown will try to find an alternative to tighter monetary policy. Fiscal policy is already tight and there is no guarantee that tightening it further would lead to a lower pound. Many of the industrialists complaining about higher interest rates would complain equally loudly about higher taxes.

Some commentators suggest Mr Brown should take specific action against the housing market. But stamp duty has already been increased, while slapping capital gains on housing is not the sort of measure a government contemplates with the Daily Mail in full cry.

Conclusion? There's more interest rate pain to come.

fields.headline: Apothecary of goth
fields.standfirst:
The Cure
Astoria, London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText: If life really begins at 40, then pity Robert Smith, a man who has spent more than 20 years ruminating on the sheer hopelessness of existence. One suspects Smith is rather annoyed that he didn't die sometime around 1982, sealing his immortality with The Cure's psychotic masterpiece of an album Pornography as a fitting epitaph. Yet not only did he survive he became hugely successful, a multi-millionaire icon for the terminally cheesed-off, so universally recognisable that he's appeared in South Park. No wonder that Smith should choose this mid-life landmark to reassert his serious artistic credentials with a new record called Bloodflowers, billed as the final part of a trilogy that began with Pornography and continued with 1989's Disintegration, generally regarded as the last great Cure album.
fields.body:
If life really begins at 40, then pity Robert Smith, a man who has spent more than 20 years ruminating on the sheer hopelessness of existence. One suspects Smith is rather annoyed that he didn't die sometime around 1982, sealing his immortality with The Cure's psychotic masterpiece of an album Pornography as a fitting epitaph. Yet not only did he survive he became hugely successful, a multi-millionaire icon for the terminally cheesed-off, so universally recognisable that he's appeared in South Park. No wonder that Smith should choose this mid-life landmark to reassert his serious artistic credentials with a new record called Bloodflowers, billed as the final part of a trilogy that began with Pornography and continued with 1989's Disintegration, generally regarded as the last great Cure album.

In other words, it's bleak, epic and conspicuously lacking in silly fluff about being a cat. Good portents, then, for this low-key comeback show. Smith's adroit pop sensibilities made him rich, but The Cure's essence always resided amid the comfort of sadness. So here we have a set dwelling exclusively on the dark side. Naturally, this is happy news for all concerned, not least the smiling Smith who looks engaged and committed, a credible presence despite ever more resembling a goth Marlon Brando. The new songs don't wield the consumptive power of yore - Smith would probably be dead if they did - but at least they sound authentic, riven with the same existential certainties that define the band's best work.

So when matters get really serious with a seething, utterly merciless One Hundred Years, it doesn't feel like an aberration. Amid this howling maelstrom, contemporary glumsters like Placebo are revealed to be mere pygmies of pain. It's followed by a swollen Bloodflowers and an encore of A Forest, effectively the first goth song, and there feels something quite noble about a man so unrepentantly immovable in his obsessions.

How much longer Robert Smith ought to sustain his adolescent world view is uncertain. As usual, he has claimed that this will be the last Cure album, but whether he really means it or not at least this would be an honourable valediction. He's the last of the dinosaurs, and as such, something of a national treasure.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible
